SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2743 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property;
Web Gives White Elephants a New Life

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
GENERATIONS of New Jerseyans shopped the Bamberger's store at the corner of Market and Halsey Streets in Newark for clothing, accessories and household goods. The throngs of shoppers have long since departed for the suburbs but the store, later named Macy's and closed in 1992, has gained an unexpected new life.
Rows of computers and telecommunications equipment now fill the floors that once displayed women's dresses and men's suits. The building has been transformed into a high-technology center, the physical repository of the machines that support the rapid growth of the Internet. 
 It is just one example of how old industrial and retail properties, formerly considered unrentable white elephants, have suddenly become highly attractive to Web hosting and communications companies who need sites to expand -- and need them now.
The old buildings have what the Internet companies need: sturdy floors and high ceilings to accommodate heavy, delicate equipment; abundant electrical power to keep the machines humming and easy access to the optical-fiber cables that are the highways of the Internet. In the case of the old industrial buildings, proximity to the high-volume fiber cables has come because the cables have been installed along established railroad lines.
As a result of this newfound desirability of certain types of industrial buildings, old factories in Jersey City, a sprawling and underutilized marine terminal and an old tire factory in Brooklyn, and various locations in New Jersey's Meadowlands are all being promoted as technology centers.
Even buildings that were at the heart of old telecommunications technology, such as AT&T's onetime manual switching center at 32 Avenue of the Americas, at Walker Street, are being adapted to new technology. The building has been purchased by the Rudin family, which is adapting it for use by companies like MCI WorldCom and Qwest.
While a new generation of equipment will be installed upstairs at the old switching center, the landmarked lobby will retain the 1932 murals and the declaration that "Telephone wires and radio unite to make neighbors of nations."
What is happening in the New York area is being replicated around the country and around the world. Everything is driven by time because new-economy companies believe that the ones who grab market share first will dominate their sectors.
"Telecommunications and the Internet are closely related, they go hand in hand," said Goodwin Gaw, the chairman of Global Gateway, a company that is building a network of servers and telecommunications equipment in the western United States and Asia. "Our customers like to be there before the wave."
Global Gateway is one of two companies being backed by $1.25 billion from Morgan Stanley Real Estate Funds to build a global Internet communications network. The other is MetroNexis, which is responsible for the eastern United States and Europe. MetroNexis recently agreed to purchase the 1.1-million-square-foot former American Can factory at 50 Dey Street in Jersey City.
For companies building the networks of computers, cable and software that undergirds the Internet, "speed to market is the name of the game, and the space has to be available now," said Mark A. Teitelbaum, a partner in Argent Ventures, a New York real estate investment company. "Anything that will not be ready for 18 months is a non-starter."
Argent has been acquiring property, including buildings in Weehawken and Jersey City and an old shopping mall in Miami, all for use as technology centers for Internet companies. "We have acquired between 6 and 7 million square feet of property in the last 12 months," said Andrew S. Penson, another Argent partner. "But that is like 10 years in Internet time."
He said that when Argent acquired the long-empty 300,000-square-foot building at 300 Boulevard East in Weehawken, Exodus Communications agreed to lease 230,000 square feet even before the purchase had closed. When Argent acquired the old Muller Noodle factory at 180 Baldwin Street in Jersey City, all 300,000 square feet were leased by AboveNet Communications, an affiliate of Metromedia Fiber Network, within two months of closing.
Now Argent is waiting for a self-storage tenant to move out of the adjacent 80,000-square-foot building at 190 Baldwin so that it can move in technology tenants, Mr. Penson said. A little more than a year ago, previous owners of 190 Baldwin were trying to market the property to printers being forced out of Manhattan by rising rents. The possibility of attracting telecommunications or Internet-based tenants was not part of the discussion.
THE million-square-foot Omni Mall on Biscayne Boulevard in Miami had one particularly significant advantage, Mr. Penson said. It was empty. He said the site could be a gateway to planned underwater communications links to Central and South America.
The increase in marketability of older buildings suitable for use by Internet infrastructure companies has come suddenly. "Nobody knew anything about this until about a year ago," said John Peters, a former broker with Cushman & Wakefield who now runs his own company, Technology Real Estate. "Now it is the 'in' thing for everybody."
Real estate executives said the scramble for growth by telecommunications and Internet-related companies made them relatively unconcerned about the cost of space. A good example, said Mr. Peters, is the old Port Authority inland warehouse at 111 Eighth Avenue, between 15th and 16th Streets in Manhattan.
Not long ago, he said, the owner, Taconic Investment Partners, was happy to sign leases in the mid $20's per square foot annually. The most recent lease, to Broadlink Communications, was at $55 a square foot, he said.
"Telecommunications has become the most profitable sector in real estate," said Sean Brady, a broker with Cushman & Wakefield. "There are buildings in Jersey City that were bought for $5 a square foot that are renting space for $30 a square foot" annually. He said there is scarcely an industrial building in Jersey City, even such unlikely candidates as two abandoned former cold storage warehouses, that have not been studied as a possible data center and telecommunications locations.
For high-technology companies, which make their money transmitting and processing information, the cost of the real estate they occupy is not much more than a decimal point in their financial calculations. According to a recent report by the Lehman Brothers investment company, Internet hosting companies average $3,000 a square foot in annual revenues.
The high-technology boom, ironically, is rehabilitating buildings that had been dismissed as obsolete, because of their size, ceiling height or amount of room for parking. But a facility that might be obsolete for warehousing and distribution could work well for Web hosting and telecommunications.
"We have old buildings that are coming back to life," said Richard Marchisio, managing director of Grubb & Ellis of New Jersey. "This is a whole new sector of real estate that did not exist previously."
An established infrastructure, particularly railroad lines, is helping old, previously industrialized areas of the region. The reason is that many of the telecommunications companies have used railroad rights of way to install fiber cables.
"Perhaps the most important requirement for a telecom hotel is a nearby fiber-optic network," Grubb & Ellis said in a recent market report. "This is the gold beneath the streets, the lifeline for an obsolete industrial building. Much of the fiber-optic networks run along existing rail rights of way in urban areas."
In Newark, it noted, the old Bamberger's-Macy's building is near fiber lines, making it attractive to such companies as Qwest Communications, MCI WorldCom and Level 3 Communications.
The success of that location has prompted some brokers, and some owners and prospective tenants, to look at the old, and long abandoned, retail buildings that line Broad Street, once Newark's prime shopping location. But if the buildings, which include the old Hahne's and S. Klein stores, are to be converted into technology centers, the change may run afoul of the city's efforts to revive the area as a SoHo-like village of residences, shops and restaurants.
There is little on the outside of the Bamberger's building to indicate that there is something approaching $1 billion worth of equipment inside. The tenants like that just fine because the last thing they want is to attract attention to themselves and their delicate equipment and vulnerable fiber links.
The problem is that the building looks abandoned, except for some stores on the ground level and an underground parking operation.
If the Hahne's or S. Klein stores were to be occupied by Internet and telecommunications companies, they would look abandoned as well. As such they could be an eyesore in an area the city wants to see redeveloped in conjunction with its sparkling new Performing Arts Center, which is on the other side of Military Park from the old stores.
The New Newark Foundation owns or controls 2 million square feet of space in an eight-block area north of Broad Street, which is wired with fiber. The foundation is charged with developing a plan that will draw people to an area that is largely unpopulated outside business hours.
But James Schmidt, the executive director of the foundation, said that technology companies have been inquiring about taking space in the old stores, which have been closed and boarded up since the mid-1980's. "We have had expressions of interest from computer-related companies and telcos for the Hahne's and S. Klein buildings as well as inquiries for offices for dot-com people interested in moving here from New York and Jersey City," he said.
He said the current plan is to convert the Hahne's store into residences, although he conceded that the building's 80,000-square-foot floors raised questions whether there would be enough light and air for the interior spaces. "The most desirable outcome for the Hahne's building would be residential," he said, "because it would provide 24-hour activity and more street life."
He said the foundation would be soliciting bids for the redevelopment of the buildings within a few weeks to determine whether expressions of interest are going to be backed by financial commitments.
Bush Terminal in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn is a 5-million-square-foot complex of buildings that have sat underutilized on the waterfront since the 1960's, when containerized ocean shipping replaced labor-intensive methods of loading and unloading ships.
But the sturdy old buildings that date to the early part of the 20th century are capable of supporting heavy loads, have high ceilings and have ample room for the powerful air-conditioning systems that Internet and telecommunications companies require.
In addition, there is space nearby to place the diesel-powered electrical generators that these companies insist on as insurance against what they see as an increasingly unreliable power supply. There is below-ground space available to store fuel to power the diesel motors in quantities intended to keep the place running for three days without an outside utility. The streets between the buildings were long ago decommissioned by the city, so cables can be installed without seeking official permission, and seven-foot-high tunnels further connect the 12 buildings in the complex.
Bush Terminal was also called Industry City because it was one of the first industrial parks in the nation. Industry has gone elsewhere, but the current owner, a private partnership named Industry City Associates, and the brokers who represent them are trying to convert it to a technology campus. This includes cutting vertical shafts called risers in the buildings, so that each tenant will have multiple connections to power and telecommunications cables.
The city has assisted the transformation process by designating the area as a technology zone similar to the Plug 'n' Go program that attracted dot-com and other computer-based companies to lower Manhattan. The six-story, 100,000-square-foot building at 269 37th Street is being developed as the Brooklyn Information Technology Center -- pronounced "Bit-sy."
Fledgling companies will be able starting Sept. 1 to rent prebuilt space that is wired for fiber-optic connections to each desk. Richard T. Kennedy, a senior director of Cushman & Wakefield, said a new lobby and elevators were being added to the structure, which now has only manually operated freight elevators. Annual rents, at $19 a square foot plus electricity, are way below the level commanded in Manhattan.
"This is the people building," said Mr. Kennedy, who added that the center will have affiliations with local educational institutions such as Polytechnic University and the Southwest Brooklyn Industrial Development Corporation.
Two other buildings in the complex will largely be devoted to electronic machinery. One early tenant is WinStar Wireless, which is said to be the first Web-hosting company to locate in the city outside Manhattan. The company signed a lease for 80,620 square feet in Telecom Center I, in part to take advantage of the 12-story building's direct, line-of-sight connection to lower Manhattan and New Jersey.
Another tenant is World Link, which is in the process of installing switching equipment in the building.
The decision to start converting Bush Terminal to a telecommunications center was made last year after observing the growth of the industry in Manhattan, said Bruce B. Federman, a partner in Industry City Associates.
"We decided to get into the telecom game in 1999 after watching it become very successful in Manhattan, and started wondering where it would land in the outer boroughs and New Jersey," he said.
He said the terminal is near two fiber lines, making it possible to position the buildings as a location for high-technology companies.
ANOTHER Brooklyn entrant into the tech-center business is the 750,000-square-foot factory building at 470 Vanderbilt Avenue in Prospect Heights. The building is vacant and is undergoing a $72 million redevelopment to erase its industrial past and to wire it for the future, said Gary Kamenetsky, a broker with Insignia/ ESG, a real estate services company based in New York.
It is being developed by the Carlyle Group, which Mr. Kamenetsky described as a $14 billion investment fund based in Washington.
He said the building is near the tracks of the Long Island Rail Road and a Bell Atlantic central office, giving it access to fiber-optic lines, and will be wired for electric power to provide 100 watts per square foot, compared with 4 or 5 watts a square foot in the typical office building. He said that the conversion work was under way and that the building would be ready for tenants on Sept. 1.
The building at 32 Avenue of the Americas was never a factory, but its floors have ceiling heights ranging from 14 to 19 feet. In the days before air-conditioning, the volume was needed to circulate air past the more than 5,000 people who worked there making connections for long-distance calls, said John J. Gilbert, executive vice president of Rudin Management.
"This building was the original telco hotel," Mr. Gilbert said. "In the 40's and 50's, if you made a call from Omaha, Neb., to Atlanta, Ga., it came through this building. There were 3,000 circuits connecting 360 cities."
AT&T's Long Lines division once occupied most of the structure, but the restructured company had no future need for all 1.2 million square feet. The company has consolidated into 400,000 square feet on the lower floors, and sold the building to Rudin last December.
Rudin is rebuilding the remaining space to accommodate the new telco tenants, including the powerful air-conditioning systems they require and the dry fire-suppression systems needed to protect expensive equipment. Backup generators are being installed on building setbacks and on the 15th floor, which has been set aside as a mechanical floor. Two 150-foot towers are being installed on the roof to permit wireless communications.
The building is being designed so that each tenant has a mechanical condominium. "Each tenant has their own generators and fuel tank and controls," Mr. Gilbert said. "They do not have to rely on shared building systems."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 11; Column 3; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 847 words

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 07-09-00;
Summertime Dues

BYLINE: By Walter Kirn; Walter Kirn is a critic and a novelist. His latest book is "Thumbsucker."

 BODY:
On my first summer job I learned to cheat. I was working in one of those cute, old-timey ice cream shops where the sundaes are decorated with toothpick flags and the staff sings "Happy Birthday" to the customers. The day I clocked in, the owner showed me how to scoop up a generous-looking ball of ice cream that was perfectly hollow in the center. The trick was in the wrist, and it took practice, but eventually I mastered the subterfuge and was serving up great gobs of rocky road that weighed, according to a hidden kitchen scale, exactly 1.5 ounces. I felt rotten. Kids would come in holding flimsy dollar bills -- all the money they'd ever had, it seemed -- and in return I would give them globes of air that collapsed inward the moment they were licked. I complained to the owner, who threatened to let me go and accused me of being a secret "heavy scooper" who didn't understand the ways of business.
Like millions of other American teenagers, I was doing what was expected of me that summer: preparing myself for the world of work by holding down a minimum-wage job that conveyed no special skills or knowledge but did breed a certain early cynicism. Like prom night and graduation, a summer job was a rite of passage in my town. Whether or not we needed the money or felt we had better uses for our time than topping off radiators at the mini-lube or repainting the foul lines on the city tennis courts, we teenagers labored straight through to Labor Day, emerging strengthened and toughened at summer's end. 
 That was two decades ago, another time. These days, according to several recent reports, the summer-job tradition is in decline. Fewer and fewer kids, the experts tell us, are showing an interest in whiling away their holidays folding boxes and weed-whipping cracked sidewalks.
What's more, the once-popular government programs that subsidized such jobs are drying up, the victims of a prosperous economy and a shrinking pool of applicants. A troubling development? Perhaps. Then again, if my own experience means anything, maybe not.
Summer jobs are supposed to build character in teenagers -- the question is, What sort of character? A lot of the jobs, let's face it, are pure make-work: clearing dead-end trails through national forests, planting violets around school flagpoles. They're the sort of duties assigned to prison inmates and pensioners in the Soviet Union, and what they mainly teach is the necessity of appearing busy for the boss while doing something that no one really needs done. At the end of the week there's a paycheck, small but helpful, which you promptly pump into the gas tank of your car or blow on Christina Aguilera tickets. The jobs are entitlement programs, basically, or political schemes to keep rambunctious kids out of the way of adults and off the streets.
Not that learning to look busy isn't valuable. One of my own summer jobs was moving books between two floors of a college library. My supervisor was barely in his 20's, a member of one of those upbeat New Age movements that preach prosperity through optimism. He called me and my coworkers his "team" and referred to our simple duties as "the mission." What he failed to notice, though, in his zeal to convert us to his beliefs, was that, after only four weeks on the job, we'd finished moving every single book. There was no more to do, and two more months to do it. The team made a decision then: say nothing. The job was so easy and the pay so generous that we agreed to keep a good thing going. We emptied half of the shelves that we'd just filled, carried the books downstairs, and started over.
Better training for corporate life would be hard to find. In that sense, the library job fulfilled its promise. I not only learned to work, I also learned when not to work. I learned to protect my friends and even my boss, who might have been laid off had someone realized that he'd fulfilled his objective prematurely. These lessons have come in handy ever since. In office after office, I've seen the price paid by those who complete assignments early, only to be handed yet more work in a continual, exhausting spiral that ends in hospitalization or unemployment. Such eager beavers tend to burn out early, perhaps because they never had summer jobs that taught them how to conserve their vital energy.
The kids who are eschewing summer work in favor of more broadening pursuits like travel, athletics and daily moviegoing may find themselves at a disadvantage someday. There's so much they won't know. Like when to steal. I learned to steal while working at a gas station. I resisted at first, but my manager pushed hard, and since he was the nephew of the proprietor, I found him persuasive. The guy stole everything, from cans of Dr. Pepper to tanks of gas, explaining that they belonged not to the station but to a multinational oil company. What's more, he said, if I tattled to his uncle he'd blame me for the thefts. I'd lose my job.
Summer work is important. Hop to it, kids. There are some things you just can't learn in school.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 16; Column 3; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1053 words

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 07-09-00: Word & Image;
The Nirvana News

BYLINE: By Max Frankel 

 BODY:
This being my last word in this space, I dare to imagine what will become of the news business. What will the newspaper of the future look like? Does it even have a future?
The answer, with apologies to the White House, is that it all depends on what your meaning of newspaper is. And of news. And of paper. 
 If you think a newspaper must always involve an imprint of inks on costly pulp that is processed from Canadian trees, trucked into urban factories and trucked out again to ever more widely dispersed readers, then its prospects are dim indeed. There is no feature of that paper product that will not soon be replicated and improved by digital technologies.
A Daily Digital can be delivered to you faster, cheaper and in much more versatile and desirable forms than any Truck Times. You could download it anywhere and read it on a portable tablet the size of a magazine. Or you could print out as much as you like on electronic sheets that feel like paper but can be endlessly reused in your home computer. Nothing magical about these forms; the technology is at hand.
Indeed, there is little that a paper journal does for you that a Web journal could not do better. A good old newspaper brings you both headlines and articles that are relevant to your life and citizenship, news that is instructive or interesting or both, plus diversions, opinions and advertisements that you either seek out or discover by browsing. The paper is portable, easily scannable and, with effort, preservable. Moreover, it forms a community of readers whose shared experience of it enhances their interests and conversations.
A Daily Digital could do all that -- faster and cheaper. It would also have infinite cyberspace for readers who want elaboration and illustration of any news item, including vivid videos and recordings. It would facilitate both rapid searching and extensive research and allow easy filing and retrieval of all articles. And it would let readers range far beyond the prix fixe menu of any single group of editorial chefs. News on the Web can be ordered la carte, from a thousand kitchens.
Without much effort, you can already consume a news stew that takes the foreign news from The Times, politics from The Washington Post, sports from USA Today, business from The Wall Street Journal and the opinions of every columnist in America. You can program this Daily Composite so that the desired features are packaged with your local weather report, TV and movie schedules and Help Wanted ads. Or you can have the mix prepared by Web editors who keep a record of your interests, down to the stocks you own and the baseball teams you follow. And as you cruise the Web, you will be pursued by electronic spies that then surmise your interests and those of like-minded people to tempt you with a customized package of articles and advertising.
As for community, the Daily Digital will instantly propel you into as many circles as you wish, with instant e-mail and chat rooms to debate public issues or share shopping experiences, recipes and gardening tips.
So when will you get The Nirvana News? Alas, not until the Web worshipers quit their rhapsodizing about "free" digital news and figure out a way to pay for its production. The Web has so far supplanted only the newspaper's trucks. It has not produced very good reporter robots or electronic editors. Nor has it figured out how to pay the costly humans needed to gather, interpret, write and package information in the coming world.
News that analyzes events and investigates all aspects of life is an expensive, handmade commodity. For the moment, the Web is getting it free of charge from the old ink media that are searching for ways to adapt to the new technology. Indeed, the Web is temporarily enriching newspapers with the self-promotions of dot-com companies. But electronic commerce will inevitably siphon off much of the advertising that has been supporting news gatherers without reinvesting that revenue in sophisticated journalism.
Unfortunately, the economics of newspapering are not easily replicated on the Web. Newspapers draw three-fourths of their income from advertising and most derive about half of that from classified ads -- the very ads for real estate, jobs and cars that will be the first to depart for the Internet and flourish there without being married to news content. General advertising will also migrate to Web sites that resemble shopping catalogs or television entertainments, sites that lack any journalistic purpose.
An enterprising electronic newspaper, therefore, will have to depend much more heavily than its printed forebears on revenue from readers. It may try to charge admission, perhaps pennies per page on a "pay as you read" basis if it can compete with the free headline services that will proliferate on the Web. The Daily Digital will surely seek income by collecting fees for reprints from its archives or for searches of reference works and other databases. Popular news sites will not only address groups of readers with "personalized" advertising but also seek to earn commissions for turning readers into customers for other merchants.
It is far from certain, however, that these forms of income will support the costs of producing a sophisticated news report. Television provides a scary example of what can happen to news gathering when a technological shift diverts the revenues of print. Although billions of advertising dollars migrated to TV from newspapers and magazines, only a fraction -- indeed, a still declining fraction -- of that money has been devoted to the pursuit and analysis of important news. On local TV, a mere handful of reporters and producers pretend to cover events that newspapers traditionally covered with hundreds. And the number of network correspondents covering national and foreign affairs has dwindled to a precious few.
There is no doubt that the Web is a much more efficient distributor of information than the two-ton truck. Newspapers must adapt to digital technologies or die. The foreseeable techniques of presenting news are dazzling, but they do not yet point to a reliable stream of income to pay for the harvesting of news. The oft-heard promise of "free news" is an oxymoron. Americans will get the journalism they pay for.

HEADLINE: IN THE GARDEN;
Some Lessons of Old From Williamsburg

BYLINE: By ELISABETH GINSBURG

 BODY:
I WENT to Colonial Williamsburg not long ago. It was Garden Week in Virginia, and, like thousands of my fellow enthusiasts, I was eager to see some of the extraordinary private gardens that were open for the festivities. I also wanted to find out what a 21st-century Northeastern gardener can learn from gardens that have been recreated over the past 60 years to resemble those that existed in 18th-century Virginia.
I am not the only one with such interests. Historic gardens are very hot right now. Expensive subdivisions seem to be full of people willing to spend vast sums of money to adorn the grounds of their new McMansions with everything from Victorian bedding-out schemes to French parterres. 
 The McMansionites are clearly the spiritual descendants of the colonial governor, Alexander Spotswood, who was convinced that he could create a fashionable watering hole within the confines of a colonial backwater by installing an ornamental water feature at the rear of the mansion. The governor's canal and fishpond have been recreated, and are sited conveniently near another of his innovations, a boxwood maze. He would undoubtedly be gratified to learn that water features and mazes have become fashionable all over again.
But pleasure gardens were not the only gardens flourishing within the colonial capital. Neatly planted symmetrical kitchen gardens, containing combinations of edible plants, herbs, ornamentals and even fruit trees, existed near the homes of working class, professional and wealthy residents. According to Kent Brinkley, director of horticulture for the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation, it is these gardens that have the most relevance for today's gardeners.
"Most of the gardens at Colonial Williamsburg are comparable in size to today's home lots," he said. "This helps modern gardeners relate to them in a more intimate way." Large estate gardens may be inspiring, added Mr. Brinkley, but it is easier to translate ideas when they are presented on a residential scale.
Williamsburg's gardens were also full of old-fashioned plant varieties that are identical or at least similar to varieties that were cultivated during the 18th century. Contemporary gardeners are becoming interested in older varieties, and a look at Williamsburg's plant lists can serve as a jumping-off point for selection of specific cultivars for a period bed or garden area. In an era when even the most devoted amateur gardeners are pressed for time, the tough plants favored by the colonists merit attention. One example of such toughness, Mr. Brinkley said, is the roses grown in some of the colonial gardens. The plants may not have the largest blossoms, but they are tremendously hardy.
Perhaps the most important lesson that I learned from Williamsburg is also the least tangible. Over the course of the past 15 years, changes in scholarship and developments in landscape archaeology have led Mr. Brinkley and other horticulturists to reexamine the way colonial gardens have been portrayed. The gardens that were reconstructed in the 1930's and 40's when Colonial Williamsburg was a new venture, were Colonial Revival rather than true colonial gardens. The difference between the two is sometimes subtle, according to Mr. Brinkley, but in general the Colonial Revival gardens in the historic area, while presenting an elegant period feel, did not reflect the economic and social status of the colonial-era owners of specific properties. Now, that has become an integral part of garden restoration.
"The use of finely crafted pickets instead of plain boards for fences says something about the status of the owner of a garden," Mr. Brinkley said. Personal wealth might also have led a colonial homeowner to install brick walks between garden beds, as opposed to dirt paths covered with a less costly material.
This emphasis on class distinctions does not please everybody, but it made me feel closer to the original gardeners, many of whom were also busy working people, with gardens that were not necessarily models of exquisite tidiness.
The other lesson that I learned from Mr. Brinkley and the gardens of Williamsburg is that in historic garden recreation, as in any kind of gardening, there is no such thing as being finished. Mr. Brinkley's cited the example of the Taliafero (pronounced toliver) Apple, a variety discovered by the father-in-law of a prominent Williamsburg resident George Wythe and cultivated by Thomas Jefferson. The apple has disappeared from cultivation, but Mr. Brinkley hopes that somewhere, on an abandoned farmstead, a Taliafero apple tree clings to life. If such a tree exists, he looks forward to providing a safe haven for it in Williamsburg, and eventually, returning both the tree and its fruit to commerce.
 
THIS WEEK
Plant Some History In the Backyard
If you have time to visit Virginia and still want something colonial in your garden, contact the Thomas Jefferson Center for Historic Plants. The center, founded in 1987, is located at Tufton Farm, a satellite of the Monticello estate. While the historians and horticulturists of the center focus on the plants that Jefferson knew and grew, research is also conducted on "the broad history of plants cultivated in America," as explained on the center's Web site.
To receive the center's catalog of heirloom flower and vegetable seeds, send your request, accompanied by a long self-addressed stamped envelope to: Thomas Jefferson Center for Historic Plants Monticello, P.O. Box 316, Charlottesville, Va. 22902.
The center's Web site: www.monticello.org/chp/
index.html.

HEADLINE: ROAD AND RAIL;
6 Miles for $6 Million

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA ROWE

 BODY:
A MERE six miles of new train track means Nick Zaderay can shave 15 minutes from his commute of 3 hours and 15 minutes. It means Chris Silvera can bicycle to the train from his home in northern Dutchess County, and it means the Metro-North Railroad could pick up hundreds of new riders.
That's why Metro-North invested five years and $6 million to build two stations opening today. The Tenmile River and Wassaic stations, both in the town of Amenia in Dutchess County, have extended Metro-North's Harlem Line just under six miles. But it might as well be 50, for all the excitment this has generated. Gov. George E. Pataki is expected at a ribbon-cutting ceremony at Wassaic station tomorrow morning, and E. Virgil Conway, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, will be on hand as well. 
 "This is the first time in our history that we've ever expanded," Mr. Conway said. "The whole suburban area is pushing north. Ridership is increasing all the time. I think it's going to continue to increase."
Indeed. Mr. Zaderay, a financial consultant who lives in Pittsfield, Mass., has no trouble rising every day around 5 a.m. for his trip to the office a few blocks from Grand Central Terminal. He shrugs off a total of six-and-a-half hours of daily commuting as the price of the good life.
"I love the Berkshires, and my business is in New York City," he said. "So I have the best of both worlds."
Mr. Zaderay will now be able to pare 10 or 15 minutes from his drive to and from the train by boarding at the Wassaic station, 5.6 miles closer to his home. "Early in the morning, even a few minutes is something," he said. He is not an anomaly. Metro-North has seen a dramatic increase in ridership over the last 15 years, and most of it comes from commuters boarding at its northernmost stations. At 6:30 a.m. one recent Thursday, all the parking spaces at the end of the line in Dover Plains were filled with commuters' cars, many bearing Massachusetts or Connecticut license plates. Since 1984, weekday ridership on those trains jumped 463 percent, to a total of 535 people riding south each day.
Peter A. Cannito, Metro-North's president, said ridership was up nearly 5 percent compared with last year, with the greatest increase on the upper Harlem and upper Hudson lines. (He and Mr. Conway both ride Harlem line trains to work, though not from as far away as Mr. Zaderay.)
Business is booming so much that Metro-North has considered building an extension into Pennsylvania Station and rehabilitating an old east-west line, which would run from Beacon in Dutchess County to the Brewster station in Putnam.
The new Wassaic and Tenmile River stations, built on existing rails, which were used from the mid-1800's through 1972, will bring commuters almost six miles north of Dover Plains and provide a total of 300 new parking spaces.
Chris Silvera, a Teamsters' official, may not need one, though. With the Wassaic station only three minutes from his home in Amenia, Mr. Silvera, who commutes to Manhattan every day, said he might bike to the train.
"Maybe I can lose some of this flab," he said with a laugh and grabbed his belly. "I think they should actually extend the line all the way north to Chatham or even Great Barrington, Mass. People are moving there and coming in to the city every day, so clearly there's a market for it."
Mr. Silvera, who moved north from New York City four years ago, said the change in locale had been well worth the logistical hassles.
"It's a quality-of-life issue," he said. "There's an inconvenience in travel, but there's a mental recoupment living in a quieter area."
Commuters who willingly ride for hours to get into the city have become such a regular part of business that Metro-North has a shuttle bus running back and forth between Dover Plains (a two-hour ride from Manhattan) and Great Barrington.
A few days before its new train station was to open, all was quiet in the tiny Hamlet of Wassaic, best known as the birthplace and former home of Borden Condensed Milk. The biggest action in town these days is a weekly livestock auction. Hand-lettered signs advertising "Piglets for Sale," hang outside some homes, and many driveways hold vintage cars in various states of repair. The station, with 250 parking spaces right off the Route 22 thoroughfare, is clean and quaint, with a pitched green roof and tasteful-looking brickwork. The platform stands between two towering mountains, which are often draped with mist in the early morning.
To many residents, even more important than an easier commute is the possibility that trains running from the opposite direction will provide a boost to tourism.
"We've focused on the reverse commute," said Kathleen Schibanoff, executive director of the Harlem Valley Partnership, an economic development and regional planning group. "The trains, we hope, will bring people from the city to this area to recreate, enjoy the biking, the restaurants, the wineries."
No one expects an immediate boom in business or wildly escalating real estate values, she said, but as suburbia creeps ever northward the effects of the railroad are undeniable.
"We've always viewed the train as our connection to the metropolitan area," she said. "I feel like it keeps us connected to life and activity, so we're not just forgotten out here."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
Value Stocks Helped Some Foreign Funds Beat the Trend

BYLINE: By VIVIAN MARINO 

 BODY:
INVESTORS who thought they could lessen their risk by diversifying overseas found little solace last quarter in international equity funds, many of which underperformed their domestic counterparts.
The funds fell by an average of 6.28 percent for the period, according to Morningstar Inc., compared with a decline of 2.91 percent for all stock funds in the United States. 
 A big reason was the 180-degree reversal of fortune for once-hot technology stocks. Many of last year's stellar funds became this year's laggards by loading up on high-priced foreign Internet and telecommunications stocks that took a downturn during a highly volatile period. Plenty of domestic funds did the same, of course, but the problem was compounded for foreign funds by adverse currency movements, particularly the euro's slide, that further eroded their dollar-denominated returns.
But a few international funds managed to beat the trend, mainly by resisting dot-com temptations and sticking with undervalued old-economy companies on the rebound. Among them were Pilgrim International Value and Longleaf Partners International, which invested primarily in middle- and large-cap stocks in Europe and Japan, and RS Contrarian, which invested heavily in energy stocks largely in Canada.
"We're really looking through the trash that everyone else has thrown out, trying to find undervalued companies run by people with integrity," said Andrew McDermott, who helps run the Longleaf fund along with O. Mason Hawkins of Southeastern Asset Management in Memphis.
Mr. McDermott and Mr. Hawkins, along with Charles Brandes, lead manager of Pilgrim International and Andrew Pilara, a co-manager of RS Contrarian, recently shared some of their stock-picking and investment approaches for the quarter. They also discussed their market outlooks for the remainder of the year.
 
No Nets, but Safety
Mr. Brandes, 57, who runs Brandes Investment Partners of San Diego, submanager for Pilgrim International, says countries and industry sectors do not matter when he chooses stocks for the $758 million fund. "Our secret is to buy good companies at bargain prices, no matter where they happen to be," he said.
That approach brought Pilgrim International a return of 7.46 percent in the second quarter and 28.23 percent for the last 12 months.
Mr. Brandes said he is a student of the Benjamin Graham-David Dodd value approach to investing, detailed in the 1930's: to buy stocks that trade at below-market ratios of price to earnings but that are poised to climb.
For Mr. Brandes, that means holding very few technology shares, which account for just 1.8 percent of the fund's assets. Instead, the bulk of the portfolio last quarter was in financial services, consumer staples, durable goods and industrial cyclicals, mainly in Europe with smaller portions in Latin America, Japan and elsewhere on the Pacific Rim.
The biggest contributors to his fund's performance, according to Mr. Brandes, included Alcatel, the French telecommunications equipment maker; Mitsubishi Heavy Industries of Japan; and National Power, the British electric utility. All three had good cash flow, and their stock prices posted double-digit percentage gains in the quarter.
 
Currency Risk, Canceled
Mr. McDermott, 31, and Mr. Hawkins, 52, echoed many of Mr. Brandes's views on value. The bargain-hunting style, out of fashion in 1999, helped the $300 million Longleaf International fund gain 10.11 percent for the quarter, second best among international stock funds, and 14.05 percent for the last 12 months. But the Longleaf fund mixes in some growth companies, too.
"We don't think we can separate value from growth," Mr. Hawkins said. "We care more about what value will build" in a company.
Mr. McDermott added: "We don't have a quarterly strategy, and we don't have an asset allocation strategy based on geography. We're strictly bottom-up."
The fund's currency-hedging strategy also helped. The managers match the expected foreign-currency earnings of their holdings with short positions in those currencies, cushioning the fund from exchange-rate fluctuations. "It's one of the reasons our funds held up in the second quarter," Mr. McDermott said. "We don't take foreign-currency risks."
It is also why the fund avoids investing in Latin America or other emerging markets, where most currencies are too volatile to hedge easily. The portfolio is concentrated instead in Europe and Japan, and focuses on services, financial stocks, retailers and industrial cyclicals.
Among the fund's top performers, according to Mr. McDermott, were Diageo, the giant British food and spirits company; Safeway P.L.C., the British supermarket chain; and Sampo Insurance of Finland.
Diageo, whose many brands include Burger King, Haagen-Dazs, Guinness and Johnnie Walker, "was selling at the cheapest price in its history," Mr. McDermott noted.
 
Back in Favor
Mr. Pilara, 58, found a few low-priced gems last year for the $100 million RS Contrarian, run by Robertson Stephens of San Francisco, and much of the payoff came during the last quarter. As energy costs have risen sharply in the United States in recent months, so have the fortunes of many oil and gas companies whose shares he accumulated.
"What's bad for the consumer is good for us," said Mr. Pilara, who joined the fund's founder, Paul Stephens, two years ago when the fund was mired in losses. Since then, Mr. Pilara has helped revamp the fund's investment strategy by reducing its heavy concentration in beaten-down industries like metals mining.
Now, about 45 percent of assets are in energy, with the remainder scattered in basic materials, communications, industrial cyclicals, technology and elsewhere. Most of the holdings are in Canada and the United States, Mr. Pilara said.
The fund suffered along with other contrarian funds in the glory years of the bull market, but it is starting to see daylight again, gaining 10.22 percent in the second quarter, the best of any international stock fund tracked by Morningstar. It gained 15.46 percent over the last year.
Among its top performers last quarter, according to Mr. Pilara, were EOG Resources of Houston; Ivanhoe Energy of Bakersfield, Calif.; and Anderson Exploration and Encal Energy, both of Calgary, Alberta. All are involved in the production of natural gas, which has soared in price recently, tripling on the New York Mercantile Exchange in the past year. "Everyone is talking about gasoline, but we think there's a bigger problem with natural gas," he said, referring to the sharp rise in its price.
Though the energy stocks don't quite fit the fund's out-of-favor criteria, Mr. Pilara said he had no plans to sell them.
"We are a contrarian fund," he said, "and we're looking for some more straw hats in the winter."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
The Powers Behind the Net May Be the Next Rocket

BYLINE: By DANNY HAKIM 

 BODY:
IF technology remains the obsession of American investors, where are money managers placing their bets now? The answers can have all the longevity of a cast member on "Survivor." To trace the path of new-economy investing, fast feet and a good line of technospeak are required.
In the beginning, there were B2C (business-to-consumer) stocks. Remember when theglobe.com, the Gen X Web portal, shot up606 percent the day it went public? Love of all things B2C evaporated around the time that Barron's labeled Amazon.com as "Amazon.bomb." Nowadays a share of theglobe is as cheap as a bottle of Snapple and Amazon.com is near its 52-week low. 
 B2C gave way to B2B (business-to-business) until B2B valuations started to look as inflated as B2C's. Then came I.S.P.'s (Internet service providers) and A.S.P.'s (application service providers), software makers, networking companies and incubators -- companies that invest in all of the above. And then there was the hype surrounding Linux, the free operating system that would, we were told, gut Microsoft faster than the Justice Department could.
Ah, for the good old days. Chastened by the technology correction, money managers now look a whole lot less favorably on companies with a future full of projected losses. Infrastructure plays -- companies that build the tangible devices that power the Internet, and actually make money -- are more sought after today.
Not that there is no appetite for speculation, especially when the word "wireless" is mentioned. The next big thing, the buzz has it, will be wireless Internet -- Web-enabled cell phones, Dick Tracy watches, gadgets in the car. Two new technology mutual funds focus exclusively on all things unplugged.
Ryan Jacob, manager of the $150 million Jacob Internet fund, likes two companies that make software for wireless devices, Aether Systems of Owings Mills, Md., and 724 Solutions of Toronto. "They're on the forefront of the next evolution we're going to see in Internet usage, which is bringing the Internet off the desktop," he said.
But for Andrew S. Cupps, manager of the Strong Enterprise fund, the recent attention on wireless-related stocks makes it difficult to find reasonably priced stocks. "We've had a little trouble identifying a stock where the valuation makes sense," he said. "An Aether, a $7 billion valuation with massive losses and very little revenue? I'm going to have to plead ignorance."
Instead, he picked up National Semiconductor in the second quarter, a veteran chip maker that now supplies components for cell phones and other wireless devices.
"We've shifted to lower multiples and profitable companies," as opposed to those that promise more than they can deliver, Mr. Cupps said. "National Semiconductor is the best example, a very profitable company that's trading at a multiple below 20," referring to the stock's price-to-earnings ratio of about 17, less than two-thirds the average for the Standard & Poor's 500.
That preference for companies in the black is shared by Peter Anastos and Gerald T. Malone, managers of the Alliance Technology fund, which with $12.6 billion in assets is one of the largest general technology funds. Their portfolio is very light on Internet stocks and heavy on semiconductors. The strategy has yielded steady, but not top-flight, long-term returns, according to Morningstar Inc.; the fund held up better than most of its peers in the second quarter and was up 11.6 percent in the first half.
The relatively traditional approach puts stocks like Cisco Systems, PMC Sierra and Nokia at the top of the portfolio. The fund has also added to its positions in companies that the managers believe are leading players in emerging areas, including Veritas, JDS Uniphase and BEA Systems. They did bite on one Internet stock, picking up Yahoo as it fell 27.7 percent in the quarter.
"Internet advertising might not show the growth this year that people expected, and advertising is the underpinning of the business model" at Yahoo, Mr. Anastos said. "It's a legitimate but short-term concern" for a company whose market share is still growing, he said.
E-commerce is on many managers' don't-like lists. Struggles in the sector began even before the April technology stock slump, and when other Internet stocks rebounded in June, e-commerce kept heading south. TheStreet.com E-Commerce index was off 59 percent for the first half.
Flying against this downdraft, Firsthand Funds has just opened an e-commerce fund, Firsthand e-Commerce. Tellingly, it owns none of the usual e-commerce suspects: no Amazon.com, no Priceline.com, no eBay.
"It's not that we have a 'sell' call on these stocks," said Kevin Landis, who manages the fund. "We've just always avoided the group. Those companies are already famous, and those stocks are already expensive."
So what is the alternative? Infrastructure. Mr. Landis said that while the fund is not interested in retail dot-coms, "we want to invest in everyone they pay" -- the Internet software makers, the networking companies, the service providers.
Among his favorites are companies that are hired to run Web sites and other computer operations for other companies. Mr. Landis added to a favorite position, Globix, based in Manhattan's Silicon Alley, as it was falling 23.1 percent in the second quarter after a run-up of 1,100 percent last year.
Mr. Landis also "took a big chunk" of the initial public offering of Genuity, which was spun off from GTE late last month.
"The market's correction has given us an opportunity to buy stocks that would normally be too expensive for us," he said. "High-growth, well-regarded, gold-plated tech companies -- you buy because this is the only time they are going to be cheap. You're less likely to go fishing for turnarounds."

HEADLINE: Personal Business;
How Best to Deduct the High Cost of Gasoline?

BYLINE: By STACY KRAVETZ 

 BODY:
DESPITE recent signs of easing, high prices at the gas pump continue to stir political debate. They may also change the calculus for another, more personal question: Which method should taxpayers use when figuring deductions for business mileage: the standard rate or the actual-expense version?
It is a decision that should be revisited whenever any of the relevant elements change, experts say. For the self-employed, the choice is especially important, though even employees who are reimbursed for their mileage can deduct expenses in excess of the reimbursement. 
 Business mileage refers to any driving done for work other than commuting to and from the office -- trips to see clients, to courthouses or to meetings, for example.
For years, the standard mileage rate -- the business expense allowed by the Internal Revenue Service for each mile driven for business -- has generally ticked up steadily but slowly, mirroring cost-of-living adjustments. The rate is a calculation of the average driver's auto-related expenses, including lease payments, depreciation, interest payments, insurance, gasoline, repairs and maintenance costs. The rationale is that while gas prices and other expenses may fluctuate, they have a relatively small impact on the overall cost of driving.
That does not mean, however, that the standard mileage rate reflects the cost of driving for any individual driver. People who live in large cities, for example, spend more on insurance, while those who finance expensive cars pay more interest. And as gasoline prices climbed this year, Midwesterners paid higher prices than others. But everyone who chooses this method of accounting gets the same standard rate, though some small items, like parking and tolls, can be deducted separately.
When the I.R.S. lowered the standard mileage rate last year, from 32.5 cents a mile to 31 cents as of April 1, it was a blow to those who thought the rate was already too low. And with pump prices up markedly since then, the actual-expense method bears extra consideration.
"We calculate it both ways for our clients, and 99 percent of the time the actual expense provides a better tax deduction than the mileage rate they give you," said Howard Leitner, a partner at the accounting firm Leitner, Zander, Sniderman & Company in Los Angeles. "With rising gas prices, if you were on the border of whether you should take actual or standard, it will push you over to the actual-expense side."
Of course, the main benefit of using the standard rate is its simplicity. A taxpayer need keep records only of the miles driven for business in a given year.
But when should savings trump ease? The only way to know the difference between the standard rate and actual expenses is to run the numbers. The calculation will include the number of business miles driven in a year and the amount spent on gasoline and other allowable costs for the portion of driving that relates to business.
The standard rate is based on average car expenses, with an estimate for gasoline costs based on prices in the previous year -- currently, about $1.50 a gallon. This hardly does justice to prices spiking upward of $2.50 a gallon, as they did recently in many Midwestern cities. For a car that gets 20 miles to the gallon, a $1-a-gallon jump in gas prices means an increase of 5 cents a mile.
"You could look at it as the I.R.S. cheating you by 5 cents a mile," said Gordon Klein, a tax lawyer and a lecturer at the Anderson School at the University of California at Los Angeles. "It could add up."
For people who barely use their cars for business or who have extremely low car expenses, the extra effort of collecting receipts and calculating expenses will generally not produce enough savings to justify the work. Similarly, employees whose companies reimburse their business mileage may not receive a big benefit, because they can deduct only the actual expenses above the amount they are reimbursed. Most employers pay for mileage at the I.R.S. standard rate. In addition, the I.R.S. does not let employees claim the interest portion of car payments as an auto expense, so their allowable "actual expenses" will be lower than those for the self-employed.
ACCOUNTANTS say the differences in savings tend to be biggest for people who are self-employed or who lease cars, or both.
"If you're self-employed, it's a real issue because you're not getting anything if you don't take it on your tax return," said David Green, a partner in the personal financial services practice at PricewaterhouseCoopers in Los Angeles. When they itemize, the self-employed may claim the interest portion of their car payments as an expense, along with all other annual costs of driving for business.
Say a self-employed woman has a $35,000 car that is used 50 percent of the time for business. She can deduct actual expenses totaling 50 percent of her gasoline, insurance, interest and maintenance expenses.
The car was financed at an interest rate of 8.49 percent, is driven a total of 12,000 miles in a year and gets 25 miles to the gallon in a metropolitan area where gasoline costs $1.75 a gallon.
The business half of the expenses includes $750 for insurance, $1,374 for interest, $420 for gasoline and $250 for maintenance. The I.R.S. also considers depreciation an expense, though it is capped for all cars, no matter their cost, and is set at a different amount for each subsequent year of use.
For cars first used for business in 1999, the cap that year was $3,060. (The cap for cars first used in 2000 has not yet been set.) In the example, that means a maximum of $1,530 (or 50 percent of $3,060) could be included as an expense. In this case, the driver would be allowed $1,530 for depreciation, bringing her total allowable expenses to $4,324.
By contrast, the standard mileage rate of 31 cents a mile would let her deduct only $1,860.
The gap between the calculations, of course, grows as fuel efficiency drops or as the price of gasoline jumps. Say the car in the example was a gas-guzzler, getting 15 miles to the gallon in a city where gas prices have risen to $2.50 a gallon. The vehicle's annual fuel costs would jump to $1,000, from $420, and total expenses would rise to $4,904, from $4,324. But the standard mileage rate would still allow for just $1,860.
Big differences are also seen in the computations for leased cars. While there are no interest expenses or depreciation involved, lease payments may be included in the actual-expense calculation. So if that same gas-guzzler were leased, with annual payments of $3,800, the total actual expenses would be $5,800.
If doing the extra math makes sense, remember that choosing the actual-expense method the first year a car is used for business obligates you to continue with it as long as you have that car. (If you choose the standard rate the first year, you may be able to switch to actual expenses in later years.)
True, itemizing expenses can be an ordeal. But the tax savings gained through using the actual-expense method may, among other things, be one small way to feel better about the pain at the pump.
 
One Way to Save: Burn Less Fuel
CAN'T itemize business driving expenses to get back more of the high cost of gasoline from the tax collector? There are other ways to keep high pump prices from stinging quite so much.
* Stick to the speed limit. Fuel efficiency drops markedly at high speeds, even for high-performance cars.
* Switch to regular. Many drivers buy premium who do not need it. High-compression, high-horsepower engines must have the extra octane; for the rest, regular gas is just as good. The difference can be $3 or more for each fill-up.
* Service the car. Changing the oil often -- say, every 3,000 miles -- and keeping the tires fully inflated will improve gas mileage.
* Empty the trunk. Keep the spare, the jack and the emergency kit, of course, but that sack of sand for winter traction and the golf clubs you use twice a year can go, lightening the load on the engine.
* Roll up the windows. At highway speeds, it generally takes less energy to run the air-conditioner than to fight the aerodynamic drag caused by open windows. (Around town, the opposite is true.)
* Turn off the engine. Idling for longer than two or three minutes burns more fuel than restarting a typical car.
* Cadge a lift. "Hey, that's a beaut you've got in the driveway, Phil. Bet she rides great. What say we tool on down to the squash courts together in your car?"

HEADLINE: IN THE GARDEN;
Some Lessons of Old From Williamsburg

BYLINE: By ELISABETH GINSBURG

 BODY:
I WENT to Colonial Williamsburg not long ago. It was Garden Week in Virginia, and, like thousands of my fellow enthusiasts, I was eager to see some of the extraordinary private gardens that were open for the festivities. I also wanted to find out what a 21st-century Northeastern gardener can learn from gardens that have been recreated over the past 60 years to resemble those that existed in 18th-century Virginia.
I am not the only one with such interests. Historic gardens are very hot right now. Expensive subdivisions seem to be full of people willing to spend vast sums of money to adorn the grounds of their new McMansions with everything from Victorian bedding-out schemes to French parterres. 
 The McMansionites are clearly the spiritual descendants of the colonial governor, Alexander Spotswood, who was convinced that he could create a fashionable watering hole within the confines of a colonial backwater by installing an ornamental water feature at the rear of the governor's mansion. The governor's canal and fishpond have been recreated, and are sited conveniently near another of his innovations, a boxwood maze. He would undoubtedly be gratified to learn that water features and mazes have become fashionable again.
But pleasure gardens were not the only gardens flourishing within the colonial capital. Neatly planted symmetrical kitchen gardens, containing combinations of edible plants, herbs, ornamentals and even fruit trees, existed near the homes of working class, professional and wealthy residents. According to Kent Brinkley, director of horticulture for the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation, it is these gardens that have the most relevance for today's gardeners.
"Most of the gardens at Colonial Williamsburg are comparable in size to today's home lots," he said. "This helps modern gardeners relate to them in a more intimate way." Large estate gardens may be inspiring, added Mr. Brinkley, but it is easier to translate ideas when they are presented on a residential scale.
Williamsburg's gardens were also full of old-fashioned plant varieties that are identical or at least similar to varieties that were cultivated during the 18th century. Contemporary gardeners are becoming interested in older varieties, and a look at Williamsburg's plant lists can serve as a jumping-off point for selection of specific cultivars for a period bed or garden area. In an era when even the most devoted amateur gardeners are pressed for time, the tough plants favored by colonists merit attention. One example of such toughness, Mr. Brinkley said, is the roses grown in some of colonial gardens. The plants may not have the largest blossoms, but they are very hardy.
Perhaps the most important lesson that I learned from Williamsburg is also the least tangible. Over the course of the past 15 years, changes in scholarship and developments in landscape archaeology have led Mr. Brinkley and other horticulturists to reexamine the way colonial gardens have been portrayed. The gardens that were reconstructed in the 1930's and 40's when Colonial Williamsburg was a new venture, were Colonial Revival rather than true colonial gardens. The difference between the two is sometimes subtle, according to Mr. Brinkley, but in general the Colonial Revival gardens in the historic area, while presenting an elegant period feel, did not reflect the economic and social status of the colonial-era owners of specific properties. Now, that has become an integral part of garden restoration. "The use of finely crafted pickets instead of plain boards for fences says something about the status of the owner of a garden," Mr. Brinkley said. Personal wealth might also have led a colonial homeowner to install brick walks between garden beds, as opposed to dirt paths covered with a less costly material.
This emphasis on class distinctions does not please everybody, but it made me feel closer to the original gardeners, many of whom were also busy working people, with gardens that were not necessarily tidy.
The other lesson that I learned from Mr. Brinkley and the gardens of Williamsburg is that in historic garden recreation, as in any kind of gardening, there is no such thing as being finished. Mr. Brinkley's cited the example of the Taliafero (pronounced toliver) Apple, a variety discovered by the father-in-law of a prominent Williamsburg resident George Wythe and cultivated by Thomas Jefferson. The apple has disappeared from cultivation, but Mr. Brinkley hopes that somewhere, on an abandoned farmstead, a Taliafero apple tree clings to life. If such a tree exists, he looks forward to providing a safe haven for it in Williamsburg, and eventually, returning both the tree and its fruit to commerce.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT: ESSAY;
Of Lions and Bulls And Squares (Oh My!)

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
IF your investing style could be a geometric figure, what kind would it be?
Perhaps a polyhedron, like the pyramid with the shining upper chamber that serves as the logotype for Fidelity Investments? Or the concentric triangles that symbolize Alliance Capital Management? Or maybe the stylistic circle that representsthe Invesco funds? 
 If you are like me, all these fund family crests leave you cold. Granted, illustrating something so fuzzy as an investment philosophy is no easy feat but can't we do any better than a bunch of polygons, sailing vessels and oak trees?
No wonder studies show that the most memorable icon of the mutual fund industry is the lion that belongs to the Dreyfus Corporation, a unit of Mellon Financial. As Merrill Lynch has proved, when it comes to building a strong public image, you can't beat a magnificent hairy beast. Investors are likely to keep identifying Dreyfus with its mascot long after they have forgotten the $2.95 million the company recently agreed to pay to settle accusations that it failed to adequately disclose the risks of its Aggressive Growth fund and that the fund's early performance was inflated by one its former managers, Michael L. Schonberg. (Neither Dreyfus nor Mr. Schonberg admitted wrongdoing.)
It comes as no surprise that people have trouble remembering that Fidelity's logo resembles the pyramid on the back of a dollar bill -- without that eerie eye -- or that the Franklin fund family logo, a portrait of Benjamin Franklin, looks as if it might come from the front of an old $100 note. If you are going to use cash to represent the promise to shareholders, why not go with a big pile, maybe in a wheelbarrow? But on second thought, that image might be mistaken for the managers carting off commissions of 5 percent plus assorted annual fees.
And, please, no more boats. What is it with money men and all things nautical? You can't walk through the headquarters of a major financial institution in the Northeast without feeling as if you have stumbled into the offices of the Dutch East India Company of the 17th century. The walls are lined with paintings and sketches of schooners and ketches. I've noticed that the money managers have learned to keep the pictures of their own yachts out of sight of the paying customers.
The State Street and Pioneer fund families, which share the home port of Boston, each use a variation on a sailing ship as a logo. The Vanguard Group has taken the seafaring theme to such an extreme that you might never guess that the company is based as far inland as Valley Forge, Pa. The index-fund giant is so hooked on sailing that one ad in a glossy magazine reads, "While many fund companies are learning the ropes of indexing, consider who built the rigging." (Rigging is a word you probably will not see in a Dreyfus ad anytime soon.)
The new symbol for the Scudder funds is distinctive: a racing shell with four rowers pulling their oars in unison. It conveys sleekness, fitness and teamwork and certainly resonates better with baby boomers than Scudder's previous icon -- an old, bearded sea captain, bedecked in foul-weather gear. He always gave me a sudden craving for frozen fish sticks.
The old salt sailed off into the sunset last year after Scudder merged with the Kemper fund family, yet Kemper has kept its more mysterious symbol, a sheaf of wheat. You can't get much more old-economy than a farming metaphor.
A bull may be a perfect symbol for a Wall Street firm, but none of Merrill's competitors has tried to rustle it lately. For the most part their mascots are avuncular bankers promising to earn your trust. But some of Merrill's rivals, who of course manage their own funds, have landed some memorable slogans, like "We make money the old-fashioned way, we earn it" and "We measure success one investor at a time."
The closest analog from a fund company comes from Massachusetts Financial Services, which flatly declares: "We invented the mutual fund."
It is hard to distinguish among Fidelity's "Invest responsibly" theme, the Aim fund family's "Invest with discipline" and T. Rowe Price's "Invest with confidence." But they are durable. Is there any slogan that says "out of step with the times" more clearly than Kemper's "long-term investing in a short-term world"?
Then there's the mythology thing. Janus, the Denver company that has become synonymous with making concentrated bets on fast-growing technology companies, has clearly studied Nike's playbook, not Vanguard's. The evidence: Nike was named for a Greek goddess, Janus for a Roman god. Nike's rallying cry was "Just do it"; Janus says "Get there."
Janus's logo is one of the more recognizable in the industry. There may already be thousands of investors who know that two-faced god symbolizes doorways and beginnings, but there probably are more who think he was the god of beating the market. Of course, more than a few old-school investors would argue that Bacchus would be a more appropriate icon for a company that so thoroughly reveled at the technology-stock feast of the last several years.
Aside from Dreyfus and Merrill, surprisingly few fund companies have turned to the tried-and-true use of animals as symbols. One is T. Rowe Price, whose mascot is a ram that represents surefootedness.
But another is a newcomer, and its choice of a logo may be spot-on. Thomas Marsico already was something of a maverick before he bolted from Janus's stable of managers a few years ago to start his own firm focused on investing in fast-growing companies. The symbol he chose looks a lot like a wild horse; that is appropriate, because his funds have taken shareholders on a exhilarating ride. The flagship Marsico Focus fund returned more than 50 percent in 1998 and again in 1999, though it was down about 9 percent this year through June 30.
For established fund firms that want to project a more sober image, inventive marketing has proved a major challenge. Consider what Fidelity, arguably the most successful fund company since somebody came up with the idea of putting stocks in baskets, has done to promote itself in recent years. To hammer home its "Invest responsibly" mantra, it hired Don Rickles and Lily Tomlin, two people who made their fortunes by sticking their tongues out at strangers.
The truth for the people who run Fidelity is that they have the single most valuable promotional resource in the industry on the board of directors. His name is Peter Lynch and, although he has not managed a Fidelity fund in many years, he is generally accepted as one of the greatest living investors.
At 56, he will probably be around for a long time, but Fidelity executives should be planning how they will continue using Mr. Lynch's Midas-like reputation after he is gone. They might consider replacing the current logo, which conjures up images of some sort of cult or a secret society, with a sketch of Mr. Lynch's brain and a simple, direct slogan, like "We didn't invent the mutual fund but we have dibs on Peter Lynch's gene pool."
