HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
Betting on the Unloved To Beat a Downturn

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
THERE were swoons and rebounds, and then more again of the same. But by the end of the second quarter, the stock market had provided enough bad news to push every major category of United States diversified equity funds into negative territory for the period. Over all, domestic diversified stock funds lost 3.1 percent.
What funds managed to shine as stormy weather lashed the markets? Generally, the winners owned shares in companies in old-economy sectors, like oil and gas, as well as in health care and some financial services. 
 Managers of three top-performing funds talked about the resurgence of once-beaten-down sectors and what they expect from the stock market during the remainder of the year.
 
Helped by a U-Turn
Cheap, small stocks propelled the $262.7 million Ariel fund into second place among funds for the quarter, with a return of 14 percent.
"Our stocks were so extraordinarily cheap at the beginning of the quarter that they were really poised to move up sharply," said its manager, John W. Rogers Jr.
Mr. Rogers, 42, looks for companies that sell for a discount of at least 40 percent to their private market value (what they would be worth to an acquirer), and whose shares trade at less than 14 times projected earnings for the next year. The fund holds just 35 issues.
One big winner was Central Newspapers of Phoenix, owner of The Arizona Republic, The Indianapolis Star and other papers. "Newspapers are cheap because investors are worrying about the impact of the Internet," Mr. Rogers said, "and publishers worry about rising paper prices."
The company's share price was so depressed, he added, that management put the business up for sale. Last month, Gannett agreed to buy it for $2.6 billion; the stock rose 89 percent for the quarter.
Another holding, Hussmann International of St. Louis, agreed to be acquired during the quarter by Ingersoll-Rand for a premium of more than 100 percent, Mr. Rogers said. The company makes refrigeration equipment for supermarkets.
"It's an industry that no one cared about earlier in the year, when people were enamored of dot-com companies," he said. "And it missed a few quarters' earnings, which gave people an excuse to neglect it."
Mr. Rogers also made money on Littelfuse, the fund's only technology stock. The company, based in Des Plaines, Ill., is a leading provider of miniature electrical fuses for the automobile industry; it recently began making fuses for cell phones, personal digital assistants and other electronic devices. The stock rose 33.6 percent in the quarter, helped by improving earnings and the move into the new markets.
Looking ahead, Mr. Rogers sees more gains for small- and mid-capitalization value stocks, even after their second-quarter sprint. "So many boards of directors and C.E.O.'s are saying that the stock price of their company doesn't reflect the value of the business," he said, "and they're taking steps to realize that value."
 
Energy and Health Care Bets
Edward J. von der Linde took the No. 13 place for the quarter with his $456.4 million Lord Abbett Mid-Cap Value fund, with a gain of 8.4 percent. "As the market broadens out and diversifies away from large-cap growth stocks," said Mr. von der Linde, 40, "investors have gravitated to the types of stocks that we buy."
One big winner was EOG Resources in Houston, up 57.6 percent, helped by rising natural-gas prices. "Investors are realizing that gas producers haven't been able to keep pace with demand," he said. Enron is more leveraged to natural-gas price increases, he said, than any other domestic gas company.
He also made money in Caremark Rx, a Birmingham, Ala., company that organizes drug benefit programs for health insurers and H.M.O.'s. The stock rose 62.7 percent in the quarter. The drivers of its performance included the divestiture of its unprofitable physician practice management business and the settlement of litigation involving a convertible bond issue. "The company has annual revenue growth of 20 percent," Mr. von der Linde said, "so once the clouds were gone, the stock price began to take off."
St. Jude Medical, a St. Paul maker of heart valves and pacemakers, rose 77.8 percent. Investors began bidding up the price in anticipation of the Food and Drug Administration approval, expected by year-end, of a new, lightweight cardiac device, he said. Moreover, a new chief executive, Terry Shepherd, who took over in 1999, has smoothed out the company's problems meeting earnings expectations. "He is communicating with Wall Street and rebuilding the earnings numbers," he said, "which is generating confidence in the company as it moves toward its new product introduction."
Mr. von der Linde is optimistic about the stock market. "I wouldn't be surprised to see the rally in the old leaders continue for another few months," he said. "Investors suddenly seem to be taking notice of earnings. The next logical step is that they'll pay attention to valuations, which will broaden out leadership in the marketplace."
 
Profiting From Credit Risk
Buying companies with strong earnings growth while keeping a sharp eye on prices pushed the $200 million Wasatch Core Growth into the No. 7 place, up 10 percent. "In the last three quarters, we've seen the strongest earnings growth in our portfolio companies that we've ever seen," said J. B. Taylor, 28, co-manager of the fund with Sam Stewart, 55.
Mr. Taylor said the annual earnings growth of the companies in the fund has been nearly 30 percent, even though their trailing price-to-earnings multiples have been less than 20, which is relatively low. "With high-tech investments in vogue," he said, "a lot of great, solid companies are being passed over."
One of them, he said, is Rent-a-Center, in Plano, Tex., which rose 50 percent in the quarter. The company operates a "rent-to-own" business that leased electronics, appliances, furniture and other goods to consumers, including those without credit cards or checking accounts or with poor credit histories. Its earnings are growing at an annual rate of 25 percent, while shares trade at about 10 times its earnings for the previous 12 months.
Another company that caters to people with poor credit is Americredit, a consumer finance company in Fort Worth whose stock rose 4.3 percent. Americredit's customers "are good loan applicants now, because they've turned around or they're willing to pay premiums for their loans," Mr. Taylor said. Annual earnings growth exceeds 25 percent, and shares trade for about 13 times trailing 12-month earnings.
He also likes Express Scripts of St. Louis, a drug benefits management organization. Its cash flow has been growing 20 percent a year, Mr. Taylor said, but its share price was depressed because of the general downturn in many health care stocks. It rose 47.9 percent in the quarter.
Looking ahead, Mr. Taylor expects value stocks to dominate. "I see an increasing focus -- or return to focus -- on fundamentals, because so many investors have been burned by hyped stocks," he said. "In the last couple of months, Wall Street has been shifting its focus to earnings."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Stephanie Jones, Nathan Dudley

 BODY:
Stephanie Lynn Jones, a performance artist, and Nathan Sanford Dudley, a teacher, are to be married today at the First Presbyterian Church of Brooklyn. Donna Walker Kuhne, a minister of religious ceremonies for Soka Gakkai International USA, a Buddhist lay organization in Manhattan, will officiate. The Rev. Dr. Paul Smith, the pastor of First Presbyterian, will take part in the ceremony.
"You won't find too many weddings where there will be Buddhist chanting and gospel singing," said Mr. Dudley, who teaches history, media studies and economics at Arturo A. Schomburg Satellite Academy High School, an alternative public high school in the Bronx. 
 Ms. Jones, who will keep her name, graduated from Howard University and is a member of the Jones Twins, a collaboration with her identical twin sister, Suzanne. They have performed at the Franklin Furnace in Manhattan and the BAM Cafe in Brooklyn, doing a combination of stand-up comedy, music and autobiographical poetry, mostly about growing up in an African-American family in an otherwise all-white neighborhood in Michigan. The bride is also a candidate for a master's in musical-theater writing at New York University.
She is a daughter of Harriet S. Jones and Dr. Edward A. Jones Jr. of Grand Rapids, Mich. Her father retired as the head of pulmonary and critical care at St. Mary's Hospital in Grand Rapids. Her mother, also retired, was the director of nursing at the Riverside Correctional Facility in Ionia, Mich.
Mr. Dudley, who graduated from Yale University, is the son of Shirley Dudley and the Rev. Carl S. Dudley of Hartford. His father is the professor of church and community at the Hartford Seminary.
The couple were introduced by a mutual friend four years ago at Lucky Cheng's, a restaurant in downtown Manhattan. "I remember thinking, 'Wow, she's really tall and really beautiful, and look at that hair!' " Mr. Dudley said. "It was flowing and very striking."
Both describe their courtship as a learning experience. She says he taught her about South America, where he had lived and traveled extensively. And she introduced him to the downtown performance art scene. She also pushed him to quit his job in sports marketing and become a teacher, a longtime dream of his.
"In four years, we went through some rough moments, but the reason I'm really happy to be getting married to Stephanie is she really helped me grow spiritually," he said. "And, I want to be with someone who helps me grow." He proposed last New Year's Eve in Copacabana, Brazil. Throughout the day, he gave her several wrapped packages, each containing a gemstone ring. "She got a ring at 3 and a ring at 6 and a ring at 9 and a ring at midnight," he said. By the time he asked her to marry him, halfway through the millennial fireworks, she had rings on many fingers.
During their wedding, the couple plan to participate in a Japanese sake ceremony in which they drink from three different cups -- a small one representing the past, a medium-size one representing the present and a very large one symbolizing their future and everything they bring together.
"We're both very independent and have our own lives," the bride said, "but when we come together we bridge a lot of different people and communities and backgrounds. I think that's what marriage can be, a way of bringing together different worlds."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 15; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1630 words

HEADLINE: A Shipwreck Fails to Halt The Technology Tide

BYLINE: By DANNY HAKIM 

 BODY:
FOR Keith B. Brown, the top marketing executive for the $512 million Amerindo Technology fund, one of the most prominent stars in the firmament of technology offerings, the second quarter was, if not the best of times, then not too shabby. Investors deposited some $12 million into his fund during the quarter -- even amid the gyrations of the technology-driven Nasdaq composite index.
For his boss, the money manager Alberto W. Vilar, the second quarter was, by contrast, definitely disappointing: the fund lost a stomach-churning 26.7 percent for its investors. 
 The story played out much the same at other mutual funds with a sweet tooth for technology -- whether aggressive-growth funds that populate so many 401(k) plans, the scores of technology sector funds that run tens of billions of dollars or the dozens of Internet funds that have emerged virtually overnight over the last two and a half years. For these fund groups, the second quarter of 2000 turned out to be a tale of two executives.
While the honeymoon ended for techno-centric money managers, their marketers still seem to be enjoying a surprisingly easy sell. No matter that the average technology sector fund was down 11.2 percent in the quarter. Or that the Nasdaq composite index lost 13.3 percent. Or that Internet companies were forced into a round of belt-tightening, layoffs and, in the case of online retailers like Boo.com and Toysmart.com, into bankruptcy. Or even that institutional investors seemed to be displaying a distinct coolness to the sector.
Indefatigable individual investors kept buying technology funds. Cash flow into technology sector funds totaled $1.97 billion for April, the worst month of the technology sell-off, according to AMG Data Services, a research firm in Arcata, Calif.; investors sank an additional $1.09 billion into the funds in May. Although that is far below the record $10.97 billion that flowed into such funds in February, the month before the Nasdaq composite peaked, it is in line with what investors were putting into the funds in 1999.
Weekly figures compiled by AMG, which cover a smaller universe of funds, show the trend continuing in June: cash flows increased assets by an estimated 2 percent for the month.
In other words, individual investors have not turned tail from technology in the way that scores of institutional money managers and analysts had predicted they would in the event of a market correction.
"What surprises me about the numbers is that they've held up so well," said Robert Adler, president of AMG. "Investors haven't abandoned the market, and they haven't abandoned technology."
Contrast that with investors' behavior during another period of market extremes, the emerging-markets meltdown of 1998. According to AMG, outflows from emerging-markets stock funds totaled $4.05 billion for the year, 12.3 percent of total assets.
In a market environment that many people see as increasingly driven by individual investors, sentiment is crucial. Even as institutional investors -- pension and hedge funds in particular -- showed signs of retreat, individuals are charting their own direction. If their money continues to pour into technology and aggressive-growth funds, the shocks of April and May may well register as only a breather in the aging bull market.
Technology is still perceived, correctly or not, as the likeliest indicator of the market's future direction, if for no other reason than that more than one-third of the market capitalization of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is in technology stocks.
TECHNOLOGY, of course, takes several avenues into the American portfolio. Sector funds are only one, accounting for only about 2 percent of the $7 trillion mutual fund industry. Far more important are the nation's growth funds, the 800-pound gorillas of the industry that form the backbone of so many portfolios and retirement plans. During the meteoric run-up in technology stocks in 1998 and 1999, many growth funds became de facto technology funds.
Consider the $29.8 billion Fidelity Growth Company fund, the sixth most popular fund in defined-contribution retirement plans, according to a study by Pensions & Investments magazine. At the end of the first quarter, 53.2 percent of the fund's portfolio was in technology, more than double the fund's position a year earlier.
Likewise, the $28.2 billion Fidelity Blue Chip Growth fund, another top 10 retirement fund, was 43.4 percent invested in technology, up from 26.2 percent a year earlier.
Other popular growth funds were even more heavily weighted in the sector. At the end of the first quarter, the $31.8 billion Janus Twenty fund had nearly 60 percent of its portfolio in technology stocks.
Investors continue to strongly favor these growth funds over funds whose managers practice a value strategy, which emphasizes stocks that are priced at a discount relative to their intrinsic worth. Though the sales gap between value and growth narrowed in the second quarter, value-oriented funds still suffered net outflows of $6.6 billion in April and May, while growth funds took in $31 billion.
"The big picture is that people are still playing where the action has been," said Donald L. Cassidy, a senior research analyst at Lipper Inc. "They haven't panicked and they're not bargain hunting."
John Rekenthaler, research director of Morningstar Inc., added: "I don't think anybody's faith in aggressive-growth investing has been rocked, or fundamentally changed. Two months doesn't change people's belief system."
TO are investors showing foresight or folly in their continuing rush into technology? Or have investors just become used to buying on dips in volatile markets?
Avi Nachmany, president of the consulting and research firm Strategic Insight, called it "a renaissance of national optimism."
"The theory I have, why the commitment to new-economy investing transcends the price level, is that in the end, you look at your own personal experiences and ask, 'How has my life changed with the Internet?' " Mr. Nachmany said.
"There are many experiences that are fundamental to your well-being. The e-mail you get from your grandmother in Florida, the health advice you can get before you go to the doctor, the cheaper plane tickets. We're just in the beginning of these kinds of experiences. They will continue, regardless of the prices on the Nasdaq."
Mr. Vilar, whose fund remains one of the top 10 performers over the past three years despite last quarter's drubbing, agreed. "The trading in Internet stocks has been dominated by individuals. A lot of people who bought the AOL's, the eBays or Yahoos were the people who used them, the clients," he said.
It seems natural, of course, that if investors continue to buy technology stocks, technology stock prices will keep going up. Perhaps that was one reason the Nasdaq recovered in June, gaining 16.6 percent. But James Grant, editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer and known for his bearish views, says continued flows into technology will just make the day of reckoning that much more painful.
"The disappointment will be sharper," Mr. Grant said. "Artificial support under a fundamentally deteriorating market does not change the fundamentals. It deepens the ultimate disappointment. We do live in an age of technological miracles, but that does not change the cyclical nature of markets.
"Flows will help at the margins, but they can't perpetuate a trend indefinitely," Mr. Grant added. "They can't perpetuate technology indefinitely."
Even as individuals went in, institutional investors showed signs of pulling back. In May, $315.4 million flowed into the technology sector from small trades -- those of less than 10,000 shares -- according to Birinyi Associates, which tracks money flows in and out of the market; such small trades generally come from individual investors. But larger block trades from institutional investors took $502.4 million out of the sector in May; it was the fourth month of outflows in the last five.
That is not a total surprise. Institutional money managers are more prone to short-term portfolio shifts, because they are usually judged on a quarterly basis and adjust their allocations to conform with risk benchmarks.
Many experts say retail investors will play the tune for the current market. "I don't think investors will go on strike," Mr. Vilar said, "and the reluctant brides, the institutional investors, will be dragged to the altar."
IT is testimony to the resilience of technology fund investors that fund families have had the confidence to add technology offerings -- and be rewarded for doing so.
When Munder Capital Management, the company that runs the nation's largest Internet fund, Munder NetNet, started an international Internet fund, Munder International NetNet, on April 10, into the teeth of a collapsing market, investors still poured money in. By the end of May, despite losing money in the market, the fund had $367 million in assets.
And Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest mutual fund company, filed on June 30 with the Securities and Exchange Commission to start Fidelity Select Networking and Infrastructure.
To John C. Bogle, the retired founder of the Vanguard Group, America's continued infatuation with technology sector funds has not brought out the best in the mutual fund industry.
"The industry has had fads all through its history," Mr. Bogle said, citing bursts of interest for atomic energy funds in the 1950's and biotechnology funds in the early 1990's. Last quarter also saw the start of a genomics-only fund, tapping into enthusiasm over the mapping of the human genome.
"We used to sell what we made," Mr. Bogle said. "Now we make what sells."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
Converging Forces Have Kept Junk Bonds in a Slump

BYLINE: By KATE BERRY 

 BODY:
REMEMBER junk bonds?
They were the play stuff of Michael Milken, the mother's milk of the 1980's leveraged-buyout craze and eventually a symbol of that decade's decadence. 
 This year, junk bonds, also known as high-yield bonds, have posted some of their worst performance in almost a decade. A total of $7.92 billion flowed out of junk-bond funds from January through May this year, according to estimates by AMG Data Services, a fund tracker in Arcada, Calif. They returned a negative 0.7 percent on average last quarter and negative 1.4 percent over the last 12 months, according to Morningstar Inc. For the five years through June 30, the funds' average annualized return was just 6.6 percent, only half a percentage point more than long-term government bond funds. So far this year, investors who crave the extra yield of junk are actually worse off than they would have been in Treasuries.
"We almost feel like an ostracized asset class," said Peter Andersen, portfolio manager of the Conseco High Yield fund. The sector's returns have previously fallen two years in a row, he said, but "now we're entering our third year," he said.
"The investor is saying: 'I'd be better off putting my money somewhere else, like a C.D.,' " he added.
Problems arose for junk bonds in the Asian financial crisis of 1997 and 1998, as collapsing demand for shipping, paper and oil on the Pacific Rim pummeled those sectors and led to bond defaults. About the same time, junk was also becoming a crucial source of financing for risky technology, telecommunications and Internet companies; when the default rate began rising last year, investors fled junk bonds for stocks.
"Historically, the high-yield market really didn't finance technology companies," said Martin Fridson, senior high-yield strategist at Merrill Lynch. "Portfolio managers preferred companies that had established cash flows, so that recoveries were likely to be high if a company failed." By contrast, he said, there is little chance of recovering anything if a technology start-up with no revenue defaults.
MAKING matters worse, the Federal Reserve's efforts to head off inflation with increases in short-term interest rates have forced junk bonds to move in lock step to maintain an attractive spread.
The spread is the interest premium that investors demand to compensate for the greater risk of default or interruption of interest payments. When yields on investment grade bonds rise, junk-bond prices must fall to keep their yields at an appetizing altitude above them.
A year ago, a typical bond rated a notch or two below investment grade yielded 10.05 percent, or 426 basis points -- hundredths of a percentage point -- above the 5.79 percent to be had on a 10-year Treasury.
Since then, the Fed has pushed up short-term rates by 175 basis points, and junk-bond yields have had to follow, with that same typical bond's yield climbing to 11.81 percent. Longer-term government rates have not risen nearly as much as short-term rates, so the spread over 10-year Treasuries has widened considerably, to 577 basis points.
The implication of all that arithmetic is that junk-bond prices have fallen much more sharply than long-term government bond prices, as is evident in the performance of the funds that hold these bonds.
The risk of default on junk bonds has also worsened lately and is unusually high for good economic times. Today, 18 percent of junk bonds are considered distressed, meaning that default is a real possibility, Mr. Fridson said. That is the highest rate since January 1992, when 22.3 percent were called distressed.
A rising default rate is bad for bond prices, of course, so holders of junk bonds suffer, just as they do when spreads over Treasuries widen. But the allure for new buyers is increasing. "We think the high-yield market is attractively valued and that the high default rate is priced in," said Tom Price, co-portfolio manager of the Strong High-Yield Bond fund, which has returned 0.75 percent this year. "Those credits that have been struggling have been taken out to the woodshed, and if they default, it won't affect the overall rate."
One difficulty in analyzing the junk-bond outlook is in measuring the default rate with precision. Experts differ markedly on how to go about it. Moody's Investors Service includes the high-yield debt of developing nations, as well as convertible bonds, which are often below investment grade; it draws the bearish conclusion that defaults will worsen in coming months. But Sam DeRosa Farag, director of global high-yield portfolio strategy for Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette, argues that including those asset classes skews the default rates upward, and that investors should look at the domestic corporate high-yield market by itself. Donaldson's forecast is for falling default rates.
The issue is important for investors, because the junk-bond market is extremely cyclical, and the payoffs for those who call the bottom accurately can be big.
"There's been a quiet storm about this, and most indicators are that the worst isn't over," said David T. Hamilton, an analyst at Moody's risk-management services. "There is still a large proportion out there at risk of defaulting."
Moody's version of the default rate for speculative-grade issues was 5.4 percent for the 12 months ended May 31, more than three times the 1.5 percent in the same period three years earlier. By June 2001, Moody's expects the default rate for the trailing 12 months to peak at 7.5 percent.
"It's a pretty big deal," said Mr. Hamilton, who estimated that junk-bond downgrades outnumbered upgrades by three to one in the first quarter of this year. Defaults have been widely distributed among industry sectors, he said, though price-sensitive commodity and shipping companies were among the first to default on their junk debt in the first quarter of last year.
HISTORICALLY, Mr. DeRosa Farag said, returns and defaults have tended to reach peaks together. "There is this assumption that if default rates go up, the returns are going to be poor," he said. "But the historical pattern is that whenever defaults peak, this is when we have the best returns ever."
Junk bonds are now "attractively valued," he said, because the average issue is trading at less than 85 cents per dollar of face value, the lowest rate since July 1991. He attributed last year's surge in defaults to the 1997-98 Asian woes, conditions that have since eased; by his estimation, the default rate is now falling slightly.
Whatever view best describes the bigger picture, an important day-to-day issue bothers the junk-bond market: liquidity. Junk-bond funds have experienced cash outflows in 18 of the last 23 weeks, according to AMG. "Week after week of outflows from the funds is an insurmountable barrier" to a recovery in prices, said Mr. Fridson, at Merrill Lynch.
So there may be a glint of light in the figures for the last three weeks, which show the flow turning positive. Some hardy investors may be responding anew to the siren call of those fat yields.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 18; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1276 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
A Seven-Year Lesson in Investing: Expect the Unexpected, and More

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
IN a way, it has been a seven-year cold shower for the idea that an ordinary investor can do any better than the market, even with expert advice.
Because saving for retirement had become a crucial issue for Americans, The New York Times in 1993 asked five mutual-fund experts how they would invest a hypothetical nest egg of $50,000 for someone who planned to retire in 20 years or more. Each quarter since then, the five portfolios have been reviewed and fine-tuned and their performances compared in these pages. 
 With results from the second quarter of 2000, the exercise concludes, and the participants discuss what they, and investors, have learned along the way.
Three of the five participants tripled their money in the seven years ended June 30. The portfolio overseen by Eric M. Kobren, president of the Kobren Insight Group and editor of Fidelity Insight in Wellesley Mass., did the best over all, with a cumulative gain of 210.19 percent.
Close behind were the portfolio managed by Sheldon Jacobs, editor of the No-Load Fund Investor, in Irvington, N.Y., at 204.42 percent, and the portfolio of "socially responsible" funds assembled by Jack A. Brill, vice president of Natural Investment Services in San Diego, with a cumulative gain of 200.10 percent. .
In fourth place was a portfolio tended most recently by Russel Kinnel, editor of Morningstar Fund Investor in Chicago, at 146.97 percent. The fifth entry, managed by Harold R. Evensky, an investment adviser in Coral Gables, Fla., finished at 123.63 percent, according to Lipper Inc.
None of the portfolios, however, managed to outperform the market over the seven-year period. In retrospect, simply investing the whole stake in the Vanguard 500 Index fund and letting it ride would have done better, yielding a gain of 277.51 percent.
But overall performance was intended to be just one dimension of the exercise. Investors also had a chance to explore the thinking behind mutual fund management as the managers discussed strategies, styles and selections each quarter.
The object lessons were limited by the unexpected way the economy and the stock market have moved over the last seven years -- almost exclusively straight up. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index returned an annual average of 20.625 percent over the period; by contrast, stocks returned an annual average of 12.1 percent in the 65 years from 1926 to 1990, according to Ibbotson Associates in Chicago.
Big growth stocks dominated the stock market for much of the last seven years, lifting the performance of large-capitalization index funds and dragging down the returns of actively managed mutual funds, which tend to own smaller stocks. According to Morningstar Inc., just 21.4 percent of 990 actively managed domestic diversified equity funds in its database outperformed the S.& P. 500 over the period.
And the stock market has become more volatile in the 1990's, jumping or slumping abruptly -- as a whole or sector by sector -- in hard-to-predict ways. Fast-moving markets stumped the experts several times along the way.
Even so, stocks -- and funds that hold them -- are still the best way to meet long-term financial goals like retirement, the experts said, because they have always outperformed other investments over time.
"This exercise shows what a prudent, diversified mutual fund portfolio can return, given time and compounding," Mr. Kobren said. "It isn't necessary to dart in and out of the market, take foolish risks in the hopes of scoring a home run or get overly complicated by owning dozens of funds."
ALL five participating managers continue to recommend diversified fund portfolios, even though diversification was a far from optimal strategy during much of the last seven years. Carefully balancing big stocks with smaller ones, or American issues with international issues, turned out to be counterproductive because of the relentless market leadership of the big-growth stocks.
But there is no way of knowing if the same will be true in the future. "I still thoroughly believe in diversification for my own portfolio and for my clients," Mr. Kobren said, "because you can never know with certainty which sectors of the market will yield the biggest returns in the future."
Sticking to a diversified portfolio while market favorites come and go can be trying, the experts conceded. "Long-term investing is my mantra and my faith," Mr. Evensky said, "but I will admit that sometimes, long-term seems interminable."
The exercise also reaffirmed the power of the financial markets to confound expectations, said John Rekenthaler, now director of research at Morningstar, who started the portfolio that was later managed by Susan Dzuibinski and then Mr. Kinnel. He stuffed his initial portfolio with funds holding small stocks, value issues and overseas holdings; they had been superior performers over the long term but had slumped around the time the exercise began, and Mr. Rekenthaler thought they looked ripe for a rebound. As it turned out, though, none caught up with the large caps. "Expect to be surprised," he said.
Mr. Rekenthaler said his own results occasionally caught him off guard. "I remembered my good picks," he said, "and then forgot the fact that I had a big stake in emerging-markets funds as the whole sector tanked." The lesson: Track your investment results carefully, so you can learn from your decisions.
Mr. Brill's success ratifies an investing approach that seemed unorthodox and untried in 1993. "Socially responsible investing works," he said. "We have competitive returns because our screening identifies high-quality, well-managed companies." He added, "I never tried to outsmart the market or get in on hot sectors."
When he started, he said, there were only about 15 comprehensively screened social-investing funds, plus an additional 25 funds without the social label that qualified based on the types of stocks they held. Those 40 choices have grown to more than 150 today, he said.
Mr. Evensky recommends diversifying within asset classes. In that vein, he used to include in client portfolios three funds run by managers who choose large-cap growth stocks. In his hypothetical portfolio for this exercise, though, he felt he had room for only one, and chose the Yacktman Fund, whose subsequent performance was disappointing. These days, he prefers index funds for large-cap growth.
Mr. Evensky said he learned another lesson the hard way: not to make a big bet on a new fund idea. At the outset he allocated some of his portfolio to the Barr Rosenberg Market Neutral fund, which aims to neutralize market volatility through a mix of long and short sales. The idea fell flat; Mr. Evensky said the fund's managers told him its undoing was a run of extraordinary behavior by the stock market that no one could have anticipated. Now, Mr. Evensky said, he advises waiting for a few years until a new concept has proved itself in different market environments.
Realigning a portfolio periodically is wise, all five experts said, because strong performance in one area could lead to an ill-advised concentration of assets. The five hypothetical portfolios could be rebalanced quarterly, and generally were; once a year is probably often enough for most long-term investors.
Finally, don't be too quick to sell, Mr. Evensky said. After he researches a fund and buys its shares, he will stick with it through two years of bad times if performance seems likely to improve. But he dumps funds immediately when managers change their stripes, say by adding big overseas positions or by switching style from growth to value-oriented.

LENGTH: 1155 words

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2001 Mazda Tribute;
A Small S.U.V. Fills a Yawning Gap

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
IMAGINE being a man of the 90's and not having a single pair of khaki Dockers in your closet. Mazda found itself similarly naked in recent years; without a sport utility vehicle, it was missing out on the hottest auto fashion trend of the decade.
Mazda had, in fact, offered a sport utility, the Navajo, but dropped it in 1994. At a time when buyers were clamoring for four doors, the Navajo came with only two. In fact, it was essentially a two-door Ford Explorer. 
 Next month, Mazda will offer another S.U.V. with some Ford chromosomes, and this one may have a brighter future. The 2001 Tribute is similar in many respects to the new Ford Escape, with which it shares best-in-class potential in a booming segment of the car market.
Sales of small sport utilities, or "cute utes," have more than doubled in the last four years, and further growth is expected both in the United States and overseas. The Honda CR-V currently leads the pack in sales, followed by the Toyota RAV4.
While both Ford and Mazda recognized that they needed a small sport utility, they initially went their separate ways. Ford looked at borrowing the underlying body structure of the Contour and Mystique sedans; Mazda considered the platform of the MPV minivan and the 626 sedan.
But in the end, the two brands -- Mazda is controlled by the Ford Motor Company -- came together to develop an entirely new platform. While Mazda staff members took the lead role in development, and the two vehicles were largely designed and engineered in Japan, they are built at a Ford plant near Kansas City, Mo. Annual capacity is a formidable 250,000 Tributes and Escapes, with Mazda taking about 40,000 for the American market; it will also build a right-hand-drive version in Japan. Ford will split the rest of the production between the United States and 167 overseas markets.
Aimed at young singles, couples and small families on budgets, the Tribute, along with the Escape, leads the pack, at least for now, in size, refinement and practicality. The four-door, five-passenger Tribute is smaller than the former Navajo and current Explorer but almost a half-foot longer than the current Jeep Cherokee.
The Tribute and Escape are the first of a new wave of cute utes that are slightly larger and more substantial. The next RAV4, due this fall, is larger than the vehicle it replaces; the next-generation CR-V will bulk up; and even the Cherokee will grow when it is redesigned as a 2002 model.
The Escape looks a little like a shrunken Explorer, and it has the same outdoorsy style. Mazda aims for a more elegant appearance; in fashion terms, the Tribute is gray flannel trousers while the Escape, with its rugged-looking front fascia and plastic lower-body trim, would be blue jeans. None of the exterior pieces are shared except for the roof, windshield and side door glass.
It's the same story inside; the two vehicles share few visible components. The Tribute's dashboard and radio are similar to those in the Mazda MPV minivan; the Escape has black-on-white gauges like some Explorers. In keeping with its refined image, the Tribute test vehicle, a top-line ES, came with leather seats, a six-way power driver's seat and an excellent optional sound system: a 190-watt, 7-speaker radio with cassette player and six-CD changer.
Despite their compact dimensions, the Tribute and Escape are roomy. Ford and Mazda say the pair have the most space in their class. My passengers certainly had plenty of headroom and sufficient legroom.
Though it's no Expedition, the Tribute can carry a respectable amount of cargo; there is 33 cubic feet behind the back seat, which folds for more space. The cargo bay is tall enough to carry bicycles upright. The large rear opening and low vehicle height make it easy to load bulky items, like the fully assembled computer desk I hauled in the Tribute. The temporary spare tire is hidden beneath the cargo floor.
The Tribute has a new one-piece unit body, a carlike design with several advantages over S.U.V.'s built with truck components. Getting in and out is easy, thanks to a low floor height, generous door openings and beefy grab handles. Since the Tribute weighs less than truck-style utilities, its handling and fuel economy are more like a car's. The base DX model has a 2-liter, 130-horsepower 4-cylinder that comes only with a five-speed stick shift. With front-wheel drive, it has a fuel-economy rating of up to 28 miles per gallon.
The ES and the medium-trim LX have a 3-liter, 200-horsepower V-6, which is paired only with a four-speed automatic transmission. This engine, one of the few V-6's offered in small S.U.V.'s, achieves 18 m.p.g. in the city and 24 on the highway, with or without four-wheel drive. With the optional towing package, the V-6 can haul up to 3,500 pounds.
I didn't tow anything, but the gold ES was plenty quick accelerating from stoplights and passing on the freeway. Equipped with a four-wheel independent suspension -- most S.U.V.'s still use relatively unsophisticated live axles -- the Tribute maneuvers like a car, and it rides smoothly. It hugged corners competently at higher speeds than I expected, yet kept passengers upright and comfortable without much body roll. But more sound-deadening material would have been nice; a trucklike abundance of road noise came through the floor.
Aside from its styling and interior appointments, the Tribute rides and handles slightly differently than the Escape. Mazda advertising has positioned the Tribute as a sport utility with a sports car soul. Commercials show a Tribute driving a slalom course around black Miata roadsters. The Tribute does have slightly tighter handling and steering than the Escape, but the differences are quite subtle.
All three trim levels can be equipped with a new on-demand four-wheel-drive system, giving the Tribute more grip on muddy, rutted roads or snowy pavement. In normal conditions, the vehicle operates in front-wheel drive. When the system detects a loss of traction, the system hydraulically and seamlessly transfers up to half of the power to the rear wheels. A dashboard switch allows the driver to lock the system in four-wheel drive on slippery roads. There is not a low gear range for extreme conditions.
The Tribute's safety features include standard dual front air bags and new child-seat latches that will be required by law next year. Side air bags and antilock brakes come as a $495 option package.
The Tribute starts at $17,520, about $600 less than the base Escape. The LX starts at $19,655, about $1,680 less than the comparable Escape. Fully equipped models run around $25,000. Mazda has kept its prices below Ford's in an attempt to lure potential buyers into showrooms that had been devoid of sport utilities. Now Mazda has the goods, they're stylish and fit nicely, and they're priced to sell.
 
INSIDE TRACK: A cute ute with substance as well as style.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Mexico Has Voted. Its Economy Hasn't.

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
WHEN a political party that has been in control for many decades is beaten at the polls, it's a good sign that voters are clamoring for sweeping change -- and an indication of how much things already have changed.
That is the case in Mexico, where last week Vicente Fox Quesada became president-elect, ending 71 years of rule by the Institutional Revolutionary Party, known as the PRI. Though Mexico is in far better shape than it was a decade ago, let alone two decades ago, it is still a developing country. 
 Investors charged in after the vote, pushing the Bolsa index up more than 6 percent for the week.
Pedro-Pablo Kuczynski, president of the Latin America Enterprise fund, a Miami-based private equity fund with about $450 million under management, took time last week to talk about the effect of the election on Mexico's market outlook. Following are excerpts from the conversation:
 
Q. Isn't the economy that Mr. Fox will inherit from the outgoing president, Ernesto Zedillo, in pretty good shape?
 
A. Zedillo is leaving him in a good position in terms of foreign trade. Exports are running between $160 billion and $170 billion annually, due mostly to increased trade due to the North American Free Trade Agreement and not to the recent rise in oil prices. As recently as 1995, following the peso crisis, Mexican exports were about $80 billion a year. External debt has evaporated as a macroeconomic issue; it is about $160 billion today, roughly what it was in 1995. And the budget deficit is totally under control. However, unemployment is a problem.
 
Q. Is the new president likely to take steps to push down the unemployment rate?
 
A. Due to a lack of flexibility in the budget, he doesn't have much room to maneuver. After paying for a number of fixed costs, like debt service and education expenditures, only 7 percent to 10 percent of the budget is left over for discretionary spending.
 
Q. What sorts of problems does Mr. Fox want, or need, to tackle?
 
A. So far he has talked about focusing on corruption and on drugs, which are important. He faces big problems in dealing with safety issues, especially in Mexico City. And the banking system is still decimated. In Mexico, credit is scarce for midsize companies and not there at all for little companies. He also faces challenges from the unions, which are controlled by the PRI.
 
Q. What are the prospects for privatization?
 
A. The biggest opportunity is in privatizing the electric utility industry, which is a $70 billion to $80 billion business, half in power generation and half in distribution. The major impediment to change there is the union. It is totally opposed to privatization.
 
Q. Because of his years at Coca-Cola and his positive attitude about foreign investment, doesn't Mr. Fox run the risk of criticism from Mexican nationalists?
 
A. What Fox has to do, and what he talked about in his campaign, is show he has a high priority for social welfare programs. That means better schools, security for people, rural investment and roads. If he does that, the private investment from the U.S. and elsewhere will be more digestible to the people. There has to be a social dimension to his program. But he won't have the money to pay for it unless he privatizes the electric utility industry.
 
Q. Your fund invests in privately held companies. How is the money divided?
 
A. About 10 percent is in manufacturing; between 40 percent and 50 percent is in various types of services, from funeral homes to telephones; and the balance is in an assortment of things, from financial companies to Internet companies. Roughly 25 percent of the money in the fund is invested in Mexico.
 
Q. Individual investors who have bet on Mexico and Latin America have not been well rewarded for some time. Is there reason to expect higher returns?
 
A. Currently, valuations in Latin America are reasonably low relative to prospective earnings growth, and that applies with some force in Mexico. With its finances in pretty good shape, if Mexico grows 5.5 percent in 2000, its market should do pretty well over the balance of the year. For example, Cemex and Telefonos de Mexico will respond to faster growth in Mexico.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Credit Comes At a Price; The Criticism Is Free

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THIS is a tale of three central banks. All face tough choices about whether to raise interest rates, and the strategies they pursue over the remainder of this year could have a big effect on the global economic outlook.
* After pushing its benchmark lending rate down to just a notch above zero in an effort to resuscitate the Japanese economy, the Bank of Japan is hinting that it will soon tighten monetary policy, even though many analysts think that deflation is still a greater risk than inflation, and that the financial system needs more money and credit, not less. 
 * With an economic upswing under way across Europe, the European Central Bank is likely to continue raising rates this year. But the 11 nations sharing a common monetary policy are running at different economic speeds and are not, at the moment, good candidates for a one-size-fits-all interest rate prescription.
* In the United States, six interest rate increases over the last year are beginning to have their intended effect, as illustrated by Friday's report from the Labor Department showing a slowdown in the rate of job creation. But there is considerable uncertainty and debate within the Federal Reserve about how much more tightening, if any, will be necessary to squelch inflation pressures without putting the long expansion at risk.
Of the three major central banks, the Bank of Japan faces the most dire situation and the most second-guessing.
Masaru Hayami, the central bank's governor, has signaled that he would like to bring to an end what he considers an emergency period of exceptionally low interest rates.
Mr. Hayami's rationale seems to be twofold: that higher rates would force Japanese industry to stop relying on cheap money for survival and get on with the painful business of restructuring itself, and that moving rates up now, when the economy is showing tentative signs of life, would give the Bank of Japan the ability to cut them again if the economy goes back into a swoon.
But his approach is viewed skeptically even in his own government's finance ministry. And many economists say Japan's problems are not linked so much to interest rates -- the cost of money -- but rather to a lack of available money and credit at any price.
According to Carl B. Weinberg, chief economist at High Frequency Economics, a consulting firm in Valhalla, N.Y., bank credit in Japan contracted 4.7 percent in the 12 months ended in May, reflecting the dead weight of bad loans held by lenders and the continued decline in the value of assets that borrowers can use as collateral.
Rather than raising rates, he and other critics say, the Bank of Japan would do better to grease the wheels of the financial system, perhaps by buying bad loans from banks, to spur new lending and get the economy humming again.
In Europe, the head of the new central bank, Wim Duisenberg, is facing the first big test of his institution's ability to weather the economic and political strains inherent in establishing a transnational institution to perform a function that has always been closely linked to national sovereignty.
In one group of European countries, including Ireland, Spain and Finland, inflation is creeping up, putting pressure on the central bank to raise rates. But in another group, including Germany and France, the economic and political heavyweights at the European Union's core, inflation is low and unemployment remains stubbornly high, a combination that argues for stable or even lower rates.
"This development raises the prospect that, over the next year, monetary policy will be trapped between the tightening needs of overheating countries and resistance to higher real rates from low-inflation ones," economists at Salomon Smith Barney said in a recent report.
THE question in the United States is whether the slowdown in growth is enough to keep inflation under wraps.
At the Fed's meeting in May, staff economists presented a forecast showing that growth would slow this year to around 3.5 percent, from a 5.5 percent rate in the first quarter. But the same forecast projected that core price inflation -- which excludes volatile food and energy prices -- would "rise noticeably" this year.
So both inflation hawks and doves at the Fed have plenty of ammunition as they debate whether to raise rates again. It may be some consolation to Alan Greenspan as he tries to sort it all out that his fellow central bankers around the world are not having it any easier.

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF;
Brewing Beer And Problems

BYLINE: By ALECIA SWASY; Alecia Swasy is assistant managing editor for business at The St. Petersburg Times. She is the author of "Changing Focus: Kodak and the Battle to Save a Great American Company."

 BODY:
IN scanning the bookstore shelves, I have long hoped to find a series of books called "Corporate Stupidity." This multivolume set would make the collected works of James Michener look like Cliff Notes, considering the number of business blunders that are committed daily.
My personal favorites are the sins of chief executives who ignore their managers or the workers on the factory floor. Or the debacles that follow when they tune out the most important audience -- their customers. There is no shortage of material from every industry, ranging from the Edsel to New Coke. 
 It's a familiar scene: company fouls up, chief executive rants when the headlines chronicle the foul-ups, six-figure consultants are hired to figure out who fouled up. If only these consultants would suggest that C.E.O.'s create a new office called the C.S.O. -- common sense officer. Its job description: the lone voice in a company who can tell the boss he might be wrong.
A recent example of a hefty dose of arrogance and the absence of anyone willing to apply some common sense comes from the Coors family, which started brewing beer in Golden, Colo., in 1876 and continued until the younger generations nearly ran the company into the ground by the early 1990's.
In "Citizen Coors: An American Dynasty" (William Morrow, $27), Dan Baum wisely singles the family out. Mr. Baum builds a strong narrative from the tale of how this big dysfunctional family made a lot of cold beer and money that ultimately financed conservative causes via the Republican Party and the Heritage Foundation. There is no lack of drama, starting with the patriarch Adolph Coors, who committed suicide by jumping out of a hotel window.
Succeeding generations had their problems, too, as Mr. Baum describes them. Pity the patriarch's grandchildren, who must have dreaded Sundays. Adolph Jr. kept notes on his children's weekly misdeeds, then spanked them each Sunday. One of the offspring also committed suicide, also by jumping out of a hotel window.
But this book also gives corporate America a primer, as valuable as any business school case study, on how not to run a company.
For starters, Mr. Baum documents thoroughly how Coors abused workers. Sure, paternalism is sweet when it's served up as free lagers during break time in the brewery. But no amount of alcohol takes the sting out of being subjected to lie-detector tests, used to screen out what the book describes as "thieves, radicals and homosexuals." Some workers were asked if they had sex the previous night. At times, employees were forced to see psychologists. Brewery workers regarded themselves, in the words of one, as "overworked animals."
Equal rights took a while to catch up with Coors. Women lacked a bathroom in the brewery. There was one in the office for secretaries, but women working in the brewery were docked for time off if they left the plant to use it. One Coors family member said that a woman's place was "in the beauty parlor."
Not that management was spared from the whims of the Coors clan. When Bill Coors, in the third generation, caught the transcendental meditation bug, all executives were ordered to take classes in the practice.
The Coors company, meanwhile, showed an amazing lack of knowledge about behemoth competitors like Anheuser-Busch. Members of the Busch family in St. Louis knew that their company was driven by the relentless marketing of Budweiser and other brands. But Coors didn't get it -- and balked at spending money on ads.
Indeed, marketing executives had short tenures at Coors. Some did manage a few hit ads, like one using "Elvira, Mistress of the Dark" to sell beer at Halloween. But Jeff Coors, a born-again Christian and member of the fourth generation, ordered an end to Elvira's selling of Coors because he considered her satanic.
Other ads were ludicrous. Senior family members once ordered the company's advertising agency to make a commercial featuring Eva Gabor, a family friend who was generous to the Republican Party. Men in the focus group, viewing the aging actress, yelled: "What's she doing selling beer?"
Even product introductions lagged behind the competition. Coors was so behind the curve that it introduced a light beer three years after Miller Lite hit the shelves. The company botched other product introductions because it failed to do market research.
"Citizen Coors" clinches the story by telling how the blunders caught up with the company. It went public in 1975 at $32 a share. By 1978, investors lost half their money. Earnings were once 30 cents for every dollar of beer sold, but slipped to just a penny by 1990. Boycotts by unions and even barley farmers hurt its image and sales. Market share wilted everywhere, even in its home state of Colorado.
What did the Coors brothers do about it? They continued to focus on pushing conservative political causes in Washington. And they bought themselves a Lear jet.
What did the board members do? They dozed off during presentations on the demographics of beer drinkers. One of the best lines of the book likens a Coors board meeting to an Idi Amin cabinet meeting: nobody objects.
Senior management did seem to pay attention to one event -- the pollution of its famous Rocky Mountain spring waters. Clear Creek was the primary reason that Adolph Coors built his brewery in Golden. Trouble was, his brewery was responsible for contamination of the once-pristine waters. The book spends far too few pages on this environmental mess. Coors knew for nine years during the 1980's that it was destroying the spring water, but covered it up, according to Mr. Baum.
To help ease the bad public relations, Peter Coors, also in the fourth generation, coughed up a $30 million check for a baseball stadium in Denver. For the money, the team would play at, you guessed it, Coors Field.
The book's final pages chronicle the Coors men stepping aside and hiring an outsider to run the company. More than a century after the brewery was founded, the arrogance and indifference had caught up with them. Mr. Baum says they would have made more money by closing the place in the early 1980's and putting their money in a passbook account.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

Chart: "Business Best Sellers "
HARDCOVER
 
1: WHO MOVED MY CHEESE? by Spencer Johnson (Putnam, $19.95). Techniques for dealing with change in the workplace.
 
2: TEN THINGS I WISH I'D KNOWN -- BEFORE I WENT OUT INTO THE REAL WORLD by Maria Shriver (Warner, $19.95). Lessons about life -- private and corporate -- from the anchorwoman.
 
3: THE MILLIONAIRE MIND by Thomas J. Stanley (Andrews McMeel, $26.95). An analysis of the people who make up America's financial elite.
 
4: BOBOS IN PARADISE by David Brooks (Simon & Schuster, $25). An examination of the rise of the bourgeois bohemians who constitute the new upper class.
 
5: CHANGEWAVE INVESTING by Tobin Smith (Bard Press, $24.95). A guide to picking stocks.
 
6: THE TIPPING POINT by Malcolm Gladwell (Little, Brown, $24.95). How and why certain products and ideas become fads.
 
7: PLAY LIKE A MAN, WIN LIKE A WOMAN by Gail Evans (Broadway, $23.95). What men know about corporate success that women need to learn.
 
8: LIVING ON THE FAULT LINE by Geoffrey A. Moore (HarperBusiness, $27). How traditional companies can survive in the Internet-based economy.
 
9: E BOYS by Randall E. Stross (Crown Business, $25.95). The story of the venture capitalists behind several billion-dollar Internet start-ups.
 
10: FIRST, BREAK ALL THE RULES: What The World's Greatest Managers Do Differently by Marcus Buckingham and Curt Coffman (Simon & Schuster, $25). Two consultants for the Gallup organization offer conclusions about what makes for great managers; based on 80,000 interviews.

HEADLINE: The Nation: Respecting Elders;
A Drug Plan Sounds Great, but Who Gets to Set Prices?

BYLINE: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN this election season, helping the elderly pay for their pills is a political no-brainer: everybody's for it. The fight is over how to do it. Republicans, not surprisingly, want private insurers to run any prescription drug benefits plan. Democrats, not surprisingly, want the government in control.
But that classic liberal-conservative clash masks the real issue: how much drugs will cost, and who will set their prices. 
 Perhaps no issue touches as many lives as the cost of medication, which is why it is consuming the political landscape this year. Last week, Vice President Al Gore attacked drug manufacturers, accusing them of price gouging. The week before, the House of Representatives approved a Republican-backed plan to give subsidies to insurance companies that offer prescription coverage, a concept favored by the drug makers.
The furor is justified, economists and policymakers say. "It's the part of the budget that is breaking the bank," said Dr. David A. Kessler, who ran the Food and Drug Administration before becoming dean of the Yale University School of Medicine. "Ask any hospital administrator, ask any H.M.O. Prescription drug prices is the one sector that is out of control."
Prescription drugs are now the fastest-growing part of the nation's health care bill. That is not so much because manufacturers are raising prices for existing drugs, but because patients are switching to newly approved medicines that cost more, and more prescriptions are being written than ever before.
In 1998, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation, Americans spent $91 billion on prescription drugs; the total is expected to reach $243 billion in 2008. The elderly bear a disproportionate burden: they account for 13 percent of the population but more than a third of drug expenditures.
Yet any effort to bring down costs is fraught with unanswered questions. To begin with, drug makers dance around the question of how they set prices. The official explanation is that the cost of medicine is justified by the high cost of research and development, which the industry puts at $500 million per drug, a figure some say is inflated.
What's more, there is no one set price for drugs. Consumer advocates often complain that Americans pay higher prices for their prescriptions than patients anywhere else in the world. And that is true -- if the patient pays the retail price, out of pocket. (That is the case for nearly one-third of the elderly, who have health insurance through Medicare but lack drug coverage.)
BUT the truth is, few people buy retail in this business. Most have insurance, and their health care providers typically negotiate discounts with the drug manufacturers. The size of these discounts, however, is a well-kept secret. The drug makers would like to keep it that way, which is one reason they are working hard to defeat any legislation that would put Medicare in charge of running a benefits plan.
"They are totally paranoid about price controls, but I think the thing that scares them more than anything is public disclosure of what people actually pay for prescriptions," said Bruce C. Vladeck, a former administrator of the Health Care Financing Administration, which runs Medicare. "They go to enormous lengths not just to keep that information confidential, but to actually obscure it."
A government-run drug benefit plan would change that. If private insurers offered drug benefits, the pharmaceutical industry could continue to negotiate behind closed doors. But Medicare would publish what it pays for drugs, and the private sector would undoubtedly demand similar discounts. And with every senior citizen in the nation enrolled in the same Medicare drug plan, the government's bargaining clout would increase exponentially.
"Medicare is the big gorilla," said Uwe Reinhardt, a health care economist at Princeton University. "But there is another fear: If you go to bed with a gorilla, and the gorilla shifts, you get squashed."
The shifting gorilla, of course, is Congress; the drug industry fears lawmakers will agree to pay for a Medicare prescription drugs benefit now, in times of surplus, and then cut back on reimbursements when money grows scarce.
That is precisely what has happened with the 35-year-old Medicare program itself. In its early years, said Drew Altman, president of the Kaiser Family Foundation, Medicare became "the largest single cash cow for doctors and hospitals around the country." But amid concerns over rising health care costs in the 1990's, Medicare lowered reimbursements, and now health providers are struggling.
Some experts, including Dr. Altman, argue that even with the cutbacks, doctors are better off with Medicare than without it. Dr. Reinhardt calculates the same would be true of the drug makers: a Medicare benefits plan might bring lower prices, he says, but the industry would make up the difference in volume.
But Alan F. Holmer, president of the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, disagrees. The drug industry consistently ranks as the most profitable on the list of Fortune 500 companies. Yet Mr. Holmer warns that lower prices would "put biomedical innovation at risk" by cutting into profits that the drug makers need to plow back into research.
"The industry could be profoundly different," said Mr. Holmer, whose two children have cystic fibrosis and have benefited from new treatments for that disease, he said. "One of the most frightening things is that if we were to proceed down that path, we would never really know which cure we were denied."
In one sense, Mr. Holmer's industry is a victim of its own success. "We have the best medical armamentarium in the world," said Dr. Kessler, the former F.D.A. commissioner. "But what good is it if people can't afford it?"
BECAUSE other countries have drug price controls, the pharmaceutical industry earns most of its profits, and conducts most of its basic research, in the United States. "We Americans fund the bulk of the research for the rest of the world," Dr. Reinhardt said, "so everyone else can mooch."
And because prices are higher here, Americans use their prescription drugs sparingly. Even so, drugs have become an essential part of American medical care. "I have some patients that are choosing between food and travel to see their children or grandchildren" or taking pills, said Dr. Diane E. Meier, a geriatrician at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York City.
Many experts are doubtful that Congress will move on drug prices this year. While the House Republican bill calls for private insurers to offer drug benefits, the insurers themselves are against it; they say that even with government subsidies, the plans would be too costly to offer. At the same time, Republicans and Democrats may not be able to bridge their ideological gap. In the meantime, says Dr. Vladeck, the industry will continue to draw its line in the sand. "The United States is their safety valve in terms of profits," he said. "I think that adds intensity to their feelings about this. They are running out of places where they can charge whatever they want."

Attributing the explosion to price gouging on the part of drug companies is too simplistic, however. Demographic shifts and changes in drug approval policy are also responsible.
 
More expensive drugs, more doctors and more approvals
 
It is true that the retail price of drugs has grown steadily over the years. But the increase in expenditures is also driven by an accelerated approval process for new drugs, as well as an increase in the number of doctors who can prescribe them.

HEADLINE: Powering a Hot City

 BODY:
New York's summer nightmare begins on a steamy evening when a few million people suddenly switch on their air-conditioners, in effect blowing the fuse for a wired city. The dimming of lights on the Upper East Side last month was a reminder that it can happen, as it did last July when northern Manhattan suffered a 19-hour blackout. Consolidated Edison has said the city's newly fortified neighborhood power grids are ready for soaring temperatures and power use. Still, there are reasons to worry about how the nationwide experiment with utility deregulation will affect the reliability and cost of power in a city that thrives on electricity.
Deregulation, which promised more competition, more alternative power sources and lower costs to consumers, appears to be playing transitional tricks in a few areas around the country, including New York City. As part of its restructuring in the last few years, Con Edison has been shedding power plants and moving steadily into the business of distributing power. That means Con Ed must now turn around and buy power to distribute, a cost that it then passes along to its customers. 
 Energy prices this summer are rising for several reasons, including higher costs for the fuel used to generate power. The inevitable spike in temperatures will also bring a spike in demand for electricity. Then there is the city's booming economy, which encourages people to buy more gadgets and appliances -- which are simply plucked out of their boxes and plugged into the walls without advance notice to the utility. Under deregulation, competition from other power sources was supposed to provide price relief. But alternative power sources are not readily available for most city residents.
New York's City Council will begin hearings next week on concerns that Con Ed's 2.8 million city customers could see energy costs go up 30 percent this summer, an increase Mayor Rudolph Giuliani labeled "outrageous." The mayor has advised the company to cut into its sizable profits rather than raise rates. On a larger scale, the hearings should determine whether the new Con Ed has begun favoring its shareholders over its city customers.
Most experts suggest that the power squeeze in the city will continue for several summers, until new plants are built or alternative power sources become available. Gov. George Pataki, the Legislature and the state's Public Service Commission should recognize that deregulation is still in its early stages and needs more oversight if such a daring experiment is to succeed in providing reliable, environmentally sound and affordable wattage, especially in an overheated New York City.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Banishing the Dickensian Factor

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
IN this era when the consumer is king, many Americans are displaying noblesse oblige toward the millions of foreign workers who make the goods that flood store shelves. High school students have demonstrated at Disney's Mickey-filled emporiums over the company's use of low-wage factories in China and Haiti. Nuns concerned about child labor have distributed leaflets outside Gap stores. At Duke and Georgetown, students have staged sit-ins to protest conditions at factories producing apparel carrying their college logos. And everyone seems to beat up on Nike.
For years, these anti-sweatshop protests accomplished next to nothing. Many manufacturers responded by simply saying they did not control the overseas factories that they contracted with. Some embarrassed designers adopted codes of conduct, which were often ignored abroad. Before monitors visited, factory owners hid their under-aged workers and ordered employees to say they worked 40-hour weeks, not the more typical 75 hours. 
 But as the anti-sweatshop movement continues to grow -- and grow louder -- manufacturers have recently taken steps that just might improve working conditions around the world. Companies see that many consumers want to know that their clothing was not made under Dickensian conditions. So for the first time, industry giants have joined an ambitious effort, the Fair Labor Association, that has adopted a code and called for large-scale overseas monitoring that begins this fall.
Nike, Reebok, Liz Claiborne, Philips Van Heusen and other manufacturers have joined the association, a White House-backed program that promises to inspect hundreds of factories yearly. Currently only a factory or two is monitored each month. The association's leaders say this latest effort, well financed and international, should make a difference. Monitors, ranging from accounting firms to union-friendly Jesuit advocates, will visit factories to check that there is no child labor, that managers do not sexually harass workers and that no one works more than 60 hours a week.
The days of companies adopting a see-no-evil stance are over, said Sam Brown, executive director of the association, which includes several consumer and human rights groups. "This effort says for the first time, 'You must know, you have to know about conditions in every single factory, and you have to bear responsibility,' " Mr. Brown said.
The association's plans call for monitoring 30 percent of its members' 4,000 factories over the next three years, with 5 to 10 percent of each company's factories being monitored each subsequent year. Some critics say the percentage is too small to uncover every problem, but association members say monitoring, and requiring that complaints about conditions be investigated, will greatly help.
Many critics say the association and other monitoring efforts will do little to improve the lives of third-world workers. They fear that corporations may hide the monitors' findings from the public, and that the accounting firms doing the monitoring will not dig hard enough to find problems.
"I think the Fair Labor Association is just window-dressing," said Charles Kernaghan, director of the National Labor Committee, a labor rights group. "You don't have full disclosure of what's found, and it doesn't require that factories pay a living wage. And it allows companies to produce in China, a country that prohibits independent trade unions."
Other monitoring efforts have sprouted because some groups think the association is too lenient toward manufacturers while others believe it is too harsh. Social Accountability International, an offshoot of the nonprofit Council on Economic Priorities, has persuaded Toys "R" Us, Avon Products and Eddie Bauer to push their manufacturers to comply with minimum labor standards developed by a group of companies, unions and nongovernment organizations. Students from 56 universities including Brown and Cornell recently formed the Workers Rights Consortium to work with nongovernment organizations overseas to review conditions at factories making T-shirts and other apparel carrying college logos. And the industry's main trade group, the American Apparel Manufacturers Association, has also adopted a code of conduct. Stung by criticisms, Nike, the Gap and others have hired their own monitors, and many critics say these companies have improved labor practices.
"None of the programs have achieved critical mass yet," said Elliot Schrage, a Columbia University Business School professor who advises companies on how to improve factory conditions, "but the principle that the conditions under which products are made is a legitimate concern for consumers is now well established."
The word sweatshop has long been used to describe factories with low wages and deplorable conditions, but whether a particular factory is a sweatshop is often in the eye of the beholder. An American or European may quickly conclude that a Chinese or Vietnamese factory paying workers $2 a day is a sweatshop. But the young women working there often say they earn far more than at other local factories or in the farm villages they left behind.
"The question is to make sure these young people, mostly women a long way from home, are not abused," Mr. Brown said. "Even if the situation is better than where they were, that doesn't mean there shouldn't be minimal standards of decency on how you treat people."
THE nation's largest apparel union, the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees, argues that free trade has encouraged American companies to move factories to countries with the lowest wages and worst conditions. Hoping to slow this exodus and help foreign workers, the union wants the World Trade Organization to allow trade sanctions against countries that perpetuate sweatshops by not enforcing their laws on minimum wage and overtime. But the W.T.O. has rejected such proposals.
Monitoring, Mr. Brown said, is the best alternative for improving factory conditions. "It is the way to think about how you make free trade into fair trade," he said. "It's a way to ensure that the goods are produced under conditions that don't shock the conscience."
