Mertz, the library contains more than 1.25 million items covering the 12th through the 20th centuries. Since it was established in 1899, the library has been collecting books, journals, botanical art and illustrations. The collection includes illustrations of plants made by 17th- and 18th-century botanists who accompanied early European explorers of the Americas. It also includes the notebooks and correspondence of some of the 19th and 20th century's leading botanists. Although none of the library's collection circulates, its books and archives are consulted by scholars from around the world and can be used by the public from noon to 6 p.m. Tuesday through Thursday and from noon to 5 p.m. Friday and Saturday.

HEADLINE: Egyptian's Arrest Seen as Penalty for Criticism

BYLINE: By SUSAN SACHS 

DATELINE: CAIRO, July 9

 BODY:
The recent arrest of a prominent sociologist on suspicion of "defaming" Egypt has alarmed human rights advocates around the region who say it reflects a policy among Arab leaders toward political criticism that can best be described as killing the messenger.
"The government has convinced the people that Egypt and the government are one and the same thing," said Gasser Abdel Razik, secretary general of a legal aid center in Cairo. "If someone criticizes the government, then it is an insult against Egypt. If any crisis erupts, they do not solve it but they punish the one who reported it." 
 The sociologist, Saad Eddin Ibrahim, who has been in an Egyptian prison since June 30, has taught at the American University in Cairo for 25 years. He founded the Ibn Khaldoun Center for Developmental Studies, a private group in Cairo that includes two government ministers on its board and conducts research on democracy, civil society and minority rights.
He recently wrote an article in a Saudi magazine, Al Majala, that satirized the efforts by some Arab leaders to groom their sons for succession. Among others, Dr. Ibrahim mentioned President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. He also has written frequently on the status of the Christian minority in Egypt, where the subject of religious tensions is taboo.
Dr. Ibrahim has been held since security agents began interrogating him on June 30 about a documentary his center produced to instruct Egyptians about their voting rights and encourage them to take part in a parliamentary election scheduled for November.
Hafez Abu Saada, who is one of Dr. Ibrahim's lawyers, said investigators had accused him of defaming Egypt because the film refers to complaints about fraud filed after past elections.
Dr. Ibrahim has not been charged with a crime but is being held for 15 days for questioning. Under Egyptian law, detention without charge can be extended up to 45 days.
Officials of the United States Embassy in Cairo who visited Dr. Ibrahim said he had reassured them he was not being mistreated. The American ambassador, Daniel Kurzer, has expressed concern about the arrest to Egypt's prime minister, according to an embassy spokesman.
"We hope that his detention is not inspired by a desire to silence a voice advocating freedom of expression and democracy," the spokesman said.
Dr. Ibrahim, a former adviser to the Egyptian government who holds dual Egyptian and American citizenship, earned a Ph.D. from the University of Washington and has written or edited 30 books in English and Arabic. He has been a frequent guest at international conferences on Arab political life.
Dr. Ibrahim's arrest has worried human rights groups and advocates around the Arab Middle East, where nongovernmental organizations and journalists who criticize their governments are routinely harassed or imprisoned.
"Saad Eddin Ibrahim's arrest reminds us that one of the leading sources of instability and political-economic distortion in the Arab world is the unchecked use of state power, combined with the state's whimsical ability to use the rule of law for its own political ends," Rami G. Khouri, a political analyst, wrote in The Jordan Times last week.
Despite apparent progress in a handful of countries that declare themselves to be democracies, like Egypt and Jordan, independent organizations have found themselves fighting for their lives, he added.
Egypt, like its neighbors, tightly regulates nongovernmental organizations and the press. Labor unions can be formed and hold internal elections only with government approval. The government licenses political parties -- and has approved only one new party in the past 22 years. A handful of others operate, but most were allowed only after appealing to the judiciary.
Last year, Egypt enacted a law requiring all nongovernmental organizations to register, report any foreign financing and submit the names of their trustees to the government for approval. The law was seen as an attempt to control groups that might serve as fronts for Islamic militants, but it was widely criticized by human rights and legal aid groups. It was declared unconstitutional, on technical grounds, by the Constitutional Court last month.
Egypt has more than a dozen groups that investigate human rights abuses and many newspapers that publish reports on torture, illegal detention, prison conditions and other topics. They have fax machines, speak openly to foreign journalists and post reports on their Web sites.
But when the subject turns to a few particularly sensitive topics -- among them election fraud, official corruption and religious tension -- the government has cracked down, often using a provision in the penal code that makes it a crime to defame Egypt's reputation.
Five journalists at the daily newspaper Al Ahrar, for example, were recently sentenced to jail terms because they had published a Government Accounting Office report on mismanagement at the government airline, EgyptAir. Officials of the Egyptian Organization for Human Rights were jailed last year, accused of defaming the country and illegally accepting foreign funds, after publishing a report on the police handling of a clash between Christians and Muslims in Upper Egypt.
"The government wants to finish off all civil society organizations in Egypt," said Mr. Abu Saada, the secretary general of the group, who was himself jailed for several weeks after the report was published last year. "Either we agree with them all the time or we are the enemy."
In Jordan, it is still a crime to insult the dignity of the king and, as in Egypt or other Arab countries, courts can shut down a publication or jail people who are found to have harmed the "public interest" or criticized members of the government.
Government officials in Egypt said Dr. Ibrahim was the subject of a lengthy police investigation before he was arrested. Hisham Saraya, the chief prosecutor of the state security agency, said Dr. Ibrahim was suspected of illegally taking money from a foreign entity, using that money fraudulently and forging election ballots.
Dr. Ibrahim's lawyers said the election ballots were printed for use in the documentary. They said he received money from the European Commission, the executive body of the European Union, to make the film.
Mr. Saraya, the government prosecutor, said protests from diplomats and other human rights advocates would have no effect on the police inquiry against Dr. Ibrahim. "No other authority -- nothing but truth and justice -- can influence our prosecution," he said.

HEADLINE: They May Be Governors, But the Talk Is Presidential

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: STATE COLLEGE, Pa., July 9

 BODY:
Republican governors outnumber Democrats almost 2 to 1, and they were a confident, even cocky, bunch this weekend as they descended on this university town in central Pennsylvania for the 92nd annual meeting of the National Governors' Association.
At every opportunity, they boasted that one of their own, George W. Bush of Texas, was a shoo-in to win this year's presidential race. 
 And to boot, they predicted, Republicans would retain control of Congress and win most, maybe even all, of the 11 governorships up for grabs.
"We could hardly feel better about the way things are going," said Gov. Edward T. Schafer of North Dakota, chairman of the Republican Governors' Association.
Democrats, not to be outdone, insisted that Vice President Al Gore would turn things around once the nominating conventions are over later this summer and voters are able to focus on the fall election.
"We're extremely optimistic," said Gov. Paul E. Patton of Kentucky, chairman of the Democratic Governors' Association. "We're looking to majority Democratic leadership in this country."
So confident was the Bush campaign that it did not send an envoy to brief Republicans -- neither Mr. Bush nor his brother Jeb, the governor of Florida, made an appearance. Mr. Gore sent William M. Daley, his new campaign manager, to reassure and assuage Democrats.
Mr. Daley met privately with the Democratic governors. No sooner had he gone than both Republicans and Democrats scheduled news conferences, events that were so politically partisan that they submerged what was meant to be the main business of the meeting, a four-day, nonpartisan discussion about "strengthening the American states in the new global economy."
Instead, there was endless speculation about whether any of the 40 or so governors present might end up as vice presidential choices.
No fewer than eight had been mentioned as possible candidates and just as the dueling news conferences by Democratic and Republican governors overshadowed the convention, so, too, did the vice presidential stir, which also had its moments of one-upmanship.
Was the stir causing any tension among the governors? Mr. Schafer was asked.
"What tension?" replied Mr. Schafer, who is not the subject of any serious speculation about being a vice presidential choice. "I haven't noticed any tension. I don't see them in any competition."
Mr. Patton said Mr. Daley exuded confidence while briefing Democratic governors.
"He was very, very upbeat," Mr. Patton said. "He said that this race would turn around as soon as people began focusing on it, after the conventions. They're not doing that now."
Why would the post-convention focus improve Mr. Gore's standing, when 9 out of 10 national polls have had him trailing Mr. Bush by 5 to 10 points for several months?
Because, Mr. Patton replied, other polls have indicated that on most major social and economic issues, voters favor the Democrats.
"The voters are with us," he said, "and when people focus on what they want, Al Gore will win."
Did the Democratic governors, by predicting a post-convention collapse of the Bush campaign, see a parallel with the 1988 campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts? Mr. Dukakis, a Democrat, led Governor Bush's father by a substantial margin for months but faltered after the conventions.
"I wouldn't necessarily say that," replied Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. of North Carolina, a Democrat. "What I do say is that when people finally focus on what counts and what they want, Al Gore will be president."
Gov. Parris N. Glendening of Maryland, a Democrat, argued that Mr. Gore would win not only because of his stands on the issues but also because he was a "proven leader," experienced in handling both domestic and foreign issues.
"Contrast that to the less-than-stellar performance and experience of George W. Bush," Mr. Glendening said.
If there was any anti-Bush argument that hit home with Republicans, the assertion that Mr. Bush was not up to handling the White House job was it. They devoted most of an hourlong news conference to arguing otherwise.
Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania, prominently mentioned as a possible running mate for Mr. Bush, said the Texas governor was an experienced leader because he had served as chief executive of one of the nation's largest states and understood how to "practice the politics of what works."
Mr. Gore does not understand that governing principle, Mr. Ridge added, because he has never been in an executive position.
On the issue of supplying pharmaceuticals to the elderly and poor, Mr. Ridge said, Mr. Gore sees it as "you're either for the drug companies or for senior citizens."
"You should try to get people together," Mr. Ridge said. "The politicization of that issue is not how to get things done."
Today, the governors managed to break free of partisan politicking for an hour or so to hear Gen. Colin L. Powell discuss programs they might put in place to help the nation's young people, a cause he has been promoting since retiring from the United States Army.
But in the end, the talk came around to politics.
First, the general was asked again whether he would accept an offer to be Mr. Bush's running mate or possibly run for president himself at some point, given his popularity with Republicans and Democrats alike.
No, General Powell replied, as he has been replying for months. But some day, he said, he might accept an appointive job in government.
Then, just as the general was preparing to leave the convention hall, Gov. Thomas R. Carper of Delaware had a word with him.
"I used to think you'd make a good president," Mr. Carper said. "Now I know you would."
Mr. Carper is a Democrat.
President Clinton will address the governors on Monday.

HEADLINE: Democrats Drawn to Tax Cuts, But Parties Still Split Over Size

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
With projections of the federal budget surplus rising and both parties in full election-year mode, the debate over tax cuts is shifting from whether to what kinds.
Republicans continue to press for bigger reductions than most Democrats will support, and there is unlikely to be any legislative breakthrough this year. 
 But in Washington and on the campaign trail, Democrats from President Clinton on down are joining Republicans in backing tax cuts -- enthusiastically in some cases, grudgingly and with conditions in others -- to a far greater degree than they were a year or even six months ago.
In one of the clearest signs of shifting sentiment, nearly a third of the Democrats in the House broke ranks with the party last month and voted to repeal the federal estate tax.
Vice President Al Gore doubled his proposed tax-cutting package a few weeks ago, to $500 billion over 10 years, moving him closer to the $1.3 trillion plan offered by his Republican rival for the presidency, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.
And Mr. Clinton announced recently that he would agree to a $250 billion, 10-year tax cut for married couples on Republican terms if Congress would pass his plan to add prescription drug coverage to the Medicare system of health insurance for the elderly and disabled.
The new political dynamics will be on display in Congress this week when the Senate takes up the two big tax-cutting bills of the year: the repeal of the federal estate tax and the reduction of taxes on nearly all married couples in the name of eliminating the marriage penalty, the quirk in the tax code that leaves some two-income couples paying a bigger tax bill than they would if they had remained single.
On the estate tax repeal, the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, said he was hopeful that he might be able to attract enough support from Democrats to overcome procedural hurdles and force a final vote on the bill this week.
If they can get past those hurdles, Republicans are all but assured of passing the bill. Repealing the estate tax has long been one of the Republicans' priorities.
The Senate legislation, identical to the version passed by the House, would gradually reduce and eventually eliminate the tax, which applies only to estates valued at $675,000 or more, a threshold that is already scheduled to rise to $1 million by 2006.
The White House has made clear that Mr. Clinton will veto the bill. But Republicans say that just passing the legislation with bipartisan support would be a powerful political symbol of opposition to the tax, and they have not ruled out bringing the bill up again as part of an end-of-the-year budget package.
For years it was Democratic orthodoxy to label repeal of the estate tax a giveaway to the very richest people in the country. But to try to reduce defections from their ranks and display their own tax-cutting credentials, Democrats in the Senate are planning to offer a less expensive alternative proposal on the estate tax, as their counterparts in the House did last month.
The Democratic proposal is expected to call for the effective elimination of the tax for two politically powerful constituencies that say they are hard hit by it -- owners of small businesses and family farms -- but to continue to impose the tax at reduced rates on the very largest estates.
Mr. Lott also plans to bring up the marriage penalty bill by the end of the week under a procedure that would keep Democrats from stalling the bill or loading it with amendments.
The bill, which would cut taxes on married couples by $248 billion over 10 years, is larger than a version passed this year by the House. As with the estate tax, Democrats plan to offer a less expensive alternative. They would seek to eliminate the marriage penalty without giving a tax cut to couples who already receive a marriage bonus -- that is, a lower tax bill than they would pay if they had remained single.
Since Republicans have shown no signs of accepting his proposal to swap a tax cut for the prescription drug coverage plan, Mr. Clinton is likely to veto the marriage penalty bill if it passes. But Republicans said they could nonetheless go to their party convention at the end of the month able to tell voters that they had done their part to enact big tax cuts and that it was a Democrat in the White House who had blocked them.
Some analysts say the two parties will remain stalemated on fiscal policy as long as control of Congress and the White House remains divided. Others are more optimistic about a compromise on tax cuts, perhaps even this year, because there is enough money for both parties to get what they want.
"It's just a question of horse trading at this point," said Bruce Bartlett, a fellow at the National Center for Policy Analysis, a conservative research group.
But the supercharged politics of the campaign season will make it difficult for any tax cuts to be enacted before a new president and Congress take office next year.
The muddled outlook reflects in part the uncertainty in both parties about how much demand there is among voters for tax cuts. And the evolving politics of tax cuts are just one illustration of how the quickly increasing surplus projections are forcing both parties to rethink their ideology and tactics on fiscal issues.
Last month, the White House increased its estimate of the total budget surplus for the next 10 years by nearly $1.3 trillion, to $4.2 trillion. Long-term budget forecasts are notoriously unreliable, and the fiscal outlook could change substantially based on how the economy performs.
The two parties have agreed not to use the portion of the surplus generated by Social Security -- $2.3 trillion over the next decade -- for tax cuts or general spending. But that still leaves a projected windfall of $1.9 trillion on the table, and just as Democrats are becoming more open to tax cuts, Republicans are proving more willing to go along with expanding government programs.
"There is a changing climate on tax cuts," said Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, a Republican who is chairman of the Finance Committee. Mr. Roth said the larger surplus projections, the possibility that the long economic expansion might be starting to run out of steam and Mr. Clinton's willingness to negotiate a deal had combined to give tax reductions new political viability.
Democrats also said the rosier fiscal outlook had made tax cutting more appealing -- or at least made it more politically difficult to reject all tax cuts out of hand.
They also said tax cuts were getting more bipartisan consideration because Republicans in Congress had dropped their insistence on putting forward all-encompassing tax reduction bills that would use all or most of the projected surpluses and instead were addressing specific types of tax cuts one by one.
Democrats generally remain solidly opposed to broad-based tax-cutting packages of the type proposed by Mr. Bush in his presidential campaign.
"Democrats have always been willing to consider, if not support, tax cuts that are fair, while reflecting our priorities and the need for sound fiscal management of the surplus," said Gene Sperling, the director of the White House's National Economic Council.
"What has changed is that instead of the Republicans in Congress offering a single, excessive tax-cut package that could be rejected immediately as breaking the bank," Mr. Sperling said, "they are now trying to slice their tax agenda into smaller pieces, which can be individually considered on the basis of fairness, fiscal prudence and priorities."
In the coming week, Democrats plan to hit the Republicans hard on those points, asserting that the Republican versions of the estate tax and marriage penalty bills are much too expensive and too tilted to the wealthy.
And they intend to make a case that tax cuts are justifiable only after the two parties agree on more pressing issues, in particular adding prescription drug coverage to Medicare and allocating more of the surplus to reducing the national debt.
"Democrats believe you can eliminate the marriage penalty and reduce the estate tax, and at the same time provide Americans with a prescription drug benefit," said Ranit Schmelzer, communications director for Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader.
"Republicans just want to do the tax cut," Ms. Schmelzer said.
Senator Roth says Republicans, too, think there is enough money for a sizable tax cut, a prescription drug benefit and a steady reduction of the national debt. He said that as he traveled through his home state, he found considerable support among voters for acting now to repeal the estate tax and to cut taxes on couples.
Republicans are banking on getting support from Democrats who are up for re-election this year and do not want to have to explain their opposition to tax cuts.
They point to Democrats like Senator Charles S. Robb of Virginia, who is in a tough race this year in an anti-tax state and who supports repeal of the estate tax.
But some Republicans acknowledge that their party also needs to be willing to compromise if it wants Mr. Clinton to sign any tax cuts into law, and that if they play politics with the issue they will be exposed to assertions by Democrats that Republicans have run a do-nothing Congress.
"I'm a strong believer that what people back home want to see at election time is what you've accomplished," said Mr. Roth, who is also in a tight re-election race. "There are some on both sides who want an issue, not legislation, but I think that's shortsighted."

HEADLINE: Mrs. Clinton Focuses On Gas Prices While Upstate

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

DATELINE: UTICA, N.Y., July 9

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton continued her emphasis on economic issues today, renewing her call for the Federal Trade Commission to broaden its investigation of sharply increased gasoline prices and urging Congress to pass legislation to create an oil reserve for states in the Northeast.
In the fourth day of her Senate campaign tour through upstate New York, Mrs. Clinton rejected as "a serious error" any move to eliminate the gasoline tax, a proposal advocated by her Republican rival, Representative Rick A. Lazio. 
 "I reject my opponent's proposal of eliminating the gas tax," Mrs. Clinton said at a news conference earlier today in Rochester. "One of the few sources of revenue that we actually get more of than we send to Washington is gas tax money for our transportation needs. It would be hard to imagine how upstate can finish all the work we need to do without the federal help that comes from transportation dollars."
On the investigation into gasoline prices, Mrs. Clinton said that it was imperative for the commission to "go beyond where it has already begun to try to figure out why, while fuel costs have gone up over 50 cents in New York, profits for major oil companies have gone up more than 500 percent."
In the tour, which is covering a dozen communities across the state's western, Southern Tier and Finger Lake regions, Mrs. Clinton has sought to discuss policies that would affect the troubled upstate economy.
While her campaign has called this trip the "Upstate Economic Tour," it has been more of a cookout and picnic tour. Mrs. Clinton has appeared at several picnics and rallies sponsored by the Democratic Party in a number of upstate counties. This afternoon, in Van Buren, N.Y., she spoke at a cookout organized by party officials of Cayuga, Oswego and Onondaga Counties. At a similar event here this evening, she spoke to more than 500 Democrats and union members from four counties. Mrs. Clinton spoke about the need to lower utility costs, to stimulate job growth and to rehabilitate this region's roads and highways.
In speaking with voters at the picnics and other events, as in previous visits to this region, Mrs. Clinton has been asked most frequently about her ideas and proposals to revive the economy in upstate New York.
Mrs. Clinton began the day at the Mount Olivet Baptist Church in Rochester. It had not been announced in advance to members of the church that Mrs. Clinton would be worshiping there this morning, and her presence seem to take nearly everyone by surprise. Seated beside William A. Johnson Jr., Rochester's mayor, she swayed and clapped to the music by the choir.
"I stand here today before you today to thank those of you who prayed for me and my husband," Mrs. Clinton said, standing in the sanctuary of the church and addressing an enthusiastic congregation. "I believe that we were both sustained and uplifted because of prayer. And so I thank you and ask you not to quit yet."

HEADLINE: Religious Group Sees Moral Choice in the Monthly Light Bill

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: CHATHAM, N.J., July 3

 BODY:
Electricity used to be so simple. A bill came from some faceless monopoly and the consumer wrote a check. Then came deregulation and the dizzying choice about who would provide one's allotment of kilowatts.
The next wave of change may bring the most wrenching consequence of all: guilt. The Rev. Franklin Vilas, the recently retired rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in this northern New Jersey community, argues that in the new world of consumer choice, electricity has become a moral issue. "If you buy the cheapest energy, you're killing your kids," he says. 
 Mr. Vilas, 65, a soft-spoken clergyman known to all as Skip, is the leading intellectual force in a coalition of religious leaders who are trying to forge what they say would be a holy alliance of good works and faith, environmentalism and economics: all the churches in New Jersey, combining their power needs to buy so-called green, nonpolluting, renewable energy as a political and moral statement.
Experts on the electricity industry and theologians say that though the steps have been early and small -- less than 1,000 green-energy customers, mostly households, out of more than 3.5 million energy users statewide -- the implications of the church effort are huge. Last November, New Jersey was the first state in the metropolitan region, and one of the first in the nation, to let all customers choose their power suppliers. By being drawn into the debate from the beginning, religion has given commercial green energy its first toehold in the nation's densest urban corridor.
"They were a big part of the reason we came into New Jersey," said John Holtz, who is the regional public affairs manager for Greenmountain.com, a company based in Vermont that entered the New Jersey market four months ago, selling electricity generated mostly by wind power, water power and landfill gas. Mr. Holtz declined to provide actual numbers of customers, but said that most signed up after hearing about the company through their congregations or synagogues.
Greenmountain is planning at least three nonpolluting energy plants in the state, two solar and one hydroelectric, he said; these would have been built elsewhere without church involvement.
Another company, Conectiv Energy, began offering green electricity in the southern third of New Jersey last fall.
Religion's connection to the environment, some historians say, goes back to St. Francis of Assisi tending to the beasts of the forest. But the members of Mr. Vilas's group, called Partners for Environmental Quality, say that utility environmentalism is a very different business.
Electricity, they say, is a disembodied idea, rather like faith, that exists only by its expression. Because the delivery and generation process is far away or out of sight, it can seem harmless and clean, when in fact the power industry, especially coal-fired generation, is one of the biggest contributors of greenhouse gases that are blamed for global warming and East Coast smog.
The group's members say that people also have to be taught how the electrical system works so that they can be convinced that buying green makes a difference, and again it comes down to a leap of faith because green energy does not flow directly into the home. Every light and computer and television in New Jersey draws its energy from the same power grid of mixed energy sources that also supplies residents across Pennsylvania and Maryland. Green-energy users have to know in their hearts that their energy purchase has affected, in a small way, the vast, amorphous power grid itself by injecting more renewable energy into it.
"People have to be educated to the fact that this is not the same kind of choice as choosing your long-distance provider; this one carries consequences," said Pamela Frank, the executive director of Partners for Environmental Quality.
Organizing churches around the support of green power and energy consciousness is not a new idea. A group called Episcopal Power and Light has been active in Massachusetts and California for several years, and its leaders have coordinated their efforts with Mr. Vilas.
New Jersey's churches moved faster, pastors and electricity experts say, simply because deregulation here moved faster. New York State, by contrast, is introducing consumer choice gradually on a region-by-region basis through next year, but for most residents there, green energy is not yet an option. Connecticut opened its market only this month.
Some of the biggest commercial power-buying pools have also been formed in New Jersey over the last year, creating a niche industry of experts that the churches are drawing on to build their own pool.
It can sometimes create a cozy world. Partners for Environmental Quality, for example, is working with a two-year-old Newark firm, Gibbons Consulting, that specializes in power pools. Gibbons, in turn, worked earlier this year with the Food Council of New Jersey, a statewide association of food retailers, wholesalers and distributors, helping the group create one of the largest power-buying pools in the nation. The effort was aimed primarily at cutting costs for the group's nearly 2,000 members.
By coincidence, the food group's president, Jim Morford, and its leading lawyer, Jim McGuire, are active Episcopalians, and through their church work, they bumped into Mr. Vilas. The Food Council ultimately signed a contract in March with KeySpan Energy, a company based in Brooklyn that generates electricity primarily by using cleaner-burning natural gas.
Mr. Morford said the main reason for choosing KeySpan was financial. The Food Council expects to save about $20 million over the 14-month contract, compared with its old utility. A secondary consideration was the belief among council members that signing with a cheaper company that relied on Midwestern coal would be bad public relations. Mr. Morford stressed that his church work and his professional duties to the Food Council were kept strictly separate during the KeySpan negotiations. But he said he is now enthusiastically using what he learned to help Mr. Vilas.
Partners for Environmental Quality, which is led by a multifaith board of trustees, has reached out to Roman Catholics, Protestants and Jews to talk about the practical and ethical aspects of participating in the power pool.
Other church efforts have moved forward on their own tracks.
The New Jersey region chapter of the United Synagogues of Conservative Judaism has formed its own energy-buying consortium separate from Partners for Environmental Quality and will present two choices to its 60 members this fall: one with a cheaper traditional energy mix, and one with a higher proportion of cleaner-burning fuels like natural gas and renewable sources.
A spokesman for the chapter said that synagogues would be under no pressure to choose one way or the other, but that he believed most would consider more than price. "Before, we had no input into how energy was generated or how dirty it was, and now we do," said Jeff Schwartz, the secretary of the New Jersey region chapter. "This is an opportunity that shouldn't be squandered."
But the message for cleaner energy is also raising some ethical dilemmas and implications of its own inside religious communities.
Mr. Vilas, who grew up in the utility industry -- his father, Franklin Vilas Sr., was the chief spokesman for Consolidated Edison in New York for many years -- has argued to pastors, priests and parishioners that the cheapest available energy comes from coal-burning plants in the Midwest that are blamed for contributing to air pollution on the Atlantic seaboard.
The structure of deregulation mandates a choice that determines where consumers stand on that pollution issue. Mr. Vilas tells people that by simply staying with the energy company they have, they are tacitly endorsing a power grid that derives nearly 50 percent of its output from coal-fired generation. Getting the point across -- that making no decision on energy constitutes a moral statement -- requires what officials of the group call agitation.
"When I say 'energy deregulation and global warming,' I see people's eyes glaze over," said Ms. Frank, executive director of Partners for Environmental Quality. "But when Skip says, 'Buy cheap energy and kill your kids,' it gets people's attention -- it may be over the top, but it gets people's attention."
Renewable energy also costs about 20 percent more than the rate paid by most customers in New Jersey, and that difference threatens to separate rich churches from poor ones. For an affluent church like St. Paul's, the additional cost of about $600 to $1,000 a year was not considered a problem.
In poorer parts of the state, however, churches are struggling simply to make ends meet. With electricity bills expected to increase this summer in many parts of the country, partly because of a recent surge in natural gas prices, many churches, individuals and businesses could be pushed by circumstances to go precisely the other way: toward cheaper and perhaps dirtier energy.
Traditional electricity companies and some energy industry analysts say that the regional power grid is improving even without green energy, as natural gas becomes a bigger source and older, less efficient coal-fired plans are decommissioned.
But there are also many small and very human implications that have emerged from the church-energy nexus, and they have less predictable results. Robert Frey, a retired mechanical engineer who attends St. Paul's, signed up with Greenmountain after company officials came to the church for Easter service, and he is now the resident green convert in his condominium complex in nearby Morris Township.
Mr. Frey has persuaded the condominium board to allow him to present a plan this fall for converting the common areas of the complex to green energy. He is preparing his presentation now, and his faith is driving him.
"If you're a family that wants to save 10 percent and buy the dirty energy, that's your choice," Mr. Frey said. "But is it beneficial to your children and grandchildren? I think not. How can you get that message across to people without religion?"

HEADLINE: N.A.A.C.P. Leader Urges Blacks to Vote to Save Civil Rights

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, July 9

 BODY:
Saying one more conservative vote on the Supreme Court could bring a setback for civil rights advocacy, the chairman of the N.A.A.C.P. urged delegates to the group's convention tonight to use their voting franchise in November.
The chairman, Julian Bond, who leads the group's national board, also said in a speech that the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People would continue its boycott against South Carolina even though the Confederate battle flag had been lowered from the Statehouse there. 
 "Where else on the face of the earth do the losers get to fly their flag as if they had won?" Mr. Bond asked.
Mr. Bond's speech served as the official start of the N.A.A.C.P.'s 91st annual convention, which is expected to be attended by 10,000 members.
Presidential politics will take center stage at the convention when Gov. George W. Bush of Texas addresses the group on Monday and Vice President Al Gore speaks on Wednesday.
Though the group does not endorse candidates, Mr. Bond said that voting was an important responsibility and that not voting could have dire consequences for civil rights.
He noted that 5-to-4 decisions had prevailed in several crucial Supreme Court rulings and said that "in 65 percent of these cases the right-wing position carried the day."
"Your one vote could translate into two, three or even four votes on the Supreme Court," he said, "determining whether the court will be a refuge for civil rights or a dumping ground."
On the flag issue, Mr. Bond said the N.A.A.C.P. would keep in place its economic boycott in South Carolina.
The Confederate flag was removed from the Capitol dome on July 1 but was placed on a flagpole on state grounds. The N.A.A.C.P. said the flag should be removed entirely and housed in a museum-like setting.
"There will be no compromise on this issue," Mr. Bond said. "The N.A.A.C.P. boycott will continue until the flag is removed from a place of honor and put in its rightful place as an artifact of history."
The national N.A.A.C.P. last year called for nationwide boycott of tourism, athletic contests, cultural events and film-making in South Carolina to pressure lawmakers to remove the flag from at the statehouse dome.
Earlier today, about a dozen protesters waved the Confederate battle flag outside the convention. The protesters said the N.A.A.C.P.'s campaign to have the banner removed from all public properties was an attack on Southern heritage.
"Leave our flag alone," said Richard Gebo, a Virginian now living in Pennsylvania. "That's all we have left."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Series Wasn't Total Loss For Mets

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The Major League Baseball people who created interleague play obviously had the Mets and the Yankees in mind. A few other matchups of geographical rivals as well, perhaps, but Mets-Yankees was the prototype series. The six games in New York this season indeed have been lucrative economically for the teams, and the fans especially found the four weekend games intense and definitely worth watching.
The Mets, however, want to know who wrote the script that left them losing three of the four games. They salvaged the fourth and final game last night, edging the Yankees, 2-0, at Shea Stadium as Mike Hampton, working on three days' rest instead of his customary four, pitched a strong seven innings and Armando Benitez completed the shutout. 
 The Mets came into the series confident that they were on their way up in the National League East standing. They were only a game and a half behind the obstinate Atlanta Braves, and the Braves figured to have as good a chance of losing as winning in their three-game series in Boston. But the Braves won two of the games and doubled their lead over the Mets to three games.
If it is any consolation to the Mets, the three games at Shea drew 162,583 fans, the largest attendance for a three-game series in Mets history. Last night's attendance, 54,286, was the largest single-game crowd in 30 years.
The six games, four of which the Yankees won, attracted 330,065 paying customers, and neither the Mets nor the Yankees could ask for anything better than that. Nor could the fans ask for games better than the weekend produced, although Mets fans would be entitled to ask why the Mets did not win more of them.
Unlike many of the games in this season of inflated offense, all four games were low-scoring affairs. The Yankees won the first three, by scores of 2-1, 4-2 and 4-2. They hardly make that kind anymore.
But well after the scores of the individual games are forgotten, this season's interborough rivalry will be remembered for the split-stadium doubleheader Saturday and the Roger Clemens pitch that hit Mike Piazza in the head, effectively knocking him out of the last two games and the All-Star Game tomorrow night in Atlanta, where he was to have appeared as the National League's leading vote-getter in the fan ballotting.
Playing in Piazza's place last night, Todd Pratt contributed two key plays to the victory. In each instance he threw out a runner trying to steal second base, completing a double play that began with a strikeout. In the first inning, Pratt caught Chuck Knoblauch as Derek Jeter struck out and in the eighth he nailed Jose Vizcaino as Knoblauch struck out. Pratt also scored the second run after leading off the seventh inning with a walk.
The Clemens-Piazza incident continued to produce repercussions, though not on the field. Both teams had wondered if the umpires, intent on keeping peace, would issue a warning to them before the game when the lineups were exchanged at home plate. They did not, but neither Hampton nor Benitez hit a Yankees batter. The Mets, for the moment, were content with winning a game. That need took precedence over retaliation.
If the Mets had taken a bigger lead, perhaps a pitch might have strayed close to a Yankees batter, but Andy Pettitte and a succession of relief pitchers held the Mets close.
If the level of heat between the teams subsides, it will do so only because the teams do not play each other again this season. But if Piazza should encounter problems hitting as a result of the beaning, the ill will will last well into the off-season and even carry over to the interleague games next season.
Of course, the Mets and the Yankees could meet again sooner than next season. Now that would be the ultimate subway series, the World Series.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1407 words

HEADLINE: Where to Feed the Love of Con and Candy

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

DATELINE: SEASIDE HEIGHTS, N.J.

 BODY:
The man who prefers to be called Frankie, not Frank, is sunbathing on the Boardwalk, as human action figures and the women who love them strut past. He has his shirt rolled up to expose a belly as white as anything coming out of that frozen-custard machine a few yards away.
He is taking a break from his concession stall, which includes a pop-the-balloon game, a shoot-the-basketball game and his baby -- the franchise -- a "Shoot the Geek" game he created. "It took a lot of intelligence," he says. 
 Carnival aficionados will wonder whether Frankie Rainey has resurrected from infamy the geek show, which involved biting the heads off live chickens and -- well, never mind. His attraction sheds no blood, but it is every bit as primal, every bit as brainless: a kid earning $6 an hour and dressed in a secondhand hockey goalie's outfit prances about while people shoot him with 30 paint balls out of a semiautomatic gun.
Cost: $5. Time spent: 45 seconds, maybe.
It is a beautiful thing, Mr. Rainey says with a roll of his shoulders. "I had the idea of 'Shoot the Geek,' and they took to it."
We, of course, are "they": who accounted for 309 million visits to amusement parks last year, who spent a combined $9.1 billion to have our insides rearranged on some loop-the-loop ride, to vent our road rage on a doe-eyed kid in the next bumper car, to shoot the geek. We are the suckers, the rubes, the marks seeking safe thrills and some trophy attesting to our prowess with a mallet or water pistol. A stuffed animal is the goal, but a plastic ring will do.
Many of us gravitate toward what the amusement industry calls F.E.C.'s -- family entertainment centers -- where the air smacks of manufactured confection. But those establishments owe a debt to their older, mischievous cousins, places where beach sand salts the funnel cake, the guys operating the rides are scarier than the rides themselves, and the soda-soaked boardwalk grips like a no-pest strip.
A place like Seaside Heights.
For decades the mile-long Boardwalk has beckoned with its come-hither lights, twinkling like a multicolored mirage on the shores of the Atlantic. It is the defiant reprobate of the Jersey Shore, outliving the disapproval of neighboring religious retreats, rebuilding itself after a vicious northeaster caused it to be consumed in rain and fire in 1955.
John Camera, the administrator of the Seaside Heights borough, says the community has made strides in polishing its somewhat seamy image. A million-dollar investment in the main road, known as the Boulevard, has attracted new businesses, and the Boardwalk itself has undergone improvements: new bathrooms, attractive garbage cans, and the periodic replacement of the Southern yellow-pine slats that bear the weight of thousands of summer visitors a day.
But Mr. Camera says the borough's elders have tried not to tamper with their home's gaudy essence. "We realize there are a lot of aspects of Seaside Heights that are honky-tonk, a throwback to the 1950's," he said. "Much of the Boardwalk looks very similar to the way it did in the 50's. And we appreciate that."
That includes the necessary assault on the senses, from the barkers shouting check-it-out come-ons above a Wurlitzer organ's grind to that perfect melange of aromas: sausage, onions, frying dough, beer, cigarette smoke, sweat. It includes the prides of teenage boys and girls sporting tattoos that will blur blue with time. And it includes the denizens, the Frankie Raineys, who bring world-weariness to amusement.
In the winter he deals blackjack in Atlantic City, but in the summer he manages his "Shoot the Geek" stall, which requires constant attention. First, there is the help, he says, pointing to an employee who appears to be approaching a Zenlike state. Then there is the scheduling: "Usually I have four geeks on hand, working three- and four-hour shifts."
Perhaps because of prolonged exposure to the sun, Mr. Rainey begins to explain the open secrets of the Boardwalk. Hold on to your straw boaters: it's all a scam.
For example, there are two approaches to the old score-a-basket, win-a-prize game. There is the one-shot-for-$2 game, just up the Boardwalk, which uses overinflated balls and small, bent hoops set at a considerable distance. Or there is the friendlier, dollar-a-ball game, offered by Mr. Rainey, with deflated balls and wide hoops positioned much closer to the shooter.
"The way we zing 'em is the prize," he explains. The prize is worth maybe 40 cents, so even if the customer wins, he loses. But he gets to show off for his girlfriend or his kid; that means he will want to come back again and be the Big Man, eagerly throwing his money away. "It's all psychology," says the man behind "Shoot the Geek." "It's all how you lay it down."
A few doors up from Mr. Rainey's psychological experiment is Lucky Leo's, where patrons play video poker and Skee-Ball to win points that can be redeemed for prizes reverently displayed in glass cases. The establishment's economy would be beyond the ken of Keynes: a plastic ring is worth 5 points; a rabbit's foot, 500 points; a ceramic "Holy Cross" or a pair of "Magic Glasses," 800 points; a 12-inch oscillating fan, 15,000 points; a gold-plated flatware set, 90,000 points; and an autographed jersey signed by the quarterback Steve Young, 300,000 points.
That is a lot of Skee-Ball.
Out on the Boardwalk, a man struggles to find a scientific method for launching a rubber frog, by mallet, into a plastic flower; a sign -- "Frog body must be in flower to win" -- heightens the pressure. Nearby, people throw their quarters away, in the vain hope that one will land on a glass plate. Above the clinking, the pot-bellied barker shouts out the odd question: "How about it?"
In the bowels of the Boardwalk, in a maze of rooms beneath the carousel, there is a glass-encased booth where crumpled cigarette stubs clutter an ashtray and faded photographs of old Little League teams hang on the wall. This is the domain of Bill Erwin, the bleary-eyed general manager of Casino Pier, a section of the Boardwalk that includes 34 rides and dozens of arcades.
"First aid?" he says into a walkie-talkie, as the smoke of yet another cigarette curls into his eyes. "Can you head down to the miniature golf course? Bring a bandage and some peroxide. Little girl cut her foot."
He is 60 years old, a former high school teacher, a local. He has spent the last 45 summers at the Boardwalk, and has done it all: operating games of chance, owning a few rides, running a stand dedicated to Taylor pork roll. He has the right to say what few others can: "Believe me, I've sliced thousands and thousands of pounds of Taylor pork roll."
He has seen some attractions fall out of favor -- Taylor pork roll, for one -- and others emerge to fill the void. He has seen lean times and flush times, all of which have taught him one thing: the weather rules. A few years ago it was a string of rainy weekends, not the economy, that sucker-punched the Boardwalk.
Mr. Erwin lumbers up the stairs, past the fun mirrors and onto the Boardwalk. He glides through the crowds to chat with some of the foreign-exchange students -- from Belarus, Kenya, Latvia, Poland -- working the booths, and to check on the rides he owns: the Poltergeist, the Gravitron and the Tornado. Yes, he says, there is a bit of a con going on, and yes, the sounds and smells can be a bit overwhelming. But think of Seaside Heights as though it were a show on Broadway, he says. "Remember: it's all a stage."
Mr. Erwin looks up, crinkles his face in concern and says, "I smell dampness."
He is right. Soon an evening storm will cleanse the Boardwalk of spilled beer, melted ice cream -- and people. But before it comes, Wilbert Jackson, a water company employee from Teaneck, pitches a plastic ring into a sea of bottles. It bounces about before coming to rest, miraculously, around the top of one bottle: a winner.
"A big lucky vinner today!" barks the Polish exchange student operating the booth, as Mr. Jackson screams for joy and hugs his wife and two young children.
"I won a bicycle!" he shouts. "First time I won anything in my life!"
The family chooses a yellow Huffy that hangs from the ceiling, and then Mr. Jackson treats everyone to funnel cake. As the rain begins, he walks the bicycle off the Boardwalk, gripping its handlebars as though he half expects it to disappear.

HEADLINE: MEDIA;
Brash, Hard-Driving Executive Steers CNBC to Top of Cable News

BYLINE: By JIM RUTENBERG 

 BODY:
Three years ago, Bill Bolster, still new to the president's job at CNBC, announced an ambitious dream: his financial news network would beat CNN, then the dominant news provider on cable, in the cable TV ratings war.
Though it seemed at the time a distant, almost improbable goal, two weeks ago Mr. Bolster achieved it. New Nielsen Media Research data showed that for the first time in its 11-year history, CNBC had averaged a higher daily audience than CNN for a three-month period. 
 In short, CNBC had become the highest-rated news and information network on cable television, ending CNN's long reign and cementing its reputation as a leading media organization of the new economy.
For Mr. Bolster, 56, the ratings represent a crowning victory in a 35-year career in broadcasting. Although he is widely described as a tyrannical bully who often offends colleagues, he is admired as a TV genius gifted not only at packaging and promoting programming but also at selling it to advertisers at top dollar.
But despite his status as king of TV financial news, Mr. Bolster is more a product of Main Street than of Wall Street -- a media mogul who is far from media-ready.
Mr. Bolster, who is 6-foot 4-inches tall and hulking, has spent most of his career in local markets out of the glare of the national spotlight, making him an unlikely leader for a network noted for having made financial news interesting to everyday people around the country. CNBC is now a regular fixture not only in brokerage houses and newsrooms, but also in gyms and bars.
"As the market has gone up, and in some ways become, at its worst, the national lottery, CNBC has grown right along with it," said Tom Wolzien, a media analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein. "They're part of the democratization of the stock market."
Mr. Bolster is credited both inside and outside his organization with making CNBC a highly profitable entity with mass appeal by incorporating some of the flashy graphics and hype associated with local television news while applying some of the bare-knuckled sales tactics emblematic of local markets.
Under his tenure, CNBC's ad rates have risen more than threefold, and profits have more than doubled, executives said. CNBC, which does not break out its financial results separately from its parent, General Electric, estimates that it will end the year with $280 million in profit.
Mr. Bolster first learned about sales, he said, from his father William, who owned Sweeney's, a women's ready-to-wear business in Waterloo, Iowa, and who also had an investment in Black Hawk Broadcasting , which started out as a small radio group. As a teenager, he would help his father with the books.
"That's where I learned the fundamentals of business," Mr. Bolster said during an interview at CNBC headquarters in Fort Lee, N.J. But he said he did not become hooked on broadcasting until after college, when he became an announcer and ad salesman at KDTH radio in Dubuque, Iowa. He later moved to Waterloo's KWWL-TV, which was owned by Black Hawk, working up to general manager before moving in 1983 to KSDK-TV, the NBC affiliate in St. Louis, as general manager.
Mr. Bolster produced major victories during his time in local television. KSDK was the No. 3 station in St. Louis when Mr. Bolster arrived. He brought it to first place in two years with heavy promotions; an early-morning local news program, which was the first in St. Louis; and an afternoon talk show, "The Sally Jesse Raphael Show."
As head of the news committee of the NBC network's affiliates board, he helped persuade the network in 1991 to delay the beginning of "The Tonight Show" by five minutes, so stations would have more ad time to sell during their late newscasts. Mr. Bolster arrived in New York as a virtual unknown in late 1991, as the general manager of the local NBC station, WNBC-TV, and scored early ratings victories by heavily using promotions, starting the city's first early-morning local news program and introducing flourishes like a news helicopter and high-technology weather radar.
"All of his competitors were saying, 'Who is this guy from St. Louis?' " said Tony Guida, now an anchor with CNNfn who was at WNBC when Mr. Bolster arrived. "He just cleaned their clocks. He knew how to market and sell TV better than anyone I've ever worked with."
Mr. Guida added, "And I say that grudgingly because there is no love lost between us."
Mr. Guida is one many on-air people and broadcasting executives who say they have clashed with Mr. Bolster, and who use the phrase "bull in a china shop" to describe him.
He is said to have a propensity for making off-color remarks and riding people extremely hard. "He is coarse, impolitic, boorish -- a bully," said Peter W. Barnes, a former CNBC reporter now working for a new financial news Web site, JAGfn.com. Mr. Barnes said he had clashed with Mr. Bolster when he tried to break his contract a few months early and was refused.
Mr. Bolster describes himself as one to speak his mind but says that he never intends to purposely offend. "If I've done something, uncharacteristically, that offends on a very personal basis -- not professionally, because professionally, that's my job -- I've got to go back and say I'm sorry, I'm wrong," he said.
Certainly his business manner is full-speed ahead. Upon his arrival at CNBC in 1996 Mr. Bolster quickly began making changes.
Within two weeks, he had changed the CNBC logo, incorporating the NBC peacock. He introduced new wrinkles like real-time stock quotes and market meters that perpetually run on the screen.
He raised ad rates by arguing to Madison Avenue that he was delivering a higher-income viewer whom Nielsen could not measure. To prove it, he gave a real estate firm free time slots advertising a $3.5 million house in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. There were 400 respondents.
On programming, he and his team approached the stock market as a big event, a daily Super Bowl.
"So you say, geez, let's do a pregame show, and it's going to be 'Squawk Box,' " Mr. Bolster said, referring to CNBC's opening-bell show. "Then you've got a game. And then the post-game show."
Unfortunately for CNBC, once the game is over -- once the main stock exchanges close for the day -- viewers tend to wander off. Despite CNBC's daytime gains, its prime-time ratings were down by about 24 percent this spring compared with last, pulling significantly smaller audiences than CNN and the Fox News Channel in the time period.
Today, executives plan to announce that one nonfinancial show, "Upfront Tonight," Geraldo Rivera's half-hour news program weeknights at 7:30, will be replaced by an additional half-hour of "Business Center."
There is some debate over how much of CNBC's success belongs to Mr. Bolster, given the public's ravenous appetite for stock market news. And the network's big name stars like Maria Bartiromo were there when he arrived.
But media industry executives say that even if Mr. Bolster was dealt a great hand, he has played it masterfully. "When he first started, I remember he was saying how he was going to take on CNN and win, and I thought he was being overly optimistic," said Tim Spengler, senior vice president at Initiative Media, a media buying firm. "But he was right. He saw what he had."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
An Insider Battles the Inner-City Trap

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:

TUFF
By Paul Beatty
259 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $23.
The eponymous Tuff of Paul Beatty's new novel is a smart small-time hoodlum from the streets of East Harlem who sees things as they are and whose dreams that they might be different smash up against the jagged edges of reality. He is 19, married and the father of a small boy, and he is surrounded by a cast of characters who, like Tuff himself, are outside the usual categories.
His best friend is a disabled anti-Semitic black Muslim who is always coming up with get-rich schemes, legal and otherwise. His father is a cant-spouting former Black Panther who begins poetry readings by firing shotgun shells into the auditorium ceiling. His self-appointed mentor is a black rabbi named Spencer Throckmorton, who converted to Judaism to marry his college sweetheart and became a rabbi even though she later left him. Tuff, whose real name is Winston Foshay, decides about midway through Mr. Beatty's satirical ghetto romp to run for city council, raising money by working in a three-card monte scam in midtown Manhattan. 
 "Tuff," in other words, is an extravagant, satirical cri de coeur from the inner city, centering on that most common of all sociological concepts, the young black urban male, which is Mr. Beatty's principal literary subject. This gifted writer's first novel, "The White Boy Shuffle," was about one Gunnar Kaufman, who in moving from middle-class Santa Monica to meaner, grittier Hillside, Calif., has to learn to handle himself in the urban arena. Mr. Beatty's new book shifts the scene from Los Angeles to New York, and from a neophyte home boy to a native son, but it stays within the genre of comic parody, with its poison darts aimed both at the black urban male himself and the sociologists who have conceptualized him.
"Tuff" is a funny book, and Mr. Beatty's blunt, impious, streetwise eloquence has a kind of transfixing power. The serious point, though never put in serious political-science language by Mr. Beatty, would seem to be the subtle power of the inner city trap, with Winston and his friends hemmed in by stiff-necked victim-culture ideologues in one corner, self-defeating in-group machismo in another and an indifferent economic system in the third.
The main ingredient of "Tuff" is portraiture, word-rich, profanity- and caricature-drenched tableaus of Winston and the off-kilter world in which he dwells. Skillfully drawn as those tableaus are, one yearns for Mr. Beatty to advance beyond his absurdist color photos of Winston's world, to do something more than slash our conventional notions into scraps.
Advance to what exactly is difficult to say. Maybe something deeper and more affecting than Winston's insouciant, self-defeating confrontation with the limitations of his world. Mr. Beatty's genre-busting technique, his mingling of parody with naturalism, seems aimed at avoiding stock situations, ghetto stereotypes. His book is a kind of anti-"Shaft" in this sense, and that is most welcome. But his unwillingness to shed the transgressive comic mode also subjects his narrative to a talky, meandering quality and a tendency to end up not in ghetto stereotypes but in ghetto slapstick.
We first meet Winston waking up from a faint in a Brooklyn tenement that has just been the scene of some drug-gang murders. That Winston fainted, and that his childhood memories are of being teased because of his bulk, lead the reader into mistaking him for a hapless figure, too flabby for the mean streets. In fact Winston is fat but far from hapless. He casually steps around the corpses, joins up with his best friend, whose name is Fariq, and heads toward East Harlem, where he is a man who knows his way around.
"If all the world's a stage, the stoop at 258 East 109th Street was his proscenium of Ghetto Tragedy," Mr. Beatty's narrator says. Soon Winston has laid out an auxiliary policeman with a punch to the chin and shot his dog. Then he tells one of his friends, an unregenerate leftist revolutionary named Inez Yomura, what it's like to stab somebody.
Winston, talking the talk of the street, refers to himself and to almost everybody with the most insulting racial epithet in the language, appropriated by the hip-hop culture as a kind of insider's insignia. Mr. Beatty's attempt in his portrayal of Winston parallels Winston's own almost pornographic use of the word, and of the sexual and racial meanness of his nonstop patter. You feel the impulse to dislike Winston, to judge him, but you can't, partly because he has charm, partly because he sees so clearly and partly because he does want a way out.
The satirical heart of "Tuff" comes when Winston, given the absence of legal ways out, decides to turn his life around by running for city council. His elderly friend Inez gives him $15,000 of the reparation money she got for being held in a Japanese internment camp during World War II, but his campaign is half-hearted and despairing from the beginning, and Mr. Beatty mines it mostly for its satirical potential. One of Winston's opponents, for example, a book writer and ex-astronaut named German Jordan, complains at a debate that despite all he's done for the neighborhood, he still doesn't feel safe parking his Mercedes there. Then he calls on his constituents "to start imagining ourselves beyond race."
"If I'd been to outer space, written books, had dollars, drove a Mercedes-Benz, I'd imagine myself beyond race too," Winston says, in one of the few statements from him that would be quotable in this newspaper. But German Jordan is so much a straw man that the answer Mr. Beatty puts into Winston's mouth doesn't have much grip, serious or satirical. Mr. Beatty sustains his book's verbal vitality to the end, but you wonder whether, having created this raucous group of rugged individuals, he himself knew exactly what to do with them.

HEADLINE: San Salvador Journal;
Pilgrims Take Inspiration From Martyrs of the 80's

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR

 BODY:
Like a testament to life's stubborn triumph, a rose garden filled with thick, fragrant blossoms rises at the site where soldiers killed six Jesuit priests at the Jose Simeon Canas Central American University in 1989. Nearby, a votive candle flickers in the room where the soldiers then killed a housekeeper and her daughter, hoping to eliminate any witnesses.
It did not work. One woman saw the crime and helped build a case against the gunmen. More important, more than a decade since the killings, tens of thousands of people from around the world have sought out the Jesuit residence's tiny garden to bear their own witness to the faith of eight people they consider martyrs who defended the poor during this country's civil war. 
 Invariably, these pilgrims also trek across town to the chapel at the Divine Providence Hospital where Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero, a vocal opponent of the elite and the violent, was shot dead while celebrating Mass.
They walk through his modest three-room house, where his bloodied vestments hang in the closet and his bedroom calendar is forever turned to the month he was killed -- March 1980. Others go to the countryside to visit the spot where four American churchwomen were also killed by soldiers in December of that year.
Centuries ago, Spanish conquistadors came here for glory, gold and God. Now many visitors come to this nation whose name means the Savior searching for a more elusive treasure along modern-day Stations of the Cross. They come to conquer their own spiritual doubts, looking for lessons from priests, nuns and lay people whose embrace of liberation theology's blend of religion and social activism exacted such a brutal price.
One recent afternoon, the shuffling steps of a dozen Americans from the University of Scranton blended in with the everyday sounds of barking dogs, tinny music and food sizzling in the kitchen of the Jesuit residence.
Slowly, the visitors encircled the garden, where the Rev. Brendan Lally, the Roman Catholic priest leading the group, quietly knelt in prayer. Afterward he plucked a tiny sprig of clover and tucked it into his pocket, like a relic.
"This is a sacred place where people gave their lives for Christ and the Gospel," Father Lally said, "and their deaths make this a holy place and an eternal symbol of the work for justice. This is a faith journey. But it is also an attempt to help us as Catholics understand more deeply our mission by coming to listen deeply to the experiences of our brothers in El Salvador and the stories of the people of El Salvador."
It is a heartening sight to the Rev. Dean Brackley, a American theologian who came to El Salvador to replace his fallen Jesuit brothers at the Central American University. He sees it as a resurrection of sorts, one that is reflected in the experiences of the dozens of delegations he ushers through here each year.
"This place, we export more hope than coffee," he said. "With all the violence, we still export hope. That is why people still come."
Yet as strong as the attraction is for visiting delegations, the religious movement that attracts them has lost ground here. The popular church, formed of communities that grounded their political and social activism for the poor in Scripture, was once virtually the only nonviolent voice speaking out against the government during the war. Now it competes to be heard.
The killings of the Jesuits and the two women drew international scorn for the government and helped to propel the peace effort that ended the war. But the popularity and influence of the grass-roots church has since waned.
Former guerrilla leaders now speak freely and have entered elective politics, evangelical Protestants have recruited thousands of Salvadorans wary of an activist Catholic clergy and skeptical of political engagement, and a conservative Catholic hierarchy looks at adherents of liberation theology as sick brethren in need of more orthodox spiritual healing.
"The hierarchy represents a line of thinking that does not look for repercussions or any social or political change," said the Rev. Rafael de Sivatte, chairman of Central American University's theology department. "It represents a religion that only deals with personal change and repentance of sins. It is an internal religion that looks at the individual with a spirituality that is very much in the air without reference to reality."
The church's challenge in peace, he said, is to find the unity that was forged and tested to the breaking point during the civil war from 1979 to 1992. Although the conflict has ended, he said, many Salvadorans still lack jobs, housing and medical care.
"We have to be even firmer than before," he said. "People have lost their aspirations and are happy with small economic advances. We have to tell people not to be content with any little thing. People say if they are working and have a little money, why should they struggle for others to work? That was a great value we had in the war. But it is being lost."
Enough of the popular movement remains in parishes like San Bartolo in the town of Ilopango, where teachers from the Central American University offer theology classes to the congregation. The students, mostly working adults, take part in discussions of social justice, grounded in the Bible.
"You have to read the newspaper, too, if you read Scripture," said Felipe Miando, a truck driver who recently enrolled in the class. "We went through a war. In the Bible, the Israelites were subjected to the Roman Empire. We were subjected to the empire of the United States and the rich of El Salvador."
The movement for a more socially relevant religion has also been buoyed in recent months by the huge crowds that came to San Salvador to mark the 20th anniversary of Archbishop Romero's assassination, as well as to commemorate the killings at the university. Their visits are familiar to Sister Rosa Avalos, who tends to the chapel where Bishop Romero was killed.
"Sometimes they come here right from the airport," she said. "They want to know where a prophet, saint and martyr lived. Sometimes they come to thank God after asking Bishop Romero's intercession in everything from health, work or some difficulty they have. Their only recourse is to ask God through him."
Outside the archbishop's former home, beside a mural of him smiling by the shore of a lake, dozens of stones are embedded in a wall, each one thanking the archbishop for answered prayers. But there are more everyday miracles to be found among the pilgrims who come here.
For them, the survival of the popular church has been imbued with a deep meaning that can be personal, political or both. They go to parishes in poor communities where people share their many stories and little food with them. They stand in silence at the relics of the Jesuit martyrs, including a book whose bloodstained cover reads "The Crucified God."
"What I want to bring back to Pennsylvania with me is this spirit of community," said Sean Farry, a college administrator who was making his second trip to El Salvador. "Here titles are dropped and you get to know the Salvadoran people. What I find about them is their spirituality. It strikes me as being part of their everyday lives and how they rely on their faith. When there is nothing else to depend on, they can't depend on the government to help them. They have to turn to God."
Mary Rowland stood inside the university's museum, which is dedicated to the slain clergy and lay people, shaking her head as she looked at the threadbare clothes, now darkened with blood, that the Jesuits were wearing when they were shot.
"My goodness," she whispered. "They took the time to get dressed. Good for them."
She said she had to come here. "Hopefully, this will make me more sensitive to other people," she said. "I want to trust people in a straightforward way. I know I fail miserably in that."
She looked at a case where tiny jars were filled with soil from where the priests died.
"This should never happen again," she said. "But it will."

HEADLINE: Alcohol Ban And a Curfew On U.S. Bases In Okinawa

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 10

 BODY:
In a concession to local concerns about the behavior of American soldiers stationed in Okinawa, the United States military has indefinitely banned the drinking of alcoholic beverages between midnight and 5 a.m. and prohibited its personnel from leaving their bases during those hours.
The curfew was imposed after a hit-and-run accident involving a staff sergeant stationed at the United States Air Force's Kadena Air Base early Sunday morning. A pedestrian was injured in the accident and the sergeant was later caught. The authorities investigating the accident said it appeared that alcohol was involved.
 
 This latest incident follows an apology from the highest-ranking United States military official in Okinawa after a marine was arrested last week for allegedly entering a house and molesting a 14-year-old girl while she was sleeping.
"The goal of this policy is to enhance discipline among service members and prevent the recurrence of liberty incidents," the military said in a statement today.
Japanese officials have asked the military to take steps to address the problem of crimes committed by its servicemen, an issue that has long bedeviled relations between local residents and the government of the prefecture and between the prefecture and the central government. "The fact that another incident of this sort has occurred at a time when we were already seeking tighter official discipline is regrettable," said the chief cabinet secretary, Hidenao Nakagawa, during a regularly scheduled news conference.
The two most recent alleged crimes occurred at a particularly sensitive time for the Japanese government, which is doing its utmost to ensure that the Group of 8 summit meeting of world leaders scheduled for July 21 through July 23 in Okinawa will come off without a hitch.
Police forces around the country have been staging drills in preparation for any trouble that might occur, and the national government has been working feverishly to end a dispute with the United States trade representative over charges imposed by the dominant telephone carrier.
The incidents have also embarrassed the United States. President Clinton's participation in the summit meeting will be the first visit by an American president since the United States returned Okinawa to Japan in 1972, and last week Japan was treated to the sight of Lt. Gen. Earl B. Hailston of the United States Marine Corps, the highest-ranking American officer here, bowing deeply to the prefecture's governor in a striking display of contrition.
About 26,000 of the 48,000 American military personnel in Japan are stationed in Okinawa, and residents of the island have long complained that they are unfairly burdened with the social and economic costs of that situation.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Share Prices End Mixed As Earnings Season Begins Dow Manages a Rise as Nasdaq Retrenches

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks ended mixed after a subdued session yesterday, with blue chips pulling ahead and technology issues slipping, as the onset of the earnings reporting season inspired some caution among investors.
Retailers, raw materials producers and manufacturers led the blue-chip sector higher on hopes the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates again this year. Alcoa rose after posting strong earnings. 
 But technology stocks, including leading computer, semiconductor and software companies, suffered as money was switched into "old economy" sectors.
The blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average finished up 10.60 points, or 0.1 percent, at 10,646.58. The technology-dominated Nasdaq composite index dropped 42.91 points, or 1.1 percent, to 3,980.29, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.28 points, or 0.22 percent, to 1,475.62.
The June employment report released Friday, which suggested the economy was slowing, heightened expectations that the inflation-fighting Fed would hold its fire at its next policy meeting on Aug. 22. Still, weaker economic growth is a double-edged sword as it is also likely to crimp corporate profits.
"The jobs data raised hopes the Federal Reserve might not need to raise interest rates again this year," said Alan Ackerman, senior vice president and market strategist at Fahnestock & Company. "Market strategists are trying to gauge the effect of a slowing economy on corporate earnings."
The quarterly earnings reporting season started yesterday with Alcoa gaining 2 1/16, to 291 1/16, after its second-quarter profits rose a better-than-expected 57 percent, because of cost-cutting and continued strong demand for aluminum products.
Among the traditional manufacturers, General Motors rose 2 1/4, to 62 3/8, and the home improvements giant Home Depot was up 2 3/8 at 57 3/4. Sears, Roebuck rose 1 1/16, to 36 1/4.
"The retail sector had been pretty hard hit because everybody thought the Federal Reserve was going to bring the economy to a screeching stop," said Michelle Clayman, of New Amsterdam Partners, in New York. "We certainly have seen signs of a slowdown, but the consumer confidence numbers are fairly solid."

Glut Hurts Treasury Prices
By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices fell as traders made room for at least $13 billion in corporate debt likely to be sold this week.
"Corporate debt is going to be a better performer as the economy slows to a more sustainable pace," said Kenneth Taubes, co-director of the $1.5 billion in fixed income at Pioneer Investment Management in Boston. He has been buying corporate bonds, like those of Deutsche Telekom, for the higher yields over Treasuries and because he expects that yield difference to narrow over time.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 8/32, to a price of 103 11/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.04 percent from 6 percent on Friday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 7/32, to 105 5/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.88 percent from 5.87 percent on Friday.
