HEADLINE: Fed Reports Fast Rise in Consumer Credit

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10

 BODY:
Borrowing by consumers rose in May at the fastest pace since the beginning of the year, Federal Reserve statistics showed today.
Consumer credit increased by a larger-than-expected $11.8 billion after rising $8.8 billion in April and $10.7 billion in March. The May figures mean borrowing rose at a 9.8 percent annual rate in May. 
 "Borrowing is being supported by consumer optimism and still-buoyant demand," Joseph Abate, an economist at Lehman Brothers in New York, said in a report. Confidence in June was close to May's record high, the latest figures from the Conference Board showed.
Revolving loans, which include credit cards, increased by $4.6 billion in May after rising $6.5 billion a month earlier. Auto and other loans rose $7.1 billion after increasing $2.3 billion.
Analysts had expected May borrowing to rise by $7.5 billion. Economists watch the Fed's report to help them gauge credit card use and consumer demand. The statistics do not track loans secured by real estate, omitting home equity loans, which have grown in popularity over the last decade.

HEADLINE: The Big City;
A New Look At Realities Of Divorce

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
WHICH sex is mostly to blame for divorce? The answer seems obvious every time a mogul like Donald Trump or Ronald Perelman or Rupert Murdoch dumps his wife.
Conservative preachers and liberal feminists are united in their disdain for philandering men who abandon their children. Journalists (including this one) and politicians of all persuasions have righteously condemned "deadbeat dads." Even Hollywood professes to be appalled at the cads depicted in "The First Wives Club." 
 But there's a problem with the conventional wisdom. Across America, at least two-thirds of divorce suits are filed by women. Researchers who have interviewed divorcing couples have repeatedly found that, in cases where the divorce is not mutally desired, women are more than twice as likely to be the ones who want out. After the split, women are typically happier than their exes.
This trend has inspired what is probably the first paper in the American Journal of Law and Economics ever to be named after a Nancy Sinatra song. In "These Boots Are Made for Walking: Why Most Divorce Filers Are Women," Margaret F. Brinig and Douglas Allen, both economists, analyze all 46,000 divorces filed in one year, 1995, in four different states: Connecticut, Virginia, Montana and Oregon.
They looked for different reasons that would prompt a woman to file for divorce. One would be to escape an abusive husband -- like a man who is adulterous or violent. But in the state with the best records of grievances, Virginia, only 6 percent of divorces were granted on grounds of violence, and husbands were cited for adultery only slightly more often than wives.
"Some women file for divorce because they're exploited in really bad marriages," said Dr. Brinig, a professor of law at the University of Iowa. "But it seems to be a relatively small number, probably less than 20 percent of the cases."
Another impetus to divorce is the belief that your partner is no longer good enough for you. The classic example is the guy who takes a trophy wife after dumping the high-school sweetheart who sacrificed her own potential to put him through medical school, but a woman can be similarly tempted to leave a husband who is less successful than she is.
The researchers found that the better-educated partner, male or female, was indeed more likely to file for divorce. But again these types of divorces seemed to represent less than 20 percent of the cases.
The solution to the mystery, the factor that determined most cases, turned out to be the question of child custody. Women are much more willing to split up because -- unlike men -- they typically do not fear losing custody of the children. Instead, a divorce often enables them to gain control over the children.
"The question of custody absolutely swamps all the other variables," Dr. Brinig said. "Children are the most important asset in a marriage, and the partner who expects to get sole custody is by far the most likely to file for divorce."
THE correlation with custody is so strong, Dr. Brinig said, that she has changed her view about the best way to preserve marriages and protect children. She previously advocated an end to quick no-fault divorces, but now believes that the key is to rewrite custody laws.
In most states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, mothers can fight for and usually win sole custody. But some states have recently begun making joint custody the presumptive norm.
That change in the law seems to be keeping more couples together, according to this study and other work by Dr. Brinig. She and colleagues have noted a decline in divorce in states with joint-custody laws. And when couples do divorce, fathers who share custody are less likely to renege on their child-support payments.
Dr. Brinig favors a law like the one recently enacted in West Virginia, which typically awards each parent a share of custody according to how much time that parent spent with the child during the marriage. Besides eliminating some of the vicious court fights that now take place over custody, she said, such a law could lead to fewer divorces.
"Custody is now a way -- in some marriages the only way -- for women to achieve a real show of force over men," Dr. Brinig said. "If you remove that distortion, it's apt to change the way men and women relate to each other and to their kids. Fathers are likely to spend more time with kids if they can expect to still see them if the marriage doesn't work out. Women will be more likely to see men as parenting partners, and less likely to use divorce as a power play." 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Lebanon and the Goblet of Fire

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: BEIRUT, Lebanon

 BODY:
If you can't be at Camp David, Beirut is about as good a vantage point as any for watching the Palestinian-Israeli summit talks, because Lebanon has many lessons, some obvious, some subtle, to offer the negotiators.
Lebanon, first off, is a reminder of what happened when Israelis and Palestinians tried to resolve their differences not with diplomacy but with brute force during that long hot summer of 1982. At that time Israel still entertained the fantasy of solving the Palestinian problem by wiping out the P.L.O., and the P.L.O. entertained the fantasy that armed struggle could win back at least all of the West Bank and East Jerusalem. But the Israeli-Palestinian war in Lebanon was a war with no winner. All sides lost. 
 A short time later, Lebanon taught the Israelis another lesson -- that simply because Israel has more power doesn't mean it is in its interest to cram a deal down the other side's throat. On May 17, 1983, with the help of a very foolish Reagan administration, Israel's Likud government imposed a peace settlement on Lebanon, which gave Israel a permanent security presence in South Lebanon. The Lebanese prime minister at the time literally cried after signing the treaty. The May 17 agreement, though, was never implemented. Because it had no legitimacy in Lebanese society it had no roots, and therefore no staying power. The only thing the May 17 agreement gave birth to was a war against Israel by the Hezbollah Shiite guerrillas -- which eventually forced a unilateral Israeli withdrawal -- and a virulent anti-American campaign that culminated in the blowing up of a U.S. Marine barracks, killing 241 servicemen.
But what is most intriguing is the latest lesson from Lebanon -- the one being taught by Hezbollah. Who said the following on TV here the other day? "The political class in Lebanon got so self-absorbed in its rules and games that it is not aware of globalization and competition and the requirements to succeed today. . . . You cannot work anymore on the assumption that we should not change our ways to meet the challenges of peace and in order to become a productive economy."
No, it wasn't the minister of finance. It was Haj Hussein al Haj-Hassan, a Hezbollah Parliament member from Baalbek. In the wake of driving the Israelis out of South Lebanon, Hezbollah has turned its focus inward to satisfy what it knows its constituency now wants most -- jobs, better schools, development, an end to corruption and integration with global trends, not more war.
"You cannot imagine how tired people are of this conflict and all the old political sloganeering," remarked Jamil Mroue, editor of The Beirut Daily Star, "and the party here that understands that best is precisely the party that has been most removed from traditional Lebanese politics -- Hezbollah."
Hezbollah first leapfrogged over the old politics here by not being afraid of the Israelis, but now, having evicted them from South Lebanon, Hezbollah is turning its attention to the economic and social aspirations of its rank and file.
So what's the lesson? Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel may be coming to Camp David without the support of all the traditional, small-minded ethnic parties in Israel. But I guarantee you, 60 to 70 percent of the Israeli people are with Mr. Barak. That is, they are ready for a real and fair deal, including hard compromises, provided the bottom line reads "The End" -- the end of this conflict so Israelis can really get on with life.
The divisions in the Israeli Parliament, like those in the Lebanese Parliament, represent the old politics of ethnic and religious division. But remember, Mr. Barak himself was directly elected by the Israeli people -- precisely to bring about a final peace. He still comes to Washington with a strong mandate for that.
Speaking of elections, Bashar al-Assad was "elected" president of Syria last night to succeed his father. On the eve of Bashar's election, what did he do? Give a speech attacking Israel? No, he ended government controls on auto imports, enabling any Syrian to import a car.
Bottom line: I don't know whether Yasir Arafat and Mr. Barak will be able to achieve what they both will consider a fair deal. But I do know this: If they do, they will each find solid silent majorities at home to embrace it, because growing underneath the old politics out here is a new politics. It may not make as much noise as the old politics, but it has a lot more support than you think. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: One Education Does Not Fit All

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich served as labor secretary from 1993 to 1997. He is writing a book about the future of work.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Thomas Lepuschitz, one of 46 Austrians recruited by New York City to help ease the shortage of math and science teachers, told a New York Times reporter recently that he thought it strange that the state required even the slowest students to take math and science in order to graduate.
It's different in Austria. "Our school system divides people who can do certain things and people who can't," he explained. "The people who can't are not lost; it's just a slower track." 
 Mr. Lepuschitz has touched a raw nerve. Standardized tests -- increasingly linked to grade promotion, graduation, even teachers' salaries and the tenure of principals -- are the single biggest thing to have hit American education since Sputnik. Responding to the understandable demands for more "accountability," almost every school in the land is morphing into a test-taking factory. Both Al Gore and George W. Bush have touted proposals linking federal dollars to scores on standardized tests.
There are obvious benefits. Uniform tests present clear goals and give students, parents and schools ways to measure progress toward meeting them. But standardized tests are monstrously unfair to many kids. We're creating a one-size-fits-all system that needlessly brands many young people as failures, when they might thrive if offered a different education whose progress was measured differently.
Paradoxically, we're embracing standardized tests just when the new economy is eliminating standardized jobs. There's one certainty about what today's high school students will be doing a decade from now: They won't all be doing the same things, and they won't be drawing on the same body of knowledge.
Jobs in the old mass-production economy came in a few standard varieties (research, production, sales, clerical, managerial, professional), but this system has fragmented. Computers, the Internet and digital commerce have exploded the old job categories into a vast array of new niches, creating a kaleidoscope of ways to make a living.
Musicians, artists, writers and performing artists are discovering multimedia outlets for their talents. Tens of thousands of people are starting their own Web-based businesses and auction houses. People who had been clerks and secretaries are turning into spreadsheet operators, desktop publishers and Web-based inventory control managers. Salespeople are becoming specialty technicians, finding or creating products to meet particular customer needs.
We're also seeing an increasing demand for people who provide personal attention and comfort. There's an upsurge in advisers, counselors, coaches and trainers. Physical and occupational therapists are needed. Home health-care workers, elder-care assistants and child-care workers are all in short supply. And we have a chronic need for teachers at all levels.
 Success in these jobs doesn't depend on mastery of one uniform body of knowledge as measured by standardized tests. Instead, many of them require an ability to learn on the job -- to discover what needs to be known and to find and use it quickly.
Some depend on creativity -- on out-of-the-box thinking, originality and flair. Others depend on the ability to listen and understand what other people are feeling and needing. Most require "soft skills" like punctuality and courtesy, although some geeks succeed wildly without even these rudiments.
Yes, people need to be able to read, write and speak clearly. And they have to know how to add, subtract, multiply and divide. But given the widening array of possibilities, there's no reason that every child must master the sciences, algebra, geometry, biology or any of the rest of the standard high school curriculum that has barely changed in half a century. Nor is it necessary that every child graduate from high school ready to qualify for a four-year liberal arts college.
This doesn't mean that "slower students" should be relegated to trade schools, as they are in much of Europe. In the new economy, specialized vocational skills soon become obsolete. Besides, the whole notion of faster or slower learning is irrelevant when there are so many new options for how and what to learn.
In our headlong rush toward "accountability," we seem to be veering toward two extremes -- either expecting every child to pass the same test or assuming that certain children are uneducable, relegating them to a vocational track.
Our challenge is to find different measures of the various skills relevant to the jobs of the new economy. It's our job not to discourage our children, but to help them find their way.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Profits May Not Be Enough to Offset Fed's Drag

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
As the second-quarter earnings season gets into full swing this week -- with reports expected from General Electric, International Paper, Motorola, Yahoo and J. P. Morgan -- the outlook is the best it has been in years.
But a look back at 1994 shows that even great earnings news may not lift stock prices much when the Federal Reserve is intent on raising interest rates to slow an overheating economy. 
 Earnings picked up steam through most of 1994, and the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index finished the year with a 16.4 percent gain in operating earnings, well above the average for the 90's. The stock market, meanwhile, disappointed. The Dow Jones industrial average eked out a 2.1 percent gain, while the S.& P. 500 fell 1.5 percent and the Nasdaq composite dropped 3.2 percent.
So far this year, the outlook for earnings is even better than it was then. In the first quarter, profits surged 23.6 percent from the year-earlier quarter, the strongest performance since the last three months of 1993, according to First Call/Thomson Financial, which collects Wall Street forecasts for the 500 companies in the S.& P. index. For the second quarter, earnings are expected to increase 19.2 percent, First Call says. And for the full year, analysts are forecasting 19.2 percent earnings growth, which would make this year's gain the strongest since 1993.
Still, the three major stock indexes are down or flat for 2000, after hitting new highs earlier this year.
The Fed's interest rate increases have taken the rally out of the market, as they did in 1994. Rising rates threaten to slow economic growth and, therefore, cut into corporate earnings. They also can raise borrowing costs for companies. And higher interest rates, when plugged into many Wall Street valuation formulas, immediately make stocks look more expensive when compared with their projected earnings.
"The market hasn't made much headway because investors had an eye on the Fed," said Thomas M. Galvin, chief investment officer of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. Although Mr. Galvin says that this year's stock market performance would have been worse if profits had not been as strong, he now expects the market to be in a holding pattern until investors sense that the Fed has taken its foot off the brake.
"There is still a fair amount of skepticism that the cool-down in the economy is not enough for the Fed," he said.
The power of the Fed to stymie the market is remarkable given that the projected earnings growth for this year is stronger than the actual growth proved to be in each year of the 1995-to-1999 run, when the Nasdaq and the S.& P. 500 rose 20 percent or more each year and the Dow climbed 20 percent or more in four of the five.
Joseph Liro, chief economist at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J., warns that although earnings growth will be strong this year, the pace will slow at the end of the year and will decelerate further early next year. "I have been fairly optimistic about earnings and remain so," he said. "But it may not be good enough for investors to get excited about."
Another factor that could continue to undermine the stock market is inflation, which some analysts expect to rise even as the economy slows. During the stock market rallies since 1995, the rate of core consumer inflation, which excludes the cost of energy and food, was in decline. It fell to an annual increase of 1.9 percent last year from 3 percent in 1995. But for the three months through May, core inflation rose at a 3.2 percent annual rate.
"Over the long haul, what is the most important thing for stock prices in any given quarter or any given year is the trend in inflation and the bond yield," said Douglas R. Cliggott, United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities.
"Earnings were great in the first quarter and will be darn good in the second quarter," he said. "But the reason the market indexes are slightly down is the inflation trend."
Thomas McManus, equity strategist at Banc of America Securities, sees another dark cloud in the outlook. Wall Street analysts are overestimating the strength in earnings for the rest of the year, he says, because they do not realize how far the Federal Reserve will go to slow the economy and curb inflation.
He is forecasting that the earnings growth rate will decline sharply this year, falling to 9 percent by the final quarter and to zero in the first quarter of 2001. That would bring earnings growth well below the 11 percent average in the 1990's.
"The only thing that is going to bring inflationary pressures down is to break through that trend line," Mr. McManus said. "And that is not currently baked into analysts' forecasts."
But while strong earnings may not be able to drive the stock market much higher in the face of expected Federal Reserve rate increases, they are still a good guide to those picking stocks. Mr. McManus says investors should stick to what he calls the predictable earnings sectors, including utilities, health care, consumer products and, to a lesser extent, financials.
Mr. Galvin urges investors to consider health care and technology stocks because they performed the best after the Fed took its foot off the brakes in 1994.
Earnings performance is far more important for stock pickers this year than it was last year, Mr. Galvin says. In 1999, companies in the Nasdaq composite index that reported operating losses had an average stock gain of 115 percent for the year. Among the companies that reported profits, the average stock gained 51 percent. So far this year, companies with losses have stock declines of 11 percent on average while companies with profits have stock gains of 10 percent on average.
There is some good news in this look back at 1994, and that is what happened in 1995: the Dow average surged 33.5 percent.
Once it is clear that the Federal Reserve has finished raising interest rates -- as long as the economy has not been slowed to the brink or even into a recession -- nice earnings ought to help the stock market forge ahead again.
The problem is, while some analysts think the pace of economic growth is slowing enough for the Fed to take its foot off the brakes, Federal Reserve officials have not given an all-clear signal yet.

HEADLINE: Web Hardware Maker Buys Digital 'Plumber' for $41 Billion

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Mention "new economy" and just what comes to mind? For many people, dot-com companies, fancy Web sites, piles of cash.
Those are all fine images, but these days, the big money in the new economy is being made not by dot-coms but by the digital plumbers. 
Most people probably never heard of the company that makes the valves inside the pumps at their local water treatment plant. And they probably never heard of SDL Inc., either. But that can hardly bother SDL's investors, because the company announced yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the JDS Uniphase Corporation for $41 billion in stock.
That is more than the market values of Amazon.com, the At Home Corporation, eBay and Priceline.com combined.
Modern cities are not possible without plumbing, and the wildfire spread of data communications and the Internet is not possible without the sort of arcane components for fiber optic networks (think lasers and amplifiers) made by companies like JDS Uniphase and SDL.
That is not an original thought; over the last year, investors have bid up the price of JDS Uniphase fivefold. But beside the stock levitation, the financial muscle of the new economy's plumbers has been felt in explosive initial public offerings and in rich acquisitions of private companies.
But SDL, based in San Jose, Calif., is publicly traded, on Nasdaq. And now the plumbers have announced what may just be the biggest technology takeover yet.
Under the deal, each share of SDL would be exchanged for 3.8 shares of JDS Uniphase. JDS Uniphase's shares closed on Friday at $116.1875, making the transaction worth $441.5125 for each share of SDL. SDL's shares, meanwhile, closed Friday at $295.3125, giving the company's investors a takeover premium of almost 50 percent.
By the time trading was over yesterday, the value of the deal had declined substantially. With such a wide spread between the implied value of the deal, as announced, and where SDL's shares had been trading, the arbitrage opportunity was obvious. Shares of JDS Uniphase fell $15.0625, to $101.125, while SDL jumped $25.375, to $320.6875.
But even with those moves, shares of SDL did not end up close to JDL Uniphase's bid. With the slide yesterday in shares of JDS Uniphase, the deal is now worth $384.275 for each share of SDL, which means that SDL could still be described as undervalued by more than 19 percent.
What that probably represents is uncertainty among arbitragers and institutional investors that the deal will be completed. After all, it must be reviewed by the Justice Department, which imposed some conditions on JDS Uniphase's last big acquisition, of E-Tek Dynamics Inc., for about $20 billion earlier this year.
But what is almost certain is that optical networking technology will in some ways remain the technical foundation of the communications revolution. That is because optical networks are generally the most cost-effective way to transmit gargantuan amounts of two-way information from one point to another, especially in the industrialized world.
Copper wires like those used to connect most homes to the telephone network also used to be employed for regional and transcontinental networks. But optical networks, which transmit information using pulses of light modulated by lasers, can be much more efficient than copper networks that use pulses of electricity.
Big communications carriers like the AT&T Corporation and WorldCom Inc. buy optical communications systems from big equipment vendors like Lucent Technologies Inc. and the Nortel Networks Corporation of Canada. This is like a city turning to a water treatment company for a water treatment plant. In turn, companies like Lucent and Nortel assemble their systems from components and modules often bought from companies like JDS Uniphase. This is like the water treatment company turning to another concern for advanced pumps.
Companies like JDS Uniphase then buy more specialized parts from companies like SDL. This is like the pump company contracting with another company for specialized valves.
But imagine that only a few companies could make the valves needed. And imagine that the overall capacity of the water treatment plant was closely linked to the performance of those valves. Then it becomes clear that the valve company is quite valuable.
"Let me put it to you in a simple way," Anthony R. Muller, JDS Uniphase's chief financial officer, said in a telephone interview yesterday. "Think of Amazon and eBay and any number of other companies that are of this genre. They all require bandwidth to deliver their products and services. And we and our competitors make the fundamental underlying technology that provides the amount of bandwidth that is required for the Internet."
In a statement, Don Scifres, SDL's chairman, said, "This combination brings together world-class technical and manufacturing teams that promise to deliver best-in-class products at increased volumes for today's systems while developing solutions for tomorrow."
Jozef Straus, the co-chairman and chief executive of JDS Uniphase, said in a statement, "JDS Uniphase and SDL share a common vision to provide customers with the most innovative and technologically advanced products that enhance their ability to deliver next-generation optical systems."
SDL specializes in a laser known as a pump laser and in components that are used to make laser systems. JDS Uniphase is hoping that by acquiring the company, it will be able to direct SDL's research in ways that are more complementary to its own technical plans.
As that happens, the dot-com companies will continue to be the most visible element of this new economy. And that will not trouble the plumbers one bit.

THE COMPANIES AT A GLANCE
 
JDS UNIPHASE
Based in San Jose, Calif., the company makes a range of optical components, including lasers and routers, for fiber-optic communication networks. It has about 17,000 employees.
 
SDL
Also based in San Jose, Calif., the company focuses on lasers and optical amplifiers for communication networks as well as for data storage, printing, materials processing and medical uses. It has about 1,700 employees. Revenue in the first quarter was $72 million.

HEADLINE: Energy-Smart Lifestyle

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "The Danger Point," by Bob Herbert (column, July 6):
Despite much natural evidence for global climate change, there is likely to be substantial opposition to any drastic measures that affect the economy or people's way of life. 
 The only effective means for controlling greenhouse gas emissions, within the constraints of not affecting lifestyle, is to do what makes sense from both economic and environmental viewpoints.
We can increase the amount of electricity from nuclear plants (which do not emit greenhouse gases) and from wind. We can also improve the efficiency of vehicles, electric motors, lighting and industrial processes.
Dealing with global warming does not have to become a sacrifice for people. What we do have to recognize, however, is that it will require economic investments and a new way of looking at how we generate electricity and use it.
 
DALE KLEIN
Austin, Tex., July 7, 2000
 
The writer is vice chancellor for special engineering programs, University of Texas system.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN;
In His Own Words

 BODY:

GEORGE W. BUSH
Speaking yesterday to delegates at the N.A.A.C.P. annual convention in Baltimore:
" For our nation there is no denying the truth that slavery is a blight on our history and that racism, despite all the progress, still exists today. For my party there is no escaping the reality that the party of Lincoln has not always carried the mantle of Lincoln. Recognizing and confronting our history is important. Transcending our history is essential. We're not limited by what we have done or what we have left undone. We are limited only by what we're willing to do. 
 Our nation must make new a commitment to equality and upward mobility to all the citizens. This is a great moment of national prosperity. But many still live in prosperity's shadow. The same economy that is a miracle for millions is a mystery to millions as well. From the beginning of this campaign I have said that prosperity must have a purpose. The purpose of prosperity is to ensure the American dream touches every willing heart. And we cannot afford to have an American segregated by class, by race or by aspiration. America must close the gap of hope between communities of prosperity and communities of poverty. . . .
There is a higher and older tradition in my party. Lincoln argued that every poor man should have a chance. He defended a clear path for all. He financed colleges and welcomed immigrants, promoted railroads and economic development. Through the Homestead Act he gave countless Americans a piece of land, a start in life.
I propose a new prosperity initiative that reflects the spirit of Lincoln's reforms. A plan to remove obstacles on the road to the middle class. You see, instead of helping people cope with their need, we will help them move beyond it.
And here are some of the ideas of the new prosperity initiative, just some of the thoughts:
We must provide a family health credit that covers 90 percent of the cost of basic health policy for low-income families in America.
We must make it possible for more people to become homeowners in this great land, to own a part of the American dream. So we allow low-income families to use up to a year's worth of Section Eight rental payments to make a down payment on their own home. Then use five years of those payments to help with the mortgage.
We will start an American dream down payment fund, matching individual savings to the down payment for a home.
Behind these last two proposals is a simple belief. I believe in private property. I believe in private property so strongly, I want everybody to have some. . . .
These are some of my goals for America. To help make opportunity not only a hope and a promise but a living reality. The N.A.A.C.P. and the G.O.P have not always been allies. I know that. But recognizing our past and confronting the future with a common vision, by doing that I believe we can find common ground. It won't be easy work. But a philosopher once advised, 'When given a choice prefer the hard.' We will prefer the hard because only the hard will achieve the good. That's my commitment. And that is our opportunity."
 
A full transcript of Mr. Bush's remarks is available from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/politics

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 350 words

HEADLINE: The Edgy City Series

 BODY:
Setting aside the frightening fact that one of Roger Clemens's 90-mile-an-hour fastballs beaned and concussed Mike Piazza, the New York Mets' All-Star catcher, the rousing four-game series between the Yankees and Mets was everything that organized baseball had hoped for when it introduced midseason interleague play in 1997. New York, of course, is unusual. There is only one other major league city, Chicago, with two teams in different leagues, and one would expect more interest in a crosstown rivalry than, say, an intrastate rivalry like St. Louis and Kansas City. Even so, the excitement reached World Series levels from the very first pitch, and when the last out had been recorded at Shea Stadium on Sunday night, New Yorkers had been treated to some sterling baseball and a few memorable moments.
Wearing a Yankee uniform, Dwight Gooden made an emotional return to Shea, where, as a Met, he enjoyed his greatest triumphs during the 1980's before his personal life spiraled out of control. Gooden was unemployed in late May when George Steinbrenner, with the benevolence he often shows to former employees, reached out and gave him a minor league contract. Gooden responded by pitching five strong innings in the front end of an unusual home-and-home doubleheader, with the first game at the Mets' ballpark in Queens, the nightcap at Yankee Stadium in the Bronx. 
 The Yankees won three of the four games and local bragging rights, at least for now. It is conceivable that the two teams will meet again in October, since both have the talent to win their respective league championships. Perhaps by then both teams will have forgotten the ugly beaning incident. Clemens insists that he did not throw deliberately at Piazza. The Mets suspect the worst, however, because historically Piazza has treated Clemens's pitching roughly, and also because Clemens had good control of his pitches when facing all the other Mets. Players have long memories, and at least for the remainder of this season, the Mets-Yankees rivalry is likely to be characterized by good baseball and bad blood.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1834 words

HEADLINE: New China Flights Put Old Foes at Odds;
New York, Chicago and 3 Airlines Lobby Hard for Lucrative Market

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
For more than a century, New York and Chicago have alternated outdoing each other by building the tallest skyscraper in the United States. Their art museums have long competed for some of the world's great paintings. And their sports teams -- be it the Giants and Bears in the early days of professional football or the Knicks and Bulls in basketball more recently -- have repeatedly battled for championships.
Now comes the latest skirmish in a long civic rivalry: the behind-the-scenes struggle over which city might become the take-off point for a lucrative set of new flights to China scheduled to begin next April. The decision -- due this summer from the Transportation Department amid a flurry of subtle lobbying from members of Congress and former top Clinton administration officials -- has added importance because of the increase in travel that is expected to follow China's entrance to the World Trade Organization. 
 In New York's corner is Delta Air Lines, which wants to fly to Beijing from John F. Kennedy International Airport. With support from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and much of the state's Congressional delegation, Delta executives are arguing that New York's size and economic importance so outweigh Chicago's as to make the decision an easy one.
"New York is the most important aviation market on the planet," Leo F. Mullin, Delta's chief executive, said.
American Airlines, which would fly from O'Hare International Airport in Chicago to Shanghai, responds that geography trumps demographics. The Midwest's unofficial capital is an excellent gathering point for passengers and offers a shorter trip to China, via the North Pole, American and its supporters say. New York, important as it is, is isolated from the rest of the country, they say -- a complaint New Yorkers have heard before.
But even as the Big Apple and the Second City highlight each other's flaws, the bickering between Delta and American may help open the door to another well-connected contender: United Parcel Service. The bilateral aviation agreement with China, unlike any other in memory, forces Transportation Department officials to choose between passenger and cargo carriers, rather than allocating routes to each separately.
"We're sort of in new territory, in terms of the department trying to make an analysis," said Will Ris, American's senior vice president for government affairs.
U.P.S. wants the same right to fly to China that its chief competitor, Federal Express, already enjoys. With the help of the Teamsters, its largest union, U.P.S. -- one of the biggest campaign contributors in the country -- has lined up a list of supporters that includes more than 300 members of Congress. "This is our No. 1 international priority," said Tom Weidemeyer, the president of U.P.S. Airlines.
The company's allies have inundated the Transportation Department with letters saying that the cargo business needs a new entrant much more than the passenger business does. Currently, Federal Express is the only American cargo company to fly directly to China, although U.P.S. flies to Hong Kong and its partners distribute packages from there. Northwest Airlines and United Airlines both now carry passengers to Beijing and Shanghai.
"There has not been a more important carrier-selection case before D.O.T. since deregulation," more than two decades ago, American wrote in its official filing. It "transcends aviation."
The passenger airlines argue that opening up their market to greater competition will promote travel between the two countries and accelerate the kind of political change the United States wants to see in China. U.P.S. says it can lower the price of shipping goods between the world's biggest economy and its most populous nation, thus increasing global trade.
The carriers' deadline for making their official case has recently passed. A decision is due soon, but it already has taken longer than other cases because of the complexity of the filings, analysts say.
"Frankly, nobody really knows quite what's going on right now," said Dale Bumpers, the former senator from Arkansas whom American has hired to help its case.
President Clinton and Zhu Rongji, China's premier, negotiated the new aviation treaty at their April 1999 summit meeting here, when Mr. Zhu was willing to make concessions in an effort to persuade the Clinton administration to support China's entry into the World Trade Organization. The pact did not go as far as American officials and airline executives would have liked, but it allowed for the doubling of flights, to about eight each day -- split equally between American and Chinese airlines. And it gave each country the right to designate one more airline to fly between the countries.
Even the airlines that already serve the market have become involved in the political maneuvering. Currently, Northwest flies to Beijing and Shanghai from Detroit. United flies from San Francisco to Beijing and, via Tokyo, to Shanghai. But in a move that most analysts consider an effort to ward off American's bid for the new flights, United has announced that it will switch the Shanghai flights to Chicago next April and no longer make a stop in Tokyo.
The incumbents, including Federal Express, a unit of the FDX Corporation, have also applied for some of the 10 new weekly round trips that the Transportation Department will hand out. Still, lobbyists expect the new entrant to get most of them so it can establish itself. In addition, Polar Air, a small cargo carrier, has filed to become the new entrant, but it has little support in Washington.
All along, federal law has barred the companies from directly lobbying A. Bradley Mims, the Transportation Department official who oversees the process. At a recent meeting of an international airline industry group in Sydney, Australia, for instance, Mr. Mullin of Delta said he had a long discussion with Mr. Mims, all about rules on how much noise airplanes can make. "I didn't mention China once," Mr. Mullin said. (Through a spokesman, Mr. Mims declined to comment.)
Instead, the airlines have hired some of Washington's best-connected lobbyists. Mickey Kantor, the former commerce secretary and top trade representative in the Clinton administration, has sent written testimony on behalf of U.P.S. And Mr. Bumpers helped American, a unit of the AMR Corporation, write its application.
The companies have also asked their outside supporters to write letters to the Transportation Department, though executives are barred from asking the politicians to lobby Clinton administration officials more directly. Hundreds of mayors, governors and members of Congress have weighed in, breaking down along predictable geographic lines. Richard M. Daley, the mayor of Chicago and the brother of Vice President Al Gore's campaign chairman, backs American. Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, supports Delta. For either city, a victory would mean new jobs, more trade with China and a bigger tax base.
One of the New Yorkers' biggest advantages is the imbalance that currently exists between the Midwest and East Coast. Detroit is already the take-off point for all of Northwest's flights to China. Once United makes its change, Chicago will have direct flights, too.
"That makes American's bid redundant," said Jon F. Ask, the managing director of Global Aviation Associates, a Washington consulting firm not working for any of the applicants. Meanwhile, no airline flies between the East Coast and China.
American's executives and their Midwestern supporters respond that Delta's flight would not actually help many eastern cities other than New York. Delta flies from only 29 domestic cities to Kennedy Airport, some 60 fewer than American and its regional partner, American Eagle, do at O'Hare. As a result, many passengers would have to make two flights just to get to Kennedy, the Chicagoans say.
For example, a resident of Syracuse who wanted to travel to China only on Delta would have to fly first to Atlanta and then north to New York. In its filing, U.P.S. argued that many people would instead choose to fly Northwest through Detroit because it would be a shorter trip. The congestion in the skies above New York could hurt Delta's case, too.
The more fundamental decision facing Mr. Mims and his colleagues at the Transportation Department, however, is whether they should award the new route to a passenger airline or a cargo carrier. Analysts say that decision is a close call.
U.P.S.'s strongest argument is that it would become only the second American shipper to fly to China, while two passenger airlines based in the United States already do so. The company is supported by Northwest and United, which say they currently lose money on their flights to China. "The market is terribly overserved," Gary Wilson, Northwest's chairman, said. "I know everybody views China as a great new market, but it's been viewed as a great new market for 500 years."
U.P.S. does already fly to Hong Kong, however, and Chinese partner companies pick up and drop off packages there. According to an Arthur Andersen study commissioned by American, that service allows U.P.S. and DHL, which also lacks direct service, to get packages to the United States about as fast as Federal Express. U.P.S.'s shipments to China were somewhat slower, though DHL's were not.
Still, Mr. Weidemeyer, the head of U.P.S.'s airline division, said the carrier's broad support, from politicians in every region in the country, indicates that it has the best application. Even some members of the New York House delegation whom Delta calls supporters -- Representative Louise M. Slaughter, a Democrat, for example, -- actually back U.P.S., according to letters they have written. They say Delta should receive the new rights only if the administration decides to select a passenger airline.
The Teamsters have also written letters on behalf of U.P.S. and with Mr. Gore looking to shore up the support of labor leaders angered by his position on other trade issues, the union could be an important voice. Even American and Delta acknowledge that U.P.S. has built the strongest base.
"They do have, probably, a political advantage because of the number of people they employ and because of the members of Congress they've signed up," Mr. Bumpers said. "They operate not only in every state, but in every village of every state."
With all three airlines presenting strong cases, a host of considerations beyond the purely technical are bound to influence the decision. American and Delta officials hope that their backers in Chicago and New York will cancel out some of U.P.S.'s support and that the administration will decide new passenger service is simply more important. But only one can win.
"There's nothing wrong with U.P.S.'s proposal or Delta's," said Mr. Ris, the lobbyist for American. "The real problem is that we have been able to negotiate only one new carrier with China."

HEADLINE: In a Turn of the Tide, Bloodshed Rises in Los Angeles

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 10

 BODY:
In the middle of a sound sleep a few weeks ago, John W. Mack, the president of the Los Angeles Urban League, was awakened by a sound he had hoped had vanished from the night here: the unmistakable rattle of gunfire echoing through the streets. The next morning, he awoke to learn that a man had been fatally shot 50 feet from his home. Several blocks away, a woman who had witnessed the shooting was "blown away, too," Mr. Mack said.
"For a while, it looked like we had turned a corner on this kind of thing," Mr. Mack said today before the start of another neighborhood anti-crime meeting here. "But this violence issue is really, really out of control." 
 A seeming resurgence in violent crime has struck Los Angeles in recent months, at a time when, with only a few exceptions, violent crime is down nationwide. Compared with this time last year, the city has had a 7.5 percent increase in violent crime, including 58 more homicides, 97 more rapes, 106 more robberies and 1,437 more aggravated assaults, Los Angeles Police Deputy Chief Maurice Moore said.
One of the most publicized cases was the killing of the 20-year-old granddaughter of the city's chief of police. She was shot as she sat in a car with a childhood friend. The friend, the intended target, was a gang member. He escaped.
But the violence has been more widespread than was generally known. Out of the city's 18 police areas, 15 report increases in violent crime, with several stations experiencing what officials consider an alarming increase in homicides. The hardest hit, the Newton station, which includes parts of South-Central Los Angeles, has had 24 more homicides than a year ago, followed by the 77th police area, with 14 more killings. The Wilshire police area, where Mr. Mack lives, was actually one of only three areas that reported a slight decrease in violent crime.
"That just goes to show that there is no sanctuary, no safe haven from violence," Mr. Mack said. "Everybody needs to wake up and help."
The police blame much of the increased violence on the city's 65,000 "identified gang members."
"What we're seeing is multiple gang frictions throughout the city," Deputy Chief Moore said, adding that there appeared to be no one reason for the increased violence. "A lot of it has to do with turf and of course drugs."
But neighborhood advocates, like Najee Ali of Project Islamic HOPE and Earl Ofari Hutchinson of the National Alliance for Positive Action, say it is too easy to just blame the gangs. And police statistics seem to back them up. So far this year, according to the police, 42 percent of the city's homicides were gang-related, meaning the majority were not. Their causes included arguments, robberies, domestic disputes or the myriad reasons people kill.
"There's a deep sense of hopelessness out there," Mr. Hutchinson said. "We spend more money on prisons than on schools. And the leadership, particularly the African American leadership, has abandoned the inner city. All these factors are coming together, and I don't think this increase in the violence is just an up-tick. I think it's a long term trend."
Violence has certainly been part of the city's past. In the 1980's and early 1990's, street gang violence was almost as much a part of Los Angeles' image as sunshine and palm trees. There have been countless meetings of politicians, ministers, neighborhood advocates, gang members and grieving parents searching for ways "to stop the violence and increase the peace." Those efforts led eight years ago to a well publicized truce among gangs. That and the improvement of the economy contributed to a lowering of the crime rate here and across the country.
Now, though, some experts say, the coming of age of younger gang members is at least partly responsible for a resurgence of violence.
Whatever the cause, the drive-by shootings, the meetings and the funerals are happening more often again. Dozens of people turned out today for an antiviolence meeting at the First A.M.E. Church, which became a shelter for hundreds of people during the civil unrest of 1992. The meeting was one of two held today to search for new and old ways to stop the killing. It was convened by Los Angeles County Supervisor Yvonne Brathwaite Burke and the speaker emeritus of the California State Assembly, Antonio R. Villaraigosa, a candidate for mayor in next year's election. The Los Angeles city attorney, James K. Hahn, another mayoral candidate, also attended.
"We were patting ourselves on the back six months ago about crime going down," Mr. Hahn said. "We have to recognize the work is not over."
The violence is not confined to Los Angeles. Mary Simmons, a 43-year-old home care worker, lives in Long Beach and she said she was "scared everyday."
"I try to get into my home before 9 every night," she said. "I've lost two nephews. We can't go to school because we got to work all the time to survive on almost no money. My son is 23. He's tired of struggling. He can't put shoes on his feet. I can't help him. I don't have any money." A tear fell down her cheek. "We can't take care of our kids," she said. "That's why we're losing our children to these gangs."

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1568 words

HEADLINE: Renovations, With Reservations;
Vendors at Essex Street Market Debate Going Upscale

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
The waves of immigrants who swept into the Lower East Side in the first years of the 1900's found almost everything they needed sold right under their tenement windows. Pushcart peddlers crowding the streets hawked fish and fruit, bread and boots, pots and pickles. And with minimum start-up costs, new entrepreneurs could scrape out a living provided they were willing to bear the long hours and exposure to the elements.
But the pushcart-packed streets made it hard for the Police and Fire Departments to get through, drew the trash of trade and aroused increasing ire from storekeepers resentful of the competition. So in 1939, Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia offered the peddlers an alternative: the Essex Street Market, four cavernous brick sheds that stretched from Broome to Stanton Streets. It soon filled with vendors whose roof was no longer the sky. 
 For years, the string of single-story structures was a vibrant venue for scores of fishmongers, butchers, greengrocers and purveyors of low-priced garb. The mostly poor bargain hunters squeezed the fruit, smiled or scowled over their fingers' findings and parted with their pennies and dollars.
But by the 1970's, as shoppers increasingly preferred supermarkets and street-front stores to indoor stalls, the market began shrinking. Today, only two dozen merchants remain in just one of the four city-owned buildings.
Yet as old markets across the country have been revived in recent years and new ones, like the three-year-old Chelsea Market in Manhattan, have opened, the city has sought to sustain the surviving slice of the Essex Street Market; even, most recently, to introduce a stylish touch.
It has refurbished the interior of the blocklong, skylighted building between Delancey and Rivington Streets, reconstructed some of the stalls and improved the heating and cooling systems. And it has leased one end of the hall for a restaurant that will be the market's first upscale operation when it opens this fall.
The restaurant's owner, Felice Banker, says she hopes to draw the hip young residents who have been moving into the area, as well as veteran Lower East Siders, with what she describes as a "new American menu with a bent toward traditional cuisines of the Lower East Side: Eastern European Jewish, and Latino." The Essex Restaurant's recessed floor lighting on newly built mezzanines will share a building with $5 skirts and $10 dresses hanging over stalls.
But one neighborhood business leader said that the city still needed to work on the building's exterior. "It's like a fortress," Howard R. Slonim, president of the Lower East Side Business Improvement District, said of the long brick expanses. He suggested stretches of glass to make the interior "visible to passers-by."
Of the three other buildings that were part of the original market, one, at Stanton Street, has already been transformed into a satellite outpatient center run by NYU Downtown Hospital, which signed a 10-year lease for the building in 1995, after it had stood empty for many years.
The two remaining market sites, one vacated more than a decade ago while the other is nearly empty, are also the focus of recycling efforts. But the attempt to revive one of them shows that redevelopment in the city is rarely a cakewalk.
One of these buildings, at Rivington Street, was leased to Henry Rainge-Megill for 20 years. Mr. Rainge-Megill, who has owned and operated food shops and bars, was given the lease by the city two years ago to transform the building, then vacant, into food kiosks, a banquet hall, a cocktail lounge and a bakery and cafe. Now, however, the city is seeking to evict him, citing rent arrears.
Mr. Rainge-Megill said he had already put more than $1 million into the building, "including my life savings." He said he had overcome the financial problems that led to the arrears (including unanticipated major structural expenses and a partner who ran out of money) and could finance the remaining $500,000 worth of work.
But the city, he said, has refused to accept the late rent payments and has moved to evict him. And, he said, a city official had told him she believed he did "not have the financial wherewithal to do this project."
But Mr. Rainge-Megill is determined to keep his lease. "I'll go to the Supreme Court!" he said. Guiding a visitor through the building, he pointed to improvements like the newly reinforced foundation and new utility lines, windows and brickwork. "All my money is in here," Mr. Rainge-Megill, 63, said. "My ex-wife's annuity money is in here."
Bruce Brodoff, a spokesman for the city's Economic Development Corporation, which administers the market sites, declined to respond because the "matter is in litigation." He would say only that the rent arrears were the reason for the eviction and that if the agency won Mr. Rainge-Megill's ouster, it would seek new proposals for redeveloping the site.
The fourth building that was once part of the market stretches the full block from Broome to Delancey Streets and stands vacant except for a street-front liquor store and small diner. It has been included in a group of five sites in the area for which the city has invited developers to submit urban renewal proposals.
Although some of the remaining merchants in the Essex Street Market favor having upscale fellow vendors, others fear that this would cause their rents to soar. But Mr. Brodoff said, "Any upscale shops that might take space at the market will have no impact on the rents paid by the other tenants."
He said annual rents for the market's stalls now range from $22 to $25 a square foot. Faith Hope Consolo, vice chairman of the retail leasing firm of Garrick-Aug Associates, said that these compared with a going rate of $60 a square foot for stores on the broad thoroughfares of Essex and Delancey Streets, but were on par with store rents on Rivington, a side street.
Even at the cheaper rents, most of the Essex Street Market vendors have disappeared. But the memory has outlasted their booths. "The pickle section, pickles in a barrel," and their crunchy taste still remain sharp for Jeanne Oberhofer, 60, who as a child frequently accompanied her mother to the market. She now munches on her market memories in Kent, Wash., a Seattle suburb.
In the market's early years, "the shopkeepers were all Jewish and Italian and the customers were mostly Jewish and Italian," recalled Allen Ruhalter, a butcher whose business, begun by his father, is the market's only survivor from its opening day. Most of the market's patrons today are Hispanic and Asian.
Mr. Ruhalter, 68, who began working at the family's meat counter while in junior high school in the mid-1940's, recalled that his schoolboy start as a market meat merchant required a contribution from the dairy stalls. "I was so small, I had to stand on a milk crate to look over the counter," he said.
He also recalled that the carcasses of the chickens sold in the market then "were still warm when they were brought in" by the supplier, and still had their heads, feet and feathers. Plucker was a job category in the market then.
Mr. Ruhalter's son, Jeffrey, 44, who also works in the operation, looked to the market's future. While his father said that their business "goes up and down, but over all it's profitable," Jeffrey Ruhalter said that business was less than in the past, and he put himself with those market merchants and other local business people who favor an upscale turn.
"I'd like it upscale to attract the people moving into the neighborhood," he said of the affluent young arrivals who in the last few years have moved into expensive apartments in renovated tenements. Their presence is signaled by the clubs, restaurants and boutiques that have sprung up on nearby Orchard and Ludlow Streets.
It is also reflected in the $1 million renovation that is transforming Ratner's, the nearly century-old landmark on Delancey Street, from a kosher dairy restaurant to a place where the dinner menu will be bereft of blintzes and barley soup. Instead, diners will feast on steaks and chops in a sophisticated setting when it reopens in two to three months.
Andrew Flamm, executive director of the Lower East Side Business Improvement District, said that the Essex Street Market already offered "fine meats, produce and fish" and that his group wanted to see "more quality food and food-related products," but only to fill vacancies and not at the expense of the current merchants.
But some of those merchants are still worried that an upgraded market could lead to higher rents that would drive them out the stalls.
Low-priced shirts and jeans hang over the entrance to the cramped nook of Juan Vargas and his wife, Carmen Salvador. "If they raise the rent, we have to raise the prices," Mr. Vargas said. "The people who shop here are medium and low income and don't want to pay too much, so there will be no business."
Jose Rivera, who has sold milk, eggs and other dairy items in the market for 15 years, said that "everyone's concerned" about rent rises.
"If it goes up, I leave," he said.
But Mr. Brodoff, the spokesman for the Economic Development Corporation, emphasized that the agency was trying to keep the current merchants viable, even as it was "continually working on improving the market."
"It's not a Tiffany's," he said. "But it's not a street cart."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Religious Organizations Seeking Radio Licenses
For months, Republicans in Congress have sought to block a Federal Communications Commission program to license hundreds of new low-power radio stations. About half of the first batch of applications are from religious organizations, mostly the sorts of fundamentalist churches active in conservative, Republican politics.
Hundreds of evangelical churches are asking for space on the airwaves to spread the Gospel. Some simply want to read Scripture verbatim; others want to preach against abortion. They will not get the chance, however, if the Republican Congressional leadership gets its way. Page A1. 

The Demise of a Celebrity Charity
After seven years, the writer Tom Clancy is scuttling a foundation that he set up to help children who had cancer and other grave illnesses use the Internet to talk with one another and learn about their diseases. Despite spending more than $5 million on travel, salaries, fund-raising and furniture, the foundation did not even have a Web site to show for its efforts. The legal fight that has broken out over the collapse of the foundation offers a rare glimpse at the inner workings of a celebrity charity. A1.
 
Alcoa Profit Beats Forecasts
Alcoa said that its second-quarter profit rose 57 percent, beating Wall Street forecasts by two cents, as aluminum prices rose and productivity improved. Revenue rose 38 percent, to $5.62 billion. Shares of Alcoa increased 7 percent, or $2.0625, to $29.6875. They had dropped 33 percent this year. C25.
 
Dow Rises as Other Gauges Decline
Stocks ended mixed in subdued trading, with blue chips pulling ahead and technology issues slipping. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 10.60 points, or 0.10 percent, to 10,646.58. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 42.91 points, or 1.1 percent, to 3,980.29, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.28 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,475.62. C12.
 
President to Establish Fuel Reserve
Reacting to widespread concern over climbing heating oil prices and low inventories, President Clinton announced a plan to establish a fuel reserve for the Northeast, where most of the country's heating oil is consumed. C2.
 
ICO-Teledesic Receives $300 Million
ICO-Teledesic Global Limited, the satellite telecommunications venture controlled by Craig O. McCaw, said it had received commitments for nearly $300 million from influential investors, including William H. Gates, chairman of Microsoft, and the private investment firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice. C14.
 
Honeywell Issues Earnings Warning
Honeywell International warned that its second-quarter profit would be 75 cents a share, about 3 cents less than it had predicted earlier this year. Honeywell also lowered its earnings estimates for the full year and for 2001. C8.
 
U.S. Sues Toysmart.com Over Data
The Federal Trade Commission sued to prevent toysmart.com, a bankrupt Internet toy retailer, from selling its database of customer information, asserting the company had assured hundreds of thousands of online visitors their personal data would never be shared with a third party. C2.
 
Chilly Reception to EADS Offering
The European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, or EADS as the new conglomerate that controls Airbus Industrie is known, received a chilly response from investors in its long-awaited initial stock offering as shares dropped more than 9 percent. Philippe Camus, a co-chief executive, responded by saying: "You must be humble with the market. The market indicated to us the price it was ready to pay. End of story." C4.
 
Deutsche Telekom Seeks a Partner
Deutsche Telekom of Germany, which is seeking an American partner, has made overtures to VoiceStream Wireless, a person close to the companies said. C4.

HEADLINE: Speaking to Governors, Clinton Sounds Conciliatory Note

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, July 10

 BODY:
President Clinton toned down his partisan, "Al Gore for President" pronouncements today at the National Governors' Association summer conference, knowing that more than half the governors in the room had a very different take on the coming election.
Instead, in what he described as a "make-a-deal speech," Mr. Clinton argued before the bipartisan audience that the two parties could still make progress on a variety of issues -- like Medicare prescription drug coverage and an increase in the minimum wage -- if they toned down all the pre-election sparring. 
 But Mr. Clinton still made the case, without explicitly naming names, that large tax cuts like those proposed by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas would endanger the longest economic expansion in the nation's history.
"I think we've got to keep the economy going by hewing to the same principles of fiscal discipline that got us where we are," Mr. Clinton told the governors in State College, Pa. "And that means I think whatever combination of spending and tax cuts any candidate for any office proposes, there ought to be enough left over to get us out of debt over the next dozen years."
Among those in the audience were Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania, a Republican who has been mentioned as a top vice presidential prospect for Mr. Bush.
In an interview, Mr. Ridge said he appreciated the president's "very conciliatory tone," but disagreed vigorously with Mr. Clinton on which economic plan of those proposed by Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore was more sound.
"As he was speaking I was thinking of George Bush's 'Prosperity With a Purpose' plan," Mr. Ridge said.
Mr. Clinton turned up his partisan tone later at a fund-raising speech in Philadelphia for Representative Ron Klink, who is running for Senate against Senator Rick Santorum.
The president condemned Republican lawmakers for failing to endorse some blacks and Hispanics that he has nominated for federal judgeships, and he accused Republicans of ignoring the poor and elderly.
But as he spoke to the governors association, the group that helped catapult him into White House, Mr. Clinton was clearly pulling his punches.
"I know all the press coverage is always on the fights that we have, but let me tell you, we actually agree on things every now and then in Washington," Mr. Clinton said. "And there are a lot of things we could do in the next six months."
Mr. Clinton added: "I ask you to help ensure an election season that is positive, open and vigorous about the real and honest differences, but devoid of the poison that has too often clouded the judgment of everybody involved in the public process."
Even as he offered his views, Mr. Clinton acknowledged that his thoughts mattered far less in these waning days of his presidency. He said his opinions plus a quarter "will get you half a soda pop."

HEADLINE: Mrs. Clinton Seeks New Formula for State Medicaid Financing

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

DATELINE: COLONIE, N.Y., July 10

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton continued her focus on economic issues today as she called for a new formula to calculate the amount of money New York receives from the federal government for Medicaid expenditures. Her formula, she said, could cut residents' taxes by an average of $400 a year.
Mrs. Clinton, who made the recommendations in a speech to about 100 people at an American Legion hall in this Albany suburb, said that the current formula reimbursed New York at the lowest rate of federal subsidy for Medicaid. Since New York's counties share the cost of Medicaid with the state, the change she proposes would provide the state with about $3 billion a year, she said. 
 Her proposal is similar to recommendations made by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the man she hopes to succeed. The difference, Mrs. Clinton said, is that an expected increase in the federal budget surplus would make her plan more palatable politically, with the increased subsidy coming from those funds.
"Now, because of the surplus, we can present this choice," Mrs. Clinton said. "And I think we have a better chance than we've ever had to create a coalition that would enable us to pass this."
The proposal came at the end of a five-day campaign tour that has taken Mrs. Clinton to a dozen communities from western New York to the Albany area. As she has done frequently during the tour, Mrs. Clinton told the audience that her most pressing priority, if she is elected senator, will be to work to stimulate the economy of upstate New York.
The plan being pushed by Mrs. Clinton would use a formula that largely takes into account the percentage of the population classified as living in poverty. Under the current system, Medicaid reimbursement is determined by the state's per capita income.
The current method, Mrs. Clinton said, means that the federal government covers about 50 percent of New York's Medicaid expenses, while other states receive more than 60 percent.
Mrs. Clinton said that her proposal was likely to be viewed skeptically by Republicans in Congress. "Obviously I'm in an election, so people on the other side of the aisle will probably come out against it within 10 or 15 minutes, if not sooner, because they don't want me to present an idea that sounds like a good idea," she said.
"But I think it could provide a way out of the dilemma we've been in," she added. "We couldn't have presented it too much earlier because we didn't have the projected surpluses that would have provided the funding for it."
In addressing other economic issues, Mrs. Clinton again discussed her interest in bringing better airline service and lower fares, as well as lower utility rates, to upstate cities. She has also talked often about promoting tourism in upstate New York.
While she has offered few specifics on many of the items in her plan, she has nonetheless made economic issues the centerpiece of this campaign trip. At every stop, her staff has distributed brochures with the headline, "Hillary's Upstate Economic Agenda."

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Trying To Be Upbeat On the Talks In Maryland

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10

 BODY:
Stunned by the political drama in Israel, the Clinton administration tried today to put the best face on prospects for the Camp David summit meeting despite Prime Minister Ehud Barak's weakened position. The administration said Mr. Barak still had sufficient popular support to reach an agreement with the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, and sell it back home.
President Clinton, who called the summit meeting after a series of requests by Mr. Barak, praised Mr. Arafat and Mr. Barak as leaders who had the "vision, the knowledge, the experience and the ability and the sheer guts to do what it takes." 
 Even so, the administration had not expected that Mr. Barak would arrive for the summit meeting's start on Tuesday depending for his political survival on the parliamentary votes of Communist and Arab parties. There was also surprise among officials here that Foreign Minister David Levy, apparently piqued at not being included in the prime minister's inner circle, refused to make the trip.
The slide in Mr. Barak's fortunes occurred as administration officials packed their bags to go to Camp David and the surrounding Maryland hills. Some officials added last-minute touches to talking points as the no-confidence vote unfolded in the Israeli Parliament. Much of the State Department's press operations moved to a school near Camp David.
There were preparations, too, to welcome Mr. Barak and Mr. Arafat and their teams of negotiators, limited to about 12 on each side. Mr. Barak was accompanied by, among others, Shlomo Ben-Ami, a popular Labor Party politician.
Mr. Arafat headed for Washington with a team that represents a wide spectrum of the Palestinian Authority's political thinking. His chief negotiator is Abu Ala, head of the Palestinian assembly in Ramallah and a veteran of the secret Oslo negotiations in 1993.
But almost all the focus today was on Mr. Barak, who was widely referred to as a top-flight soldier but a less than top-flight politician. Describing the reaction to Mr. Barak's tumultuous day in Jerusalem, one official said, "This was like lightning on a clear day."
Turning a seeming negative into a positive, a senior administration official argued that Mr. Barak's predicament "underscored that the prime minister is willing to take the political heat for moving forward." That would in turn let Mr. Clinton convince Mr. Arafat that the prime minister was the "best" Israeli leader with whom to deal, because few other politicians would be as willing to risk their position and offer compromises, the official said.
In pushing aside the perception of the prime minister's weakness as he arrived -- an expected 12 hours later than planned because of the no-confidence vote -- the official said the White House was firm in its view that Mr. Barak had the resolve to complete an agreement.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said this morning that Mr. Barak enjoyed the support of more than 55 percent of Israelis and would hence be able to go to the people with an agreement.
But Israeli opinion surveys are quite fickle, an administration official said, adding that it was a thin reed to hang the future of a yet-to-be-negotiated agreement on polling.
Diplomats in the region and Middle East experts appeared to be in consensus that the chances had diminished for an overall end-of-conflict accord that the White House would like. One experienced diplomat in the region said Mr. Barak would have to fight for the toughest terms he could, because any agreement would be portrayed as a sellout by the right wing in Israel. At the same time, the diplomat said, Mr. Arafat would see that the Israeli was "desperate" for an accord and would toughen his conditions.
The administration has left itself various possibilities for claiming success. In announcing the meeting last week, Mr. Clinton said he wanted an agreement on the "core issues" that have fueled the Israeli-Palestinian conflict for more than 50 years. But he also set a slightly lesser goal, saying the meeting would be where the two leaders would "start drawing the contours of the long-awaited peace," a phrase that seemed to indicate that a deal on some general principles might also be enough.
Mr. Clinton is scheduled to leave for Okinawa, Japan, on July 19 for a summit meeting in of leading industrial economies. He said today he did not want to set an "artificial deadline" for the talks.
