HEADLINE: METRO BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:

 
NEW YORK
 
MANHATTAN: PARK ROBBERY SUSPECT -- A suspect in five robberies at gunpoint in Central Park was arrested Sunday evening after a chess player in the park recognized him from a wanted poster, the police said yesterday. The suspect, Reinaldo Joseph, 38, of Brooklyn, was charged with robbery and criminal possession of a weapon in connection with three robberies in the park since April. Investigators said Mr. Joseph was the leading suspect in two other robberies as well. In all the robberies, women in their 20's were approached by a man with a gun as they walked in the park. Kevin Flynn (NYT) 

YONKERS: HOSPITAL CONTRACTS -- New York's largest health care union canceled picketing scheduled for yesterday at two hospitals in Yonkers, St. John's Riverside and Yonkers General, after negotiating its first contract with them. The contract covers nearly 1,000 workers and raises the salaries and benefits of registered nurses and others to the levels of their New York City counterparts. The contract, negotiated by 1199, New York's Health and Human Service Union, raises wages for the lowest-paid workers to $12.86 an hour from $7.75 over four years. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)
 
MANHATTAN: BOND RATING RAISED -- Standard & Poor's, the Wall Street rating agency, raised its credit rating for the New York State Thruway Authority's bonds to AA- from A yesterday, noting that the state is dedicating more revenues to the trust fund that backs the bonds. The authority is selling $458 million in bonds, and under the state's new transportation capital program, it plans to spend more than $17 billion over the next five years on highway and bridge construction, railroad and aviation projects, and maintenance. Leslie Eaton (NYT)
 
BETHLEHEM: MUDSLIDE AID -- The state will provide grants to help businesses hurt by a mudslide in Albany County in May, Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday. The Bethlehem Landslide Disaster Recovery Program will provide up to $5,000 to businesses suffering economic losses from a mudslide along the Normanskill Creek. Businesses claiming complete loss of property will be eligible for up to $100,000 in state aid. The money will come from the $55 million Community Development Block Grant program. (AP)
 
MANHATTAN: "IRAN 10" PROTEST -- Elie Wiesel, the Nobel Peace Prize laureate, left, and Richard C. Holbrooke, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, joined a group of New York politicians at a rally near the United Nations yesterday calling for the immediate release of the so-called Iran 10, the 10 Jewish men sentenced to prison on espionage charges in Iran after a long, closed trial. "We must allow our anger to speak," Mr. Wiesel said. (AP)
 
SYRACUSE: FRATERNITY LAWSUIT -- A federal judge has ruled that Hamilton College did not violate antitrust laws by requiring students to live on campus and not in fraternity houses. Judge Norman Mordue of United States District Court found that "there is no genuine issue as to any material fact" in the 1995 antitrust case, and ordered that it be dismissed in a decision rendered on June 29. The fraternities sued the college in Clinton under the Sherman Antitrust Act, arguing that the college was a monopolist in providing services to students. (AP)
 
EXTRADITION HEARING AWAITED -- Kathryn Gannon, a former star of X-rated films who is wanted in the United States on insider trading charges, will wait two more weeks to learn the date of her extradition hearing. Ms. Gannon, 31, appeared briefly in a court in Vancouver, British Columbia, yesterday as her lawyer asked for a delay in the hearing on whether she will be sent to New York to stand trial. Justice Patrick Dohm scheduled a July 25 court appearance. Ms. Gannon, known as Marylin Star in X-rated movies and publications, was arrested in May. She was charged in December along with James McDermott Jr., the former chief executive of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods. (AP)
 
NEW JERSEY
 
GALLOWAY TOWNSHIP: IDENTIFICATION SOUGHT -- The police say they are asking for help in identifying a woman who has been comatose since she attempted suicide on June 29 at a Days Inn in Galloway Township, outside Atlantic City. The woman is black, 5 feet 5 inches tall, about 250 pounds and thought to be in her 40's or 50's. The police said she has a one-inch lesion above her left eyebrow and a scar under her chin. A Bible, bifocal glasses and clothing with the label "Teddi" were found in her room. She carried a bus schedule for a route from New York City to Cape May. Laura Mansnerus (NYT)
 
PLAINFIELD: 3 INJURED IN FIRE -- A firefighter and two other people sustained minor injuries yesterday morning in a fire at a Plainfield rooming house. The injured were being treated for smoke inhalation and respiratory problems, the authorities said. Deputy Fire Chief Paul Newborn said the blaze, reported about 2:05 a.m., began in the basement of the home at 219 East Fifth Street. Authorities would not comment on whether the fire was considered suspicious. (AP)
 
CONNECTICUT
 
BRISTOL: NEW PARK RULES AFTER DROWNING -- Lake Compounce, the amusement park in Bristol, has tightened safety regulations for a popular water slide after the drowning of a 6-year-old boy who met the ride's height requirement but could not swim. On July 1, the boy, Devon M. Alexander of Hartford, slipped off the inner tube that he had ridden down the 375-foot-long slide and spent 25 minutes underwater before lifeguards found him. He died on Friday. Under the tighter rules, life jackets will be required for children between 46 inches and 56 inches tall. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)
 
HARTFORD: BLOOD SUPPLY CRISIS -- Connecticut has a blood emergency, Red Cross officials said. While no elective surgery has been canceled because of the shortage, patient transfusions may be jeopardized if the blood supply continues to fall, said Dr. Richard Cable, acting executive director of the Connecticut Region of the American Red Cross. Red Cross officials said Sunday that 1,746 donors were needed for three-day supply of blood. Theresa Crapanzano (NYT)

HEADLINE: Moment of Truth on Tough Issues

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10

 BODY:
When President Clinton announced the Camp David summit meeting, he said he hoped that it would resolve the deepest matters dividing the Israelis and Palestinians, questions of "beliefs, political identity, collective fate" that raise dark fears and emotions. He also sounded a note of weary familiarity, saying that the issues were so well-known that the solutions should be within sight.
As the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, begin their final peace talks with Mr. Clinton, they are expected to test how far apart they are on the future status of Jerusalem, the fate of more than three million Palestinian refugees and the borders of a Palestinian state. 
 What is intertwined with these overarching issues is the question of how many Israeli settlers on the West Bank would remain in Israeli territory and how many would come under Palestinian rule and then, most likely, be resettled in Israel. The future of the Jordan Valley will also be on the table.
International financial assistance is likely to be discussed, including an American component, to compensate refugees but also to help form a new Palestinian state. Separately, the Israelis are seeking an upgraded security relationship with the United States, though one that falls short of a mutual defense pact.
The American team, led by Mr. Clinton, has not said whether it will work on all the issues at once or single out those where the most progress can be made. Nor has it signaled whether it will present precise American ideas -- known in negotiating parlance as "bridging proposals" -- for all the issues or just for some.
Since the former Israeli prime minister, Yitzhak Rabin, and Mr. Arafat agreed in principle seven years ago on a peace settlement in which Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization recognized each other, these crucial issues have been kicked down the road for a final round of talks designed to formally end the more than five-decade conflict.
The 1993 agreement, which was negotiated in Oslo and signed on the White House lawn, called for the two sides to make a final settlement by May 4, 1999.
That deadline was extended last September -- in an agreement at Sharm el Sheik, Egypt -- to Sept. 13, 2000, the date Mr. Arafat has set for unilaterally declaring a Palestinian state if there is no final peace accord.
Since Oslo, the Israelis have withdrawn from the Gaza Strip and about 40 percent of the West Bank. These moves were carried out after wrenching negotiations for interim accords, including one in 1998 at Wye, Md., where Mr. Clinton mediated between Mr. Arafat and the conservative Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu.
Now that the two sides have been called to the endgame on the hitherto too-tough-to-deal-with issues, the differences appear acute on every front. A senior American official said that in on-and-off talks over the last seven months, including back-channel negotiations in Stockholm, the two sides had "demythologized" the issues. But he said that gaps had been narrowed only in some areas. And that small progress, he said, was beginning to be eroded by bitterness in the last month.

Jerusalem
 The question on which the least progress has been made, according to all participants in the negotiations, is Jerusalem. In Stockholm, there was a little bit of "brainstorming" on Jerusalem, but "brainstorming is cheap," said an official familiar with the talks. A senior Israeli official said here last week that it was possible that agreement would be reached on several major points but that an agreement on Jerusalem was much more unlikely.
The heart and soul of the Israeli position is still that Jerusalem is the undivided and eternal capital of Israel, the official said.
In contrast, Mr. Arafat said last month that he remained insistent that East Jerusalem become the capital of a Palestinian state. Those who disagreed, he scoffed, could "go and drink from the Dead Sea." Mr. Arafat, his aides say, will not give up on Jerusalem.
Israeli officials have suggested that Mr. Barak is considering granting increased autonomy to Palestinians in East Jerusalem -- specifically, more control of public services.
A 1995 document by Yossi Beilin, now Israeli justice minister, and Abu Mazen, secretary of the Palestine Liberation Organization, had compromises on a range of issues, but, showing how tough the issue is, not on whose capital the city would be.
Published versions of the document, known as the Beilin-Mazen agreement, outline compromises on all the major issues in the Palestinian-Israeli conflict and components of it are being revived as the talks open. One version of the document says the boundaries of greater Jerusalem would be expanded to encompass Palestinian districts, including the towns of Abu Dis, Al Ayzariyan and Salwan. The Palestinian Authority would create a capital in these new districts and call it Al Quds and not Jerusalem.
For the estimated 200,000 Arabs who live in Jerusalem, a municipal council would be formed to manage local affairs under the supervision of the Israeli council that is now responsible for the whole city. And the Palestinian flag would be flown from the Islamic holy sites.
In essence, because the plan does not recognize Palestinian sovereignty over East Jerusalem, it has been dismissed by Arab diplomats as the "Jewish solution." It seemed impossible, they said, that Mr. Arafat would be able to live with what would amount to only linguistic niceties, such as Palestinian "autonomy" in East Jerusalem.
Administration officials, as well as Israelis and Palestinians, have said that if the Camp David sessions get as far as tackling Jerusalem, the compromises necessary on both sides will be so substantial that the talks could break down at that point. In the days before the meeting, there have been increasing suggestions that the White House might have to settle for an agreement that would leave decisions on Jerusalem for another day.
But some officials have said that in an overall package there could be the possibility of both sides moving to fall-back positions on Jerusalem in return for a final agreement that ended all claims by either side.

Territory
 On the question of territory -- how much and where the Israelis will give up land on the West Bank -- there appears to have been some behind-the-scenes movement. Indeed, both Israelis and Palestinians say this has been where there has been the most progress.
Mr. Arafat and his aides have repeatedly declared that Israel must withdraw from the West Bank and Gaza to the borders that existed before the 1967 war, in accordance with the United Nations Resolution 242. Part of Mr. Arafat's insistence is based on what he calls the precedent laid down by Israel in its peace deals with Egypt in 1979, when 100 percent of Sinai was yielded, and in Jordan in 1994, when Israel exchanged some land with Jordan to compensate for land taken by Israel decades before along their joint border.
But in private, the Palestinian leader has acknowledged to American officials that large Israeli settlements on the West Bank are certain to be annexed by Israel in a final deal. In return for such a concession, Mr. Arafat contends that Israel must "swap" some Israeli land to be included in the new Palestinian state. Mr. Barak's advisers are reported to be divided on this issue.
Israeli officials said that Mr. Barak opposes swapping land because it would encroach on the notion of Israeli sovereignty.
So far, the Israelis have not been precise on the amount of territory they are prepared to give up on the West Bank. The Israeli press has reported that between 90 and 92 percent would be ceded -- much more than the 60 or 75 percent that had been generally thought. The Barak government has not officially acknowledged that it is considering these higher figures, though.
A senior Israeli official said that land with about 70 percent of the 175,000 settlers would be annexed to Israel. The future of the remaining settlers -- those in outlying areas or scattered settlements -- would have to be negotiated.
These settlers, according to preliminary discussions, would have a choice of taking Palestinian citizenship -- a highly unlikely choice -- or of being moved back to Israel. The Israelis are insisting on no "arbitrary" dismantling of settlements.

Refugees
 In many respects, the negotiators believe that the future of more than three million Palestinian refugees, most of whom either left Israel after the 1948 Arab-Israeli war or are their descendants, may be the easiest problem to solve. About a million are in camps run by international agencies in Lebanon, Syria, Jordan, Gaza and the West Bank.
The mantra of the Palestinian Authority has been that these refugees must have the right to return to Israel and that Israel must accept responsibility for the fact they fled or were expelled. Israel says it refuses to accept responsibility and will not acknowledge the right of return but will show "empathy" for the refugees, said a special adviser to Mr. Barak, Yossi Alpher.
The Barak government is prepared, Mr. Alpher says, as a "humanitarian gesture," to allow some family reunification.
Palestinian officials faced with budgetary and space limitations on how many refugees they want to take into their new state could be willing to go along with a concept that grants the right of return in principle but stops short of actually carrying it out, officials said.
About 2.7 million Palestinians live on the West Bank and Gaza, and United Nations officials estimate the Palestinian Authority would accept the return of up to 500,000 refugees phased over a number of years.
A sizable international aid package spread over 20 years has been suggested for compensating the refugees and the governments that have been hosts to them. Japan, the European Union and the United States would be the major contributors.

Other Issues
 On the future of the Jordan Valley, the Israelis officially assert that the area will remain Israel's security border but that the security presence may be phased out over a period of time. While the eventual loss of the Jordan Valley is not popular in Israel, it is not nearly as sensitive an issue as Jerusalem.
For Mr. Barak, particularly in his precarious political situation, the size of the American aid package and the upgrading of the security relationship are of utmost importance. Part of his ability to sell a peace deal in general elections would depend on how much he was able to bring home from Washington in terms of new weaponry and radar capable of detecting missiles.
Similarly, Mr. Arafat is expecting financial aid from the United States, as well as Japan and the European Union. Mr. Arafat's chief economic adviser, Mohammed Rachid, said the Palestinians would ask the Americans for $40 billion, much of it for refugee assistance.

A chart on Tuesday listing issues to be discussed in the Middle East peace talks at Camp David referred incorrectly to Resolution 242 of the United Nations Security Council, which was approved after the Middle East war of 1967. It calls for the withdrawal of Israeli armed forces "from territories occupied in the recent conflict"; it is the Palestinians who associate that language with the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "On the Table at Camp David"
The summit meeting that begins today is intended to resolve the most difficult issues in the Palestinian-Israeli peace effort that began with secret talks in Oslo in 1993. In the Declaration of Principles signed in Washington later that year, Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization agreed to recognize each other and set in motion a series of moves toward, but stopping short of, the establishment of a Palestinian state. These have included Israeli withdrawal from parts of the West Bank and Gaza and limited Palestinian autonomy.
 
The 1993 accord called for final settlement of the most contentious issues by May 1999. That deadline has been extended to Sept. 13, 2000, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, has said he would unilaterally declare a Palestinian state on that date if negotiations fail.
 
The Major Issues
EAST JERUSALEM: Israel, which annexed East Jerusalem in 1967, claims all of Jerusalem as its capital. The Palestinians are demanding that East Jerusalem become the capital of their future state.
 
TERRITORY: The Palestinians want a settlement based on United Nations Resolution 242, which calls for an end to Israeli occupation of the entire West Bank and Gaza, seized in the 1967 war. Israel rejects a return to the prewar borders, and seeks a permanent security presence along the Jordan River border between the West Bank and Jordan.
 
JEWISH SETTLEMENTS: The Palestinians say Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza must be dismantled or transferred to Palestinian control. Israel wants to annex major settlements near its present borders, but has indicated willingness to evacuate isolated settlements or negotiate a new status for them under Palestinian rule.
 
PALESTINIAN REFUGEES: The Palestinians demand a right of return to present-day Israel for Arabs who fled when the Jewish state was established in 1948. Israel objects to these refugees returning to Israel but has considered compensation for those who lost property.

HEADLINE: Research Predicts Summer Doom for Northern Icecap

BYLINE: By WALTER GIBBS 

DATELINE: OSLO, July 10

 BODY:
The mythic ice scape that stretches south in all directions from the North Pole is melting so fast that Norwegian scientists say it could disappear entirely each summer beginning in just 50 years, radically altering the Earth's environment, the global economy and the human imagination.
Climatologists have warned for a decade that the northern icecap is retreating. But researchers at the University of Bergen's Nansen Environmental and Remote Sensing Center are apparently the first to predict the disorienting specter of a watery North Pole open to cruise ships and the Polar Bear Swim Club within the lives of today's young people. 
 "The changes we've seen have been much faster and more dramatic than most people imagine," said Tore Furevik, 31, a polar researcher and co-author of the article "Toward an Ice-Free Arctic?" in the latest issue of the Norwegian science journal Cicerone.
Not all ice specialists agree with Mr. Furevik, but his 50-year projection is supported by the director of the Bergen research center, Prof. Ola M. Johannessen, whose own study will appear in the fall issue of Science Progress, a British journal.
Professor Johannessen, 61, said the receding and thinning of Arctic sea ice have outstripped the theoretical effect of global warming from greenhouse gases by a factor of three. "The greenhouse is here, no doubt about it, but there is more to it," he said, speculating that a conjunction of long-term oscillations in North Atlantic air pressure have hastened the melting. If so, he said, the cycles will eventually decouple and the ice, or what is left of it, could regain stability.
Since 1978, the coverage of Arctic sea ice in winter has decreased by 6 percent, equivalent to an area the size of Texas, according to satellite pictures. As for average ice thickness in late summer, submarine sonar measurements since the 1950's have shown a decline to 5.9 feet from 10.2 feet, or 42 percent. The Norwegian researchers' prediction of zero ice in a half-century is based partly on extrapolation of the submarine data and partly on Professor Johannessen's discovery last year that hard-core, year-round ice is shrinking twice as fast as the overall winter perimeter.
While an ice-free Arctic Ocean would most likely disrupt the global environment, researchers said, it could have positive economic aspects. It could shorten shipping routes, for example, and expand the range of offshore oil drillers. Rich new fishing areas would probably appear, though established fisheries to the south could decline.
Dr. Drew Rothrock, a University of Washington oceanographer, said he agreed that Arctic sea ice was on a trajectory to disappear in 50 years. But, he added, that did not mean it would. The ice is being expelled from the Arctic by abnormally strong winds before it could achieve its accustomed thickness, he said, and that could be a temporary phenomenon.
"I think it is quite possible that in the next 10 years we will see the winds revert to a more historical pattern, so that the ice begins to reside longer in the Arctic and thicken up again," he said. "I would be cautious about predicting doom."
Unlike the ice in a pond, Arctic sea ice consists of independent floes of varying age that join together, pull apart or pile up on one another in reaction to wind and currents. In winter, it extends as far south as Hudson Bay in Canada. By late summer it pulls back to the roughly circular Arctic basin.
The seeming permanence and impregnability of the northern icescape have given it almost continental status in the human imagination. As a mythic anchor point, the North Pole, home of Santa Claus, has few geographic rivals.
"The North Pole is the strongest symbol of mankind's struggle against, and with, nature," said the Norwegian adventurer Boerge Ousland, the first man to ski there alone without aerial reprovisioning, in 1994. "If the ice disappears, well, I just can't imagine it."
The sea ice is thickest above North America, where Canadian islands and the fingers of northern Greenland act as a sieve in the current. As the floes stack up there, they create pressure ridges up to 40 feet high. By contrast, a branch of the warm-water Gulf Stream keeps Norway's north coast ice-free. That warm flow continues under the ice along most of the northern Siberian coast.
If the trend continues, it is there, the Eurasian Arctic, that the first significant opening of ice-clogged water is expected. Russia, Scandinavia and Japan are laying plans. Government ministers and shipping executives met in Oslo last fall and declared that "considerable profit potential" existed for a proposed shipping lane linking Western Europe and Asia across the mellowing Arctic. The Northern Sea Route is a centuries-old dream comparable to that of the Northwest Passage of Canada, which is even more solidly frozen.
Ships using the Arctic to move cargo from Hamburg, Germany, to Yokohama, Japan, would save about 4,800 miles compared with the usual route through the Suez Canal. Current traffic is limited to the Russian Navy and a handful of heavily subsidized nickel ore carriers escorted by nuclear-powered icebreakers. But receding ice could open the way for a parade of cargo vessels and oil tankers, shipping industry experts said.
A proponent of the shortcut is Ivan Ivanov, leader of an Arctic shipping demonstration project carried out by Finland's Fortum energy company with financing from the European Commission. Citing what he called official Russian estimates, he said the Russian Arctic shelf contained three times the oil of Saudi Arabia.
The vision of an industrialized Arctic Ocean alarms environmentalists, who see the dwindling of ice as a disaster. They said the loss of white surface area would cause the Arctic to reflect less of the sun's energy, accelerating the warming. On the other hand, open water makes a better "sink" for absorbing atmospheric greenhouse gases.
Thus, according to one model, an ice-free Arctic Ocean could do as much to slow global warming as the melting did to stimulate it. Yet even a modest change in Arctic dynamics could have wrenching effects elsewhere. If the changes divert the Gulf Stream, Professor Johannessen said, much of Western Europe could be plunged into an ice age.
One sure thing is that melting sea ice cannot be implicated in the coastal flooding that many global warming models have projected. Just as melting ice cubes do not cause a glass of water to overflow, melting sea ice does not increase oceanic volume. Any future rise in sea level would result from glaciers melting on land, of which there has been little evidence to date.
Another sure thing is that the polar bear and other creatures face a bleak future if their habitat keeps liquefying. So do Eskimo populations that hunt game like seal and walrus. Alan Springer, a wildlife specialist at the University of Alaska in Fairbanks, said Alaska's 250,000 walruses seem to have suffered weight loss and stress from retraction of the pack ice they need for resting and raising pups.
"The sea ice in summer has been receding so far north that it carries the walruses into very deep water, far from their optimal feeding ground," Dr. Springer said.
Mr. Furevik, the Norwegian researcher, said he could foresee ice-dwelling mammals making "a desperate last stand" north of Greenland, where he believes the final patch of Arctic sea ice will linger before vanishing into the waves in about 2050.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
The direct marketing industry hopes to get Internet retailers to see things in an old light.

BYLINE: By Bernard Stamler 

 BODY:
Ask anyone in the direct response industry to describe e-commerce, and you're bound to get the same response: Internet retailing is simply another kind of direct marketing, not fundamentally different from the catalog and club businesses that have long made their money selling directly to consumers.
But, at least until recently, many online sellers did not agree. When making advertising decisions, they viewed theirs as a business apart, a totally new endeavor with new rules or, more accurately, no rules. And with little direct marketing experience of their own, few paid attention to the lessons of an industry that long ago learned to choose its media carefully and to control the costs of acquiring customers. 
 "Call it naivete or Silicon Valley arrogance," said Jim Nail, an analyst with Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass., who specializes in online marketing and advertising. Either way, the result was the same: online retailers spent lavishly on general advertising, often paying full price for print and broadcast ads while eschewing cheaper and often more effective direct response advertising. Their focus was on "branding," and on the hope that getting themselves known would be enough to garner customers and win the good will of Wall Street.
But branding is not sufficient by itself to generate sales, Mr. Nail said: "All it does is implant an idea in the consumer's head." To get actual customers, he said, "you have to target your advertising to high-quality prospects, measure the value of your customers and constantly use your data to fine-tune your strategy." In short, "you need direct marketing."
Of course, it is hardly surprising that this is the view of H. Robert Wientzen, president of the Direct Marketing Association. He is not surprised that branding alone has yielded e-tailers too few customers at too high a cost. Indeed, he and other direct marketing industry members used to scratch their heads, he said, and wonder just how long such a mistaken strategy could last.
Not very long, as it happens. The Internet bubble has burst. Wall Street is less interested in branding than in bottom-line profitability, the kind that few online retailers can demonstrate. Many Internet sellers are watching their colleagues and competitors go belly-up, and are realizing that they, too, may soon be in trouble. And they are turning to direct marketers -- and direct response agencies -- for help, said Robert Johnston, president of the New York eCommerce Association, an industry trade group whose members include software companies, Internet service providers and a number of Internet retailers.
"For e-tailers," he said, "the trend of the future is direct marketing."
"Basically, I think that what the Internet has done is that it has validated direct marketing," said Wendy Riches, president of D'Arcy Marketing Communications Group, a division of B Com3 Group. Her agency is among those that have recently seen a number of new e-tailer clients. So has MediaCom Digital, a division of Grey Global Group, according to its president, Harvey Goldhersz. And the trend is not limited to large shops; smaller boutique agencies like Iris Shokoff Associates, a direct media buyer, are also benefiting.
What do they offer their new clients? "Accountability," Mr. Goldhersz said. Ms. Shokoff agreed. "Dot-coms need to find out just who is buying from them so they can target those people again," she said. "And they need to figure a way to get to new people, cheaply and efficiently, by using media wisely and by negotiating rates."
In the past, many Internet retailers did none of this. Indeed, if they measured at all, they limited their observations to what they could see online, generally doing little more than counting impressions -- that is, the number of people who saw their banners -- and clicks on a given site.
Hardly a coherent strategy, Ms. Riches scoffed. "Clicks alone mean nothing," she said. "It's not enough to bring a client to a Web site, you've got to get them to buy."
How badly were the e-retailers doing? Well, Ms. Shokoff said that she heard tales of Internet retailers spending as much as $5 to $50 to acquire each sale, even though direct marketers generally consider $10 or less a customer to be appropriate under most circumstances, according to Mr. Wientzen of the Direct Marketing Association. He said that he had heard of worse numbers, too, of Internet companies paying customer acquisition costs anywhere from $80 to $400 a customer. They would even brag of customer bases of perhaps 100,000, he added, a figure traditional direct marketers -- many of whom count their customers in the millions -- would generally consider to be unprofitably low.
Ms. Shokoff, Ms. Riches and Mr. Goldhersz all said that they could do better. They have techniques of measurement, or metrics, media buying resources and research capabilities that the Internet sellers do not, they said, not to mention years of experience in the field. But none would name specific Internet clients or give specific examples of how they were helping them, for fear of offending those that might be embarrassed by their prior missteps.
Nevertheless, Mr. Goldhersz did allow that his clients included companies like the Vitamin Shoppe and GoAmerica, a wireless Internet service provider. And he said that one of his clients -- not necessarily one of the two -- had suffered rather acutely from its ignorance of direct marketing before turning to his agency.
"They spent $14 or $15 million in the last quarter of last year, all of it on branding," he said.
"And nothing happened."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1578 words

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT: Taking at the Office Reaches New Heights;
Employee Larceny Is Bigger and Bolder

BYLINE: By GREG WINTER 

 BODY:
Clifton Richards was more than just a mailroom clerk. He tackled the phones, mastered new software and bought supplies at the Social Science Research Council, a nonprofit foundation where he worked in Manhattan. Always friendly, invariably dependable, he seemed to be a true asset, his co-workers say. He even dressed better than many of the staff, they say.
Then, $650,000 in checks turned up missing over three months, the foundation says, and the United States Postal Police were called in to investigate. In March, Mr. Richards was charged with bank fraud, accused of stealing 22 grant payments from the company's mail and pawning them off to an intermediary for pennies on the dollar. (Efforts to reach him or his lawyer for comment were unsuccessful.) 
 Now, the shaken managers of the foundation are setting up security protocols they never knew they needed. "It's analogous to what one would do when someone burglarizes your home," said Craig Calhoun, the president. "You change the locks; you put in a burglary system. But that doesn't mean you're invulnerable or can stop this from happening again."
Indeed, in enterprises of all sizes and shapes, from shoestring nonprofits to giant corporations, the scale of employee theft has soared. Spurred by the gold-rush mentality of the late 1990's, emboldened by technology and quick to prey on the loose financial controls at start-ups and small companies, workers at every rung of the corporate ladder are stealing more money than ever before, fraud examiners say.
Though it is unclear how much the number of incidents has grown, a 1998 survey of 5,000 businesses, government agencies and nonprofits calculated an average loss of $624,000 from check fraud by employees, including forgeries and mailroom theft, nearly twice the figure in a 1994 poll. The survey, by consultants for KPMG, the accounting firm, also found that the looting of company bank accounts by employees using A.T.M. cards had more than doubled, to an average of $300,000.
Theft and misuse of company credit cards by employees tripled, to an average loss of more than $1.1 million, from 1994 to 1998, the KPMG survey showed. And the average loss from employee expense account abuse grew to $141,000, nearly seven times what it was four years earlier.
Fraud investigators say these statistics only scratch the surface of a surge in workplace larceny. Anonymous surveys are one thing. But, fearful of bad publicity, companies are loath to report theft cases to law enforcement, masking a problem that has grown alongside the soaring economy.
"In the early 1980's, when I first started in this business, I was not a very busy person," said Toby Bishop, a partner in the fraud division at Arthur Andersen, the consulting firm. "Today, I can't handle all of what comes in the door."
When the Association of Certified Fraud Examiners, which is based in Austin, Tex., conducted one of the nation's first comprehensive studies on employee fraud in 1996, it reported that companies typically lost 6 percent of their annual revenues to such theft, roughly twice most earlier estimates.
Two years later, in a survey of 587 fraud examiners, nearly 70 percent said that fraud levels had increased since the initial report and that they expected the trend to continue.
Fraud examiners attribute much of the recent wave of office criminality to the stock market boom that has created hordes of overnight millionaires and stirred impatience with the occasional pay raise.
"You see the guy down the street who cashed in his stock options and is now worth a million dollars, and you're still making $30,000," said John Warren, general counsel of the fraud examiners' group. "It makes it easier to rationalize fraudulent behavior."
Then there is the widening gap between executive and worker compensation. Edward Wolff, an economics professor at New York University, says corporate chief executives made an average 400 times what their average employees did in 1998, up from a ratio of just 40 a decade earlier. The disparity in pay has fueled discontent and eroded loyalty to such a degree that stealing on the job is often seen as acceptable behavior, fraud investigators say.
"It used to be extremely rare that anyone would acknowledge theft taking place," said Jim Baker, founder and president of Baker Technologies Inc. in Rowlett, Tex., who has been investigating fraud for 30 years. "Now it's rare that we don't hear of someone knowing about it. People have a cavalier attitude. There's no shame attached to theft."
One consequence of the growth in such theft has been a large gain in the number of fraud investigators. Membership in the Association of Certified Fraud Examiners, the principal professional group, has increased to about 25,000 from about 8,200 in 1992.
"They see it as a growth industry," Mr. Warren, the general counsel, said.
Stealing often starts in the mailroom, a favorite haunt of unscrupulous employees, investigators say. "When you get a new employee, where do you stick them? The mailroom," said Patrick Casey, a federal postal inspector and spokesman for the postal police. "That's often the lowest-paying job in the corporation, yet a lot of the company's money goes through there. Criminals sometimes seek out those jobs because they realize they will have access to the ingoing and the outbound checks."
But workplace theft is costliest when committed by high-ranking employees, who tend to have the most access to funds. According to the fraud examiners' association, the median loss from crimes by managers is $250,000, four times that of crimes by employees. And the median loss from owners and executives is $1 million, 16 times that of their employees.
In some ways, workplace thieves have become easier to catch. Technology has expanded the arsenal of video cameras, decoys and other tools used by fraud investigators. But computers, modems and the Internet also offer employees new ways of tampering with financial records, transferring funds and covering their tracks.
"It's a double-edged sword," said Bill Olsen, the mid-Atlantic director for business fraud and investigation at Arthur Andersen. "With the same technology we're using to detect and deter fraud, there are people out there who are using it to commit crimes."
Many investigators also worry that a growing inattention to the issue is making it easier for employees to steal. As labor shortages threaten rapid growth, companies are becoming more likely to forgo thorough background checks so as to speed up hiring.
And with the pressure to post record earnings quarter after quarter, many businesses have cut back on departments like accounting and security that help detect theft but do not generate revenue. Start-ups, racing to post profits, are particularly short on checks and balances.
"Internal controls are still very much viewed as cost centers," said Richard H. Girgenti, director of investigations at KPMG. "What doesn't dawn on management is the connection between money spent on fraud protection and the bottom line."
Still, even the most elaborate safeguards can fail. The Social Science Research Council says, for example, that Mr. Richards came from an employee agency that professed to do background checks. The foundation itself has five accountants in a staff of just 50, an unusually high ratio, even in the private sector.
Mr. Richards has yet to stand trial on the federal charges. The complaint says that he admitted taking the checks and that a teller at Chase Manhattan Bank approved cashing them. Investigators say they suspect that the teller deposited the stolen checks in false accounts. The bank said it was looking into the matter and would reimburse the foundation if any wrongdoing was uncovered.
The foundation said it did not know anything was amiss until students who had been awarded research grants started calling from schools around the world, asking when the money would arrive. Then it took weeks to track down the source of the thefts.
"The scariest thing is that we kept watching it happen and it kept coming," said Kristine Dahlberg, the foundation's chief financial officer.
Inadequate staffing and an atmosphere of trust often make nonprofits susceptible to theft, but investigators say that most fraud still occurs at corporations, large and small, where money and opportunities for fraud abound.
Many regard the ever-increasing trend toward corporate mergers as a prime opportunity for white-collar criminals. "When merging with companies that have different profiles, management's eyes are off the ball," said David Sherwin, a partner with Ernst & Young who oversees the company's fraud surveys. "There is no real status quo anymore. The old benchmarks are no longer valid, so it becomes easy for fraud to go undetected."
Steve Albrecht, associate dean at the Marriott School of Management at Brigham Young University, says that in his consultations with national banks, he noticed fraud levels rising 33 percent a year from 1996 to 1998. As huge mergers become common and layoffs ensue, Mr. Albrecht said, employees cease to identify with the companies they work for, developing a sense of detachment that makes theft simpler to justify.
"Employees are not viewed as long-term investments; they're viewed as short-term assets that can be bought and sold," Mr. Albrecht said. "As a result, there's not the allegiance to the organization that there used to be."

HEADLINE: As Problems Mount, Colombia's President Shuffles His Cabinet

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 11

 BODY:
In an effort to revive the Colombian government's sharply declining political and economic fortunes, President Andres Pastrana replaced more than a third of his cabinet today, bringing in several figures associated with opposition parties in hopes of dampening their campaign to cripple his government.
The long-anticipated cabinet shuffle comes as the Clinton administration is poised to begin delivering an emergency $1.3 billion aid package, composed mostly of military assistance, to Colombia and neighboring countries. The money is intended to slow a huge increase in cocaine and heroin production and thereby weaken the finances of Marxist-Leninist guerrilla groups that have been fighting the Colombian government since the mid-1960's. 
 "This is a cabinet of national unity, of great openness," said Minister of the Interior Humberto de la Calle, himself a member of the opposition Liberal Party who took office barely three months ago. Of the 22 posts in the cabinet, slightly more than half are now held by members of Mr. Pastrana's Conservative Party, with the rest in the hands of Liberals and independents.
Nine changes were announced as a result of the the shakeup, which began Friday night with the resignation of Minister of Finance Juan Camilo Restrepo. Planning Director Mauricio Cardenas and Minister of Economic Development Jaime Cabal Sanclemente stepped down today, meaning that all three of the government's top economic leaders will be new.
The shuffle did not, though, affect the two officials who have the most contact with the United States and are most closely identified with the American aid package, part of a larger $7.5 billion counter-narcotics and social support program that Mr. Pastrana calls "Plan Colombia." Luis Fernando Ramirez Acuna remains as minister of defense, while Guillermo Fernandez de Soto continues in the foreign affairs portfolio.
But the composition of the restructured cabinet pitches the Pastrana government somewhat further to the left. The new minister of labor, Angelino Garzon, for instance, is a former president of the country's largest trade union federation and was also a vice president of the Patriotic Union, a leftist political coalition with links to leftist guerrillas that was all but wiped out by paramilitary death squads in the late 1980's and early 1990's.
"We consider Angelino Garzon to be a friend of the labor movement and wish him success in his new post," Julio Roberto Gomez, president of the General Confederation of Democratic Workers, a labor group that has often quarreled with Mr. Pastrana, told a local radio station. "We regard his appointment as a piece of good news."
Mr. Pastrana took office two years ago next month with the highest vote total ever recorded by a candidate for president of Colombia. But he has been weakened, among other things, by an apparent lack of progress in peace negotiations with the two main guerrilla groups and by what economic analysts describe as the worst recession in a century, with unemployment at 20 percent and the peso at an all-time low against the dollar.
Hoping to arrest that decline, this spring he proposed a referendum to replace Congress, which is dominated by the Liberals and is widely seen as corrupt and ineffective, with a new and more-streamlined body. But the plan backfired, and Mr. Pastrana was left with a poisoned relationship with Congress and a diminished ability to govern, after legislators suggested that the president's job be put to a vote as well.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A Real Aircraft Man Running Brazil's Top Airline

BYLINE: By JENNIFER L. RICH 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, BRAZIL, July 11

 BODY:
Ozires Silva, the new president of Brazil's largest airline, Varig, says he has earned the right to speak his mind about airplanes. He assembled models as a child, flew military jets in the air force and built passenger jetliners into the country's leading export business.
So Mr. Silva, 69, a former top executive of the Embraer aircraft maker, is blunt about the problems that he says confront Varig -- high costs, big debts, excessively stringent government rules and a bad reputation among the flying public. 
 "The hostility that our society has toward air transportation companies is palpable," Mr. Silva said. To remake Varig, he said, "we have to remove these obstacles; you have to have soil that is relatively fertile in order to grow."
Mr. Silva, who had been a member of the Varig board, was appointed in May to replace Fernando Pinto as president after the airline reported a $53 million loss last year and its debt grew to almost $1 billion.
Mr. Pinto was not directly blamed for Varig's problems -- the Brazilian economy was a large reason. The recession last year caused passenger numbers to drop precipitously, while the devaluation of the real, Brazil's currency, virtually doubled the industry's already large stock of dollar-denominated debt.
Of Varig's three major Brazilian competitors, one, Vasp, is battling to keep creditors from repossessing its planes, while the others, TAM and Transbrasil, have entered into what amounts to a merger that enabled them to cut flights and costs.
Mr. Pinto, nonetheless, did make some strategic decisions that hurt Varig. One of the most notable was a cutback in routes to save money. United States carriers quickly filled the gap and have been taking away a larger percentage of Varig's international passengers.
As it became more obvious that the company needed a strong hand Varig's board decided Mr. Silva was that hand.
Mr. Silva has made a career of his love for airplanes. At age 13, he was already building them: models imported from the United States to his small town in the interior of the state of Sao Paulo. Even as a child, he remembered in an interview, he would open the kits and wonder why, with so many natural resources, Brazil even had to import wood for the base of the plane.
"I asked myself why Brazil had fallen behind in this race," Mr. Silva said. "Why couldn't Brazil manufacture its own planes?"
The question stuck with Mr. Silva for 25 years, as his fascination with aviation grew. At 17, he joined the air force. He had his start as a pilot by carrying mail and supplies to distant outposts in the middle of the Amazon, landing his hydroplane on the region's snaking uncharted rivers.
By his late 20's, Mr. Silva, who was already a seasoned pilot, had become a flight instructor at the Galeao air base in Rio de Janeiro. It was there, he said, during a particularly illuminating 3 a.m. flight check over the crescent shaped Atlantic beaches, that he decided to return to his passion of building airplanes.
After earning a degree in aeronautical engineering at the Aeronautical Technology Institute in Sao Paulo state, Mr. Silva came up with the design for the Bandeirante, the first-ever regional commercial jet.
"At the time, we never imagined that we would be able to export the plane, so we didn't give much thought to the name and used something very Brazilian," Mr. Silva said. "It turned out to be a huge complication. Imagine an American trying to say Bandeirante. It eventually became the Bandit."
Appealing to nationalist sentiments that Brazil should build its own planes, Mr. Silva finally persuaded the government and the military to support him. Embraer, known formally as Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica, was born.
"On Dec. 22, 1969, the minister of the air force called me to his office and said that Embraer had to begin operations on Jan. 2, 1970, and that I was to be the president," Mr. Silva said. "I was shocked. When I tried to convince him that I was not the person for the job, he told me: 'You have already created enough problems for me. Don't create another,' and threw me out of his office."
The decision was fortuitous. Mr. Silva ran Embraer off and on for 21 years until its privatization in 1995. Despite some bumps in the road, many consider Embraer the country's greatest corporate success. Indeed, the company is currently Brazil's largest exporter.
With Varig, Mr. Silva has a similar challenge -- to build a competitive airline. As a start, he plans to renegotiate the company's debts with banks and leasing companies. He also wants to take over some of the routes that his competitors have been forced to give up in recent months.
Mr. Silva said he also would concentrate on using his influence in military and aviation circles to persuade lawmakers in Brasilia to relax the stringent controls that govern the air transport industry in Brazil.
His first priority, he said, will be to press for the removal of price controls, which now limit how much the airlines can charge on domestic and international routes. Until the restrictions are removed and the airlines are allowed to adjust prices to fill seats, he said, Varig and other Brazilian carriers would have trouble making money.
"When I go to Congress, I am not going to ask them to get rid of price controls," Mr. Silva said. "I am going to ask them to explain to me why they exist in the first place. They won't have an answer because there isn't one."
The government says changes will be made. A bill before Congress would create a National Civil Aviation Agency, which would be responsible for reorganizing the entire industry to increase competitiveness. How and when the changes will be made remains unclear, but Mr. Silva says he plans to be in the middle of those decisions.
"In the end, I would like to contribute to creating conditions so that the next 500 years of Brazil are different than the last 500 years," Mr. Silva said.

HEADLINE: Technology Is Heightening Job Worries, Greenspan Says

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
Rapid technological change is making jobs less secure in the United States, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today, suggesting those anxieties would keep a cap on wage demands and inflation even as unemployment holds close to a 30-year low.
This "heightened level of potential job dismissal," Mr. Greenspan told the National Governors' Association conference in State College, Pa., is a "less welcome byproduct" of the expansion of real-time information and use of the Internet, which are transforming the labor market. 
 "In the past," said Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y., "Greenspan has used the worker insecurity story to help explain the relatively low rates of wage increases in the current expansion."
The comments by Mr. Greenspan suggest worker demands for higher wages are being moderated by the fear of being laid off amid "job skill obsolescence." That would mean there is less inflationary pressure that the central bank would choose to address by raising interest rates even as the unemployment rate, at 4 percent, is close to its 30-year low of 3.9 percent reached in April.
Stocks were mixed after the speech.
Mr. Greenspan's speech echoes some of the themes he has been addressing for more than a year: technological change is generating worker productivity gains that have helped take the economy to new levels. In addition, he has identified labor force flexibility -- the ability of American companies to fire workers without fear of significant legal or cultural disapproval.
"Because our costs of dismissing workers are lower, the potential costs of hiring and the risks associated with expanding employment are less" than in Europe and Japan, Mr. Greenspan said.
Mr. Greenspan said he saw no sign that productivity gains were ending. It will take a recession, however, to prove how much recent gains reflect "endeavors on the part of our business community to stretch existing capital and labor resources in ways that are not sustainable over the longer run," he said.

HEADLINE: City Needs More Power Plants, Lawmakers Are Told

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The chairman of Consolidated Edison and New York State's top utility regulator, in their first joint appearance since a power shutoff in Manhattan last month, both said yesterday that New York City residents would have to accept a new generation of electricity plants to avoid a future of brownouts and soaring prices.
The officials had been asked to appear before the City Council's Consumer Affairs Committee, which is looking into power failures and rising electricity costs, but instead of offering apologies, the regulator and the regulated both went on the offensive. They said it was city lawmakers' job to convince residents who have raised environmental concerns about the construction of new plants, especially in matters of air quality, that the plants were a necessity. 
 Con Ed's chairman, Eugene R. McGrath, said the balance of supply and demand had grown more and more uneven in the 25 years since the last power plant was built in New York City. He said the sharp increase in electricity rates expected later this summer, and the increasing difficulty of holding sufficient reserves during peak demand, suggested a bleak future if plants were not constructed. On June 26, which was the third-highest day of energy use in the city's history, Con Ed cut power to a two-block area of the Upper East Side.
The utility regulator, Maureen O. Helmer, chairwoman of the State Public Service Commission, was equally blunt.
"I would ask you to work with your constituents to deliver the message that New York City, like other areas of the Northeast, the Midwest and California, is indeed in a very serious situation," Ms. Helmer said. "The most important step we can all take is to expedite the process for power plant siting."
Members of the City Council, which has no authority to regulate Con Ed or the prices it charges, mostly just seethed in frustration.
"I have to ask you this: we can't hold you accountable for the negligence of the federal government or state oversight regulatory bodies?" said Stephen J. Fiala, a Council member from Staten Island, in questioning Mr. McGrath. "What is within your control?"
The Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said the real message of the hearing was that deregulation of the power industry, which began in the mid-1990's, had failed.
"It's a real mess," Mr. Vallone said. "It doesn't protect our prices, what we're paying for it, and it doesn't protect our quality of air."
Mr. Vallone called the statements by Ms. Helmer, who has great clout in power plant decisions as chairwoman of the State Board on Electric Generation Siting and the Environment, particularly troubling.
"Right now, the people who are in charge of our destiny, the Public Service Commission, apparently feel it's not their jurisdiction to concern themselves about our environment," he said. "That's a startling admission."
A heightened conflict between the city's energy needs, which have grown sharply in recent years, and concerns about its air quality is only one of the points of tension that electricity experts say is looming for New York. Some Council members expressed concerns, for example, that ever-rising energy prices could short-circuit the city's economic boom, especially among high-tech companies with large demands for energy.
Moreover, regulators and industry experts said at the hearing, in an unregulated market, power plant builders would build only where they could make a profit, which means that even if lawmakers wanted to go back to the monopoly days of price controls on electricity, the city would suffer because power plant builders and suppliers would simply sell their electricity elsewhere.
"You can't put the genie back in the bottle," said Edward A. Smeloff, executive director of the Pace Law School Energy Project.
Con Ed, which has sold most of its power plants in New York to retool itself solely as an energy provider, has said the price of electricity it is buying is going to rise this summer, and consumer utility bills could rise by up to 30 percent in July and August compared with last summer's bills. Mr. McGrath said Con Ed could not do much about the increase because "the market, not Con Edison, sets the prices."
But Mr. Smeloff said that while the market might have become a powerful force in the newly deregulated industry, supply and demand did not explain everything. In every other state, he said, regulators have imposed rate freezes to protect consumers during the transition to a competitive market, or at least required electricity companies to delay passing on cost increases to their customers.
Only New York, he said, allows a utility to pass on price increases to consumers immediately.
Several Council members appeared to seize on that statement, which suggested the possibility of assigning blame for the city's energy troubles on human behavior rather than anonymous market forces.
"It seems that someone's been asleep at the switch," Mr. Vallone said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Yahoo's Quarterly Profit Beats Analysts' Estimates
Yahoo posted better-than-expected quarterly earnings, quelling investor concerns that consolidation and business failures among struggling dot-coms might hurt its revenue base.
Yahoo reported net income of $65.5 million, or 11 cents a share, exceeding analysts' projections of 10 cents a share. Revenue was $270.1 million, up from $128.6 million in the period a year earlier, and beat analysts' forecasts of $240 million. Shares of Yahoo fell $4.50, to $105.50, before the results were announced, but they rebounded as high as $121 in after-hours trading. Page C10. 

China Looks to Pick Up Reform Pace
Though China has been marching famously on the road toward economic change for more than two decades, barriers to capital formation keep most private businesses from providing more than a handful of jobs. There is growing pressure to change that. With World Trade Organization membership expected to open the domestic market wider to foreign companies, foreigners could take over a huge part of the economy unless China unleashes private entrepreneurs soon. A1.
 
A majority of Senate Republicans urged their leader, Trent Lott, to delay until September a vote on a major bill establishing permanent normal trade relations with China. A5.
 
Lessons on Capability and Integrity
Ronald W. Dollens, chief executive of Guidant, says he learned life's lessons from his father during drives to and from work at the family grocery store: "He taught me about integrity and respecting people no matter what their stature. He had a wallhanging in the kitchen: 'Don't try to teach a pig to sing. It wastes your time and annoys the pig.' I have that saying framed in my office. It reminds me that you have to start with a certain amount of capability or you're pretty limited in what you can do." The Boss. C8.
 
Dow Rises Again, but Nasdaq Falls
The Dow Jones industrial average rose for a third consecutive session, gaining 80.61 points, or 0.8 percent, to 10,727.19. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 5.26 points, or 0.4 percent, to 1,480.88, but technology stocks slumped, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 23.87 points, or 0.6 percent, to 3,956.42. C10.
 
Virgin Atlantic Ushers In Cell Calls
Virgin Atlantic Airways has introduced a system that routes incoming cellular calls to handsets at passengers' seats. Incoming calls ring quietly on passenger earphones or are announced as a text message on in-seat video screens. Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. C9.
 
Most United States airlines said that they would reduce some fares by about 25 percent into December, trying to maintain the strong traffic levels seen recently. C9.
 
Lawyer in Coke Case Is Restricted
A federal judge ordered a Florida lawyer who is representing four black former Coca-Cola employees in a racial-discrimination lawsuit not to interfere with the settlement reached last month between Coke and four other employees with similar claims. C21.
 
Profit Triples at International Paper
International Paper, the maker of paper and forest products, said that its second-quarter profit more than tripled as a result of higher prices and cost-cutting. The results beat Wall Street expectations by a penny. Shares of International Paper rose $3, to $35.25. International Paper had dropped 43 percent this year. C2.
 
Harper to Acquire British Publisher
HarperCollins Publishers agreed to acquire Fourth Estate, a small and highly regarded British publishing house based in London whose authors include the popular historian Dava Sobel and the novelist Annie Proulx. Terms were not disclosed. C6.
 
Bank Strike Ends in South Korea
The South Korean government and labor leaders agreed to end a strike by bank workers who walked off their jobs to protest mergers that could lead to thousands of layoffs. C4.

HEADLINE: New York and London Urged to Learn From Each Other

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
Does New York City need lessons in how to redevelop its waterfront? Take a look at what London has done. Does London need guidance in revitalizing old neighborhoods? Have a gander at New York's methods.
Those themes emerged when the government of the City of London, which is one of 33 boroughs that make up the overall city, decided to study the economies of the two cities with an eye to strengthening London's economic base. 
In the process, the recently completed study turned up some advice for New York. But if the reaction yesterday of one New York City official is typical, that advice may be seen as cautions from a well-meaning cousin who happens to be out of touch.
As viewed from the City of London, the borough that contains the city's financial district, London and New York are "without debate the leading global cities in the year 2000," and are cities whose economies have arrived "at an extraordinary point of symmetry."
Among the "striking parallels," according to the 402-page study, made public last month, are the cities' leading roles as centers of finance, culture, communications and tourism. But they also have common problems: long-term declines in older manufacturing industries; growing disparities in incomes; local unemployment rates that, though improving, remain higher than those of their nations'; and difficulties in "lifting the education and skills levels of residents and immigrants."
Those parallels are played out in cities with nearly identical numbers of residents: 7.4 million in New York's 5 boroughs and 7.2 million in London's 33.
Among the lessons "London can learn from New York's successes," according to the study, is the redevelopment approach used in downtown Manhattan, which has involved rezoning and other policies to stimulate both commercial rejuvenation and residential development.
London can also benefit from a system like New York's business improvement districts, dozens of which have proliferated in the city's commercial areas over the last two decades. The districts levy special taxes on property owners in their jurisdictions to pay for sanitation, security and other services and to promote local businesses.
The districts have attracted so much interest from London that the Central London Partnership, a group of business interests and local government officials, sent a delegation to New York recently to meet with leaders of some districts.
And the study also urged London's government to look at how New York had encouraged utility companies to participate in programs for supporting small manufacturing companies.
On the other hand, the study says, "London provides lessons for New York in the extensive redevelopment of its great waterfront, a process which is lagging" in New York.
And it urges state and city officials in New York to look at how London has expanded public transportation, including its recent expansion of the Underground.
In New York, the study says, little has been done in the last 30 years to expand the capacity of the region's public transportation, though it acknowledges that financing has been proposed for the long-delayed Second Avenue subway and that a rail link is being built to Kennedy Airport.
Among the study's directors was Rosemary Scanlon, an economic consultant, who served as deputy state comptroller for New York City and as chief economist for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. She took part in the study while she was a visiting research fellow at the London School of Economics.
Responding yesterday to some of the study's suggestions, Michael G. Carey, president of New York's Economic Development Corporation, took issue with some of the assertions, including that of not doing well on waterfront redevelopment.
"They're not aware of the different things we're doing," he said. He mentioned the park being built along the Hudson River from Battery Park City to 59th Street, plans for a Brooklyn Bridge Park along the Brooklyn waterfront and other plans to revitalize Coney Island and the area around the ferry terminal in St. George, Staten Island.
"And we reopened Howland Hook," he said, referring to a major Staten Island site for receiving seaborne freight.

HEADLINE: Liberties;
L.A. Story: It's About Me!

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:

Memo
 
To: Terry McAuliffe, Chairman of the Democratic National Convention
From: Bill Clinton, Still President of the United States
Re: The Clinton Convention
Hey, buddy, I know you're really busy digging up more dollars for the cause. So I've taken the liberty of drafting a schedule for L.A. that makes a heap of sense. 
 Day One: Our theme is "Putting People Who Are President First."
1 p.m. Welcoming party, LAX.
3 p.m. Welcoming party, Century Plaza lobby.
4 p.m. Welcoming party in suite.
8 p.m. Hollywood Hails a Boy From Hope.
10 p.m. to 2 a.m. Miramax Salute to Welfare Reform at Spago.
 Day Two: Our theme is "Defending the Constitution."
1 p.m. Opening address by Senator Robert Torricelli: "The Inanity of Impeachment."
4 p.m. Panel with presidential scholars Sean Wilentz, Sidney Blumenthal and Salma Hayek: "The 22nd Amendment: A Good Idea Gone Bad."
Day Three: My prime-time speech about how I led the Democrats back from the wilderness, rescued the U.S. economy and made world peace. On stage, offering tributes, will be Barak, Arafat, David Trimble, Gerry Adams, Tony Blair and Tom Hanks.
Day Four: Our theme is "Savoring the Clinton Legacy."
8 a.m. Gores arrive at LAX. Janet Reno greets them.
9 a.m. "Thank You, Mr. President" Breakfast. Al can have his star turn introducing me.
3 p.m. Clinton Job Fair, with recruiters from DreamWorks, Sony, Goldman Sachs, Citigroup and AOL-Time Warner.
10 p.m. Hillary returns to Buffalo. I go to David Geffen's to chill on his cream leather couches.
 
Memo
 
To: Terry McAuliffe
From: Hillary Clinton
Re: The Hillary! Convention
Ideas for my convention:
Day One: Tribute to Hillary Rodham Clinton, First Lady of First Ladies.
Day Two: Tribute to Hillary!, Senate Candidate Extraordinaire and Superstar Successor to Bobby Kennedy. With a moving bio, "The Girl From Chappaqua."
Day Three: I make a rousing prime-time speech lambasting New York City electric rates, as Bill and Derek Jeter watch adoringly.
Day Four: Eleanor and Hillary, a Musical Paean to Two Great New York Dames, with Rosie O'Donnell.
I think we can best utilize the vice president by having him backstage hosting the Webcast each night, chatting online with New York voters about how I'm doing.
 
Memo
 
To: Terry McAuliffe
From: Al Gore
Re: The Gore Convention
Terry -- some musings about how we should prioritize the week.
Day One: 6 p.m. Clintons arrive at LAX for airport rally. They appear at the door of Air Force One, smiling and waving. I know Bill and Hillary are resisting a joint appearance at a time that competes with Monday Night Football. But it's only an exhibition game, and we'll time their appearance for halftime.
6:05 p.m. Clintons are No. 1 for takeoff. They disappear into the wilds of the Adirondacks on vacation. Are not seen or heard from again. At all. All week.
Day Two: Our theme is "Tipper Beats the Drum for Al."
6 p.m. Tipper plays the drums, accompanied by Karenna and Naomi Wolf, in an all-girl band salute to me.
8 p.m. Tipper gives a prime-time speech aimed at women voters about what a hunk of burning love I am. Afterward I come out and do a few push-ups to show how incredibly buff I am and then we dance to Motown, as film clips from "Love Story" play on a big screen.
Day Three: The theme is "Rediscovering the Human Side of Al Gore," including a yet-to-be-selected Gore family tragedy.
Day Four: The theme is "Rediscovering the Lighter Side of Al Gore," including hilarious and beloved comedy routines where I balance a broom on my nose, do the booty-call line dance and hypnotize chickens.

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
Building Glass Houses

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
On Monday, when JDS Uniphase and SDL announced their plans for a merger -- at $41 billion the largest technology merger so far -- my reaction was the same as that of most other people: "Who? What?" After a bit of reading established that JDS is based in Ottawa, I supplemented that initial reaction with a hearty "Eh?" What ever happened to companies whose names are recognizable, or at least give some hint about what business they are in?
But the mysterious obscurity of the companies and uninformativeness of their names are part of why this story is important. Most of the real "new economy" consists not of household names with easily understood businesses -- like Amazon.com -- but of less familiar companies doing mind-numbingly technical things. And the JDS-SDL merger is a reminder that while the dot-coms may have had their day, the era of the new economy is by no means over. 
 JDS and SDL are in the business of fiber-optics -- the use of light, rather than electrons, to carry information. To transmit a short, old-fashioned piece of plain text, like this article, copper wire will do; to transmit a concert video of the latest teenage pop star, or whatever it is that tomorrow's Web consumers will demand, glass conduits for light waves are what you need. If you, too, have been mystified by those Qwest ads -- the grungy motel with the comprehensive movie selection, and so on -- now you know what they are about (though I remain puzzled about how my willingness to "ride the light" will help Qwest's bottom line).
Fiber-optics isn't a high-profile business -- much of its product is literally underground -- but it nonetheless shares five features with more glamorous high-tech industries:
Globalization: O.K., residents of the United States have a hard time thinking of Canadians as foreigners, or indeed thinking about them at all. But this is another small step toward the dissolution of the nation-state as a meaningful economic unit.
The network economy: In a literal sense, of course, JDS and SDL are selling the stuff of which the network itself is built. But in a broader sense they are also beneficiaries of "network externalities," the way the Web creates demand for itself.
Market exuberance: As the dot-com bubble deflates, we are starting to hear mutters about an old-fashioned item called "cash." But that word is not being heard much in the fiber-optics sector. True, JDS and SDL aren't Boo.com or Toy smart.com; they have real products and earn real profits. But their stock prices are nonetheless extraordinary, hundreds of times earnings. And JDS, following in the footsteps of other tech companies, has in effect used the high value investors place on its stock as the basis for a series of acquisitions -- an empire built on expectations.
Neophilia: One slightly peculiar feature of the current business environment, which I discussed a few columns back, is the positive preference of the market for companies without a past, or a low-tech business on the side. This neophilia appears to have played some role in the JDS-SDL story: the rival fiber-optics company Corning was also interested in SDL, but was unable or unwilling to match the JDS offer because Corning stock sells at more modest multiples of revenue and earnings. There may be sound business reasons for the difference, but Corning reportedly feels that the market still values it a bit like a cookware manufacturer, and is considering spinning its fiber-optics off as a separate business.
Antitrust dilemmas: Even high-tech companies are not supposed to engage in old-fashioned monopolization; and last year a report on the industry by the technology magazine Red Herring declared that "three vendors -- JDS Uniphase, SDL, and E-Tek -- own their market now and for the foreseeable future." When you realize that JDS acquired E-Tek at the end of last month, you start to wonder. But on the other hand, JDS and SDL are both genuinely innovative companies; and temporary monopoly power is justified if it is the reward for innovation.
It's a judgment call; but if you ask me, the regulators should leave JDS/ SDL alone. (On the other hand, I've said that about Microsoft too.) It's a brave new world that has such mergers in it; and we should give that new world a chance to evolve before we start to place it under too many old-economy strictures. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Senate Takes First Step On Repeal Of Estate Tax

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
The Senate took a first step today toward a vote on a Republican proposal to repeal the federal estate tax, and Democrats scrambled to avoid defections that could allow passage of the bill later this week.
The legislation, which passed the House last month with support from some Democrats, would gradually eliminate the federal tax on large estates. Republicans said the tax robs many people at death of much of any wealth they have accumulated for their heirs, and hits family-owned farms and small businesses particularly hard. 
 "The idea that the federal government would reach into the grave and pull back half of a life's work offends people regardless of race, sex, region, financial situation or anything else," said Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican majority leader.
The Senate began debating the estate tax bill today as Congress also prepared to take up other tax legislation. The Senate also plans to begin debate this week on a Republican plan to cut taxes for married couples.
In the House today, a bipartisan group unveiled a bill, which could come to the floor for a vote as soon as next week, that would allow increased tax-free contributions to individual retirement accounts and 401(k) plans.
President Clinton has signaled that he would veto the estate tax bill. But mindful that 9 of 45 Democratic senators have endorsed repeal of the estate tax, Democratic leaders unveiled an alternative proposal today that would eliminate the tax for most family-owned businesses and farms but leave it in place for a relatively small number of multimillion-dollar estates.
But it was unclear whether Democrats would be able to block the Republican bill as it confronts a procedural hurdle. To cut off debate on the bill and bring it to a final vote, the legislation's sponsors would have to muster 60 votes, meaning that Republicans would have to be joined by at least five Democrats.
The nine Democrats who support estate tax repeal urged Mr. Lott tonight to allow consideration of the Democratic alternative as well as other Democratic amendments.
So far Mr. Lott and his Democratic counterpart, Thomas A. Daschle of South Dakota, have been unable to agree on what measures should be considered, and if there is no agreement that Mr. Lott could force a vote on cutting off debate later this week.
Mr. Daschle said he is confident that all 45 Democrats will stick together to block a final vote on the bill if Republicans do not allow them to vote on the amendments they want to offer. But Mr. Lott said that if he can find a way to have a final vote, the bill would win support from as many as 70 senators.
The Republican bill would decrease federal revenues by $104 billion over the first 10 years, and $750 billion in its second decade. Democrats said their alternative would reduce revenues by $64 billion over the first 10 years and $300 billion over the second decade.
Democrats said that by insisting on full repeal of the tax, Republicans were intent on handing over a huge chunk of projected federal budget surpluses to the rich while doing nothing to address issues of concern to working people.
Under current law, estates valued at up to $675,000 are exempt from federal taxation, and the exemption is scheduled to rise to $1 million in 2006. Family-owned businesses and farms are exempt up to $1.3 million. Above those levels, estates are subject to a graduated tax with a top rate of 55 percent.
The issue has become politically potent as the 76 million members of the baby boom generation, their wealth swollen by the strong economy and stock market, has begun estate planning.
