HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: A Dot-Com Revolution in China;
Venture Capital Backs Talented Young Entrepreneurs

BYLINE: By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
China's economy is throwing millions of people out of work each year, but an unemployed Internet journalist, Shao Ying, says she can get a job whenever she wants among the hundreds of Internet companies opening offices here.
Her eyes widened when asked how she could be certain to find one that pays if so few Chinese Internet companies have any revenue. The answer, to her, is as obvious as the mole on Mao Zedong's chin. 
 "America," she replies. "Didn't you know?"
Ms. Shao is right: hundreds of millions of American investment dollars have fattened the bank accounts of China's young Internet entrepreneurs over the last year, making dot-com companies the most vibrant part of the country's fledgling but still struggling private sector. And despite the high-technology stock slump in the United States, as much as $1 billion more in venture capital, most of it from America, is hovering overhead waiting to dive into China's fast-developing Internet industry, venture capitalists say.
The torrent of cash into private hands is without parallel here under Communist Party rule. It also is particularly conspicuous given the enormous financing difficulties that many budding Chinese entrepreneurs confront in a society that still officially discourages real capitalism.
The money also could quickly vanish or move elsewhere if foreign venture capitalists decide China is not worth the risk, leaving people like Ms. Shao stranded.
But if the money keeps coming, the impact could be as big as the breakup of the country's Maoist communes 20 years ago. A capital-backed private sector may be the economy's best hope for survival as hundreds of millions of workers spill from sinking state-owned enterprises, and foreign competitors eagerly await China's market opening after it joins the World Trade Organization.
For the first time since a fledgling private sector reappeared in the late 1970's, a group of private businesses here are accumulating capital.
"China is seeing a core entrepreneurship being established that is different from the old one, which never really grew because it didn't have access to capital," says Dong Tao, an economist with Credit Suisse First Boston in Hong Kong.
The new entrepreneurs, many with American educations or American companies on their resumes, are outrunning China's ideologically hobbled bureaucracy not only because of their youth but because they are supported by a powerful constituency abroad: men and women often times not much older who represent millions of dollars in investment capital and are not intimidated by China's authoritarian government or its byzantine rules.
On a sultry night in June, more than 200 young men and women crowded into a fashionable Shanghai restaurant, wearing colored stickers on their lapels identifying them as either someone looking for money (red) or someone with money to give (green). Rapid-fire volleys of industry jargon were part of conversations around the room. One Chinese man told a Silicon Valley banker that his Web site would handle transactions next year worth 1 billion yuan, about $120 million.
"Who here would like Goldman, Sachs to underwrite their Nasdaq I.P.O.?," a young man in a white-collared blue shirt shouted from atop a chair in an effort to get the crowd's attention for the evening's speaker from the American investment bank.
Like their counterparts in the United States, men and women in their 20's have emerged from such evenings to find themselves deploying millions of dollars, in some cases tens of millions of dollars, almost overnight.
The money is not yet sinking very deeply into China's economy. Buses and bus stops in most major cities have been taken over by dot-com advertising. And interior design firms are doing a booming business. At the Internet auctioneer Eachnet.com's sleek offices in a new Shanghai bank building, visitors are greeted by an orange-tiled wall bearing the company's logo -- recently redesigned by a Japanese firm. Against the glass wall of the chief operating officer's office lean presentations from a handful of interior design companies showing various high-tech versions of the company's new offices soon to be built in another building a few doors away.
But as China's old Marxists know, capital is power and if the country's young Internet entrepreneurs can hang onto their assets and make them grow, they could emerge as a potent force shaping the country's economic -- and political -- future.
So far, the big capital formation is limited mostly to Internet companies, though China is exploring ways to make it easier for a business's original investors to cash out when it goes public. China's regulators are considering a second board on the country's stock exchanges that might allow share sales by companies before they are profitable, for example. And Chinese start-ups can, in theory, list their shares on a second board already operating in Hong Kong. Several domestic venture capital funds have even appeared, though they are mostly government controlled.
If that model takes hold, it could fundamentally alter economic life in China, where, despite 20 years of changes that have made the economy more flexible and market-driven, the ever-present state still decides how resources are allocated.
"Many good mechanisms have been introduced to China, such as venture capital and stock options, which will help trigger the restructuring of industries throughout the country," says Wang Zhidong, chief executive of Sina.com, one of the few mainland Chinese Internet companies to list shares on Nasdaq so far. He says the success of those private businesses will also influence the country's attitude toward its educated youth, who remain suspect in the eyes of many Chinese officials.
But China's notoriously slow government must act quickly or the dot-com phenomenon might disappear as quickly as it came without having made much of an impression on the country's economic landscape. Venture capitalists, despairing of any easy exit through which to sell their investments, may move on, leaving China's fledgling Internet industry gasping for cash. The Ministry of Information Industries already estimates that most of the country's 16,000 Web sites will be gone by year-end for lack of financing.
For now, few of China's Internet companies are seriously considering raising capital at home. Current listing requirements make that impossible and the approval to go public is a political favor that private companies rarely win.
And most of the foreign investment in China's Internet sector remains technically illegal under rules barring foreign ownership of value-added telecommunications services. In June, China's stock market regulators issued a new rule requiring companies that want to list abroad to first submit to Beijing documents detailing their ownership structure and showing that the structure adheres to Chinese law.
Even Sina.com had to strip its primary asset -- the mainland China Sina.com Web site -- from its Cayman Islands shell company to get Beijing's approval to list on Nasdaq. Investors in the United States stock own a stake in the shell and its ancillary Chinese-language Web sites in Hong Kong, Taiwan and North America, but not in the Chinese operations.
Rivals angling for a Nasdaq listing are having to do the same, but acknowledge that China's changing rules could make even the restructured operations illegal. Sohu.com, one of the China's most popular Internet portals, stated in a recent Securities and Exchange Commission filing that "relevant P.R.C. authorities could, at any time, assert that any portion or all of our existing or future ownership structure and businesses, or this offering, violate existing or future P.R.C. laws and regulations."
Yet, with China expecting to join the World Trade Organization later this year, a feeling of invincibility -- some say hubris -- has permeated the industry. "The same deference isn't being paid to the ministries and bureaucrats as was paid in the past," says Greg Shea, an American who is working for a venture capital fund sponsored by Siemens A.G. and one of China's own investment companies, the China International Trust and Investment Corporation. The money Mr. Shea's company is investing comes from a telecommunications-equipment-leasing business that was unwound last year after China declared that the structure violated Chinese law.
Even if the current trend does die without transforming China's economy, it has taught a group of bright, ambitious young people the basic tools of capitalism. And not all of those people are likely to go away. Michael Brownrigg of the San Francisco-based Chinavest, one of the first venture capital firms to invest in China, said, "The Internet shows that young people can run businesses here and that will resonate for a long time to come."

HEADLINE: Huge Rail Merger Is in Doubt After U.S. Court Upholds Ban

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
The American and Canadian railroads that were planning to combine resources to create a rail system spanning North America lost a court appeal yesterday and will probably end up scuttling their proposed $6 billion merger.
A federal court in Washington upheld a temporary ban on railroad consolidations that was imposed in March by the Surface Transportation Board of the United States. The board had frozen action on all mergers after the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corporation and the Canadian National Railway Company announced plans to put together a vast freight network that would crisscross the United States and Canada and offer service into Mexico, too. Their merger would have been the largest in railroad history. 
 The railroads argued that the board lacked the authority to impose such a ban and could only approve or reject merger applications. But the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, in a 2-to-1 decision released yesterday morning, ruled that the board had not exceeded its statutory authority.
The decision effectively upheld the ban that began on March 17 -- the day the board originally imposed the moratorium -- and runs until June 2001.
In a joint statement, the two railroads expressed disappointment over the court's decision but did not signal their next move.
"Neither B.N.S.F. nor C.N. will speculate about its options," the statement said. "The managements of C.N. and B.N.S.F. will discuss the ruling's implications for their proposed business combination, and each will consult its respective board of directors."
Both companies already have quarterly board meetings scheduled for this month. The Burlington board is to meet next Thursday, and the Canadian National board on July 24. Spokesmen for the railroads refused to say whether the future of the proposed merger or any further legal action, including a request for a rehearing or a filing with the Supreme Court, would be discussed at those meetings.
But analysts are almost certain that the deal will be stopped.
"The deal is dead for the foreseeable future," said James M. Higgins, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. He said that the Burlington Northern board in particular was impatient and unwilling to be held up for more than a year during which anything could happen.
In comments shortly after the ban was imposed in March and the railroads had filed their appeal, Robert D. Krebs, the chairman of Burlington Northern, expressed doubt that the deal would go forward if the moratorium was not overturned. In answer to a question at a luncheon in Washington on March 24, Mr. Krebs said the economic climate in the industry would change so much during the postponement that the proposed merger would probably no longer make sense.
At that same luncheon, Mr. Krebs also expressed concerns about the Surface Transportation Board's announced plans to consider new rules and regulations governing mergers that would be different from those under which the venture had been planned by the two railroads. And he said that the uncertainty generated by such a long delay would hurt investors and further depress the rail lines' stocks.
The board itself acknowledged that financial markets would react negatively to a moratorium, but it found that such danger would be outweighed by the potential consequences of moving forward "without appropriate rules in place at the beginning."
Since the plans were disclosed in December, railroad stock prices have gyrated wildly in reaction to expectations about what federal regulators in Washington would do. Over all, Burlington Northern shares have fallen more than 5 percent this year, while Canadian National declined a bit more than 1 percent. Both were up slightly today as investors responded positively to the court's action because they believed that some of the uncertainty that has dogged the rail lines since the merger was proposed had been lifted. Shares of Burlington Northern rose 68.75 cents, to $26.9375, while Canadian National also jumped 68.75, to $30.75.
From the beginning, the plans of the two large carriers to create a coast-to-coast, cross-border rail network have been both praised and condemned. The new system would include 50,000 miles of track and combined annual revenue of $12.5 billion. Analysts liked the fact that despite their huge dimensions, the two systems overlapped in few places. Railroad executives promised that few jobs or miles of parallel track would be lost.
But the vision of a transcontinental railroad came just as shippers and manufacturers that use the rails were adjusting to a previous round of mergers that had greatly disrupted service and left a large number of rail clients unhappy. Many feared that the Burlington-Canadian National combination would bring on even more mergers and leave North America with just two very large national railroads, a situation that, critics feared, would decrease competition and lower the responsiveness of the railroads to client needs.
Federal regulators in Washington say that more consolidation is likely in the rail industry. They say they imposed the moratorium to review regulations and make sure the industry develops in an orderly way.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Nasdaq Gains on Strong Earnings and Inflation Report

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The Nasdaq market chugged to its highest close in more than three months yesterday as strong earnings and a tame inflation report bolstered hopes that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates again this year.
Financial stocks led blue chips higher, despite another battering in the drug sector and a record $145 billion punitive damage award against cigarette makers in a Florida case involving sick smokers. 
 "The friendly inflation number was one of the things that said it was safe to get back in the water again," said Doug Myers, vice president for equity trading at Wachovia Securities in Atlanta. "Earnings did not disappoint. But the most recent tobacco verdict puts a little bit of a damper on things."
Technology stocks clicked into rally mode on a view that June's surprising drop in the core Producer Price Index, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, could take pressure off the Fed to keep fighting inflation.
The Nasdaq composite index jumped 71.32 points, or 1.7 percent, to 4,246.18, as some of its technology heavyweights came back with a vengeance. The index's close was the highest since April 7, when it finished at 4,446.45.
The Nasdaq gained nearly 5.5 percent for the week and is up 4.4 percent for the year.
Cisco Systems, the data networking equipment company, bounced up 3, to 68 1/4, while Amazon.com, the Internet retailer, gained 7 1/2, to 42 1/2. Both companies have been dogged recently by questions about their high valuations.
Salomon Smith Barney said it expected a good third and forth quarter for Amazon.com and reiterated its buy rating on the stock.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 24.04 points, or 0.2 percent, to 10,812.75 on the back of J. P. Morgan & Company. The Dow ended up 1.6 percent for the week and is down 6 percent so far this year.
Broader stock indexes also gained ground, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index up 14.14 points, or 0.9 percent, to 1,509.98.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 24/32, to a price of 102 29/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.09 percent from 5.99 percent on Thursday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 29/32, to 105 7/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.88 percent from 5.82 percent on Thursday.
J. P. Morgan's stock shot up 4 3/8, to 128 1/2, after its earnings beat Wall Street estimates. Both Merrill Lynch and CIBC raised their ratings on J. P. Morgan.
The Dow component Philip Morris slipped 5/8, to 24 3/8, after a Miami jury ordered the cigarette maker to pay $73.96 billion for injuring Florida smokers in the landmark Engle sick-smokers trial.
A rival, R. J. Reynolds Tobacco, fell 15/16, to 26 3/16, after it was assessed $36.28 billion in punitive damages out of the total $144.8 billion that five cigarette makers were ordered to pay. Both Philip Morris and R. J. Reynolds said they would appeal.
Earlier, the Labor Department reported that the overall Producer Price Index for June grew by 0.6 percent, while the core Producer Price Index, excluding volatile food and energy prices, declined 0.1 percent.
The core index was forecast to have risen 0.1 percent in June, and the overall index was expected to have risen 0.5 percent, according to economists surveyed by Reuters.
Analysts linked the rise in the overall index to higher oil prices.

HEADLINE: Security Lapses Signal Unsettling Shift in U.S.-University Nuclear Tie

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 14

 BODY:
From the dawn of the nuclear age a half century ago, when J. Robert Oppenheimer moved from Berkeley to the New Mexico desert and led the effort to build the atomic bomb, the University of California has been the government's close partner in running its nuclear laboratories.
Even in the post-cold war era, this historic relationship has endured because of a belief that the university was uniquely suited to nurturing the independent scientific minds needed for creating these complex weapons. 
 But suddenly, and unexpectedly, the partnership is poised for unsettling changes, and not because the threat of nuclear war has all but disappeared and the mission of the laboratories altered. The series of security lapses that have swamped the Los Alamos National Laboratory over the past year have disrupted that bedrock partnership and put the government on an uncertain new course of breaking free, at least partly, from the University of California system.
The arrest last year of a scientist on charges of mishandling vast amounts of secret data, the unexplained disappearance and then reappearance of computer hard drives packed with classified material, and a growing climate of anxiety about further criminal investigations related to misplaced secrets have prompted the government to consider contracting out some duties to private companies.
Energy Secretary Bill Richardson has announced that he will strip the university of its oversight of security at Los Alamos and the other two government labs it manages, as well as some functions like construction management. The university would still manage the most significant tasks, for example research, insuring the reliability of the nuclear stockpile and administration. It is a shift, though, that some people feel could have subtle but profound implications for the scientists at the labs.
In many ways the current tension between the government and the university reflects a wider historic clash present at Los Alamos since it inception. The scientists have long argued that without a free flow of information they cannot accomplish their tasks, while the government has contended that too much openness can harm national security.
The fear is that tightening security now outside of the university's control could undermine the whole rationale for having an academic institution overseeing weapons research -- maintaining a semblance of intellectual freedom, required for scientific innovation, even while following strict secrecy provisions.
The university has long argued that its solid academic reputation and influence traditionally shielded the laboratories' scientists from some potentially stifling government restrictions on communication so that sophisticated scientific research could still be conducted. The question now is, if the university loses its ability to control security will it also lose its ability to protect the laboratories' limited intellectual freedom?
Mr. Richardson insisted that it would not, but said the scientists would simply have to cope because, as he put it, "The status quo isn't working."
"What I want to do," Mr. Richardson said in an interview, "is to use what the University of California does best, and take away what it doesn't do well, to enhance the overall management of the labs and perhaps establish a pattern of joint ventures with the university."
He added: "We're not punishing or scapegoating the University of California. We want to use their strengths and eliminate their weaknesses."
Sidney Drell, a professor emeritus of physics at Stanford University and a member of the presidential commission that criticized security at the government's nuclear labs last year, put it more bluntly.
"It's painful for me to say, because I'm one of those scientists," Dr. Drell said, "but I think the freedoms they had in the past and the open attitude are unacceptable now."
There is an even more basic concern. Many officials at Los Alamos are girding for the possible indictment of some respected, senior laboratory scientists on criminal charges for their mishandling of the disappearance of the hard drives earlier this year. The fear is that this could not only harm the lab's already substantial problems in recruiting young scientists, but could cause an exodus of senior scientists fearful of heavy-handed government prosecutions. Those fears have led some of those in charge at Los Alamos to warn that any reductions in the University of California's role should be prudent, thoughtful and modest.
"I believe that whatever appears to have broken can be fixed," said John C. Browne, the lab's director and a university employee. "The benefits to the country of this relationship far outweigh the problems. To me, if you go too far, it's like you're going to throw away the whole system because of a couple of bad apples."
In principle, Mr. Richardson agreed, saying that dropping the contract with the university and bringing in a private defense contractor to run Los Alamos could be devastating. If a large government defense contractor were to take over, Mr. Richardson said, "then you would have an exodus from our labs."
University officials have expressed a willingness to negotiate a new arrangement with the Department of Energy, but clearly the institution's pride has been wounded.
"It sounds arrogant to say, but we don't need this relationship for the university," said an official, echoing a common view. But others say that, while eager to mend the partnership, they are looking at possibly deeper changes in the future.
"The point when we separate is easy enough to identify," said John Davies, a university regent and until recently the board's chairman. "It's the point when the security becomes so burdensome that it drives the scientists out of the labs. For me, at this point, though, I don't think we're anywhere near that."
Rulon Linford, a former lab scientist who is now the associate vice provost for research and laboratory programs at the university, said: "I think the university gets out of the deal what it has always gotten out of the deal. Its motivation is public service. If the university walked, the national security of this country would be harmed."
The relationship between the University of California system and the government began informally in the early 1940's as the Manhattan Project got under way, and it was first codified in 1943 with the historic contract W-7405-Eng-36, which established the university's management of the previously secret Los Alamos site. Eventually, the number of labs overseen by the university grew to include Lawrence Berkeley as well as Los Alamos and Lawrence Livermore. The Berkeley site is devoted to nonweapons research, while the other two labs do both.
The relationship, however, has traditionally been bumpy. The scientists have always chafed under the government's security restrictions. Also, throughout the 1960's and 1970's, many university faculty members objected to having an academic institution so intimately involved in creating weapons of mass destruction. On several occasions committees explored the relationship and drew up alternatives, including separation.
And in the 1970's, as the research at Los Alamos expanded to include the environment and energy, a consortium of Midwestern universities asked for control of the labs to utilize this new expertise. The proposal was rejected, but it led to other examinations of the partnership and a series of changes throughout the 1980's.
The university says the relationship has created little in the way of financial rewards. Under the current five-year contract, which expires in 2002, the university receives a series of fees, some of which can expand or shrink, depending on performance.
The fee is broken down into several components. There is a payment of $11 million to cover several federal contracts, another payment of $3.5 million to $4 million specifically to cover the costs of a central administration office, and an administration fee, adjusted to reflect performance, of roughly $14 million, but which could go as high as $16 million. About half of those fees are used to operate Los Alamos, with the rest used to pay for the other two labs.
But there are some very substantial benefits to the relationship for the university. The laboratory scientists are not like faculty members at university campuses; they do not have tenure, they do not have complete academic freedom and they must comply with a large body of government rules. Also, none of the university employees at Los Alamos are unionized, although some are at the two California labs.
The relationship, however, is an important recruiting tool. Many young scientists who might not be thrilled at the prospect of working at a government lab devoted to building weapons of mass destruction find the idea of being a University of California researcher far more palatable. The relationship also means that, should a scientist decide to leave the lab, getting a job in academia would be easier.
For instance, Xian Chen, a young biophysicist at Los Alamos involved in nonweapons work, said the fact that he became a university employee was critical. "That's the reason I was attracted," he said. "Los Alamos has a good reputation in the scientific world."
In addition, Los Alamos has some of the fastest computers in the world and other sophisticated research equipment, all paid for by the government. Weapons scientists can use some of these tools for nonmilitary research.
"It's not a one-way street," acknowledged Ronald A. Nelson, the university's director for contract management. "We get some of the scientific results of those labs and that reinforces our reputation for excellence and prestige."
And there are important financial incentives. The university system offers a lucrative retirement package that some believe is perhaps the single most important amenity offered. Also, children of Los Alamos scientists can attend the university at the same rates as California residents, a huge savings.
Hugh Gusterson, a professor of anthropology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who is writing his second book on the weapons labs, said that he believed the supposed intellectual freedoms were a myth. Historically, Mr. Gusterson said, the university has not stood up for scientists who had angered the government, which is certainly the case in the recent series of security lapses. But the economic benefits, he maintained, have been crucial.
"The retirement package is incredibly important," Professor Gusterson said. "But it's my own view that the labs wouldn't be very different without the University of California. They've been sort of an absentee landlord. I think the U.C. element has always been this little carrot the recruiters could dangle."
The reality now is that the priorities are changing, and whatever protections the university could provide for the scientists involved in sensitive research will be diminished.
"The present climate has already cost them young people," Dr. Drell said. "The question is how we stop it and protect the quality of the labs. The university is at its moment of truth in standing up to this, and finding a way to make all this work. I don't think the tensions are unreconcilable, but they are more difficult."

LENGTH: 1000 words

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
After Reluctant 'Yes' to Ministry, Confident Climb to Top

BYLINE: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN 

DATELINE: CINCINNATI, July 12

 BODY:
She knelt down in her stiff new robe stitched with purple and gold brocade, surrounded by a tight circle of four bishops and five elders. One by one, they laid their hands on the crown of her head in a mighty stack, consecrating her the first woman bishop in the African Methodist Episcopal Church.
"Pinch me," the Rev. Vashti Murphy McKenzie of Baltimore says she told herself. "It's really happening, but it seems unreal. All I was saying was, 'Let's not cry now. Let's cry later. Don't cry here.' " 
 When she stood, she was dry-eyed, but many of the 5,000 or so church members watching at the convention center here were not. Men and women streamed down the aisles to get close enough to snap pictures of the new bishop, bathing her in a benediction of flashes.
The laying on of hands happened at 1:02 a.m. on Wednesday after seven days of campaigning at the church's quadrennial convention. At 3:15 a.m., she was still in the convention center, meeting with the pastors and lay leaders from the district where she will serve her first four years: the 18th, which covers Mozambique, Lesotho, Botswana and Swaziland.
She plans to move to her district Africa with her husband, Stan McKenzie, a former National Basketball Association player.
Many said the A.M.E. Church could not elect a woman as bishop because the churches in Africa -- home to about a third of the 2.5 million A.M.E. members -- were not ready to accept a woman's leadership. But Bishop McKenzie said that, to the contrary, some African delegates had asked her to come to their districts if she were elected. They told her they could use the experience she had gained in Baltimore developing programs to help the uneducated, unemployed, or those suffering from AIDS.
"Instead of placing my gender in front of me, I'll place who I am and what I do, and who I serve in front of me," she said in an interview. "They know I'm a woman when I walk in the door. So what. I've been one all my life. Get over it."
She is a fitting first. Tall and regal, her bearing recalls the runway modeling she did as a teenager. Professional and prepared, in her campaign for bishop she had the glossiest brochure of any of the 42 candidates, the brightest red T-shirts on her supporters and the slickest video promoting her accomplishments in 10 years as pastor at Payne Memorial A.M.E. in Baltimore.
"She is qualified to be bishop, forget the gender," said the Rev. Richard Greene, a pastor from Maryland who joined a huddle of 20 men in the convention center praying passionately for her victory minutes before the final vote. "She cares about people, and finds the best in people. I am a country boy," and quite traditional, Mr. Greene said, "but I believe in her. She has always been there for me."
As the reality of her purple and gold robe sank in, Bishop McKenzie, who said she is in her 50's, looked back over her life and said she "realized that all of it was the preparation for this moment."
The ministry was not her first career. Initially, she went into journalism, the family business. Her great-grandfather, John H. Murphy Sr., had founded The Afro-American newspaper in 1892, when very few blacks were literate, she said. She honed her writing at The Arizona Republic and The Afro-American, which still publishes in Baltimore and Washington. She cultivated her speaking skills as a broadcaster on gospel radio.
But when the first of her three children was born 25 years ago, she faced a crisis, she said. She had heard the call to ministry. She fasted. She prayed. And she said she resisted.
"It can be a very frightening thing when all of a sudden you realize God is calling you to preach," she said.
There were only one or two women she knew in ministry then, she said, and no books on how to do it. Few mentors. She went ahead and earned her master of divinity degree from Howard University School of Divinity in Washington and her doctorate of ministry from Union Theological Seminary in Dayton, Ohio. The first church she was assigned to had seven members.
When the pastor of Payne Memorial died in 1989, church insiders buzzed about who would fill that prestigious pulpit. At a church gathering, Bishop H.H. Brookins called her aside and told her he wanted to assign her to Payne.
She recalls that he asked her, " 'Can you handle the pressure, because if you are not successful, it will be a long time before a woman will be given a major pulpit again.' I said I could."
Her church was the first in Maryland to join the welfare reform effort by winning a $1.5 million state contract to open a job training center, in 1997. The church's nonprofit affiliate took over a failing public school. It bought a five-story apartment building and an office building to house the church's youth and senior programs, computer classes and a catering service that employs former welfare recipients. The church grew to 1,700 members from 300.
She says she follows the "Ten Commandments for Women Leaders" that she composed in her book "Not Without a Struggle" (United Church Press, 1996). The first commandment is: "Thou shalt not forsake one's femininity for the sake of one's position."
"You see beautiful women stripping themselves of their femininity just to be able to hold a position of power," Bishop McKenzie said. "I believe you don't have to give up your femininity. Esther may have been a good-looking woman and that may have gotten her an interview with the king, but it was her character that earned her the crown, and it was her relationship with God that saved her people."
Her very feminine approach to power was on display at the convention. She was campaigning when she found herself in a too-long embrace with a churchgoer who said he had heard her preach (she has topped Ebony Magazine's "15 Greatest Female Preachers List").
"You came to see us, and I remember you," the man gushed, "because you're so beautiful."
As he planted a sloppy kiss on her cheek, she never lost her composure.

SECTION: Section A; Page 7; Column 5; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1142 words

HEADLINE: Substitute Teachers See a Time to Shine

BYLINE: By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14

 BODY:
Yvonne Christensen approaches her job like a stand-up comedian. "You've got about 15 seconds to grab 'em," she said.
Walter Fletcher sees it as similar to being a relief pitcher: when you walk onto the mound, players are already on base. 
 And Cindy Manzo sounds as if she's joined the circus. "I'll stand on a chair, I'll dance around, I'll pretend my shoe is a phone," Mrs. Manzo said of her 15 years as a substitute teacher in three states. "Anything to keep their attention."
These three longtime substitutes were among 50 who exchanged horror stories and survival strategies here at the first-ever national conference of substitute teachers today, part of a scattershot effort to raise pay, benefits and working conditions for what is perhaps education's least respected profession.
The nascent effort, organized by far-flung substitutes who met over the Internet, comes at a time of the most severe shortage of substitute teachers in memory. With student enrollment and teacher absenteeism growing, class size shrinking and the unemployment rate near record lows, school districts across the country are scrambling to fill gaps at the front of the classroom.
Many districts have raised wages, but others have lowered requirements: in half the states, all it takes to be a substitute teacher is a high school diploma.
Substitutes have long been disrespected by students, teachers and administrators alike and largely ignored by researchers and politicians. But students, on average, spend a full year of their school lives in classes taught by substitutes, a fact that has fueled a small but growing movement to improve training for these guest workers and take their role more seriously.
"It's like driving a car; it's skill-based," said Geoffrey G. Smith, executive director of the Substitute Teaching Institute at Utah State University, which has made a CD-ROM that provides a self-taught seminar for potential recruits. "There are skills that one can learn."
Mr. Smith said that fewer than 10 percent of school districts provided training for substitutes, but those that did had found it decreased the number of complaints and attracted more applicants.
Expert estimates of the number of substitutes range from 500,000 to 1 million, but nearly everyone agrees there are not enough. In a recent survey by Mr. Smith's institute, 86 percent of school districts reported a substitute shortage, with more than half calling it a "serious problem."
Pay varies widely, from $30 to $185 a day, with an average of about $65. Qualifications also range: Some districts require a full-fledged teaching credential, others simply do a criminal background check.
For decades, the ranks of substitutes were filled with teachers unable to find full-time work, retirees and parents helping out in their children's schools. But now, as the nation faces a teacher shortage of some 2.5 million in the next decade, substitute rosters are threadbare, and districts are turning to flight attendants, firefighters, college students and others.
The full-employment economy, where potential substitute teachers might make better money flipping burgers, is not helping. Nor is the rise in the number of professional development days that pull full-time teachers out of class. Assistant principals and even superintendents are having to fill in in emergencies, and some districts ask cafeteria workers and bus drivers to serve as subs. Last November, the Kelly Services temporary agency began providing substitute teachers nationwide.
In the Atlanta suburbs of DeKalb County, full-time high school teachers can earn an extra $15 for teaching during their planning periods. When Georgia passed a law slashing the number of teachers' aides statewide, the district also decided to turn 600 aides into substitutes this fall rather than fire them.
"The obvious thing to do is to pay more money," said Franklin D. Grant, director of the office of human resources at the 97,000-student DeKalb district, and president of the American Association of School Personnel Administrators. "How do you get a commitment out of anybody for $30 or $40 a day?"
The shortage has provided fertile ground for organizing efforts. The National Education Association and the American Federation of Teachers each represents substitute teachers in a handful of cities and towns; substitutes have also affiliated with other labor groups, including Service Employees International Union and the United Food and Commercial Workers.
In Oregon, legislators recently passed the eighth in a series of bills focused on substitute teachers, setting pay scales at 85 percent of a district's average teacher salary. In Michigan, the state teachers' association has adopted a substitute's "bill of rights" calling for health benefits, a safe environment and "the dignity and respect that, as professional educators, they have earned."
The keynote speaker at today's conference was Shirley Kirsten, founder of the Fresno Area Substitute Teachers Association in California. The group began with five people having coffee in her living room in 1997 and ended up negotiating a contract last year on behalf of hundreds of substitutes that raised substitute salaries to $80 or $90 a day, from $65, depending on the assignment.
"We have been isolated for too long," Ms. Kirsten told attendees, who had come from Nebraska, Florida, New York, Oregon, North Carolina and Virginia. "We now need to get together under one umbrella. That umbrella is respect."
Most of those attending the conference were longtime substitutes with teaching credentials, many of them having chosen the flexibility of daily assignments over the responsibilities of a full-time classroom.
Mrs. Manzo, who is 52, said substituting fit with her military husband's mobility (they have relocated 18 times) and enables her to care more easily for her son and her father, both of whom have medical conditions requiring her attention.
But substituting can mean teaching French and physics and fourth grade -- all in one week. Adaptability is essential.
Mr. Fletcher, who organizes substitutes in Los Angeles, keeps boxes of teaching material in his car, in case someone forgets to leave a lesson plan. He does not know sign language, except the sign for "interpret," so he can direct someone to translate if he is teaching a class of deaf and hearing-impaired students.
Then there was the time he was teaching band, and all the instruments were locked up. He passed out paper and pencils he had brought, and taught the students to write musical notes.
Pamela Routh, a substitute in San Francisco for 25 years, revealed a secret for controlling a rowdy classroom of children she's never met. "You say, 'Kevin, sit down,' " Ms. Routh confided. "There's always a Kevin, so the students think you know everybody's name."

HEADLINE: Journal;
Tomorrow Is Another Day

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Ga.

 BODY:
Tom Wolfe set some of his last novel near here but even he couldn't make this scene up:
In the packed, sweltering living room of the tiny house that serves as the Dylan Glenn for Congress headquarters, a Louis Farrakhan acolyte is brandishing The Final Call, the Nation of Islam newspaper, and ranting about a Washington conspiracy to rob Georgia's peanut farmers. Listening to him are a couple of dozen angry and weather-beaten black farmers, lifelong Democrats, as well as Mr. Glenn, who wants their vote. Looking down on them all is a regal poster-size photograph of a starchy Barbara Bush, replete with pearls -- but it's not there as a gag. Mr. Glenn is a 31-year-old black Republican, an unabashed George W. Bush cheerleader, who believes he can be elected to Congress by a white-majority district that has never sent any Republican to Washington. 
 "That's the first Black Muslim I've ever seen in southwest Georgia," the candidate muses after the meeting, in which he seems to win over his audience, Muslim included, just as I'd seen him win over the all-white staff of a small local telecom business a few hours earlier. Such cross-cultural incongruities abound in Mr. Glenn's race: his campaign coordinator, Lizanne Clay, is a white Jewish Democrat gung-ho for Al Gore. The district itself, Georgia's Second, is one big anomaly. Because Mr. Glenn's opponent, the Democratic Congressman Sanford Bishop, is also black, this is that rare white-majority district in the South, let alone the country, that offers no white choice in its House race. "The race card is more or less removed from the table," says Mr. Glenn.
The district is also unusual in having missed out entirely on the New Economy that has showered spectacular growth on Atlanta, 150 miles and a world away. Though Georgia's Second encompasses some of the South's most spectacular old hunting plantations -- the prototypes for the fictional spread owned by the hero of Mr. Wolfe's "A Man in Full" -- it is among the nation's poorest precincts. The poverty level in some of its 31 counties is three times the national average, and unemployment in Albany, the largest town (pop. 80,000), nears 8 percent. Functional illiteracy levels approach 40 percent in some counties -- giving the local chain outlet's midnight party for Harry Potter a special poignancy. While Jimmy Carter may still live in Plains, young people flee faster than such past native sons as Ray Charles and Jackie Robinson.
Dusty, deserted storefronts are common; billboards heralding dot-coms are absent. Ms. Clay, a fourth-generation "Albanian," doubts her own daughter will return after college. "It's like a third world country down here," she says.
So what's an ambitious young black middle-class Republican doing in a place like this?
I first met Dylan Glenn a few months ago and was curious to watch him for a simple reason: If Governor Bush's "compassionate conservatism" is more than a campaign slogan, it must reside in someone like Mr. Glenn, a smart candidate blessed with charisma and a sense of humor who is taking on a seemingly quixotic political mission. No black Republican has ever defeated a black Democrat in a modern Congressional race; his opponent is a formidable incumbent whom Mr. Glenn himself regards as "a decent man." As Mr. Glenn's strategist, Ron Jensen, explains, Mr. Glenn can win only by holding on to the all-white G.O.P. base (with no defections from any racists who might want to abstain altogether), peeling off some conservative white Democrats and, most crucially, winning some 15 percent of the heretofore monolithically black Democratic vote.
If the potential crossover black Democrats I met are any indication, they won't leap easily. One such Glenn enthusiast, a 71-year-old county commissioner and 60's civil-rights veteran named James Mays, regards both George W. Bush and his father as among "the most evil people in the world."
Mr. Glenn, who was a young aide in President Bush's White House, hammers in the George W. message -- the classic Republican mantra of "growth, lower taxes, opportunity, individual responsibility, jobs." In essence, he sands down any ideology beyond a faith in free enterprise. The son of educators, he presents himself as an educational reformer and as an energetic, well-connected rainmaker more likely than Mr. Bishop to attract new businesses to an area in desperate need. Like the Texas governor in his address before the N.A.A.C.P. this week, Mr. Glenn doesn't pretend that his party has a distinguished record with minorities. "There's a perception that the Republican Party is intolerant -- against immigrants, gays, blacks," he says, "and we play into that."
To put it mildly. In primary season, Mr. Bush and John McCain both lacked the courage to take on South Carolina's Confederate flag. Last month Colin Powell, who is a Glenn contributor, went on Fox to say that the G.O.P. is "certainly not seen as the black guy's party" and to dissent strongly from its opposition to affirmative action. This week the Bush campaign made light of a Washington Post reporter who dared bring up the hard-line white supremacist past of its ally Strom Thurmond. Meanwhile, even as Mr. Bush appeared before the N.A.A.C.P., the news media feasted on a 1996 photo of a Republican governor, Christine Todd Whitman, broadly grinning while frisking a black man. Whatever Governor Whitman's intentions, the image was a bizarre echo of antebellum porn.
Unlike the white compassionate conservatives in his party, Mr. Glenn can speak with some moral authority. He is a sharecropper's grandson and the great-grandson of emancipated slaves. When pressed, he can cite instances of experiencing discrimination, and he recalls being the sole black person at a White House meeting a decade ago where he had to speak up to challenge other Bush ites' derisive views of welfare recipients.
In between campaign stops that ranged from a diesel-scented drag strip populated equally by blacks and whites to a watermelon festival parade in Cordele ("Watermelon Capital of the World"), I asked Mr. Glenn if the latent, tentative G.O.P. embrace of minorities is more spin than action, more election-year packaging than substance. He unsurprisingly asserted that Governor Bush is "100 percent sincere" and is intent on moving beyond the "outreach programs and window dressing" that have often constituted the G.O.P.'s attempt to woo minorities. "I know the party isn't seen as motivated by the right reasons," he adds. "It's seen as the party of the rich, white country club and doesn't have a lot of credibility." He argues that if he can bring economic relief to those left behind in Clinton-era prosperity he can help turn the page. As the first black Republican elected to Congress from a Confederate state since 1901, he would certainly be a highly watched test case of whether there can be results to back up his party's compassionate rhetoric.
Whether Mr. Glenn wins or not, there's no doubt he is on the edge of a generational shift. The Albany area was the site of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s biggest, and legendary, defeat on the road to Montgomery. It's where a sheriff told the New York Times reporter Claude Sitton, in a famous 1962 front-page story, "We want our colored people to go on living like they have for the last hundred years." But while such events may have helped forge Mr. Glenn's opponent -- who, as Morehouse College student president, sang at King's funeral in 1968 -- they happened before Mr. Glenn was born. Now they are history: the Albany Movement is documented in a new museum at the old Mount Zion Baptist Church, once the site of overflow civil-rights rallies led by the Freedom Singers but today a quiet refuge in a somnolent town segregated in its entirety from the American boom.
"My generation and younger didn't live through the civil-rights movement," says Mr. Glenn. "We know and understand it and respect what it did, but we want to go on to the next step." If the Republican Party is really to be a credible part of that next step, it will not be enough for its presidential candidate to pose incessantly with black schoolchildren and boast about his "heart." It will need someone like Dylan Glenn to make good on his promise to lift up both black and white Americans in a patch of the country as ripe for change as this.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Plan Would Give Boost To Middle-Class Teams

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Seeking to correct a mushrooming competitive imbalance because of payroll disparity, baseball's latest economic study committee presented a plan yesterday that would seem to take from the rich and give not to the poor but to the middle class.
George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, did not attend the owners meeting, where the 87-page report was presented, but it was primarily his money -- as well as Fred Wilpon and Nelson Doubleday's and that of a few other owners -- that the four-man panel took aim at in one of the major elements of its plan. 
 Following an 18-month study, the panel members recommended that the owners share 40 to 50 percent of their local revenue, levy a 50 percent competitive-balance tax on portions of payrolls above $84 million, encourage clubs to have a minimum payroll of $40 million and withhold central-fund money from clubs that did not reach the minimum.
As ways of enhancing the talent on weaker teams and keeping wealthy teams from gobbling up the best amateur players, the report also advocated a worldwide draft of amateur players, changes in the existing drafts of amateur and minor league players, allowing the trading of draft choices and elimination of compensation picks for lost free agents.
The committee also said financially troubled clubs should be permitted to relocate more readily. No Major League Baseball team has moved since 1972.
The four independent members of the panel were George J. Mitchell, the former Senate majority leader; Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve; Richard C. Levin, the president of Yale University; and the columnist George Will.
Baseball, Will said at a news conference at the Waldorf-Astoria in Manhattan, "can get well by deciding to get well."
"Failure to act promptly will have grave consequences," he added.
Some of the panel's recommendations are enhancements of practices already in place. In negotiations for the last collective bargaining agreement, for example, the clubs increased the amount of revenue they share, with money being transferred from the highest-revenue clubs to the lowest. But the panel cited the so-called local revenue as perhaps the biggest component of the disparity in the teams' economic status.
The committee said that local revenue -- gate receipts, local television and radio contracts and stadium signage -- was really industry revenue and should be shared more liberally with all teams.
In 1999, according to one of the many charts in the report, the Yankees received $175.94 million in local revenue. At the other end were the Montreal Expos, with $11.97 million.
The panel would take 40 to 50 percent of each club's local revenue, put it into a pool and divide the pool evenly among the 30 teams. The existing plan has a two-tiered payout that benefits clubs below the industry's average local revenue. The panel's plan would remove that benefit from the poorer clubs and treat the middle-level teams the same as those below them economically.
A baseball lawyer said at least some baseball officials have wanted to benefit middle-level clubs at the expense of the poorest clubs and at the same time take a huge chunk of money from the wealthiest teams.
Although no panel member acknowledged knowing of any such desire -- Mitchell said the recommendations were exclusively the panel's -- Levin talked about the benefits the middle teams could gain from the revenue-sharing plan.
Asked if he thought a bottom-tier team would sign a free agent passed up by a top-tier team because of the steep tax proposed, he said: "Yeah, or a team in the middle. I actually think it will be a pronounced effect on midrange teams, second- and third-quartile payroll teams, because I think they will now see their playoff chances are going to be better if they invest in players. I think that's where you'll see more bidders in the market for the talented players."
And while most owners chose not to comment on a report they said they had not yet read, Drayton McLane of the midlevel Houston Astros said he was "encouraged very much" by the report.
A person who attended the meeting said some representatives of low-level teams grumbled about the suggestion of a minimum payroll. But that grumbling does not figure to be any louder than the behind-the-scenes outrage certain to be expressed by Steinbrenner. A Yankees official said Steinbrenner would have no comment on the report, but the owner is certain to make his feelings known to Commissioner Bud Selig.
The Yankees are expected to pay about $25 million in revenue sharing this year under the existing formula. That sum would escalate significantly under the proposed plan.
Telephone efforts to reach Wilpon were unsuccessful, but the Mets would be hit hard, too. They were second in local revenue last year with $132.32 million.
The proposed competitive-balance tax would also hit the Yankees. If the proposed 50 percent tax were in effect this year, the Yankees would have to pay about $16 million.
The luxury tax that existed for the previous three years under the 1996 labor agreement used a 35 percent and 34 percent rate and a floating threshold determined by the average of the fifth and sixth highest payrolls. That tax, which is not in effect this year, "failed to moderate the rapid escalation of club payrolls," the report said.
The report said that only the Yankees ($64.5 million), the Cleveland Indians ($45.92 million) and the Colorado Rockies ($12.44 million) were profitable operations over the past five years, 1995 through 1999. The San Francisco Giants, it said, were the biggest losers ($97.02 million).
The panel was appointed by Selig and, unlike the last committee, had no members selected by the players' union. Asked about the report, Donald Fehr, the union head, said, "We always get some report like this before a negotiation."
The union is expected next month to exercise an option in the current labor agreement to extend the contract until the end of the 2001 season.

HEADLINE: BELIEFS;
Are those who speak out for evangelicals really conveying what the Christians believe?

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
Count on it: The Religious Right will be back. In about two weeks, the Republican National Convention will anoint George W. Bush's choice of a running mate, and depending on that choice, conservative religious leaders will be featured in the news, either voicing praise and support or expressing disappointment and opposition.
But how closely do those leaders' views, often partisan and sometimes downright inflammatory, correspond to the outlook of the nation's conservative Christians? A considerable body of critical opinion, no less inflammatory itself, has assumed that the correspondence is close. As Pat Robertson or James Dobson goes, so go the evangelicals. 
 Military metaphors abound in commentary on the Religious Right. Not just the prominent leaders and their organized cadres but the mass of conservative believers are often portrayed as an angry army on the march, legions of intolerant zealots eager to use governmental power to impose their favored moral order on the nation.
Christian Smith, a professor of sociology at the University of North Carolina, is blunt about such sweeping portraits. "Most of those who disparage evangelicals in general terms really don't know what they are talking about," he writes in his latest book, "Christian America? What Evangelicals Really Want" (University of California, 2000).
Few critics, Professor Smith says, "have significant personal relationships with enough ordinary evangelicals to inform their views." Typically, the critics' views spring from characterizations in news articles and popular entertainment, from hoary mythology of the Elmer Gantry sort, from the newsletters and fund-raising appeals of organizations engaged in today's cultural wars or, lastly, from the impressions of people just like themselves.
In Professor Smith's previous book, "American Evangelicalism: Embattled and Thriving" (University of Chicago, 1998), his extensive polling and interviews challenged the widespread stereotype that evangelicalism only flourished in intellectual and economic backwaters, isolated enclaves guarded from what Walter Lippmann famously called the "acids of modernity."
Instead, Professor Smith found that by most standards, measuring contact with this elusive thing called modernity -- years of higher education, employment patterns, income levels, urban versus rural residence, age or sex -- people who identified themselves as evangelical Christians scarcely differed from other Americans.
His new book is based on a three-year national study involving more than 200 extended interviews, as well as polling data. He quickly identifies four fallacies that have distorted many descriptions of evangelicals: that their views can be equated with those of a supposedly united evangelical political elite; that their views are accurately represented by the formulations used in public opinion polling; that their views are ideologically consistent, and that they form a monolithic religious bloc rather than a conglomeration of often bickering subgroups.
In his own interviews, Professor Smith did not shy from the hot-button questions. Did evangelicals want to restore a "Christian America?" What did they think of moral and cultural diversity? Did they have a duty to save neighbors of other faiths from hell? What could and could not -- or should not -- be attempted through politics? What should be the content of public education in a pluralist society? What about male leadership in the family and equality between men and women?
On all of these questions he found a range of views, including extreme ones. That, in fact, was his first important discovery: that evangelicals were not united or monolithic.
Still, Professor Smith found the bulk of evangelicals grouped around certain convictions.
They were deeply committed to freedom of religion and speech, not simply as a matter of unavoidable compromise, but as a matter of their religious beliefs.
They believed strongly in individual change, personal conversion of the heart, and consequently they remained wary of social movements, political involvement and institutional reforms.
Far more than politics, they stressed personal example and loving gestures, including prayer, as a means to change.
They frequently disagreed with the positions of their most visible political leaders and often said so quite explicitly.
They were critical of their own failures to live up to the Gospel.
These views were typically conveyed in rambling statements, not particularly eloquent, circling around in second thoughts and near contradictions, statements too long and too loose-jointed to serve reporters in need of the pebble-hard sound-bite, but statements with the authentic ring of ordinary people reflecting and not leaders posturing.
Here is a woman, 54 years old, Midwestern and middle-class, who thinks that gays, the National Organization of Women and the news media are all hostile to Christianity, and who once marched outside an abortion clinic. But she has "mixed feelings," she says, about the "back-and-forth yelling thing" and says "one-on-one evangelism" is "far better than this group stuff where you're so militant and radical."
"I really frown on evangelicals that are kind of hostile themselves," she says. "You don't win people that way. You've got to love them first. We should just stand firm in our beliefs, of course, but try to reach them in a loving way, try to talk to them and befriend them, rather than go and just start yelling things back and forth. What does that accomplish?"
"I don't believe in what you call 'hard-sell' Christianity," she says, with much elaboration. "I don't believe in preaching at people. I invite them to Christian things, and if the conversation can be such that I can talk to them about Jesus, I do that. I never hit anyone over the head with the Bible."
American evangelicals "are neither angels nor demons," Professor Smith concludes. "They are much too diverse, complex, ambivalent and inconsistent for that." Most are not particularly interested in waging the culture wars. They are neither apostles of multicultural diversity nor shock troops of intolerance. They are susceptible to demagogy but also resistant to it, in much the same ways as other Americans.
The oratory surrounding political conventions sometimes leaves the impression of a citizenry divided into alien species. Professor Smith's book argues that it just isn't so.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

A Jury in Florida Awards $144.8 Billion to Smokers
A jury in Florida ordered the tobacco industry to pay $144.8 billion in punitive damages to 500,000 smokers in the largest damage award in United States history. 
 But even as some of the sick smokers and the widows and widowers of others celebrated the verdict as a victory over the industry, tobacco executives called the award ridiculous, and one that would push the companies into bankruptcy if it is paid. They vowed to appeal the verdict, which could take years. Page A1.
 
Senate Repeals Federal Estate Tax
The Senate voted to repeal the federal estate tax, brushing aside a veto threat from President Clinton and giving Republicans a symbolic victory on an issue at the top of their election-year agenda. The vote was 59 to 39. Although Democrats have long said repeal of the tax would be a hugely expensive giveaway to the rich, 9 of 45 Democrats voted for the legislation. Four Republicans voted against. A1.
 
Nasdaq's Highest Close in 3 Months
The Nasdaq market finished with its highest close in three months as strong earnings and a tame inflation report bolstered hopes that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates again this year. The Nasdaq composite index jumped 71.32 points, or 1.7 percent, to 4,246.18. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 24.04 points, or 0.2 percent, to 10,812.75. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 14.14 points, or 0.9 percent, to 1,509.98. C3.
 
Consumer Spending Stays Strong
The nation's shoppers kept spending through the spring despite an increase in interest rates and gasoline prices, according to government reports. Retail sales climbed 0.5 percent last month, to $269.3 billion. The Labor Department's report on prices paid to producers, which excludes both services and imported goods, showed a 0.6 percent advance for finished goods. C4.
 
New Presence in the Boss's Office
A federal agency's ruling this week that non-union workers summoned into a boss's office can bring along a fellow employee as a witness has won derision from managers and praise from labor activists. But both sides say the decision is unlikely to alter the dynamics of the workplace anytime soon. C2.
 
CBS Checks Past of a Cast Member
CBS said it was "looking into" a report that one of the participants in its new reality series, "Big Brother," was an associate of the militant anti-Semitic black leader Khalid Muhammad, but the network said it saw no reason to remove the man from the program. C3.
 
Impresario Settles Suit With KPMG
The Broadway impresario Garth Drabinsky, a Canadian citizen wanted on criminal charges in the United States related to the collapse of his Livent production company, said he had settled his suit against his former accountants KPMG and KPMG Investigation and Security Inc. KPMG acknowledged that it had breached its fiduciary duty by allowing KPMG Investigation and Security to conduct an inquiry into Livent's financial affairs. C4.
 
Japan Recovery Said to Be on Track
Japan's Finance Minister said the failure of the giant retail chain Sogo would not undercut the country's economic recovery and Standard & Poor's called the Sogo bankruptcy necessary medicine for the Japanese banking system. A bailout of Sogo collapsed after Shinsei Bank, a big Sogo creditor that was recently purchased by foreign investors, balked at forgiving any Sogo debts. C2.
 
PepsiCo Has 21% Gain in Earnings
PepsiCo reported a 21 percent rise in second-quarter earnings this week, soundly beating estimates. The performance was driven by double-digit gains at its salty snacks and juice businesses. C14.

HEADLINE: CONGRESS CLEARS A BILL TO REPEAL THE ESTATE TAX

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14

 BODY:
The Senate voted today to repeal the federal estate tax, brushing aside a veto threat from President Clinton and giving Republicans at least a symbolic victory on an issue at the top of their election-year agenda.
The vote was 59 to 39. Although Democrats have long said repeal of the tax would be a hugely expensive giveaway to the rich, 9 of 45 Democrats voted in favor of the legislation, reflecting the shifting politics of taxation at a time of widespread prosperity and growing federal budget surpluses. Four Republicans voted against. 
 The House passed identical legislation last month. Republican leaders said they would send the measure to the White House promptly and use Mr. Clinton's promised veto -- which the vote today suggested Senate supporters of the bill would be unable to override -- to support their case that voters will not get tax cuts until a Republican becomes president. Gov. George W. Bush, the apparent Republican presidential nominee, supports elimination of the estate tax. His Democratic rival, Vice President Al Gore, backs a far smaller reduction in it.
Republicans presented the legislation, which would phase out the tax over the next decade, largely as an effort to help families pass farms and small businesses from one generation to another. Heirs are sometimes forced by the tax to sell part or all of the estate to pay the Internal Revenue Service.
But even under current law, the tax is levied on only a tiny proportion of estates, those worth more than $675,000, or $1.3 million in the case of family-owned farms and businesses. And in calling for full repeal of the tax for all types of estates, the bill's supporters had in mind some of their wealthiest constituents as well as the growing ranks of voters who have seen their net worth surge as the strong economy drives up the value of their homes and their holdings of stock and other investments.
Republicans said the tax was inherently unfair, no matter who paid it, arguing that there was no justification for the government to use death to make a claim on wealth amassed over a lifetime. They conjured images of the government's reaching into the grave to seize property and said that nothing less than abolishing the tax was acceptable.
"It's a cancer," Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, said after the vote. "It's wrong. We want to get rid of it totally."
Democrats said they favored exempting family-owned farms and small businesses from the estate tax, and offered their own plan to do so. But they said the Republican plan, in going much further, amounted to a tax break worth hundreds of billions of dollars in coming decades to a tiny slice of extremely rich people.
Moreover, Democrats said during the three days of debate that led up to today's vote, the money that would go to the estate tax repeal could be better used to address issues of more pressing concern to all Americans. They cited Democratic goals including the addition of prescription drug coverage to Medicare and the enactment of tax breaks for college tuition.
In a statement, Mr. Clinton called the legislation "a budget-busting bill that provides a huge tax cut for the most well-off Americans at the expense of working families."
Charitable contributions are a common way for the wealthy to reduce their projected estate tax liability, and so Mr. Clinton warned that repeal of the tax could also cut charitable donations by $5 billion to $6 billion a year.
"When this bill comes to my desk," he said, "I will veto it."
The bill would phase out the federal estate and gift tax -- what Republicans call the "death tax" -- in small steps over the next 10 years, with most of the tax disappearing only at the end of the decade.
Under current law, the amount of tax exemption for estates in general is already scheduled to rise to $1 million by 2006 from its current level of $675,000; the $1.3 million exemption for family farms and small businesses is already in effect. Above those limits, estates are subject to a graduated tax with a top rate of 55 percent.
The bill would start by eliminating a 5 percent surcharge on some estates next year and by reducing the top rate to 50 percent from 55 percent in 2002. Starting in 2003, it would begin reducing all estate-tax rates by one to two percentage points a year.
The tax would be repealed entirely in 2010, at which point the bill would bring changes in the way taxes are assessed on stocks, real estate and other assets held by an estate.
In simple terms, gains in the value of assets held by the estate would be taxed at capital gains rates starting in 2010 rather than at estate-tax rates. The bill would allow surviving spouses to avoid capital gains taxes on $3 million in assets, and in some cases on up to $4.3 million in assets.
The changes would reduce federal revenue by $104 billion over the first 10 years and by $750 billion in the second 10 years, according to the Treasury Department.
On Thursday, the Senate rejected an alternative offered by Democrats that would have substantially raised the exemption for all estates -- and even more so for family-owned farms and small businesses, effectively freeing nearly all of them from the tax. The vote against the Democratic alternative was 53 to 46.
Some members of both parties said there was a slim possibility of a compromise later this year as part of a bigger bipartisan deal on tax and spending legislation. But Republican leaders showed no public willingness today to consider taking what the Democrats had offered.
They said the Democratic plan would be subject to I.R.S. rules so complex that few family farms and businesses would be able to take advantage of it. And if even a scaled-down version of the tax remained, Republicans said, Democrats would press to broaden its reach again whenever they got a chance.
"The Democrats offered a fig leaf," said Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the Republican whip.
In debating the bill, the Senate had adopted a number of tax-cutting amendments, including a repeal of the 3 percent federal excise tax on telephone service and the permanent extension of a corporate tax credit for research and experimentation costs.
But under orders from the Republican leadership, the Senate voted today to strip out all the amendments, intent on sending Mr. Clinton -- and voters -- an undiluted message about the majority's position on the estate tax.
While the debate today put on display the continuing deep differences between the parties over tax cuts, it also demonstrated that Democrats had become more willing to champion tax cuts of their own, although at substantially lower levels than sought by Republicans.
In addition, it illustrated the breach in the Democratic ranks over the estate tax, an issue that the party long considered of interest only to a tiny sliver of very wealthy people and the tax lawyers and accountants who make a living by developing estate plans that help the rich escape the full brunt of the tax.
The Democrats who voted for the bill were Senators John B. Breaux of Louisiana, Max Cleland of Georgia, Dianne Feinstein of California, Mary L. Landrieu of Louisiana, Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas, Patty Murray of Washington, Charles S. Robb of Virginia, Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey and Ron Wyden of Oregon.
The Republicans opposed were Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island, James M. Jeffords of Vermont, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and George V. Voinovich of Ohio. Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota, and Tim Hutchinson, Republican of Arkansas, did not vote.
A number of the Democrats who voted for the bill are Southerners regularly to the right of their party. Another of them, Mr. Robb, faces a tough re-election race this year and did not want to give the Republicans ammunition to portray him as against tax cuts. Still others come from states with some combination of high real estate prices, large numbers of successful technology entrepreneurs and significant numbers of family-owned farms.
"The estate tax is a wildly clumsy, inefficient tax that basically is a full-employment program for lawyers and accountants," Mr. Wyden said. "We ought to be phasing out the estate tax, and we should work toward a tax code that is both progressive and entrepreneur-friendly."
