HEADLINE: Near Chicago's Downtown, a New Gold Coast

BYLINE: By ROBERT SHAROFF 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
IN a throwback to the early years of the 20th century when wealthy Chicago families tended to live in such close-in neighborhoods as Prairie Avenue and the Gold Coast, the city's Lincoln Park area is experiencing a boom in mansion construction.
In the last five years, the neighborhood, about a mile and a half north of the Loop, has seen construction of dozens of examples of the kind of house that had not been built in any great number in the inner city in many years. They are palatial residences of at least 6,000 square feet w that start at around $2.5 million and go much higher. 
 The number of such houses, like the official definition of what constitutes a mansion, is difficult to ascertain. Most people seem to know one when they see one, however. And the evidence of a dramatic change in the neighborhood's fortunes is clear from a walk down any of the long blocks of Howe or Mohawk or Burling Streets just north of Old Town.
Looming over the remaining original housing -- mainly modestly scaled clapboard cottages and brick three-flats that date from just after the Chicago fire in 1871 -- are the elaborate limestone facades of dozens of new three- and four-story houses.
Who is buying them? Real estate agents and builders say the main clients are couples and families in their mid-30's and early 40's who have struck it rich in the booming economy of the last decade and are choosing to stay in the city rather than move to the suburbs.
"This is the new wave," said Sean Conlon, director of sales and marketing for Sussex & Reilly, a leading North Side residential brokerage firm. "The last people to build houses this big downtown were the great industrialists and robber barons of the 1890's. But they built over on the Gold Coast. A new neighborhood is emerging here."
Mr. Conlon, 31, recently moved into a new four-story, 6,000-square-foot house on Mohawk Street with a slate mansard roof, arched windows and lavish detailing. "They had homes like this in Paris and London in the 1700's and 1800's," he said. "It's an exquisite, timeless style."
Mr. Conlon's house is typical of the prevailing look of the new houses. The style, which leans heavily toward limestone columns, balustrades and elaborate fruit and flower friezework, is usually described as Georgian or Classical or Beaux-Arts.
In some ways, it is an unlikely look for Chicago area, the birthplace of modern architecture and the home of such modernist giants as Frank Lloyd Wright and Mies van der Rohe.
"They look like banks," said one top real estate agent. who requested anonymity.
John Vinci of Vinci/Hamp Architects, a firm much noted locally for historic renovation work, calls them fantasy houses. "They're emulations of turn-of-the-century Parisian or Belgian grand houses," he said. "It's just fantasy to build these houses now."
Mr. Vinci is also the architect -- along with the late Max Gordon, a British architect -- of the house that many say was the beginning of the whole downtown mansion trend. Nine years ago, Lewis Manilow, a local investor and chairman of President Clinton's Illinois fund-raising committee, went looking for what he called "a country house in the city." When he could not find one, he decided to build a new house on four adjoining lots he had acquired on Howe Street.
Howe Street at that time, Mr. Vinci said, was "a street of small houses" in a neighborhood that had been steadily gentrifying since the 1970's but that had yet to see much new construction.
The house Mr. Vinci designed is a modern, 10,000-square-foot tan brick structure with a sizable garden.
"I wanted to consolidate my life," Mr. Manilow said. "I used to have a condo as well as a loft where I had my office and part of my art collection. Now everything is in one place."
Why Lincoln Park? "It's very urban," Mr. Manilow said. "You can walk downtown, to the lake, the park. There's lots of people on the street. It's just a very friendly neighborhood."
Another consideration is the availability of land for construction, free of landmark-district constraints. Traditionally, the wealthy in Chicago have lived on the Gold Coast, a roughly 12-square-block area that includes Lake Shore Drive and Astor Street and is just south and east of Lincoln Park.
DEVELOPED around the turn of the century, the housing is a mix of mainly co-op apartment buildings and historic mansions and row houses, many of which are official landmarks.
"There's only 80-some single-family houses on the Gold Coast," said James M. Kinney, president of Rubloff Residential Properties, a leading downtown residential brokerage. "And you have to get neighborhood approval to tear anything down. Lincoln Park, however, aside from a few areas, isn't landmarked. You can build what you want."
Which is exactly what is happening. "I get calls every day from people who are looking to build in the neighborhood," said Elizabeth Ballis, a saleswoman with Coldwell Banker's Lincoln Park office.
The new houses are a mix of build-to-suits and speculative ventures by half a dozen custom builders. The two most influential are the Metzler Hull Development Corporation and the BGD&C Corporation. Both are local companies that build four or five houses a year. The houses generally take 12 to 14 months to complete.
According to Jay Metzler, one of the principals of Metzler Hull, the process begins with finding land, something that has become more difficult in the last few years. Single 25-foot-by-125-foot lots now sell for up to $700,000 or $800,000 and the ideal is two or more contiguous lots.
"We're building a $2.8 million spec house right now on a single lot and the land is a quarter of the price," Mr. Metzler said. "We like doing specs. They give us a chance to exercise our creativity. We've done 12 to 15 of them over the last few years and all but one sold well before they were finished."
BOTH companies stress that what sells are luxurious details and craftsmanship. "We spend a lot of time in Europe researching moldings, door designs and other features that people seem to have gotten away from over here," said Charles Grode, vice president of BGD&C. He added that the company recently built an 8,500-square-foot Venetian-style home on a double lot on Burling Street that is authentic "right down to the chimney caps." The roof, he added, is made of "100-year-old clay tiles from a building in Philadelphia."
His customers "want the details to be rich," Mr. Metzler said. This means, as a matter of course, mahogany paneling and window frames throughout, marble and oak floors, grand curving staircases and -- in some houses -- 20- and 25-foot-high ceilings.
How do they differ from the grand houses of the past? "They don't have ballrooms," said Mr. Vinci, the architect.
What they do have, however, are children. Both companies say that children's rooms and activities have a new prominence in most of their houses. Mr. Metzler said he was building a roller-hockey rink in the basement of one house and was planning a basketball court in the basement of another. The basketball court alone, he said, will add more than $200,000 to the cost of the house.
"This is an absolute dream house," said Elizabeth Saltzman, who along with her husband, Richard, the owner of Banner Wholesale Grocers, recently bought a Metzler Hull house. "We looked at some older houses, but we have four kids and it can be tough to find that many bedrooms in an older house.
"There's a very welcoming feeling here. People sit on their porches and stoops. The kids have a certain freedom that they probably wouldn't have in other neighborhoods. They can walk to the park and do things by themselves."
Her verdict? "As long as we can afford it, we're staying."

HEADLINE: Nassau Needs Space, but Needs Money First

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
IN the worst of financial times for a government struggling to stay afloat on a sea of surrounding wealth, Nassau County is advancing its first comprehensive plan to protect environmentally sensitive lands and scenic open spaces.
The plan could be a blueprint for the preservation of properties that include Greentree, the 450-acre Whitney family estate in Manhasset, the 81-acre Underhill property in Jericho and parcels as small as two acres in the densely populated Town of Hempstead. 
 But with severe budget strictures dimming prospects for county financing of land programs that advanced little even in better days, the fiscally more robust towns in Nassau appear likely to take the lead. North Hempstead is close to formally proposing a $15 million Environmental Legacy Fund and Oyster Bay is discussing a similar program for up to twice that amount.
County and town officials said the open-space plans, which place high priority on protecting groundwater, were responses to strong public support for preservation. "This should have been done 20 years ago," said May W. Newburger, the North Hempstead supervisor.
Still to be tested is the public's willingness to pay for such programs. In North Hempstead, the town board is to vote in September on whether to place the $15 million proposal on the ballot in November. The town said the cost would be less than $9 a year for homeowners.
The officials also see an opportunity to attract funds from the state and federal governments during the current economic expansion. For example, a bill approved in the House and now before the Senate would take some of the $900 million a year paid by companies drilling oil offshore and divide it among the states for preservation.
In its land preservation efforts, Nassau lags far behind Suffolk, where voter-supported programs began in the 1970's. Suffolk is more than three times the size of Nassau, which covers 183,488 acres. But Suffolk has 37,000 acres of county parks and preserves, more than five times more than in Nassau, with 6,520 acres.
Six of Suffolk's 10 towns have financed open-space programs, including a $15 million program overwhelmingly approved two years ago by voters in Huntington.
While North Hempstead and Oyster Bay move to follow the financing examples of the Suffolk towns, Hempstead will rely on available funds for open space and park programs, said Supervisor Richard V. Guardino Jr., who oversees a $50 million budget surplus.
Mr. Guardino cited one example: a partnership with the state Department of Environmental Conservation under which the department bought more than 70 acres of wetlands in Lido Beach that the town will manage and maintain.
The newly released Nassau County plan, intended to be the opening phase of a master plan the county adopted in 1998, includes the first inventory of all open spaces. These range from the 3,606 acres of county parks and 2,914 acres of county nature preserves to 6,011 acres of road rights-of-way, 1,050 acres of recharge basins and 714 acres of cemeteries, and include 4,741 acres of estate lands and vacant properties that are available or may become available for development.
The county plan lays out options for keeping land open: outright purchase, purchase of development rights only, conservation easements and preservation by private groups and businesses.
Paul F. Ponessa, the director of the Nassau County Planning Commission, said the county would rank properties to place key ones first while assuring protection efforts were extended to all parts of the county. He emphasized that only willing owners would be approached, but neither he nor other officials would discuss specific properties.
Nor are the owners forthcoming. While the Greentree Foundation, which owns the old Whitney estate, has never publicly expressed interest in selling, the estate -- currently zoned for one house every five acres -- is in a state-designated groundwater protection area that makes its preservation a high priority.
The Underhill property in Oyster Bay is also in a watershed area. Last week the Appellate Division upheld a ruling that the town had violated state law by relying on a 10-year-old environmental impact statement in approving housing proposed by Tilles Investment, the land's owner.
Officials and environmental groups supporting the Nassau plan said the county's current financial problems should not detract from preservation plans that are intended to unfold over many years.
Paul P. Rabinovitch, executive director of the Long Island chapter of the Nature Conservancy, which has played a major role in preservation, said his group had pledged to assist Nassau and saw no reasons to be discouraged by the county's financial situation.
"Funding is obviously important, but as important is intent," he said. "If the intent is there, preservation will happen, and there are other options for preserving land rather than just to buy it."
Joseph H. Lorintz, a lawyer and president of the Society to Preserve Underhill, said the need to protect that property and others was too urgent to be delayed by Nassau's financial malaise. "Even with the county's miserable financial condition, you can't just ignore the environment," he said.
Others said the county could finance a program by reallocating some or all of the sales tax revenues that the county currently divides among Nassau's three towns and two cities. The revenues, initially provided for landfill closures and solid-waste management, are projected at more than $45 million this year.
"What you need is a dedicated, earmarked fund, and it should come out of a small portion of the county sales tax," said Neal Lewis, executive director of the Long Island Neighborhood Network.
But town governments would be likely to resist any reduction in their shares. "Why take money away if we are already doing something?" Supervisor Newburger asked, a reference to the proposed environmental fund.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
In New London, a Garde Audience Is Growing

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
THE attention-grabbing summer news in New London may have been all about tall ships, but yesterday, they sailed away. Now, how can a town of 28,000 follow that act? With professional summer theater, that's how.
For the grandly restored Garde Arts Center, Operation Sail was a stopover for millions, but a first-ever Summer On Stage season -- it opened Thursday and goes on through Sept. 1 -- is here to stay. And it is the newest chapter in the evolution of a town and of its theater. 
 After last year's splashy reopening of the Garde, a movie palace and a vaudeville house in its glory days more than 70 years ago, the necessity for an emerging artistic vision became abundantly clear to Steve Sigel, the 1,488-seat showplace's managing director.
Although Patti LuPone was a top draw in her opening-night concert, star quality of that caliber was not to be an every-night affair. Bus and truck tours of musicals -- "Annie," "1776," "Camelot," "Victor/Victoria" and "Show Boat" -- followed, each for two performances. "A large house in a small community cannot do a big Broadway show for a full week," Mr. Sigel said. But the Garde audience grows. For the fall-winter season, which already shows a 50-percent increase in ticket sales, Mr. Sigel said, "Godspell" is scheduled for three shows. And there will be four for the "Phantom" by Maury Yeston and Arthur Kopit.
Other successes also tell a growth story. One scheduled appearance by the jazz singer and musician, Diana Krall, was increased to two. Then there's the word-of-mouth popularity of "Late Nite Catechism," an Off Broadway sendup in the manner of Sister Mary Ignatius and all those "Nunsenses." After eight performances in a reconfigured space, seating 350 in January, it is to play a seven-performance encore Aug. 8 through 13, the fourth show in the new summer series.
Summer On Stage opened with "Grease." "Forbidden Hollywood" is to play Tuesday through next Sunday. On Aug. l5, "If You Ever Leave Me . . . I'm Going With You," written by and starring Renee Taylor and Joe Bologna, will give the first of seven performances. "Five Guys Named Moe" and "Tony and Tina's Wedding" finish the season, six performances each.
The summer part of the Garde's theater programming reflects the cultural awareness of a gritty little town, to rephrase the words of the arts center's publicity representative Patty Freedman, who went on to say that attention to substance is the Garde's new thrust, now that its spectacular $15.75 million renovation, is proven. "The economics are still being attended to," Ms. Freedman said. "But it's time to look at what's going on artistically."
And don't forget acoustical preservation; it was Ms. LuPone who gave testament to that and thanks during her first-night concert last October. Mr. Sigel loves to talk about the seats. "Great personal comfort when you're sitting for two and a half hours matters as much as architecture and marketing," he said. "Going to the theater should not be a back-breaking experience."
Not that he deflects queries about that artistic vision. That takes time, he concedes, and the Garde is in a formative phase, learning from process and exploring possibility. Three months ago, the peerless Savion Glover and his troupe took over the theater, the studios and rehearsal spaces for one week to work on his new show, now on tour. Before leaving, Mr. Glover held the world premiere performance of "Footnotes" at the Garde.
As for the summer series, with weeklong shows scheduled for the first time, Mr. Sigel talked about attracting audiences "we don't normally get, especially the people who live here, but go to Florida in October."
"We want to do shows with an intimate feeling," he went on. "With the Garde's lighting, you don't notice the disappearance of a full proscenium." Mr. Sigel is eager to find new ways of producing, or presenting, new or old material for new audiences. "We want to interest other producers in coming here. The blockbuster type show is on the way out, and more theaters" -- he mentioned Goodspeed in East Haddam and the Bushnell in Hartford -- are planning smaller stages. "There is a paucity of product to command a large stage," he added, looking to alliances with regional theaters and expressing interest in extending the life of Off Broadway plays and musicals.
As the art part evolves, the Garde has real estate to spare and to accommodate it. The Garde owns six buildings -- 187,000 square feet in all -- some now used for office rentals, some for its Institute for Creativity classes in performing arts. Thinking back on the movie palace of old, Mr. Sigel mentioned a modern-day homage to Hollywood classics.
"Casablanca" was screened in March "and 1,100 people came," Mr. Sigel recalled. Don't think he is not thinking of a small cinema. "Now the Garde is listening to the community," Ms. Freedman added.

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 11; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 924 words

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
'Cowches' To Graze At Home

BYLINE: By LISA SUHAY

DATELINE: RHODESTOWN

 BODY:
If you're in the market for a cow, Helga Tacreiter can be of some help.
She doesn't use cloning or gene therapy, but rather a combination of sewing and vegetarianism to create what she calls a "cowch." 
 These creations are life-size animal floor pillows, each named and individually patterned after the cattle tended by Ms. Tancreiter. The herd is an odd mix of cows and bulls that includes Jersey, Mexican, Scottish Highland and Black Angus breeds she has taken in over the years. So far, more than 1,000 cowches graze people's homes.
One of her higher-profile customers is Gateway, the computer maker based in San Diego, whose company logo is a black-and-white cow printed on its shipping boxes.
The 48-year-old Ms. Tacreiter lives on an 80-acre farm just south of Shilo, in Hopewell Township, where she has spent the past 10 years raising what she calls "companion cattle" -- 15 bovine pets. She is, it should be noted, a vegetarian.
While she started with a herd of six calves, other cattle have been brought to her farm for fostering from animal lovers from around the state as well as the group called Farm Sanctuary in Watkins Glen, N.Y., PETA (People for the Ethical Treatment of Amimals) and individuals from Pennsylvania and Maryland
Sometimes she keeps the animals, and sometimes they move on to Farm Sanctuary. "It depends on how the animal fits in with the herd," Ms. Tacreiter said.
Born in Gdansk, Poland, Ms. Tacreiter moved several times after her parents -- her mother was a chemist and her father a psychiatrist -- divorced when she was a toddler. Her mother moved to Nova Scotia, and her father raised her.
Helga and her father moved to England when she was 5, then to Ontario at the age of 7, and finally settled in Maryland when she was 12. She attended California State University, where she majored in English literature.
"If I didn't go to some college somewhere," she said, "my father would have been heart-broken.'
While at the university she met a young man who lived in Shilo and decided to follow him here. Last year, after 23 years, their relationship ended.
"He's a neat freak and I'm a slob and it became unbearable on both sides," she said.
During their time together she did odd jobs at local farms and crafted tiny replicas of homes that she sold. She wrote "Possum Huts" -- a photo book of the intricately detailed miniature homes with stained-glass windows and hand-dipped taper candles that she made herself -- which was published in 1984.
She said she decided to become a vegetarian after reading Upton Sinclair's "The Jungle" in high school. "Everyone else saw the animals representing people, but I also saw the slaughter of the animals and that stuck with me," she said.
Ten years ago, while working for a local horse ranch that also had a small herd of cattle, Ms. Tacreiter first began rescuing livestock.
"It started out when I was taking care of this really sick calf, Harvey," she said. "The herd I was caring for was struck by lightning one night and the 15 adults were killed. Six calves survived and Harvey was in shock and very ill."
Ms. Tacreiter took Harvey home and spent weeks tending him.
"I would snuggle with him," she said. "I had this teddy bear when I was 2 that was as big as I was and this reminded me of those days. One day I woke up and realized that here I was spending all this time healing this animal that we're going to slaughter."
Ms. Tacreiter convinced the farmer to give her the calves, which she determined to save from human consumption.
"I was thinking about it one day and I thought that if people had stuffed cows instead of teddy bears they would relate to them and not want to eat them," she went on. "Then I thought I really wanted to reach adults, too, so I thought having the animal be big enough for an adult to cuddle would be ideal.".
With that, she was off to the fabric shop to gather materials and try her hand at creating a life-size stuffed cow. Returning to the farm with several bolts of faux fur material, she found Harvey was keenly interested in her project and followed her around.
"I decided to try modeling the fabric and pinning it on Harvey," she said. "He stood still for five hours while I made the first pattern right on him."
The first effort was a minor disaster. "I had home economics in eigth grade and that's about the extent of my sewing training," she said. "It looked like an alien cow. I keep it in the attic."
Subsequent attempts improved her results, and today Ms. Tacreiter turns out about 100 cowches a year on her own, and more if she hires help.
The creations range in price from $300 for a calf to $500 for a yearling and $800 for an adult-sized cowch. She also does horses. The sale of the cowches and her book -- along with donations -- keep home and herd together.
Two years ago, at Gateway's request, Ms. Tacreiter created a cowch with a black world map instead of spots, for which she was rewarded with a computer. "The World Cow," she said, sits today in the office of the company's chief executive, Ted Waitt.
On the whole, Ms. Tacreiter prefers transactions to be cash cows rather than items for barter since it costs about $1,000 a year to feed each cow and about the same amount for each of the two horses. Ms. Tacreiter raises her own hay top help keep costs down.
"Let's just say that my life has always run on miracles," Ms. Tacreiter said. "Just when I'm sure I can't make the mortgage, like now, something happens to pull us through. I'm waiting for the next one."

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 1; Column 2; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 2016 words

HEADLINE: A Fight Over, of All Things, an Insurance Office

BYLINE: By STACEY STOWE

 BODY:
IN 1957, the Connecticut General Insurance Company abandoned Hartford, the insurance capital of the world, for suburban Bloomfield. The company's president, Frazer B. Wilde, commissioned a mammoth company headquarters, designed by a world-renowned architect and sculptor to be set amid hundreds of pastoral acres.
Forty-three years later, the company, now known as the Cigna Corporation, is planning to reduce its ownership of the land to less than 30 acres. The rest will be sold to developers. The flagship building and one other will make way for a golf course, hotel and houses. Its proposal to sell the property has already passed one round of town approvals and has the support of Bloomfield's mayor. 
 The architectural community, however, is outraged. Although the buildings are deep in the suburbs and are, after all, just the offices of another insurance company in a region that has plenty, many architects say the buildings and their grounds are historically significant.
"Frazer Wilde's plan redefined the American workplace," said Tyler Smith of Smith Edwards Architects, a Hartford firm that is leading the effort to save the buildings. "The Wilde building is as cultural significant as Samuel Colt's factory 100 years ago."
Mr. Smith and the other principal of the firm, Jared Edwards, are enlisting the aid of their high-profile colleagues, architects like Robert A. M. Stern, the dean of the Yale University School of Architecture, and David M. Childs, chief architect for Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, the firm chosen by Mr. Wilde more than 40 years ago to build his dream corporate campus, as well as directors from the Museum of Modern Art and both the National and the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation.
At stake is the fate of two Modern corporate buildings: the 827,000-square-foot Wilde building as well as the 570,000-square-foot North Building, once the headquarters of the Emhart Corporation, a hardware company. Both buildings were designed by Gordon Bunshaft, a leading proponent of International Style , which is characterized by pure geometric shapes, an absence of ornamentation and a reliance on engineering principles to convey structure. Among Mr. Bunshaft's designs are Lever House in New York City and the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library at Yale University.
The Wilde Building features four interior courtyards and sculpture by Isamu Noguchi, a sculptor and landscape designer whose work is featured in the Unesco building in Paris and the sunken sculpture garden at the Beinecke Library. Cigna executives said Mr. Noguchi's work "The Family," an exterior sculpture on its Bloomfield campus, will be sold to developers along with the rest of the property, a subject of concern, along with the proposed destruction of the courtyards, to directors of the Isamu Noguchi Foundation and Museum, said Amy Hau, administrative director of foundation in New York.
The North building, across the street from the Wilde complex, was Gordon Bunshaft's first poured-concrete building. Its cantilevered design gives it the effect of floating.
Executives for Cigna have dismissed the outcry from the architectural community as the inflated opinion of impractical elitists.
"Cigna's history and tradition is not a building," said Kenneth J. Ferraro, director of public relations for the company. "It's providing competitively superior value and service from its employees to its customers and shareholders. This development proposal allows us to continue to do this."
The existing buildings, Cigna executives said, are too big, too costly to operate and outmoded for today's technology. While the Bloomfield campus houses more than 4,500 employees, the company headquarters moved to Philadelphia in 1982, shortly after Connecticut General merged with Insurance Company of North America.
The architects said Frazer Wilde was among the first to change where corporate America worked in the 1950's, by moving to the suburbs and commissioning cutting edge architects and artists as well as the designer Florence Knoll, who designed the streamlined furnishings in the building and went on to form Knoll Furniture.
Mr. Wilde also influenced how corporate America worked. The open-floored, three-story Wilde building featured 360-degree views of ponds, gentle hills and wildflowers. It also included a bowling alley, a hair salon and a boutique-sized Lord & Taylor department store. Yet Cigna executives said the needs of its work force have changed.
"Employees today are less interested in making work their whole world," said Anthony J. Paticchio, assistant general counsel in investment law for Cigna. "They're more concerned about a diverse work force, competitive salaries and things like parking."
When it was unveiled, the Wilde building was the new thing, earning accolades from magazines like Time and Fortune and awards from the architectural community. The building was a departure from its peers, buildings that were more typically stone and ornately designed. By contrast, the enormous yet sleek Wilde building sheathes its steel skeleton in a green-hued glass skin. The building is one large rectangle attached to smaller rectangles on the south, west and north sides. The rectangularity of its exterior is echoed in the multi-sized rectangular windows; from inside, the rolling acreage appears through the windows as a series of framed landscapes. The ceilings soar and the corridors are enormous and often open to courtyards, whose doors are locked but the space features a bench or two. The sheer size of the space makes an airport terminal seem cozy. It is the dream work place of a claustrophobe.
Yet it is the very size of the building and its horizontal layout that is most bothersome to the Cigna executives.
"If you look the company archives, the building was designed along the lines of a light manufacturing model," said Mr. Ferraro. "People moved paper around like a human conveyer belt. We don't work that way anymore." Both he and Mr. Paticchio commended the building's usefulness in Wilde's time.
Mr. Smith and Mr. Edwards describe the Wilde building as a model of meritocracy, designed so the company president was spotted in the building as easily as a filing clerk. The horizontal design was a physical reaction against the hierarchy of corporate America.
Cigna's response?
"It was never about the romantic notion of creating a meritocracy," Mr. Ferraro said. "That notion was applied to justify it as an architectural monument. In its day, 2,000 people were on a schedule and a whistle was used to call them to lunch."
Company executives estimated that to merely maintain the building's mechanicals and increase the wiring necessary for merely adequate -- never mind state of the art -- computer technology will cost $40 million over the next seven years.
But Mr. Childs, whose firm, Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, is restoring the exterior of the Bunshaft-designed Lever House in New York, said adaptation of the Wilde building is indeed possible if the idea that the building is a cultural landmark is adopted. Much older buildings with significant challenges to modern adaptation have been restored and renovated.
"The property is the prototype for the suburban corporate park," Mr. Childs said. "Too often in America when something becomes outmoded, we just throw it away when it could be adapted and treasured as part of our cultural history."
His colleague, Mr. Stern, said that the kind of architectural patronage of the 1940's and 50's, as evidenced by the Seagram, I.B.M. and Connecticut General buildings, is not seen today. Instead, corporate architecture tends to be anonymous, built by developers to be leased to corporations, Mr. Stern said.
Another hurdle is the preservation movement itself. The cherishing of Modern buildings is a relatively nascent concept outside the architectural community. Modern buildings are held to a much higher standard than their antecedents, Mr. Stern said.
"The preservation movement grew up in protest to the destruction of some buildings of the 19th and 20th century to make way for International Style buildings," he said. "This movement tends to be skeptical about the merit of these buildings."
Unlike New York City, where buildings can be made landmarks for preservation, organizations seeking protective status for Connecticut buildings cannot do so without the permission of the building owner. Although the State Historical Commission and State Historic Preservation Office have said that the Connecticut General campus merits preservation, these organizations cannot halt demolition. The campus will be proposed by Smith Edwards Architects for listing on the state and national registers of historic places.
Nor can the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation prevent demolitions of historic properties in the state. Christopher Wigren, assistant director for the group, said his organization has no regulatory powers. At the moment, Mr. Wigren said the group is collecting information on buildings similar in style and period to Bunshaft's that were successfully adapted to new uses, such as the Reynolds Metal building in Virginia and the General Motors headquarters in Michigan.
The next challenge for the Cigna proposal is a town planning and zoning meeting on Wednesday. Several zone changes for the property will be reviewed.
With the raging real estate market, Cigna plans to sell almost all of its 650 acres to developers. They have worked out a master plan with the assistance of Elkus/Manfredi, a Boston architectural firm. It includes an 18-hole Arnold Palmer-designed golf course, a 275-room hotel and conference center where the Wilde building now stands.
The residential component of the plan includes 158 single family houses priced at about $275,000 and 240 "luxury" apartments. The 4,600 employees will move to the company's remaining 30-odd acres on the southern part of the campus where the South building now stands. Two new buildings will be added by developers and Cigna will lease space from the owners. As of yet, no developers have been hired.
Both Connecticut General and Cigna have kept the 650-acre site open to the public. Anyone can meander the property. Bikers and joggers are a common sight as are soccer and tennis players on the company's fields and courts.Tom Hooper, the town planner, said many Bloomfield parents have taught their children to drive on the quiet roads of the campus. Although plans for the new site will feature a public golf course, the development proposal will certainly change the public's use of the property, yet officials said very few people are complaining.
"There's tremendous support for the proposal everywhere I go," said Faith McMahon, who has been Bloomfield's mayor since 1993. Cigna is far and away the town's biggest taxpayer. In 1999, the corporation paid $198,376,324 in taxes; the second highest tax revenue was $23,120,338 paid by the Kaman Corporation.
The proposal seems to have quelled an uncertainty about the corporation's commitment to the town since the company moved its headquarters from Bloomfield to Philadelphia in 1983.
"One thing we've always worried about with regard to Cigna is the diversity issue," Ms. McMahon said, referring to the town being so dependent on one company for tax revenue and jobs. "This plan offers diversity and the golf course still keeps some open space."
Diversifying the site is something Mr. Smith and Mr. Edwards said they could agree upon with Cigna. Both men have said they do not question the corporation's right to develop the property, but claim the proposal is "so transparently a scheme to maximize a one-time return on this real estate." The architects have promoted the economic benefits of a 20 percent historic tax credit for companies who chose to restore rather than tear down historic buildings, but said their discussions with Cigna thus far have been "fragile, at best."
"We just know there is a better way to develop this property and maintain it as a cultural landmark," Mr. Edwards said.

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 9; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1545 words

HEADLINE: Home Health Care Aides Are in Demand, but in Short Supply

BYLINE: By JOY ALTER HUBEL

 BODY:
WHEN he was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis six years ago, Keith Fields, an avid boater and fisherman, was living with his girlfriend in Ronkonkoma and working as an alarm installation technician. Today, at age 33, he can't even move his arms.
His mother, Dianne Davis, who oversees his care while working full-time as a hairdresser, said that when his symptoms worsened about three years ago, she hired home health aides through certified agencies. But when the aides repeatedly failed to show up, Mr. Fields's girlfriend persuaded him to go into a nursing home. 
 "A year ago, I took him out of there. That was no place for him," Ms. Davis said. "He should be at home as long as he can be. He is still very mentally aware, and should be allowed to feel as independent as he can be made to feel."
For the present, Mr. Fields is back in his own apartment in Ronkonkoma with a 24-hour live-in home health aide who, for little more than minimum wage, feeds, bathes, cooks and cleans house for him. He relies on the aide, supplied through a home health agency that is reimbursed by his Medicaid benefits, to protect what is left of his independence and keep him from landing back in a nursing home.
It is a struggle. Recently, Ms. Davis discovered that her son had not been changed and cleaned for a six-hour stretch. "I nearly went ballistic," she said, "but people tell me not to complain."
She knows how hard it is to find well-trained and reliable home health care on Long Island.
The region's healthy economy, with the lowest unemployment rate in New York State, has not been so healthy for many of Long Island's sick, disabled and elderly. Nowadays, the home health aides that they rely on for the tasks associated with daily living can easily find less demanding, better-paying jobs. And they do.
"When the economy was in the slumps there would be people lined up around the corner willing to train for certification in home health aide," said Mary Lou Boyle, director for public health nursing for the Suffolk County Public Health Department.
"Today, someone can get a job at Stern's or Macy's for the salary equivalent to what a home health or personal aide can expect -- about $7 to $10 per hour -- and not have to worry about changing adult diapers or hoisting heavy bodies into bathrooms," Ms. Boyle said. "It is also a very lonely job. It's not like working at a store where you can be with fellow employees."
Many home health aides are women from poor or minority backgrounds and are sometimes looked upon by elderly clients not so much as trained paraprofessionals but as maids. "It is not unusual to have a client expect a health care aide to wash their windows," Ms. Boyle said.
Dr. Mary Ann Wilner, director of health policy for Paraprofessional Health Care Institute in the Bronx, a nonprofit affiliate that oversees a group of five employee-owned home health care agencies, said it is demographics rather than the healthy economy that is creating the crisis in home health care.
"Even if there were to be a downturn in the economy, the problem will still not go away," Dr. Wilner said. "Compared with the stagnant caregiver population, a cohort group that tends to be women in the 25-to-50-year age range, the elderly population is growing in leaps and bounds." She said that the only way to correct the problem is to transform the profession into something more appealing and reduce the annual turnover rate, which, on a national basis, is 40 to 60 percent.
"There is very little concern for worker benefits, training and health," Dr. Wilner said. "But what we try to do is focus on the fact that it can be a good job. Many people love the work and care about caring for people. We need to figure out how to make this job more attractive. We need to extend training, improve wages, and provide full benefits, opportunities for advancement, support and supervision."
Susan Hechtman, vice president of Aides at Home Inc. in Hicksville, said the problem is money. "We get constant calls requesting home health aides all day," she said. "And out of 15 of these patients we may be able to service only five. The root of the problem is money. Agencies get reimbursed $10 per hour from insurance, which also has to include profit and overhead."
Karen Dargo, downstate market manager for Norrell Health Care, which provides nurses and paraprofessionals to health consumers, said that her employee roster has declined 25 percent to 30 percent in two years..
"Based on what we can pay our staff, we can't compete with food service and retail," she said. "These jobs can guarantee workers one job at one location for a full eight-hour day. Home health aides often have to travel between two and three clients within an eight-hour day."
Fione Ferrier, a 33-year-old home health care aide for the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System, visits four patients within her eight-hour shift. She helps her clients get out of bed, helps them shower, changes their linens, and possibly provides a meal, all within 90 minutes. Added to her duties is travel time, which, depending on traffic can be 15 to 30 minutes between visits.
"I have one patient with Parkinson's disease, and it takes him a half hour just to get out of the bed," she said. "By the time you get him into the shower, it's almost time to go."
She has worked for a variety of agencies in the past, but they were only able to provide her with part-time work, which had not included benefits. She says that at North Shore, she gets full-time work, benefits, gas reimbursement, training seminars and thus feels less isolated. Eventually, she hopes to go to school to become a registered nurse.
For many entry-level workers like the Jamaican-born Ms. Ferrier, a position as a home health care or personal aide assistant can provide a pathway to better-paying jobs in the health industry.
Home health care agencies on Long Island have been trying to compete more aggressively in the employment market by providing work incentives in the form of sign-on bonuses, health benefits, college tuition and gas allowances.
Steven Sternbach, chief executive officer of Star Multi Care in Huntington Station, which runs 15 home health agencies in five northeastern states, offers his employees a choice of packages.
"Do you want $8 per hour and no benefits or $7 and full insurance?" Mr. Sternbach said. "Maybe you have a working spouse and don't need the insurance. We also provide 401K plans and try to educate them about benefits."
He said that despite his efforts, his four Long Island offices are filling only about 75 percent to 80 percent of customer demand. There are approximately 6,020 home health aides and 4,360 personal home care aides on Long Island, according to 1997 state statistics. But the agency estimates that there will be an additional 2,400 annual openings per year through 2006.
Home health care agencies are not optimistic that these openings can be filled, given the rate at which the population is aging and insurance reimbursement rates are falling. Nationwide, Medicare spending on home health care has dropped by 45 percent, from $17.5 billion in 1997 to $9.7 billion in 1999, based on data complied by the Congressional Budget Office. Furthermore, additional cuts of up to 15 percent are threatened when a new Medicare reimbursement system begins in October 2000.
This system, as well as other recent cuts in health care benefits, underscores what amounts to a baffling medical paradox for health care providers.
"I think that economic pressures of health care dictate that more and more patients are cared for at home," said Dr. Charles Robbins, associate dean of social welfare at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. "And most patients do heal better in familiar surroundings. Families are increasingly being called upon to provide the services that were once performed by the hospitals and health care workers, yet the psycho-social supports are not in place to help them."
If it has become financially and psychologically healthier -- for both the patient and the economy -- to manage health care at home, then why aren't health care benefits being realigned?
"What it will take is a legislator's mother who is not able to get home care," Dr. Robbins said.
He also said that the shortage in home health aides is forcing patients to languish in hospitals after their medical care is completed.
"The inability of home care agencies to attract the staff needed to provide services to patients results in our inability to move patients through the system as soon as they are ready," he said.
Dr. Robbins also worries that agencies, though not saying so outright, will hesitate to take on the more complicated cases if they think they can't provide care within Medicare's prescribed dollar amount.
"The reality is that we trust people who are the most vulnerable in our society to be cared for by home care staff," Dr. Robbins said. "Their adult children have families and careers. But we, as a society, don't value the care well enough to pay livable wages and benefits. The consequence of a good economy is that people are not willing to do these jobs. It is very hard work. We need to rethink some of our values."

HEADLINE: L.I.@WORK;
Business Comes a-Courtin' to Cold Spring Harbor

BYLINE: By WARREN STRUGATCH

 BODY:
ONE night two months ago, James Watson -- Nobel laureate, president of Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory and inspiration to several generations of scientists -- rose from his seat to accept a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Long Island Association, the region's largest business group. Although the scientist lives and works just minutes from the posh country club the group favors for major events, most of the black-tie attendees were meeting Dr. Watson, discoverer of the structure of DNA, for the first time.
No slight was intended. It's just that the lab's international focus, and the continuous pursuit of financing, keep Dr. Watson, 72, on the road. 
 But even when he's home, he moves in different circles. While the lab is host to thousands of visitors a year at its scientific meetings and conferences, guests are more likely to hail from Australia than Amityville. The lab remains enigmatic, if not unknown, to the local business community.
"We don't usually turn to Long Island to meet our needs," Dr. Watson said. "In terms of fund-raising, in terms of grantsmanship, in terms of research funding, our scope is entirely national. In our role as a teaching place and a research place, we are small and focused, but very international."
In recent years, the lab has come under pressure to be a bit more, well, neighborly. Business, government and academic leaders hope to foster a biotechnology industry here, and are pressuring the lab to play a leadership role. They point to burgeoning biotech corridors in Cambridge, Mass., San Francisco, San Diego and Austin, Tex., where prestigious research institutions galvanize intensely cerebral and collaborative communities known as clusters.
That has not happened here. During the 1990's the lab spun off 14 companies based on its patents, siting all but four elsewhere in the country. According to Bruce Stillman, the lab's director and Dr. Watson's chosen successor, the choices were driven by business realities: each company was sited where it seemed most likely to prosper.
"It isn't easy for small biotech companies to grow on Long Island," Dr. Stillman said. "Just getting appropriate commercial space can be very, very difficult."
The L.I.A. and other business and government leaders acknowledge his point, but rue the exodus of jobs and capital. According to the group's chief economist, Pearl Kamer, the 14 spinoff companies have hired 1,722 people, all but 226 of them employed off Long Island. Only OSI Pharmaceuticals in Uniondale, with nearly 200 employees, raises a blip on the local economic radar. Most of the aggregate financial benefits, including $357 million in annual expenditures, accrue off-Island.
"I would like for the lab to take a pro-Long Island view in terms of siting spin-off companies here," Mr. Crosson said. "I would like their stance to be: Let's build up a Long Island genetics corridor. It's regrettable and avoidable that those companies were spun off elsewhere."
Signs are the lab is prepared to play a more active local role. Construction is nearly complete on the $15 million Biosciences Park, a collaboration between the lab and the State University of New York at Farmingdale. The original plan was to build an incubator. When OSI Pharmaceuticals, which had outgrown its Uniondale building, began looking elsewhere for space, the plan was hurriedly revised. The new plan cedes most of the building to OSI, positioning it as an anchor for the expected cluster.
When the project is complete, supporters say Long Island will finally have the infrastructure it has been lacking: brainy scientists, trained students looking for part-time work and entry-level positions, incubator space near permanent space for expansion, all of it centralized. Advocates hope the new park stems the biotech exodus.
It has been tried before. The Island's original high-tech incubator is in Stony Brook, and there are three others: two, in Bethpage and Stony Brook, for computer software; and one, also in Farmingdale, for manufacturing. Another biotech incubator, operated by the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System in Manhasset, is nearing completion.
Does the profusion of incubators undercut their chances of achieving critical mass?
"Absolutely not," said Peter Goldsmith, chairman of Listnet, a Great River software and technology co-op. "Demand for tech centers is so great on the Island."
John Cleary, a Farrell Fritz lawyer who is chairman of the Farmingdale incubator, said the formula has worked elsewhere. "You want to bring together different companies having the same discipline in a geographically defined area," he said. "As you develop synergistic relationships, the cluster draws other companies."
The dynamic of such clusters is more interactive, and social, than is the case in most industries.
"It isn't just coming to work, going into the office and leaving at 5 o'clock," Mr. Cleary said. "It's a question of interacting with people of like mind dealing with similar issues in a congenial environment."
But tradition and the lab's culture are not on their side. According to Dr. Watson, the lab's mission is to focus on pure scientific research, untainted by commercialism.
"Maybe 2 percent of our revenues come from commercial applications," he said. "Transferring technology to business is nice, especially if it's something our scientists want to do. We like to help make that happen. But it isn't our mission. Our mission is to do pure, bleeding-edge science."
Dr. Stillman, who became director in 1994, offered a similar emphasis on separating research from commerce. He agreed, however, that the development of a biotech corridor would allow the lab to transfer technology to local companies more easily.
"It's rather a Catch-22," Dr. Stillman said. "You can't attract biotech companies until you have established a cluster. But you don't have a cluster until you attract the companies."
For biotech executives and investors, a cluster assures enough trained employees to provide adequate staffing. For employees, clusters mean competition, and competition means higher wages and career mobility. That, in turn, attracts better employees, or so goes the theory.
Mr. Crosson sees the lab's role in developing the Biosciences Park as an indication it expects to play a bigger role in the local economy.
"Dr. Watson is indeed very familiar with the Long Island economy, despite the fact that he is on the road so much of the time," Mr. Crosson said. "And I think that Dr. Stillman will prove to be even more involved with Long Island."
Invited recently to address a luncheon in Hauppauge held by another business group, Dr. Stillman encountered an audience eager to learn more about the lab and the opportunities in genomics and biotechnology.
"Afterwards, so many people approached asking to come visit the lab that we are organizing a tour specifically for that group," he said. "I was delighted to see so much enthusiasm. However, I was a bit surprised that some of the business people seem never to have heard of us."

HEADLINE: AMERICAN SINGERS;
A Place to Be Heard

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In regard to the July 2 article "For Singers, a New American Way" by Anne Midgette, there is no doubt that the situation in German theaters has changed from the 1960's -- but so has the economic situation around the world. In every industry today, American businesses have to compete with cheaper products produced in other parts of the world and changing market needs. The opera business in not unique. 
 Having worked the last three years as a consultant for the Deutsche Oper am Rhein in Dusseldorf/Duisburg, I can attest to the great interest still shown for American talent in Germany. The training, discipline and motivation of American opera singers are still highly desired and greatly valued. The Deutsche Oper am Rhein intendent, Tobias Richter, and his new American music director, John Fiore, have successfully engaged many gifted American singers.
Singers still recognize the valuable experience to be obtained from a contract at a German theater. After all, who wouldn't want to sing 12 performances of "Aida" in Dusseldorf rather than be unemployed in New York?
 
MICHAEL PRESSER
Manhattan

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/430 West 14th Street;
A Developer Puts a Bet on the Meatpacking District

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
THE building certainly does not look very glamorous. A couple of bars and meatpacking tenants occupy most of the ground floor space at 430 West 14th Street, which has a broad corrugated metal canopy mounted on it to shield workers from the weather as they load and unload trucks in the early morning hours.
Nevertheless, the Washington-based Starwood Urban Investments has paid $10.2 million for the five-story brick building with blocklong frontage on Washington Street, between 13th and 14th Streets. 
 The investment is the first in New York for Starwood Urban, which is a joint venture by the Starwood Capital Group of Greenwich, Conn., and Wennett Urban Retail of Washington. Starwood Urban officials say they are prepared to invest as much as $250 million over the next 12 months in retail, loft and manufacturing properties in what they describe as "emerging chic" areas in Manhattan like the meatpacking district, west Chelsea, Union Square, the garment district and Clinton.
The far western end of 14th Street is clearly in the midst of change, even if it may not fit traditional definitions of chic. The fashionable clothing store Jeffrey shares space in a building with Moishe's Mini Storage. Art galleries like Long Fine Art and Katzen-Stein have moved into the area, but the sidewalks are still often blocked by forklifts moving foodstuffs, and the cobblestone street is obstructed by delivery trucks.
Nevertheless, Robert S. Wennett, the president of Starwood Urban, said he sees 430 West 14th Street as a prime retail opportunity. He said the building's 200-foot frontage on Washington Street, plus 50 more feet each on 13th and 14th Streets, are ideal for restaurants or stores.
"Retailers like exposure without great depth, so this is a fabulous retail building," Mr. Wennett said. He said the 15,800 square feet on the first floor and in the basement would be offered to tenants with high profiles and original concepts.
Most of the leases of the current tenants will expire in the short term, or the tenants are already renting on a month-to-month basis, making it easy to recapture the space for new uses. "That was part of the opportunity," he said.
He said luring upscale retail tenants to what were formerly marginal neighborhoods was part of the formula for Starwood Urban, which has previously invested in Washington, South Miami Beach, Coral Gables, Fla., and Norwalk, Conn. "We do not buy buildings in neighborhoods without retail opportunities," he said.
Starwood Urban was formed two years ago to make investments in city neighborhoods that appear to be changing for the better. "We go into emerging areas and focus on retail and offices," Mr. Wennett said. "We target areas earlier than institutional capital."
The meatpacking district of Manhattan is just such an emerging area, he said, adding that many people like working in areas that are industrial by day but filled with urban sophisticates by night, drawn by new restaurants and exotic bars. He said the area is making the transition from industrial to residential and retail in the same way that SoHo and TriBeCa developed.
He noted that Starwood Urban has an all-the-time casual dress policy and said the properties the company invests in are being developed to appeal to new-economy ventures. The company plans to spend about $1 million at 430 West 14th Street, to repair the brick facade, improve the heating and air-conditioning and to upgrade the elevators and lobby.
Mr. Wennett said he planned to market the 46,000 square feet on the building's upper floors to full-floor tenants or to a single large tenant.
Mr. Wennett said many new media and Internet workers are more concerned about lifestyle than location. "They don't want to be in Class A office space," he said.
Constance Collins Davis, the general counsel of Starwood Urban, said: "Young people are coming back to cities. They want to mix art and entertainment with the work experience. We look for places where we would like to work."
The Starwood officials noted that restaurants like Markt, Pastis and Lotus have opened in the area, that a hotel is scheduled to be built a block or so away and that the Chelsea Market has become a tourist attraction nearby at Ninth Avenue and 15th Street.
T HE area is moving, no doubt about it," said David Gmach, the executive director of the Union Square-14th Street Business Improvement District, whose western boundary is the Avenue of the Americas. "The question is how quickly." He said the possibility of the area's being designated a landmark or special zoning district might influence the way it develops.
He noted that some people think enough of the area to spend as much as $2 million for a condominium in a converted bank building at 14th Street and Eighth Avenue.
Some retail specialists say the lack of a local population base and the distance from transportation make it likely that the West 14th Street area will take a long time to emulate SoHo, if it ever does.
"It took SoHo a long time to become SoHo," said Richard A. Seligman, the president of Retail Development Partners, a brokerage firm. "And SoHo is bounded by two well-established retail corridors, Broadway and West Broadway." He said he had not received any inquiries from retailers seeking locations on or near West 14th Street. Nevertheless, Starwood officials are predicting that once renovations are complete, 430 West 14th Street will command retail rents of $80 to $100 a square foot.
Robert K. Futterman of RKF Associates, another retail brokerage firm, said retail rents in the area were unlikely to exceed $50 a foot and that the most likely tenants would be restaurants and bars, rather than stores.
"There is a lot of buzz about the area, but it is mostly about restaurants and saloons," he said. "You are not likely to see many traditional retailers in that area."
He said retail tenants seeking locations in a city look for a critical mass of population, good transportation and other stores so shoppers will be drawn to the area, all of which the West 14th Street area lacks. "We just expanded Banana Republic at 111 Eighth Avenue," he said, referring to the building that runs from 15th to 16th Streets. "That's where the traditional retailers want to be."
Mr. Seligman said that for $80 to $100 a square foot, a retailer can rent space in an established shopping area and not have to wonder whether West 14th Street will develop as a daytime shopping destination, as it has as an evening eating and partying location. "For $125 a foot a retailer can go to lower Fifth Avenue and not worry if the area is going to happen," he said.
Although some art galleries have moved to 14th Street, it does not have the concentration of galleries that were present in SoHo before rising rents paid by retailers drove them to other parts of the city. "SoHo always was a cool place to walk around, but it still took 10 years for it to be transformed from an artsy New York neighborhood to an international shopping center," Mr. Seligman said.
He added that by locating in an established retail area, "you know who your neighbors will be, which is important when you are paying $3 million to $4 million a year in rent -- it is well known that retailers travel in packs."
Mr. Wennett of Starwood Urban said he was convinced that long-term trends were working in his favor, even if the short term may be uncertain. "New York and San Francisco are the centers of the new economy," he said, "and that trend is not likely to die even if Wall Street takes a dive."
He said the West 14th Street area may come to resemble European cities, where the meat and fish shops operate during the day and then give way to cafes and restaurants at night. "That is an attractive urban fabric," he said, "and we like investing in these types of neighborhoods."
He also hopes some of the industrial character of the area can be preserved. "We are not interested in turning this into a mall," he said. "SoHo is a mall."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1457 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
As Doors Close for Developers, New Ones Open

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
DIVERSIFICATION is much on the minds of home builders these days as market conditions, demographic trends and regulatory constraints are nudging them to branch out into different segments of the housing market.
Three developers moving in new directions are cases in point: 
 *The Kushner Companies of Florham Park, best known as an owner of garden-style rental apartments, are planning to convert a motel in West Long Branch in Monmouth County to the companies' first assisted-living center, offering housing along with meals and personal care to elderly residents.
*Pinnacle Communities of Millburn, which for the last decade has built luxury single-family attached and detached homes, is entering the market for residential retirement communities, with 120 homes for buyers age 55 and over in Washington Township in Warren County.
*The Matzel & Mumford Organization of Hazlet, a developer of upscale single-family homes, is returning to the town-house market after a nine-year absence with a 262-unit project in Montgomery Township in Somerset County.
"When sites are available, developers will move into areas they have not traditionally been in if the market is there and they can make money," said Joanne Harkins, the director of land-use and planning at the New Jersey Builders Association in Robbinsville.
Constraining factors that developers are facing include the dwindling supply of land in New Jersey and more restrictive zoning. In the next decade the state plans to buy up a million acres of open space, and in the last several years, it has been encouraging development in urban areas, where utilities, roads and mass transit are in place, and discouraging it in rural areas.
Some developers, Ms. Harkins said, have responded by redeveloping former industrial sites in cities or recycling abandoned buildings in older suburbs. Others, she added, are entering the housing market for the elderly with assisted-living or "55 and over" projects, a nod to the state's aging population.
David Schoner, a vice president in the new homes and land division of Coldwell Banker, the residential brokerage company with headquarters in Short Hills, said developers also favor housing for the elderly because many municipalities view it favorably, since it has less impact on municipal services, especially schools, than other high-density projects.
Dr. James W. Hughes, the dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, said, "With the tidal wave of maturing baby boomers entering the market, developers basically will be life-cycle riding." Dr. Hughes noted that next year the first baby boomers will turn 55, a milestone that successive waves of boomers -- by definition those people born between 1946 and 1964 -- will hit during the next 18 years.
FROM here forward, Dr. Hughes said, empty nesters will determine the course of new construction. In turn, he said, housing that offers a maintenance-free living, like condominium town houses, makes sense, as do projects that offer entertainment and recreational amenities.
These shifts are occurring when the state's residential market is slowing a bit in response to rising interest rates and a turbulent stock market. Jeffrey Otteau, the president of the Otteau Appraisal Group in East Brunswick, said that prices have risen 10 to 25 percent for all types of housing in the last year and as a result, "buyers are stepping out of the market." Sales activity is down, the supply of homes, particularly resales, is up and houses that a few months ago sold in hours or days are taking weeks to sell, he added.
Though Mr. Otteau said he expected the slowdown to last at least until October, "it is still a strong real estate market." His advice to developers: "Know your market."
That is an exercise the Kushner Companies went through before deciding to convert a 100-room motel on Route 36, next to Monmouth Raceway in West Long Branch, into an assisted-living residence. Though the growth of such projects has leveled off, "we think there is a niche we can fill," said Jeffrey Freireich, a managing director. "Unlike most of the high-end projects that have been built. this will be more economical for tenants," he added, because Kushner will save money by converting an existing structure.
"In just 10 years," Mr. Freireich said, "the number of Monmouth County residents 75 and older -- the age group we're targeting -- increased by 22 percent."
The $8 million project, which will begin this fall and will be called the Esplanade at West Long Branch, is being developed with the Scharf family, which runs similar residences for the elderly in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, and FBE Limited, a real estate partnership in Manhattan.
The conversion will include the renovation of all the rooms, which average 325 square feet. A new front entrance will be added and the grounds of the four-acre site will be landscaped. Rents, including all meals and services, will be $2,500 to $2,900 a month.
Mr. Freireich said his company planned to develop similar projects "on a selective basis" until the assisted-living market strengthens, because this housing segment "makes sense for us."
Over the last two years, a Kushner company, Westminster Communities, has gained a foothold in "55 and over" housing, known as the "active adult" market. It has seven such projects in New Jersey, totaling 1,441 residences, in various stages of the development. Among them is Sea Oaks, with 376 single-family homes, under way in Little Egg Harbor.
That is the market Pinnacle Communities is also pursuing. It is advancing plans for the Village at Hawk Pointe, with 120 detached houses on 31 acres adjacent to an 18-hole golf course on Route 31, not far from Interstate 78 in Washington Township.
Having built upscale housing with no age restrictions, "we want to bring that edge to the 'active adult' market where there is an unmet demand for larger, more expensive homes," said Paul Schneier, the vice president for operations at Pinnacle. Other factors in Pinnacle's decision, he said, are that many towns are more receptive to such projects, shortening the approval process; demographics support them; and Warren County is not saturated with "55 and over" housing.
Pinnacle is under contract to buy the site contingent upon receiving local approvals, he said. If approved, the project will be part of a 317-acre development that will include the golf course and up to 340,000 square feet of commercial space, which Pinnacle will build with the developers of the golf course.
As now envisioned, the 120 houses, each with 2,000 to 3,000 square feet, will sit on lots of about a quarter acre. The initial prices are expected to be $300,000 to $350,000. Amenities planned include a clubhouse and pool. Construction of the houses, a $40 million project, is to start early next year.
Mr. Schneier said that Pinnacle was planning two other such communities in New Jersey, each with 100 to 200 homes. "It's an opportunity," he said.
That is also the way Roger Mumford, the president of the Matzel & Mumford Organization, described his company's purchase of 76 acres with approvals in place for 262 town houses on Blue Spring Road, off Route 206 in Montgomery. "Given our desire to diversify and the lack of large suitably zoned land, we jumped on it," Mr. Mumford said.
Montgomery Hills, as the project will be known, is the undeveloped portion of an earlier project that began in the 1980's. The site was rezoned for town houses to help the township meet its obligation under the state's Mount Laurel doctrine, which requires municipalities to provide zoning for low- and moderate-income housing. The previous developer built just the first 84 of the 346 town houses originally planned. Matzel & Mumford will build the remaining town houses, along with 60 rental apartments for people 55 and older with low to moderate incomes and 35 condo apartments with income, but not age, restrictions.
"There is a solid market for town houses," said Mr. Mumford, whose company became an affiliate of K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank last year.
Mr. Schoner of Coldwell Banker said, "Town houses will be the first step out of single-family homes for many baby boomers." Mr. Otteau, the appraiser, agreed, and added that because the prices for detached houses have risen faster than those for town houses, entry-level buyers are choosing them as starter homes for the first time in 15 years.
The town houses at Montgomery Hills, with 1,661 to 2,220 square feet, will cater to both markets, Mr. Mumford said. Construction and sales are expected to begin next month, and prices are expected to start at $230,000.

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS;
Putting in Your Own Backyard

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI

DATELINE: CROSS RIVER

 BODY:
LESLIE and SUSAN SIMON are both golf enthusiasts, so on their lunch hour they decided to practice their putting.
But Dr. Simon, a dentist, and Mrs. Simon, a lawyer, who maintain professional offices in their handsome white home here, did not have to travel to a club or public course to work on their game. Instead, they simply headed out to the yard and their new home putting green. 
 "I keep golf shoes in my office," Dr. Simon said, as he lined up a putt. "If I can go out at lunch time and practice 20 minutes or half an hour every day, it's got to make you better. Putting is half the game."
Mrs. Simon, still dressed to meet with clients and fretting that her high heels might mar the new green, also had a putter in hand. "You don't know the pressure I'm under since he got this," she said, looking over at her husband. "He told me it was for me, but I think it was for him. But if I could save one putt a hole, I could shave 18 strokes off my game."
The putting green makes the Simons part of a growing trend in the region. The latest must-have for homeowners is a personal set of golf holes, complete with green and -- in elaborate setups -- multiple holes, sand traps, irrigation, waterfalls and lighting for evening play.
Blame Tiger (Woods) Mania. Since 1986, the number of golfers in the United States has increased 33 percent. There are 26.4 million golfers age 12 and older, according to the National Golf Foundation, an industry market research and trade group in Jupiter, Fla. And they're willing to pay to play. Golfers spend $30.5 billion annually on equipment, related merchandise and playing fees. In a strong economy, the business of home putting greens is taking off.
It was a market that Michael Lehrer foresaw five years ago when he began his Armonk-based business Home Green Advantage.
Since then Mr. Lehrer has installed more than 130 putting greens, which range from about $3,000 for a basic setup of three to five putting holes to up to $75,000 for greens that include nine holes, rock walls, water hazards, sand traps and other enrichments. The average job costs between $10,000 and $15,000, Mr. Lehrer said.
"When I started in this business, no one else was around," Mr. Lehrer said. "Now everyone and his cousin is into it. People who were doing aluminum siding last week are putting in greens."
Most home putting greens are made of synthetic turf, which is generally maintenance free. The technology of synthetic greens has improved greatly since the earliest days of AstroTurf.
Today, the speed of the green can be controlled by altering the amount of fill used between the blades and by changing the length of the blades themselves.
Mr. Lehrer considers himself the grandfather of the home putting green business in the region. Not only has he installed greens in many private homes but he has also put one on a rooftop of a building at Chelsea Piers, and he recently installed a putting green indoors at the headquarters of Fox News in Manhattan.
The growing appeal to homeowners goes beyond the exploding popularity of the sport, Mr. Lehrer said. The average home putting green is still considerably less expensive than installing a tennis court or a swimming pool. Also, installing a green does not usually require much in the way of permits. Putting greens are generally considered landscaping, and short of problems with wetland areas, they do not require the approval of zoning authorities.
In addition, golf is being increasingly promoted as a family sport, and for many there is great appeal in a project that cannot only enhance property but also provide an activity for both children and parents.
"It is a wonderful, beautiful piece of scenery," said Bob Lewis, for whom Mr. Lehrer recently built a green with several holes, sand traps and dramatic landscaping in Mount Kisco. "I haven't exactly been to the Masters. But I did want something I could share with my children. Golf is really a time-commitment sport, and having it right here will bring the family together instead of dividing it."
For fanatical golfers, having a putting green at home offers an opportunity to practice without leaving a golf widow or widower behind.
"Most of the calls I get are from housewives looking to put in the green for their husbands," said Michael Ratki, who owns Home Putting Greens, based in Croton-on-Hudson. (His Web site is www.homeput .com.) "Maybe they want them to stay at home. Otherwise, on Sunday morning the husband says, 'I got to go,' and guys usually like to make it an event. They go in the morning, they have lunch and maybe a couple of beers."
Mr. Ratki, who said he had installed about 30 putting greens, described them as "a big boy's playground." His greens tend to be more modest than Mr. Lehrer's -- averaging 12 by 24 feet -- and cost $2,900 to $3,500. Mr. Ratki had one client from Harrison, who had recently moved from India. The customer, who had no interest in golf, wanted not a putting green but a cricket court.
Mr. Lehrer said he has installed putting greens for people who do not themselves even play golf but who just want the look, entertainment value -- or the status -- of having a home green. He maintains a Web site (homegreenadvantage.com) but gets most of his business through referrals.
"I just built a green in Orienta," Mr. Lehrer said. "The neighbor came over and said, 'When you're done with this, you can start mine.' They can link up if they're not adversaries -- you play over my hole, I'll play over yours."
Bonnie Shyer, of Westport, had a putting green installed in her backyard as a surprise wedding gift for her husband five years ago. Mrs. Shyer described her husband as a pretty devoted player, and said her stepgrandchildren, ages 6 and 9, play in tournaments. Now the Shyers' 3-year-old daughter, Samantha, is starting to visit the putting green.
"Right now, it's just a game for her," Mrs. Shyer said, "not like the rest of us, for whom it's a religion."
