HEADLINE: They Think It Can;
Is the Light-Rail Line an Affirmation of a Long-Awaited Rebirth Or a Misguided Way to Deal With Jammed Roads and Tainted Air?

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
WITH a gentle whoosh, the 11:05 a.m. pulled out of Exchange Place here and began its 7.5-mile run through a landscape of crisp new office towers, overgrown scrap yards and century-old row houses. The two-car tram to Bayonne was empty, save for a wistful-looking man gazing out of the oversized windows. 
 It was Stephen Sosinski's first ride on the three-month-old Hudson-Bergen Light Rail, and the journey was carrying the 48-year-old horse trainer back to his childhood, when he and his mother would ride the clattering Jersey Central to the ferries bound for New York.
By the time Mr. Sosinski left home 25 years ago, the Jersey Central had gone under, as had most of the factories, shipyards and refineries that sustained Hudson County's waterfront. All the years he lived in Florida, Mr. Sosinski rarely admitted he was from this dying corner of New Jersey. "It was a sinking ship, a depressing place," he said. "I vowed never to return. And I never did."
But this 23-minute trolley ride, he said, was shaking up his senses -- dizzying construction at every turn, the reawakened riverfront, and most of all, the electrified trains that have helped reconnect his former hometown to New York and the rest of the world. "Believe it or not, I'd consider moving back," he said as the sleek black and white cars eased into 34th Street, a few blocks from where his sister still lives. "Suddenly, this place feels like the center of the universe again."
Boosters of the Hudson-Bergen line would be heartened by Mr. Sosinski's sentiments, especially since ridership, a third below projections, has been so disappointing. While the $1.1 billion system has been championed as a salve for congestion and air pollution and a spark for urban renewal, light rail is having other salubrious, if somewhat intangible, effects on the people and places it serves.
For Jersey City and Bayonne, these modern-day streetcars reaffirm a long-awaited rebirth. Egalitarian and exhaust-free, the trains are a curious sight on local streets, and they inspire nostalgia and civic pride in a way that buses do not.
While such abstractions are never included in transportation planning studies, America's romance with trolleys is helping spur a veritable boom in light rail around the state, making New Jersey the second most active place for new construction after California.
Less expensive than commuter trains and far easier to build, light rail runs on low-voltage electric lines and can move along local streets with minimal disruption. Manufactured in Japan and assembled in Harrison, the system's 29 cars can climb hills with ease, quickly reach 55 miles an hour and brake faster than buses. And unlike heavy rail, the trains are entered at street level, making them easily accessible to the disabled and the elderly.
Yet as the love affair with light rail blooms, there is an insistent group of transit experts who see these modern-day trolleys as wasteful and misguided attempts to grapple with overcrowded roads and tainted air. Most light rail systems, they say, have failed to make a noticeable dent in congestion, and ridership has consistently fallen short of projections.
Nonetheless, in addition to the Hudson-Bergen route, which is expected to reach Ridgefield by 2010, New Jersey Transit broke ground last month on a 34-mile system connecting Trenton to Camden. Work on another line, linking Elizabeth and Newark, is expected to get under way in the next few years. The Newark City Subway, essentially a trolley that runs partly underground, will soon receive the same cars that run on the Hudson-Bergen line, and transportation officials hope to extend those tracks to the Meadowlands and Paterson before the end of the decade. From Cape May to northern Bergen County, there is talk of another half-dozen projects.
"The future of New Jersey is filled with light rail," said Jeff Warsh, executive director of New Jersey Transit. "It's not bravado, it's not spin. It's the plan."
That future partly depends on federal largesse, which has been responsible for up to 80 percent of all light rail construction costs nationwide. But as dozens of cities jump on the light rail bandwagon, the pool of money is shrinking. When the Hudson-Bergen line broke ground in 1996, there were 20 projects angling for $5.8 billion in federal dollars. This year there are nearly 200 vying for $6.3 billion. "The competition," Mr. Warsh said, "has become severe."
BUT Gary Brosch, editor of The Journal of Public Transportation, said there is a growing debate among planners about whether light rail is a cost-effective alternative to buses, which are cheaper and more flexible than fixed rail lines. Both sides, he said, have been known to engage in hyperbole.
"The advocates feel so passionately about its needs that they overstate the benefits," Mr. Brosch said. "The result is that once a system is built, there is bound to be disappointment."
In selling its first light rail project, New Jersey Transit predicted 14,400 daily riders on the first leg of the line, which includes 12 stations between Bayonne and Jersey City. As of last week, that number was 4,633.
Still, light rail enthusiasts have been heartened by a healthy rise from the system's first weeks, when an average of 2,781 passengers rode the trains each day. "It's creeping up slowly and steadily," said Douglas J. Bowen, president of the New Jersey Association of Railroad Passengers, an advocacy group. "People don't change their travel patterns overnight."
And some people do, among them 22-year-old Ian MacDonald, who was taking the train to Jersey City's West Side Avenue station one recent afternoon. Until the line was inaugurated in April, Mr. MacDonald rode a bus to his job at the Hudson Mall, leaving him with a 20-minute walk. With light rail, he is five minutes from work. Mr. MacDonald said everyone he knows is excited about the train, which includes a spur through his battered neighborhood here. "It's quiet, quick and it gets me there on time," he said as he stepped on to the platform.
Cynics of light rail may hold up Mr. MacDonald as an example of why its benefits are illusory. Light rail, they say, siphons riders from bus lines, creating the semblance of demand. "Rail tends to be sexier than buses, so as long as the trains are shiny and clean, people call it a success," said Wendell Cox, an Illinois-based transportation consultant. "They just doesn't serve modern America's transportation needs."
Because light rail travels on a fixed route, it will only appeal to a tiny segment of travelers, Mr. Cox said, and die-hard drivers will never trade in their cars for the train. "Light rail has no transportation function at all," he said.
On a recent afternoon, Brett Caracciolo was proving the naysayers wrong. A systems analyst from Millstone, Mr. Caracciolo, 37, was on his way to a meeting in Jersey City, having driven to a Park-and-Ride lot at the Liberty Science Center. In the past he would have driven to Exchange Place, but downtown traffic and $22 parking lured him from his car. Including parking, the round trip costs $5.
"This is fantastic," Mr. Caracciolo said, taking in the pristine upholstery and that new-car smell. "There's no way I would drive now."
So far, most of New Jersey Transit's 2,400 Park-and-Ride spaces remain empty most weekdays. But transit officials say they expect the number of users to rise in the coming months as workers install pedestrian bridges linking platforms to parking lots.
For his part, Martin Robins, a transportation expert at Rutgers, said it was premature to judge the Hudson-Bergen line. Mr. Robins pointed out that two-thirds of the route remained unfinished, including the leg to Hoboken terminal, used by more than 40,000 commuters a day. That segment, and another to the Newport Mall, will be completed in 2002. And with a score of office and apartment buildings in Jersey City quickly rising, the number of potential riders customers is expected to mount.
"You have to remember, some very important ingredients are missing," he said. "This is just the beginning."
More than 75 percent of light rail riders are from Bayonne, something that has surprised many officials. In response, New Jersey Transit added a handful of express trains from Bayonne to Exchange Place, cutting the 23-minute journey to 15 minutes.
When the light rail system was proposed two decades ago, some experts argued against extending the line to Bayonne. "They said, 'No one from Bayonne commutes to New York,' " recalled Mr. Bowen of the New Jersey Railroad Passengers Association. "I said, 'Well maybe one day they will.' "
When the line is extended to the foot of the Bayonne Bridge, officials said it will provide commuters from Staten Island a quicker way to reach Manhattan.
After years of job losses, Bayonne is giddy about light rail, saying it is the best thing to happen to this working-class city in decades. The mayor, Joseph Doria, credits the train with lifting real-estate values by 25 percent. Residents gripe about parking lost to commuters, but they are also thrilled by the notion, heard up and down Broadway, that Bayonne is the next Hoboken.
"It's going to give Bayonne a big boost," said Lynn Edelman, who owns a dress shop a block from the station. "We're so close to Manhattan now. It makes perfect sense."
Ann Smith, a payroll company executive, says the easy commute to her Manhattan office is the reason she recently bought a house in Bayonne. "The buses are old, cruddy and they stop at every other block," Ms. Smith said. "If there was no train, I don't think I would have bought."
Ms. Smith said that almost every week, someone knocked on her door to ask if she might sell her house, across from the 34th Street station. "I feel like I'm sitting on a pile of gold," she said.
In a pioneering private-public arrangement aimed at controlling costs and speeding up construction, New Jersey Transit hired Twenty-First Century Rail, a consortium of companies to design, build and operate the system's first segment.
Like most public transportation systems in America, the Hudson-Bergen light rail does not pay for itself, although officially, it is supposed to break even by 2010, when 100,000 daily riders are expected. One-way tickets cost $1.50 and are sold from machines on station platforms. Because there are no people working in ticket booths, some older passengers have complained, saying the vending machines make travel a bit daunting. In addition, fare collection is honor-based, although ticket agents occasionally hand out $71 fines to scofflaws.
Most people encountered during a full day of riding the rail were enthusiastic about the trains, although there was some grumbling: platform signs were insufficient; fares were too high; the trains move too slowly around Jersey City's curves. "At some spots, I could walk faster than the train," said Atef Mikhael, 28, a medical resident. "And why do they have to stop at every traffic light?"
Many light rail experts agree with the criticism, saying that an efficient system should turn red lights to green, something known as signal pre-emption. Vic Simmons, a light rail consultant from England who was making a study tour of the Hudson-Bergen line recently, agreed.
"They should be given the right of way," Mr. Simmons said. "It doesn't make sense that 100 people are being held for two cars."
Dan Censullo, a light rail specialist for New Jersey Transit, said the system was not designed to change traffic lights immediately; however, it does speed up signals to favor trains. As the system matures, Mr. Censullo said, travel time may be reduced by adding more trains and cutting back how long they wait on the platforms. In the end, however, the system is limited by traffic rules, which in Jersey City prevent street-level trains from moving faster than 25 miles per hour.
While the trains nearly fill with commuters during rush hours, they are often sparsely used at other times. But compared with the first few weeks, when some trains ran empty, use is clearly on the rise. One recent afternoon, Krystle Bransky, 16, and Vinnie Fonti, 15, were taking the train to Liberty State Park from Bayonne "just for the heck of it," Krystle said. There were plenty of other joy riders, including 3-year-old Nicholas Stallone, who was taking his first ride. "Every day we go out, he makes me drive by the train," said his mother, Sharon. "If we don't see the train, he cries."
THEN there was the couple from Bayonne on their way to meet friends at a Jersey City bar. "We could have driven," said the man. "But then we wouldn't have been able to drink as much."
Tourists have also been venturing on the train. Gerry McNamara, 61, a teacher from Dublin who was headed to Liberty Science Center, was mesmerized by the haze-shrouded silhouette of lower Manhattan. "I prefer this to driving," Mr. McNamara said. "I would not have been happy in a car, not with the way my sister drives."
Although it remains to be seen whether more commuters will give up their cars, many of them will eventually be forced to do so by the reality of the new Hudson River waterfront. The parking lots that once accommodated their cars are giving way to new construction, and the density of development is making driving increasingly untenable. Mayor Bret Schundler said that without light rail here, congestion would have choked off new investment. "Our roads can only take so much," Mr. Schundler said.
Ultimately, he and other officials hope the line will carry some of that prosperity to other parts of the city. This year, a shopping center opened alongside the Martin Luther King Drive Station, the first for a neighborhood that has seen little redevelopment in decades. Mr. Schundler said he envisions suburbanites, swayed by an easy commute, moving to homes adjacent to the line.
There is a sad irony in light rail's return, more than 40 years after the last streetcar line was torn up in Jersey City.
"Trolleys were once so ubiquitous in American cities, you couldn't go a few blocks without hitting one," said Stephen Goddard, who wrote "Getting There: The Epic Struggle Roads and Rail in American Century" (Basic Books, 1994).
Killed by the ascendant automobile, the very success of the private car is fueling the trolley's return, often on the very same abandoned track beds. Most of the Hudson-Bergen line, for example, occupies the right-of-way used by defunct rail companies.
"People talk about light rail as if it's a futuristic thing," said Mr. Warsh of New Jersey Transit. "It's really a return to the past. We're putting back what was once there."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 3113 words

HEADLINE: Breathing Life Into City's Barren Plazas

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
AT first blush, it seems unfair that a city without an Olmsted Park should have a Balsley Park. Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903), designer of Central Park and Prospect Park, transformed whole swaths of New York. The landscape architect Thomas Balsley (b. 1943) transforms far smaller plots, like the third of an acre on Ninth Avenue, between 56th and 57th Streets, once known as Sheffield Plaza, that now bears his name.
But consider this: Sheffield Plaza was a notorious failure as a privately owned public space. Not just hard-edged, it could be downright dangerous. A resident of the Parc Vendome condominium next door was stabbed there. By contrast, Balsley Park -- a greensward, playground and alfresco cafe -- is so welcoming that an official of the Clinton community board and a member of the Parc Vendome board have actually sent thank-you letters to Mr. Balsley and the landlord, Adam R. Rose, who undertook the $1 million renovation. 
 Olmsted, look to your laurels.
The reopening of Sheffield Plaza two weeks ago shows that even the most arid space can be redeemed, given an owner's commitment, public pressure and enough time, money and creativity.
The changes to this and other neglected plazas underscore the enduring influence of Jane Jacobs and the late William H. Whyte, who discerned the relation between safety, vitality and variety in urban spaces. But the changes also raise the question of whether the term "public" -- as in, "We want the public to feel comfortable" -- is sometimes shorthand for "anyone but the homeless."
The transformation of Sheffield Plaza also illustrates a paradox: the improvement of privately owned public space often comes at the price of some diminution in public access. Either the area is closed at night, or a portion of it is given over to a commercial operation. Or both.
"The goal is to make sure the public is getting something worthwhile in exchange," said Joseph B. Rose, the chairman of the City Planning Commission. "Most spaces require several efforts to get them functioning optimally."
Over the last four decades, bonus plazas and arcades have generated enormous benefits for their builders, roughly 20 million square feet in extra floor area. (Think of it as five World Trade Center towers.)
They are supposed to reward the public commensurately. When they work, they offer lovely oases in the city's thicket of skyscrapers. When they do not work, however, the developer still gets the use of the bonus floor area while the public is left with a barren patch of pavement. So many spaces have failed to live up to their promise that they are now viewed suspiciously.
Even the City Planning Department is wary. It has recommended the elimination in the future of all plazas at residential buildings, saying that they "tend to become privatized" and are "frequently inconsistent" with the physical character of existing neighborhoods. The recommendation is part of a larger rezoning proposal that is now under review.
Plazas and arcades will come under closer scrutiny this fall with the publication of "Privately Owned Public Space: The New York City Experience" (John Wiley & Sons). Written by Jerold S. Kayden of the Harvard University Graduate School of Design, in collaboration with the City Planning Department and Municipal Art Society, it is the first comprehensive analysis of 503 spaces at 320 buildings.
Typically the most troublesome spaces were built in the 1960's and early 70's, before design standards were imposed.
Cohen Brothers Realty Corporation inherited such a space two years ago when it bought the Blue Cross Building, 622 Third Avenue, between 40th and 41st Streets. The extra floor area attributable to the public space amounts to 137,310 square feet; that is, five of the 39 floors. But a pedestrian coming across the tunnel-like arcade on Third Avenue could have been forgiven for not recognizing it as a benefit.
"This was a dark and forbidding place," said Charles Steven Cohen, president and chief executive of Cohen Brothers, which renamed the tower Grand Central Plaza. Under a $10 million renovation, designed by Thomas Balsley Associates and Moed de Armas & Shannon, the lid has been taken off the arcade, bringing daylight to the 100-foot-long passageway for the first time since its construction 27 years ago.
Another early plaza now under reconstructive surgery by Mr. Balsley is the sunken courtyard in front of the General Motors Building at Trump International Plaza, 767 Fifth Avenue, between 58th and 59th Streets. It is being raised 11 feet and turned into a podium with a sculpture garden, above a 22,000-square-foot retail space.
"I've always said that courtyard hurt the building," said Donald J. Trump, who owns the property with Conseco, an insurance company based in Carmel, Ind. The plaza did not hurt the size of the building, however. It added 252,969 square feet of space, or eight of the 50 floors. The plaza renovation will completed by October, Mr. Trump said.
Some early plazas that have already been renovated are now in need of a second round. Marsh & McLennan Companies are facing that challenge with the space behind their headquarters, 1166 Avenue of the Americas, between 45th and 46th Streets. It was successfully redesigned in 1983 by Hideo Sasaki as International Paper Plaza and remains verdant and popular.
There is a big problem, however. The plaza is actually a roof deck over the basement. And it leaks. That has prevented the use of the fountain, the meandering waterway and even the sprinklers. It has also occasioned a redesign by William Fellows Architects that would, Mr. Fellows said, "make a good park better."
Seating and plantings would be increased substantially. The fountain would be moved, keeping its centerpiece sculpture, "Throwback," by Tony Smith. The waterway would be eliminated but five dawn redwoods at the north end would remain. This little grove was added as a signature of the International Paper Company, whose headquarters were once in the building.
The redwood grove also marks the location of a five-story building, 56 West 46th Street, whose owners held out when the Tishman Realty and Construction Corporation was assembling the site for 1166 Avenue of the Americas. Without the midblock property, Tishman could not set its new tower back from the avenue. Instead, it flipped the customary arrangement and put the plaza on the inside. The public space at the base of the building generated a bonus of 242,195 square feet, or six of the 44 floors.
Four years after the tower was completed in 1974, the holdout was acquired and demolished. Because no basement had been excavated underneath its site, there was room for very large redwood root balls.
Marsh & McLennan, whose business includes risk and insurance services, investment management and consulting, owns a 70 percent share in the building and occupies roughly that much space. Pending city approval, the renovation would begin next year and be completed by the spring of 2002. The space would be known as MMC Plaza. Marsh & McLennan executives would not put a price tag on the project.
Mr. Fellows, who is working on the project with Hoffmann Architects and H. M. White, said the original design of the plaza by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill was "pretty brutal" -- basically a swath of travertine.
CONCERNED about the lack of amenities in public plazas, city planners began introducing design standards in the mid-70's. But Mr. Rose, the planning chief, acknowledged that standards do not necessarily guarantee a good plaza, "if you have an owner that's not committed to making the space work."
The city gave itself further leverage five years ago with provisions that allow owners to add kiosks or fences in exchange for improving their plazas. "Putting a cafe into a space, as long as it's done with the agreement of the public sector, is perfectly legitimate," Mr. Rose said. So are nighttime closings, he said, for plazas that have become "dumping grounds and campsites."
The Municipal Art Society supported the idea of nighttime closings, said Ellen P. Ryan, the director of planning issues, since the rationale for the plazas was to ease daytime crowding. "But there's no question that there's a price to pay," she said. "Has it been worth it? It's too early to tell."
Community Board 5 in mid-Manhattan is concerned that such provisions have "incentivized hardship," said its chairman, Kyle Merker. In other words, an owner may let a plaza go to seed and then appeal to the city to save the space by permitting a nighttime closing. "We don't want to reward bad management of a plaza by giving them the right to take something back from the community, such as hours," Mr. Merker said.
One of the spaces authorized to close at night is currently a bleak cul-de-sac alongside the Ritz Plaza apartment tower, 235 West 48th Street. The 7,173-square-foot space, which generated a 40,143-square-foot bonus, has planters with benches front and back. The back benches make good bunks since they are invisible from the street. Last Monday evening, a shoeless man lay under a cardboard blanket on one bench. Another man claimed a second bench nearby for a nap after growling at a visitor.
"It's an encampment for the homeless and it's unsafe," Mr. Merker said. "The idea is not to keep homeless out. The idea is to make sure all users of a plaza are using it in the manner for which it was intended. Sit there. Eat lunch. Relax. But if you're living there, it's a problem."
Mr. Balsley has drawn up a plan that would replace the planters with a fountain, add gates and turn the deepest recess into an extension of the adjoining restaurant.
He said his redesigns are intended to include the "broadest constituency" because "anyone is well behaved in a space that has a balance, a good cross-section."
Some of the more intractable plaza problems arise at apartment towers that have been converted to condominium or co-op ownership. "The developer builds a bonus plaza, sells out and moves on to the next building," Mr. Balsley said. "Now the residents have this bonus plaza. But it's no bonus to them. What they see is a hardship."
That was the case at the Harmony co-op, 61 West 62nd Street, whose developer obtained a 95,314-square-foot bonus for what turned out to be a dismal public atrium.
"The situation is something we inherited, not something we negotiated," said Neil S. Goldstein, president of the co-op board. "Anybody who knew that space had to know it wasn't working." In 1996, the storefronts in the atrium were vacant or covered over.
Then came the ExtraVertical Climbing Center, operated by Ralph Erenzo, with climbing walls up to 50 feet high. Crowds gathered inside and outside to watch the human mountain goats at play. Mr. Goldstein said ExtraVertical had "added a point of interest, attraction and attention."
What would seem on the face of it to be an upbeat ending, however, is clouded by a legal battle. Mr. Erenzo said the failure by the co-op to heat the atrium for three winters in a row seriously damaged his business and hurt his investors, who have not recouped their money. He is seeking damages or an extension of the very favorable initial term of his lease, which called for a rent of merely $100 a year.
Mr. Erenzo blames the co-op for not acting except under legal threat and the planning and buildings agencies for not enforcing the terms under which public spaces are managed. "Planning writes the contracts but nobody is checking to see if the owner is doing it," he said. "Buildings doesn't even know what they're supposed to enforce."
Despite their dispute, Mr. Goldstein and Mr. Erenzo agreed in separate interviews that the Harmony Atrium seemed finally to be coming to life in its 20th year, thanks to the recent addition of the Rosa Mexicana restaurant and Breadsoul Cafe.
"We have good, hard-working neighbors now," Mr. Erenzo said, "and the atrium looks like it will be a success."
Mr. Goldstein said the co-op board was "committed to making it work" and had spent hundreds of thousands of dollars toward that end. "We're on the right track at this point," he said. "We're very optimistic. And I say that notwithstanding the present difficulties with ExtraVertical."
Five blocks south, another long-running saga seems to be nearing an end.
In retrospect, it appears that Sheffield Plaza, at Ninth Avenue and 57th Street, was flawed from the outset. For one thing, the public space does not adjoin the development for which it created a bonus. The 48-story Sheffield apartment tower, 322 West 57th Street, is separated from the Ninth Avenue plaza by the Parc Vendome.
There is a second plaza at the base of the Sheffield. These two public spaces together yielded a bonus of 183,183 square feet.
The original developer in the 1970's, Hyman Shapiro, planned to link the Ninth Avenue plaza to the midblock plaza through the central courtyard of the Parc Vendome. But that approach was scrapped by the time the unfinished project was taken over by Rose Associates.
As designed in 1980 by Abel & Bainson, the Ninth Avenue plaza complied with existing seating, planting and access guidelines. It had a waterfall, planters with flower beds and a small stage surrounded by amphitheater-style seating, where programming was to be staged by WNET-TV, Channel 13, which was then across 57th Street. "People genuinely believed these were good solutions," said Adam Rose, the president of Rose Associates.
By the mid-80's, the amphitheater was largely unused except as a latrine and dormitory. The waterfall was shut off. The planters, long since empty of flowers, were filled with concrete in an attempt -- not altogether successful -- to discourage rats.
Jeanne McArthur, a member of the board of managers of the Parc Vendome, said the husband of another board member was stabbed in the plaza early one evening a few years ago. She also recalled a homeless encampment whose residents had gone so far as to hook up a television set.
"I've never pretended that it was a successful green space that attracted the right kind of people," Mr. Rose said. "But I've been equally insistent that the initial design was done in direct response to specific organizations' and city agencies' requests. The amphitheater was to be filled with cultural programming provided by Channel 13. Never happened. The security function was to be volunteers from John Jay College of Criminal Justice. Never happened."
The only bright note at Sheffield Plaza was the farmers' market operated every Wednesday and Saturday by the Council on the Environment of New York City, through its Greenmarket program. Rose Associates charges no rent to the market.
Efforts to renovate the plaza hit an impasse in the 1980's over how, even whether, the plaza could be closed at night and what sort of fence ought to be used. Mr. Rose said the process -- already complicated by the involvement of the Greenmarket, Parc Vendome, block association, community board, borough president, Buildings and Parks Departments -- was further frustrated in the previous administration by city planners who "kept redesigning the redesign."
Enter Mr. Balsley. "The biggest move I made was a no-brainer," he said. "Put in a cafe at an important corner. You need to anchor the space with a real amenity that will be open all the hours the park is open, managing the tables and chairs, someone you can count on no matter what time of day." The operator of the cafe pays no rent.
The next step was creating a transverse route through the park as a shortcut to lure pedestrians. "With a large amount of positive traffic walking through," Mr. Rose said, "it deters loiterers of all types." To draw even more users, Mr. Balsley added a small, enclosed play area at the south end.
Perhaps his most audacious move was to replace the sunken amphitheater with a grassy hillock. "People have an attraction to lawns," Mr. Balsley said. "The idea of a carpet of grass -- there's something magical about it. You don't expect it when you round the corner. The lawn says, 'Come up and lie on me.' " (It says something else to neighborhood dogs, which is a problem.)
Mr. Rose knows the turf will have to be replaced every couple of years. "I'm willing to bear that cost to have such a beautiful feature," he said. "To be in an urban plaza and see a swath of green is relief in itself."
THE plaza has something else it never had before: six-foot-high fences. They retract during the day but are an imposing barrier when they are drawn shut. In winter and fall, the park will be open from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. In spring and summer, it will stay open two hours later. The nighttime closing was approved by the City Planning Commission without the participation of its chairman, Joseph Rose, who is Adam Rose's cousin.
As far as Ms. McArthur is concerned, "it's wonderful that it can be closed at night but what I most admire is that the design has brought in children and families."
"A place nobody wanted to go is suddenly full of people," she said.
Simone Sindin, the chairwoman of the Clinton land-use and zoning committee of Community Board 4, thinks the new park is lovely. "It's been a lure," she said. "It's been marvelous. People love sitting down there and having a cool drink."
Not every review is a rave. The farmers' market lost its space on 57th Street and did not get its wish for a design that would accommodate trucks on the plaza. Moreover, it had to close from September to March because of the construction. "For us, the verdict is still out in terms of whether it will bring more clientele," said Tony Mannetta, the director of Greenmarket.
One neighbor is Richard Barth, director of the Manhattan office of the City Planning Department, who walks by the space every day and noted with pleasure how quickly it filled with people after reopening.
He said the redesign incorporates many lessons learned in the last 40 years: provide constant "eyes on the street," eliminate sharp changes in grade level, offer a variety of seating and create some distinctive feature like the lawn. "I think it really does function as a park," Mr. Barth said.
To reward Mr. Balsley for his accomplishment and to make up for the many occasions in which the landscape architect received no credit, Adam Rose proposed naming the new park after him, calling him an "unsung hero" of public spaces.
The dutifully modest honoree accepted on behalf of his profession. "The running joke was that the naming of the park was in lieu of payment of the last invoice," Mr. Balsley said. Well, then, did Mr. Rose also pay up? "Of course he did."

LENGTH: 1268 words

HEADLINE: THE CENSUS;
The Age of Affluence

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
In a broad demographic profile that anticipates the findings of the 2000 census, researchers from Rutgers University have portrayed the New Jersey that everyone suspected was out there: an aging, affluent population sustained by immigration, employed at record levels and creating a new exurban landscape. In this picture, the state's population is moving ever outward, and while its cities are finally stanching losses, they have been overtaken by burgeoning, sprawling suburban townships like Woodbridge and Edison. And these are populated largely by baby boomers who are entering peak earning years and "producing an era of demographically driven affluence."
But the report, made public today, says that while New Jersey may feel more congested than ever -- and it is -- the census will find that the state is growing only half as fast as the rest of the nation. 
 In sum, the census will confirm that "New Jersey survived the economic trauma of the early 1990's," James W. Hughes, the report's main author, said in an interview. "It's a confirmation of a vibrant diversity, because of all that immigration, a thriving economy, and always a maturing baby boom generation lurking beneath everything."
The report was meant to "set the stage so people are aware of the trends and can evaluate the raw numbers that are going to be spewed out over time," said Mr. Hughes, who is the dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers. He prepared the report with Joseph J. Seneca, an economist at the university, and Connie O. Hughes, an assistant commissioner of the state labor department.
"There is a hunger for information on Census 2000," Mr. Hughes said, "and we're on a diet until late 2001."
The report calls New Jersey a "population laggard." Using the most recent census estimates and data on long-term trends, the researchers projected that the census would find a population increase of 5.8 percent for New Jersey and a 10.4 percent increase for the nation.
But the report says the state has been "a growth dynamo in its own region," with a 5.3 percent population gain through 1999, compared with 1.1 percent in New York and 0.9 percent in Pennsylvania. Connecticut lost 0.2 percent of its population during the decade.
Thus the nation's most suburban and most densely populated state became more so. Still, for the third consecutive decade, New Jerseyans left in sizable numbers. The net loss to other states was 378,495, according to Census Bureau estimates as of the end of December, while the state gained 377,830 immigrants.
And those immigrants have changed the state's racial and ethnic composition, the report says. In a reflection of nationwide trends, New Jersey is a little more African-American than it was in 1990 (15.2 percent of the population, up from 13.9 percent) and considerably more Hispanic (12.8 percent, up from 9.7 percent) and Asian (5.8 percent, up from 3.6 percent).
"In 2000 New Jersey will be somewhat more diverse than the nation as a whole -- but not dramatically so," the researchers wrote.
They said this year's racial and ethnic data are hard to anticipate, because the census allowed people for the first time to check more than one racial classification. When results are anaylzed, Mr. Hughes said, "we'll have a good feeling for what our communities are in this high-immigration era."
The report says the census should also document a continuation of the relentless suburbanization that Mr. Hughes, an urban planner who began his career as a specialist in housing trends, has detailed over several decades.
The waves from New York and Philadelphia spread ever farther, the report says, with two decades of suburban office construction along freeway corridors. The six counties in the state's midsection (Hunterdon, Mercer, Middlesex, Monmouth, Morris and Somerset) led the growth. "It is here that the new information-age economy positioned itself, and where maturing baby boom housing choices are oriented," the researchers wrote.
In their share of the state's population, these "wealth belt" counties should approach parity with the "mature core metropolis" (Essex, Bergen, Hudson, Passaic and Union counties) in the 2000 census, the report says, and should surpass it soon after.
The older cities lost population overall in the 1990's, but at a slower pace than they had in the previous four decades. The researchers said that in the next decade the "big six" cities (Camden, Elizabeth, Jersey City, Newark, Paterson and Trenton) as a group might register their first increase since the 1940's.
The interim census figures made public last year showed tiny population increases from 1990 to 1998 in Jersey City and Elizabeth. And in all the big six except Camden, investment has risen sharply in the last few years. According to state figures made public this month, spending on building rehabilitation in the five biggest cities was almost twice as high last year as it was in 1996, with only Newark suffering a decline from 1998.
While urban centers struggled through the decade to reverse losses, the townships identifed in the Rutgers report as the "big six suburbs" (Brick, Dover, Woodbridge, Edison, Hamilton and Cherry Hill) kept growing. Four of them -- Brick, Dover, Woodbridge and Edison -- had already surpassed both Camden and Trenton in the 1998 census estimates.
And New Jersey is still rich -- "an extraordinary consumer market," the report says -- and will likely rank only behind Connecticut in income.
But the rest of the nation is catching up, apparently: the report projects that the census will find New Jersey's median household income 31 percent higher than the national median, while in 1990 it was 36 percent higher. (In 1980, the state's advantage was only 18 percent.)
The gap shrank in the early 1990's, when the recession took an especially high toll in New Jersey, and then widened again with the economic expansion in the second half of the decade.
And New Jerseyans are employed as never before. The report said Census 2000 should find record low unemployment rates -- the natural result of a surging economy and a modest increase in the work force. While the state's population grew 5.3 percent, the number of 20 to 34 year olds declined as the baby bust generation came of working age, and the labor force grew just 3.5 percent.
In the meantime, the baby boomers were swelling the ranks of middle-aged, which the report says is "the most powerful age-structure shift that will be revealed by Census 2000." Almost one in three New Jerseyans is a boomer, now 36 to 54 years old.
"Never before in history," the researchers wrote, "has America and New Jersey had such a coincidence and concentration of its population in the stage of the life cycle when individual economic productivity and income peak."
The data on household makeup will show fewer married couples with children under 18, the report says: in a pattern of drastic change from the era when the boomers' parents were suburbanizing, only one-quarter of households consist of a married couple with children under 18, while about the same percentage is single people living alone.
In a centurylong perspective, the researchers noted that after explosive population increases in the pre-Depression decades and the postwar boom, growth slowed drastically, to a rate of 2.7 percent in the 1970's. It rose to 5 percent in the 1980's.
The report, "Anticipating Census 2000: New Jersey's Emerging Demographic Profile," is the 18th in a series tracking demographic changes in the state and region.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 10; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 730 words

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: PRELUDES;
Of Perks and (Tupperware) Parties

BYLINE: By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. Her column on starting out in the world of money appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
TUPPERWARE, not software. Maybe that should be my new motto as I consider joining the ranks of those who sell polyethylene fridgeware for a living.
Think about it. Selling Tupperware has an awful lot in common with the new-economy jobs that young adults crave. You can work any time you want and as much as you want. The biggest rewards go to those who are the most immersed, the most passionate, the most relentless. No soul-deadening shirt-and-tie office environment here: your workplace is the friendliest, funkiest available -- your own home. No health insurance, pension plans or other young-people-don't-need-'em benefits to bite into the paycheck -- just plenty of incentive-based compensation, plus perks like free cars (a Jeep Cherokee! a Dodge Caravan!) and vacations (Myrtle Beach! Las Vegas!) for hitting goals. They could call it www.tupperware.com. 
 In fact, they do. A year-old Web site by that name supplies the company's million-strong worldwide army of consultants with product information and stories of sales success. American customers can shop on the site, or, with a consultant's referral, at www.my.tupperware.com, a newer site that lets consultants customize their own home pages. Customers order online, and the consultant gets a commission.
Forget hausfraus in housecoats. Tupperware, Avon, Amway and other direct marketers have figured out that the way to cater to younger, Web-savvy consumers is to recruit younger, Web-savvy sales reps.
Clearly, a lot has changed in the 55 years since the first Tupperware snap-top container appeared. These days, more and more of the company's 75,000 American consultants are college-educated, said Christine Hanneman, a vice president of the Tupperware Corporation in Orlando, Fla. "We're looking for people to work their way up," she said.
Colleen Layne, 24, has been selling Tupperware for nearly five years and says she now earns more than $5,000 a month working 20-hour weeks. Ms. Layne got started as a high school senior in Garden City, Mich., while her friends were baby-sitting or shoveling French fries. Cool it wasn't -- "no one was into it," she remembered -- but she stuck with it, even throwing Tupperware parties in her college dorm room. She is now a senior executive manager overseeing 20 consultants, driving the Dodge minivan that she earned as an incentive.
"I don't plan on ever leaving," she said by cell phone while on a vacation. "It's too much fun."
THE story is similar at Avon Products, the doorbell-ringing cosmetics concern. Those doorbells have gone through considerable modifications since 1886, when a few pioneers sold their first lip rouge.
The company has been online since 1997 and in September plans to revamp the site to give sales representatives their own Web addresses. Reps who need them can lease a computer and get Internet access cheaply through the company. At the end of this month, Avon will be starting a "'beauty advisor" training program for the women -- and some, but not many, men -- who want to become certified experts in loveliness.
"We're offering career opportunities that attract young people," said Laura Castellano, a spokeswoman for Avon in Manhattan.
If that's not enough to make you quit your day job, the DeVos and Van Andel families, who brought Amway into the world, created quixtar.com last fall. It is intended to attract young entrepreneurs who want to sell Amway and other products online instead of door to door.
"Most Web e-tailers are trying to establish their brand and get customers, as we watch a lot of them struggle," said John Parker, vice president for sales and marketing at Quixtar, which like Amway is based in Grand Rapids, Mich. "We're not a typical dot-com because of the entrepreneurial opportunities, and we're not a typical direct-selling company because we have the dot-com piece. We're creating a new niche."
Is it working? A Quixtar spokesman said the half-million or so people who have signed up so far are, on average, about 10 years younger than those joining Amway lately.
It's too soon to know if newfangled multilevel marketing systems will have staying power, or if their young recruits will become jaded with the rah-rah tactics and move on to other businesses or their own start-ups.
If they do get fed up with Avon or Amway, I have a tip for them. It's just one word: plastics.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1278 words

HEADLINE: THE BUSINESS WORLD;
In Japan: Outsourcing Without A Capital 'O'

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
IT'S treated as a dirty little secret here, but Japan Inc. is embracing, gingerly, one of America's most hard-knuckled business tactics.
Pressed by a need to streamline their balance sheets, cut costs and drastically upgrade their information technology to regain competitiveness, Japanese companies are farming out chunks of their computer operations to companies like IBM Japan, Fujitsu and NTT Data. 
 Japan Inc. is often choosing, however, to forgo one of the most lucrative side effects of such outsourcing -- the shrinking of the corporate work force and the resulting cost savings.
As American as outsourcing may be, in Japan it reflects a business culture stubbornly resistant to practices that sacrifice employee well-being for the sake of efficiency. Japan's version suggests, more broadly, why technologies and management practices that are propelling the American economic boom have had less impact here.
When IBM Japan and Daiwa Bank put themselves on the map in 1997 with what was billed as Japan's first real outsourcing deal, the treatment of the people involved was a bigger issue than the business and financial ramifications. "Given the unique character of the Japanese employment system, there was some initial resistance at the bank and perhaps within society itself," said Yoshinobu Ishigaki, general manager of IBM Japan's service business development division. "Even the government showed some concern about it."
Still, the Daiwa deal spawned business that more than tripled IBM Japan's outsourcing revenue. This year alone, IBM Japan, a wholly owned subsidiary of International Business Machines, has scored contracts worth more than $3 billion.
"We saw a turning point in 1997 -- and it was a sharp one," Mr. Ishigaki said. "Japanese companies realized they needed to demonstrate their ability to change, and maybe more importantly, Japanese society began accepting outsourcing."
GIANTS like Fujitsu and NEC are also using outsourcing -- both as providers and as clients -- to meet the new challenges of a global business world that is increasingly reliant on computers and the Internet. Many businesses, particularly those in financial services, realize that they can no longer afford to invest in sophisticated information technology themselves.
"Banks in Chiba, Ehime, Hokkaido and lots of other places are looking to outsourcing as a way to survive," said Fumio Ohue, the partner who until recently headed the outsourcing business of Andersen Consulting and is now chief operating officer of the Netyear Group, a Japanese company that is devoted to providing strategic consulting services online. "It's hard for them to try to catch up with new products, networks and business management services on their own."
Outsourcing is a radical departure for most Japanese companies, which have long taken pride in doing everything themselves, or at least within their cluster of affiliated businesses.
"There was a sort of all-by-ourselves-ism that developed," said Sachio Nishiyama, chief manager of the systems administration division at the Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Corporation. "Now we're casting off that attitude, because we understand that there are areas where other companies can simply do it better."
After a year of discussions among senior executives, Mitsubishi Trust handed over to IBM Japan the operation of its data centers and the management of networks linking its sales offices; the deal is worth more than $350 million over the next decade. The bank expects to cut the cost of systems administration by 10 percent.
The costs would have fallen further if Mitsubishi Trust had sent the 50 employees associated with those activities to IBM Japan. But all were offered jobs elsewhere in the bank, according to Masahumi Abe, manager of the systems administration division.
"In the U.S. and Europe, this is probably hard to understand, since there, outsourcing is not just IBM Japan taking over the work but also taking over the people," he said. "But in Japan, outsourcing hasn't reached such an extent."
Not nearly. In fact, only a few Japanese companies are advertising their move toward outsourcing various aspects of their business, including accounting and human resources. In this land of lifetime employment, outsourcing conjures up an image of job-cutting, which is still in many ways taboo. So most companies would rather not talk about it.
"Excuse me, but why is The New York Times interested in our outsourcing efforts?" asked Fumiaki Ito, senior vice president of the Meiji Seika Company, a candy, dairy and pharmaceuticals company that hired IBM Japan in February to manage many of its computer systems. "We are not the only company adopting outsourcing, you know. It's not such a big deal, is it?"
Katsuhiko Minami, director of Meiji Seika's information systems department and manager of the 70 employees affected by the deal, was quick to point out that only nine jobs were lost -- and that those workers were given other posts or allowed to retire. "There are always new needs within the company," he said.
Retaining workers would seem to defeat the purpose of outsourcing. But Mr. Minami appeared happy with the 100 million yen, or $943,000, that Meiji Seika would save each year for the five years of its contract with IBM Japan.
"It's not a lot on a percentage basis," he said, "but it's a lot of money saved nonetheless."
At some companies, however, such sensitivities are fading fast. A recent television documentary about NEC's efforts to overhaul itself showed four workers wrestling computers into shipping boxes, tears streaming down their faces. They were part of a group of 300 white-collar employees, all formerly parked behind desks, who were dispatched to a packaging and warehousing company affiliated with NEC.
A spokesman for NEC made no effort to explain away the scene.
"We regard the case shown on TV as outsourcing," he said, bluntly declining to use more euphemistic terms for the longstanding practice of sending unnecessary workers to affiliates.
Others work harder to make outsourcing difficult to distinguish from more traditional business practices here. Mr. Ohue classifies many recently created joint ventures as outsourcing in disguise.
CONSIDER the case of Toyo Information Systems, an affiliate of Sanwa Bank, and Komatsu, the struggling general building contractor. As part of a reorganization, Komatsu sold 65 percent of its software subsidiary, Komatsu Soft, to Toyo. Komatsu can continue to rely on its former subsidiary and, as a major shareholder, still be treated as a special customer. Yet it shed responsibility for some 700 employees.
"This is win-win outsourcing done in a very Japanese way," Mr. Ohue said. "I think we'll see more of that kind of outsourcing because it allows everyone to save face and is not as harsh as outsourcing U.S. style."
Outsourcing still faces opposition here, no matter how soft the touch. NCR Japan has been one of the biggest outsourcers, moving 1,200 people off its payroll and fighting at least one bitter battle with labor. In 1994, the company temporarily transferred 700 employees to a new, partly owned affiliate to handle maintenance work. Four years later, when NCR tried to make those transfers permanent, some union members took the company to court. The case is still pending.
That has not discouraged Isao Aoki, head of NCR Japan's human resources operations. "I introduced outsourcing to this company because I believe it will strengthen the whole company," he said. "It was the only effective way to restructure in Japan, where simply cutting jobs is considered unjustifiable."

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
Is a Harder Landing in the Works?

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
REMEMBER stagflation? That's when the economy slows and inflation rises -- the worst of both worlds. It was the curse of the mid-1970's, as the economy fell into recession and the Consumer Price Index rose 12.3 percent in a single year, 1974. And it returned in 1980, when the C.P.I. jumped 12.5 percent while the economy ground to a halt.
Inflation has come way down since then, and the economy is now in the longest period of continuous growth on record. So who's talking about stagflation? Not many people -- and that may be a problem. 
 Now, the few who are talking are not predicting anything like the stagflation of yore. But they are saying that investors could face a period of slowing economic growth, which they equate loosely with stagnation, and of rising prices, which is inflation. They warn that increases in unit labor costs associated with this more benign stagflation will also cut into corporate earnings. But the stock and bond markets have not yet factored this in; instead, Wall Street forecasters still expect earnings to grow this year at the quickest annual pace since 1993.
At the worst, this small group of worried economists and strategists adds, the Federal Reserve could raise short-term interest rates higher than is now expected, in response to reports of a climbing C.P.I. That extra tightening could push the the economy into a recession.
How could this happen, especially when many Wall Street strategists think that the Fed is guiding the economy to a soft landing, slowing it down to a manageable but still positive pace?
To begin with, a slowdown in economic growth would set off a decline in the growth rate of worker productivity, measured by the value of output for each hour worked. In the last two quarters of 1999, productivity surged, rising an annual rate of 5 and 6.9 percent, respectively. Unit labor costs declined during those quarters, by 0.3 and 2.9 percent. Corporate earnings, meanwhile surged 22.7 and 21.4 percent.
But with economic growth slowing, productivity gains will shrink, said Paul A. McCulley, a portfolio manager at the Pacific Investment Management Company, a bond powerhouse in Newport Beach, Calif. That would happen because companies do not shed workers quickly as demand for products slackens. Indeed, with workers so difficult to find these days, few employers would be willing to consider layoffs at the first sign of a slowdown. So the same number of workers would be producing fewer goods, and that works out to lower productivity.
Smaller productivity gains mean that unit labor costs, which equal total worker compensation minus productivity, would rise. In the first quarter of this year, productivity gains slowed to 2.4 percent while unit labor costs rose 1.6 percent, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. While corporate profits remained strong, the C.P.I., not counting prices for food and energy, jumped at a compound annual rate of 3.2 percent in the first quarter.
FACED with rising unit labor costs, companies have two choices. They can pass them on to consumers in higher prices, which adds to inflationary pressures, or they can absorb them -- because of competitive fears -- and reduce their profits.
It is also likely that workers will be pushing for wage increases to compensate them for the high productivity gains of the last few years. Pay raises are usually backward-looking, because they are based on profits the company has already made.
Mr. McCulley says the period -- or "interregnum" -- of rising prices and slowing growth should not last long, provided that the Fed does not raise interest rates too much and cause a recession. On the far side, an economy with inflation again in check and the Fed on hold will be good for stocks.
But, he said, "the equity market has not embraced an interregnum of stagflation." Equities, he said, are already overpriced for the shock of rising inflation and slowing growth; if the Fed tightens too much in response to an inflationary spurt, he sees stocks headed for disaster.

SECTION: Section 12; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL: Subaru Outback;
New All Over, and Down Under

BYLINE: By BOB KNOLL 

 BODY:
ANYONE who has watched network television in the last few years has seen Crocodile Dundee (a k a Paul Hogan) tearing through desert and swamp in the "world's first sport utility wagon," the all-wheel-drive Subaru Outback. But those with an interest in auto history will recall a few other wagons that also offered all-wheel drive and could have made a case for an S.U.W. label: the 1988-91 Dodge Colt Vista, the 1992-94 Mitsubishi Expo LRV, the 1988 Nissan Stanza and the 1990 Nissan Axxess.
None of those are around today, perhaps because they failed to capitalize on the rising trend, perhaps because they were not very good. Automotive history is dotted with successes and failures, of cars that caught fads on the rise and others that arrived as trends turned south. 
 There is no doubt that Subaru had the timing right with its Outback, which began as a trim package for the 1995 Legacy station wagon. Since then, the Outback gained higher ground clearance and a raised roofline to set it apart from the Legacy, and it spawned a whole range of models, including an Outback sedan and a fancy Outback Limited. Last year, Outbacks -- which are nearly identical, mechanically, to other, less expensive models -- accounted for 39 percent of all Subaru sales and 69 percent of Legacy production. Subaru's full line of wagons has been first in wagon sales in the United States for three years.
The Legacy/Outback wagons, which are assembled in Indiana, were little changed from 1996 to 1999. But for 2000, Subaru performed major surgery on the Legacy and the Outback, which is now a separate, distinct series.
The new body is smoother, rounder and about 3 inches longer, with a slightly longer wheelbase. But those familiar with the previous model will have no trouble recognizing the Outback wagon, since most of its visual cues have been kept, including the slightly raised roof and large fog lamps.
The engine remains a flat four cylinder -- called a "boxer," for the way its pistons flail outward, rather than move up and down -- but it has been redesigned for more low-end torque and better fuel economy. Cars with automatic transmissions have a slightly different all-wheel-drive system from those with stick shifts, but drivers will not notice any difference in their smooth function.
The front suspension is largely unchanged, but the rear suspension is a new multilink design that intrudes less into the cargo area. The change results not only in a smoother ride and better handling, but also in a cargo floor that is 5.2 inches wider and significantly more useful. There are disk brakes on all four wheels and an antilock system.
Safety improvements include three-point belts for all five occupants and child-safety-seat anchors for all three rear-seat positions. The Outback (except for the Limited, which comes with leather upholstery) offers as a $200 option a folding, integrated child seat in the center rear position.
The front safety belts incorporate pretensioners to better position the occupant during a crash and force limiters that work in conjunction with the front air bags to help protect one's chest. The Outback Limited has front seat side-impact air bags in the upper portion of the front seatbacks. The body structure has been designed to dissipate energy better in front, side and rear crashes.
This new design seems to have paid off. The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety has given the Legacy wagon a good rating and calls it a "best pick" for its performance in an offset-front crash test at 40 miles an hour -- a severe test of the body structure. Few automobiles in this class have received such a high rating.
In front-impact tests by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, a Legacy sedan received four stars for the driver and passenger. In side-crash tests, the Legacy got four stars for driver safety and five, the top rating, for rear passengers. The tested car did not have side air bags, which might have improved the driver rating.
In these days of extreme popularity for truck-based sport utilities, it is worth noting that the Outback is certified as a passenger car. Other manufacturers are classifying car-based S.U.V.'s as trucks to take advantage of less stringent regulations governing the safety and emissions of light trucks. This means that the Outback has complied with the full set of Federal safety and emissions regulations, in contrast to vehicles like the Lexus RX 300, the Honda CR-V and the BMW X5, to name a few.
Compared with previous Outbacks I have driven, and a 1996 model that my wife owns, the 2000 model is a step up in ride quality, noise reduction, and steering and handling. The wagon feels more European in its control over challenging roads and in its precise, nicely weighted steering. Braking is smooth and sure, although there is a bit more free play in the pedal than I would like. The annoying throbbing sound of the 2.5-liter engine has been all but eliminated, and wind noise is fairly low.
Powerful engine response has never been a Subaru virtue. It still is not, but the new engine has more low- and medium-range torque so that at less than full throttle it feels fairly strong. One unfortunate result: the wagon moves out almost too abruptly on takeoff from a stop.
In October, there will be two additional 2001-model Outbacks: the H6-VDC and the H6-3.0 L. L. Bean Edition. These cars will have an all-new 3-liter six-cylinder engine -- the only six that Subaru has offered in this country since the sporty SVX coupe was discontinued in 1996. The L. L. Bean model will wear the logo of the mail-order company inside and out.
As one who has driven many thousands of miles in Subarus, I am always impressed by the completely seamless action of their all-wheel drive. Many manufacturers claim that their S.U.V.'s have all-wheel drive that reacts instantly when a wheel loses grip, but in reality many delay, stutter and bump as they compensate for a loss of traction.
Drivers who venture into challenging four-wheel-drive territory will find that the Outback is hindered by its lack of special low-range gearing and its relatively soft suspension. Yet Subaru says the Outback is capable of recreational off-roading, and with its large tires and generous 7.3 inches of ground clearance, that claim seems fair. But the main advantages of a seamless all-wheel-drive system are smooth response on dry pavement and increased security in heavy rain or moderate snow.
Inside the Outback, consumers looking for a user-friendly instrument panel and control layout will like what they see. Owners of previous Legacys who have cursed the awkward cup holder will feel much better about the new one. The window and lock switches are simple and easy to use, as are the wiper and light stalks. The Limited has heated front seats and two power moonroofs, one over the front seat and one forward of the rear seat. Their operation is rather strange in that the front moonroof doesn't slide; it only tilts. And although the rear one slides open, it can't be operated unless the front one is tilted. One wonders what the advantage of this curious arrangement may be.
Buyers looking for the safety and security of all-wheel drive, and who would not be happy with a cruder truck-based sport utility, have a number of very good station wagons to choose from. Subaru has the lowest-priced wagons in this category, including Legacys that start around $19,000 and the $20,000 Outback Sport -- which is based on the smaller Impreza, not on the Legacy. But in size and comfort, the Sport cannot match wagons in the $25,000 to $30,000 range.
There, the regular Legacy-based Outback, the Volkswagen Passat 4Motion and the Audi A4 Avant Quattro are attractive, strong-performing wagons. The Audi A6 Avant and the Volvo Cross Country are competitive in the $40,000 range. Another $10,000 puts you into Mercedes territory.
 
INSIDE TRACK: Safety on boulevard or back roads without the aggressiveness of a truck.

HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS JOEL KOTKIN;
A Gusher of Technology In Downtown Tulsa

BYLINE: Joel Kotkin is a senior fellow at the Davenport Institute for Public Policy at Pepperdine University. His column on the Main Street economy appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail may be sent to grassrts@nytimes.com

DATELINE: TULSA, Okla.

 BODY:
A DECADE ago, Tulsa was a played-out oil-and-gas town.
Today, the town's boosters have recast it in the role of telecommunications superpower. The area has more than 54,000 high-technology jobs, which account for roughly 8 percent of local employment, a share that matches well-known technology centers like Raleigh-Durham, N.C.; Dallas; and Stamford, Conn. In the next three years, a recent survey of area employers showed, the region is expected to add up to 6,000 positions in telecommunications alone. 
 The area's emergence as a high-technology center seems all the more impressive because it is occurring in a state not widely known for its high-technology infrastructure or its educational system, said Craig Knutson, chief Oklahoma economist for Southwestern Bell. According to the American Electronics Association, Oklahoma ranks 28th in high-technology jobs among the 50 states and has a per capita income below the national average. The Tulsa area, with roughly a quarter of the state's population, accounts for 60 to 70 percent of Oklahoma's high-technology employees and revenues.
That such an unlikely place has become a new-economy hotbed is, in fact, largely a legacy of its previous boom, Mr. Knutson said. For one thing, the explosive growth of the city in the 1920's bequeathed it a magnificent array of impressive Art Deco buildings, many of which are now attracting Internet and other information-oriented companies. The oil boom also left the city with elegant close-in urban neighborhoods that are ideal for skilled professionals and managers.
And philanthropy fueled by oil wealth has given Tulsa, which has a metropolitan population of 800,000, an attractive civic infrastructure that includes a respected ballet and orchestra, and art museums.
But perhaps more important, the energy legacy -- specifically its management information systems component -- gave Tulsa many employees with high-technology skills. This labor pool, plus a relatively low cost of living, has attracted a host of large information businesses, including Sabre Holdings, the travel-reservation company; WorldCom, the communications giant; and aerospace companies like Aeromet.
ANOTHER key factor has been the makeover of the Williams Companies, which was founded in 1908 and grew up as essentially an oil pipeline business. Since the early 1990's, the company, long an anchor of the old energy economy, has been using the rights of way from its extensive gas pipelines to create one of the nation's primary fiber optic networks; it has become a leading provider of broadband services for telecommunications companies like SBC Communications. (Two SBC rivals, Sprint and Qwest Communications, were spawned by the Southern Pacific Railroad, which also used its right of way to find a place in the new economy.)
The Williams Communications unit, which had roughly 200 employees in Tulsa in 1996, now has more than 2,000. The number is expected to double by the end of next year.
That surge in employment, including thousands more temporary jobs at Williams itself and others created by its subcontractors, is helping to transform Tulsa's once-sleepy downtown. The symbolic center of the new activity is Williams's new 15-story, 45,000-square-foot stacked urban campus, which is being designed to serve as the nerve center of the company's national fiber optic network. Over all, downtown office vacancy rates, which stood in the 20 to 30 percent range in the mid-1980's, have fallen into the single digits.
Tulsa's emergence parallels the rise of several other "second tier" cities -- places like Albuquerque and Cedar Rapids, Iowa -- that are finding new niches in the information economy. In many cases, these cities offer lower living costs, equally good business climates and a more family-friendly atmosphere than places like Silicon Valley, Boston's Route 128 or Dallas-Fort Worth.
The resurgence of such cities also often parallels -- and is spurred by -- the reinvention of many of its residents' careers. A decade ago, for example, Carol Mersch and Tony Bacher were among the last to leave the sinking ship that was Tulsa's old energy economy. Co-workers in the information systems division at Reading & Bates, a local drilling company, they hung around to process the pink slips of their fellow workers before ultimately issuing their own.
"It seemed like half of Tulsa was being terminated," Ms. Mersch said.
The two technologists decided to start their own firm, Mersch-Bacher Associates, to develop business software products for I.B.M.'s new AS-400 computer platform. The company was a big success. Seven years later, in 1996, the two began another venture, an Internet service provider called Webzone, which by 1999 had more than 12,000 subscribers. The partners sold both companies last year for more than $6.5 million.
"We started because we didn't have jobs and no prospect of getting one," Ms. Mersch said. "When the oil bust came, it forced a lot of people to rethink their careers."
Reading & Bates moved to Houston in 1989 as part of a major restructuring and has since merged into the R & B Falcon Corporation. Ms. Mersch and Mr. Bacher are now vice presidents at Pinnacle Business Systems, the computer development and services company that bought Mersch-Bacher Associates.
Not even Tulsa's most ardent boosters, however, are ready to sell the city's downtown as a rival to creative Internet centers like Boston's Cyber District, Lower Manhattan or San Francisco's South of Market. As a city with a modest nightlife, lacking both a highly recognized research university and convenient air connections, Tulsa is unlikely to emerge as a full-fledged information-age capital, Mr. Knutson said.
Indeed, most of the growth, whether at giants like WorldCom and Williams or at smaller companies, continues to stick largely to the telecommunications and enabling-software side of the information boom.
Still, in many ways, such infrastructure concerns -- those that provide the roads or software for the information superhighway -- may prove stronger and more impervious to market fluctuations than the Internet content companies, largely unprofitable so far, that have prompted the revivals in other cities.
Typical of Tulsa's new arrivals are companies like SecureAgent.com, which provides encryption software for major corporations. The company's founder, Brent Johnson, spent much of his life in the Bay Area before coming to Tulsa to work as a consultant for American Airlines. In 1992, he founded SecureAgent, not in Silicon Valley but here, in a place that offered an expanding telecommunications network in a lower-cost business environment.
"Tulsa is a little-known secret," said Mr. Johnson, whose company employs 24 people and plans to hire 40 more in the next 18 months.
He sees the costs for engineers, who are paid, on average, roughly 40 percent less than their Bay Area peers, as a major plus for his company, and he likes the relatively low prices for housing and his company's office space in a refurbished downtown structure. "This building has a lot of character," he said, and "costs me less than it would have cost me in California 10 years ago."
Mr. Johnson said that because his company was in a technical niche, it had an easier time flourishing in a city like Tulsa, which lacks the high numbers of fine restaurants and other accouterments of centers like New York or San Francisco. Unlike a media or content firm, he explained, a company like SecureAgent.com does not depend on regular face-to-face contact with prime customers.
"Our customers are all over the world," he said. "We are not going out to lunch with them. We can do just fine where we are."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Greenspan's Way of Pulling His Punches

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
ALAN GREENSPAN gave two speeches last week. He was unusually talkative. He declaimed at length about financial crises, productivity, job training, education. But in all those hundreds of words, not one dealt with the current condition of the long economic expansion.
That is understandable. Talking about the expansion at this particular moment could get him or the economy, or both, into trouble. Wall Street hangs on his words, ready to send stock prices soaring if he signals that the Federal Reserve no longer needs to raise interest rates; the bubble that had seemed to subside would balloon again. Or he could warn about inflation, suggesting that it might accelerate because scarce workers are demanding, and getting, higher pay. The implicit solution: Let unemployment rise -- in an election year -- to tame the workers. 
 No wonder his speeches dwell on easier themes. He puts off assessing the economy until he can put it off no longer. That moment will come on Thursday when, as Fed chairman, he testifies before Congress on the state of the economy. The trick will be to explain what is happening without having the explanation change what is happening.
Mr. Greenspan will almost certainly note that the economy slowed in the second quarter from its blistering winter pace. He has no choice: the statistics are fairly convincing. The argument that saw the Fed through six interest-rate increases over the past year is temporarily unavailable. The economy no longer appears to be growing so rapidly that the demand for goods and services exceeds the supply, threatening faster inflation.
But does that mean that the Fed is done raising rates? Is further slowing no longer necessary? Mr. Greenspan certainly does not want to leave that impression.
Just as rate increases or the threat of them tend to inhibit stock market investors -- for myriad reasons, not all of them rational -- the suggestion that rates won't rise tends to produce exuberance. Stock prices could climb after months of moving sideways. Demand and spending would then grow as stock portfolios fattened and consumers felt flush again -- a sequence called the wealth effect. And the economy's growth rate would rebound to what the Fed considers an inflationary level.
Maybe things have changed, and the old exuberance can no longer be summoned so easily. "The tone of the marketplace is a lot more subdued than it was six months ago," said Albert Wojnilower, a Wall Street economist. But soaring stock prices and a revived wealth effect remain dangers that are likely to prevent Mr. Greenspan from declaring that the economy has slowed enough.
SO he will almost certainly lace his assessment with caveats and ambiguity. After all, the growth rate cooled in the second quarter of 1999, only to turn torrid over the next nine months.
Moreover, not all of today's statistics portray a slowdown. Some, including the retail sales report on Friday, suggest unexpected strength. Loan rates still encourage borrowing. And the data is still coming in for June, not to mention July. Who knows what those numbers will tell the Fed before its next policy meeting, on Aug. 22?
"The sensible thing for Mr. Greenspan to say is that there have been scattered signs that economic growth is moderating, but they are far from convincing," said Chris Varvares, a partner at Macroeconomic Advisers in St. Louis. "That is our view, and that leaves the door wide open for him to do what he wants."
Mr. Wojnilower adds a note: "He could mention that the stock market has stopped adding wealth, and in that way give the message that if the stock market adds to wealth again, the slowdown might not continue."
There is a second aspect of inflation that Mr. Greenspan will almost certainly address. Apart from the oil shock, prices have been gradually rising this year, and some at the Fed think that inflation could continue to edge upward even if a slowdown persists. The concern is that low unemployment drives up wages and, in turn, prices.
That has not happened yet, despite many months of low unemployment. Some economists now declare the wage-price linkage broken, or effective only at an unemployment rate below today's 4 percent.
Mr. Greenspan himself is a doubter. He speaks much more often about improvements in productivity, in effect giving employers more revenue to pay for raises without raising prices. But in deference to a Fed tradition of linking wage increases and price increases, he is likely to mention the potential inflationary danger of a prolonged labor shortage.
Not that he will suggest a higher unemployment rate, or a crackdown on raises. Not in a Senate hearing room full of politicians three months before the election.
