HEADLINE: Arab-Israeli Negotiations Turn on the Chemistry of the Central Players

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG and JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
Given the total seclusion of the Camp David peace talks, photographs issued by the White House offer the only glimpse inside the presidential retreat. They present frozen images of men in shirtsleeves, pens poised over note pads, their faces absorbed in thought.
While it is impossible to know what is going on at those negotiating tables, the delegations themselves offer a road map to the process. Israelis, Palestinians and Americans, their political, military and diplomatic careers have been interwoven and, in some cases, steered exclusively toward this goal: the supposed endgame of the Israeli-Palestinian peace effort and the resolution of 52 years of conflict. 
 For the three members of the American peace team, for instance, this summit meeting marks the culmination of a professional life spent shuttling between Israelis and Arabs, a career that became a personal mission.
In negotiations that will surely go right to the wire, and then trip it, everything will eventually come down to the leaders themselves. But the fabric of relations is knitted by the negotiators, by, say, the interaction between Shlomo Ben-Ami, the popular Labor Party politician who is a potential future challenger to Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel, and Abu Ala, the Palestinian parliament speaker, who is a potential future heir to Yasir Arafat, president of the Palestinian Authority.
Mr. Barak, leader of the Labor Party and a general turned peacemaker, brought the smallest delegation, a relatively lean, mean team of mostly military men and center-left politicians like himself. This fighting trim was not intentional; it reflects the defection of the rightist parties in his government on the eve of his departure. But it could serve to streamline his approach, since he will not have to answer to the deep-seated reluctance of those ministers who would otherwise have come.
"Barak is so intent he is like a horse with blinders, and this will make it simpler here, although harder when he returns home," an adviser to the prime minister said.
In contrast, Mr. Arafat traveled to the United States not only with his senior negotiators, security professionals and economic advisers but with some opposition party leaders and with a vocal critic as the appointed spokeswoman.
Unlike Mr. Barak, a democratic leader, Mr. Arafat, who is often considered to be an authoritarian, has surrounded himself with a consensus-building organism. The opposition leaders are not inside Camp David -- in fact, the Americans would not admit them when they banged at the gate this week -- but even within the group inside, there is a spectrum ranging from the more pragmatic to the more cynical, from money men to ideologues.
Some American and Israeli officials think Mr. Arafat would not have made the journey in such complete Palestinian company if he were not intent on reaching some kind of deal.
But an adviser to Mr. Arafat cautioned that the Palestinian leader has always "tried to bring people inside his tent" -- and that has been a strength and a weakness. Sometimes, hard-liners have kept him "too pure," an Israeli official said.
Also, the main opposition leaders, like Sheik Ahmed Yassin of the radical Islamic group Hamas, did not unite behind the peace effort.
"This time," a former diplomat said, "Arafat will only make a deal when it is to his advantage and he won't let artificial deadlines force him into something he doesn't want to do." That deadline is President Clinton's scheduled departure for Okinawa on Wednesday for the meeting of major industrial nations.
Behind Mr. Clinton at Camp David, there is a triptych of diplomats who -- sometimes symbiotically, sometimes competitively -- have devoted themselves to the Middle East since the 1980's: Dennis Ross, 52, chief Middle East peace envoy; his deputy, Aaron D. Miller, 51; and Martin Indyk, 49, who is now on his second tour as ambassador to Israel.
For all three men, their formative experience was the 1973 Arab-Israeli war. Mr. Miller and Mr. Indyk were graduate students in Israel; Mr. Ross had just left. And as young Jewish intellectuals, colleagues say, they came away believing that Israel needed peace with its neighbors as badly as it needed to be protected from another devastating war.
From that conviction, their concept of Israel grew, fortified by a strong security relationship with the United States, making peace with its neighbors through incremental steps. These ideas were developed by Mr. Indyk, who became the first director of the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, an offshoot of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, and by Mr. Ross, who perched there briefly in 1992.
After Mr. Clinton became president, he gave the three men a chance to turn position papers into policy. Mr. Indyk, an Australian, became an American citizen in order to do so.
The three began with the 1993 Oslo interim peace accord. Mr. Miller cultivated relations with Mr. Arafat, whom he had first met in Tunis. Mr. Ross and Mr. Indyk concentrated on the Israelis. And when Mr. Barak was elected prime minister last year, the three made little secret of their pleasure at having an Israeli leader whose peacemaking platform matched theirs.
Palestinians, who think that American policy has long been skewed toward Israel, frequently note quietly that all three American negotiators are Jewish. But over the course of their repeated trekking to Gaza and Ramallah to visit Mr. Arafat, the three have come to be seen as fair -- although this judgment could fray in the heat of negotiations.
Before leaving for the meeting, one of the three said that it was the most "extraordinary development" he had experienced in 20 years. "The stakes are incredibly high," he said -- and it was clear he was talking personally and diplomatically.
Stakes are high, of course, for all present. There is not a single Palestinian official with Mr. Arafat's stature. But in the speculation about who would succeed the 70-year-old leader, his longtime deputies, Abu Ala and Abu Mazen, are the top contenders. They are formally positioned to split his two roles: Abu Ala to succeed him as president of the Palestinian National Authority and Abu Mazen as chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
As such, they have an investment in negotiating a final peace accord that could stand the test of time. And yet, while they are both relative moderates within the Palestinian world, the delegation's official position is that the summit meeting is being held too soon, without the proper groundwork laid for a full or even partial resolution of outstanding problems.
Inside Camp David, Mr. Abu Ala, 63, a pragmatist and strong strategist, is certain to play the visible lead role. Although Mr. Arafat occasionally considers him a bit too independent, he has relied on Mr. Abu Ala for the hands-on part of all key negotiations. Mr. Abu Mazen, 65, the godfather of the breakthrough Oslo talks in 1993, is more the overseer.
Palestinians think of Mr. Abu Ala, a forceful white-haired politician who comes from the town of Abu Dis, adjacent to Jerusalem, as a businessman for his role overseeing P.L.O. investments, and consider that the key to his negotiating skill. He negotiated the 1995 interim peace agreement, Oslo II. But, on the plane ride to Washington for the signing ceremony, Mr. Arafat informed him that Mr. Abu Mazen would sign the agreement and deliver the speech. Mr. Abu Ala was crestfallen, and withdrew to the sidelines of the negotiation process for some time.
Mr. Abu Ala was accorded no official role in the present final-status peace negotiations. But he played the more important unofficial part in back-channel talks that eventually moved to Stockholm this spring and became the main channel.
In the 1970's, Mr. Abu Mazen, whose West Bank villa in Ramallah has been the site for late-night meetings of Israeli and Palestinian leaders, oversaw secret contacts between the P.L.O. and progressive Israelis. As a result of relationships he nurtured, Israeli doves and American peace negotiators regarded him as the most flexible Palestinian official. This made it difficult for him to play a central role, because it discredited him on the Palestinian streets. But Mr. Abu Mazen, anyway, prefers to be behind the scenes, thinking the big thoughts.
Saeb Erekat, a political scientist who is almost 20 years younger, has been most visible to Americans, since he makes media appearances and whispers English translations into Mr. Arafat's ears. He was not an original member of the P.L.O., never lived in exile and is thus considered to be in better touch with popular sentiments.
Dr. Erekat made his diplomatic entrance by defying his superiors' orders in the Madrid peace talks in 1991, when the Palestinians were trying to keep a low profile. He walked into the talks with a kaffiyeh draped over his shoulder. Mr. Arafat scolded him later, but Mr. Erekat disarmed him by saying, "Mr. Chairman, I felt I was carrying a piece of you inside."
Mr. Arafat is also accompanied by his senior security chief, Mohammed Dahlan; his information minister, Yasir Abed Rabbo, who plays the role of house skeptic; and his senior economic adviser, Mohammed Rachid, who is an Iraqi-born Kurd.
Mr. Rachid is the most pragmatic and least ideological of the delegation and Mr. Arafat is said to feel indebted to him for creating the monopoly businesses that generated the first income for the Palestinian Authority -- along with allegations of cronyism and corruption. Before the summit meeting, Mr. Rachid was preparing the Palestinians' compensation demands -- $40 billion, mostly for refugees -- and making clear that he would steer Mr. Arafat toward the practical if he could.
The Israeli delegation is not a well-oiled peace team, like the Americans and the Palestinians, but a disparate, experienced group of politicians, lawyers and generals. At the last minute, after the meeting had begun, Mr. Barak summoned Dan Meridor, a right-leaning legislator, to round out the center-left delegation.
Elyakim Rubinstein, a religious Jew and the attorney general, was reportedly reluctant to come. But he is there as the government's lawyer, and as the only delegate who participated in the original Camp David in 1978, bringing with him the accumulated experience of all the peace agreements from then on. Insiders say that he also tells the jokes.
The two central negotiators are Mr. Ben-Ami and Gilad Sher, a private lawyer who used to be a lawyer for the military. Mr. Barak trusts Mr. Sher, who negotiated the most recent interim agreement last September, precisely because he is apolitical.
Mr. Ben-Ami, on the other hand, is a Moroccan-born Israeli. He rose from humble beginnings to become an Oxford-educated historian and Israeli diplomat who, in the most recent Labor Party primary, shot up to the top spot behind Mr. Barak. Insiders say that it signals Mr. Barak's keen desire for an agreement that he is willing to use him as a resource, to tolerate his meetings with President Clinton on the back porch of the Aspen Cabin, which surely raise Mr. Ben-Ami's political capital.
"But Barak is confident, more confident than I have ever seen him," said an Israeli cabinet minister. "At Camp David, he is everything. The team is not essential. They are just there to fill the chairs, make the atmosphere."

SHLOMO BEN-AMI -- Minister of internal security. Mr. Ben-Ami, a professor of history, served as ambassador to Spain. He is a popular, Moroccan-born Labor Party politician. DENNIS ROSS -- Involved with Middle East policy since the Bush administration, Mr. Ross became President Clinton's chief Middle East adviser soon after the president took office. He has worked on all the major agreements in the last seven years.

ABU ALA -- Speaker of the Palestinian Authority's Legislative Council. The senior Palestinian negotiator of the 1993 Oslo accord. Although no clear successor to Mr. Arafat has emerged, he is seen as one of two top contenders. Ran Stockholm talks for the Palestinians.

SAEB EREKAT -- Minister of local government. Chief Palestinian negotiator on matters connected with the interim settlement. The only member of the team representing the Palestinians who never went into exile or was deported. Former academic.

HEADLINE: RUSSIA IS PUSHING TO INCREASE SHARE IN WEAPONS TRADE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: NIZHNY TAGIL, Russia, July 13

 BODY:
Stung by meager defense orders from an impoverished army at home, Russia's military industrial establishment is engaged in a major effort to increase arms sales to Asia, the Middle East and Africa and is expanding its share of the lucrative global arms market.
The United States and western Europe dominate the international weapons bazaar. But this week, on a once-secret test range in the Ural mountains, the men who fashioned the formidable arsenal that once made NATO anxious and was paraded with pride by the Kremlin each Nov. 7 showed that they could attract plenty of customers -- and had plenty to sell, too. 
 Defense officials from India and China -- Russia's major customers for weapons -- Kuwait, North Korea, South Korea and dozens of other nations watched attentively as a T-90 tank, one of Russia's newest weapons, sent a laser-guided missile streaking toward a target more than two miles away. South Korean officials kept a watchful eye on any weapons that piqued North Korean interest.
Baton-twirling majorettes paraded along the range's esplanade as Russian officials toasted their guests from vodka bottles bearing the imprint of a Russian tank. And Mikhail Kalashnikov, the 80-year-old designer of the AK-47, strolled through the crowd, posing for pictures.
Executives from General Dynamics, the American defense contractor, were also there, scrutinizing the Russian tanks. Russian officials say that General Dynamics is discussing the purchase of a revolutionary Russian system to protect tanks from missile and grenade attacks.
"Exports are the most important thing for us because they bring in real money," said Viktor A. Yamov, the chief of advertising for Uralvagonzavod, manufacturer of the T-90 tank. "We don't see much real money from the Russian Army."
There are two ways to calculate arms sales: agreements made and actual deliveries. In terms of deliveries last year, the real money from the rest of the world totaled $2.8 billion, putting Russia fourth, behind the United States, France and Britain, in weapons sales. Russian weapons accounted for 6 percent of all arms delivered -- compared with the United States' 49 percent -- but Terence Taylor, assistant director of the Institute of Strategic Studies in London, said that Russia is now expanding that share toward 10 percent.
During Soviet times, the military sector had first claim on resources here and defense plants churned out thousands of tanks, artillery pieces and air defense missiles. Weapons production was surrounded by intense secrecy, and, although the Soviets dispatched tons of weaponry to friendly nations, a fair to sell arms to the world was unthinkable.
With the Soviet collapse, Russia's defense complex plunged into depression. Defense orders dried up. Debts to suppliers and utilities mounted. Conversion to civilian production remained largely a pipe dream. Exports became a vital, if tenuous, lifeline.
"At this point, the Russian armed forces are buying very little," Mr. Taylor said in a telephone interview. "Virtually all of the production is going for export."
Mr. Yamov's factory, a sprawling complex near this test range that used to employ 45,000 people, is a case in point. It produced all of the Soviet tanks, from the legendary T-34 of World War II to its T-72, operating under the cover story that it turned out mere railroad cars. Now, it lives for exports.
Russia is on the verge of announcing a major arms deal with India under which New Delhi would purchase about 300 T-90 tanks. One hundred of them would be manufactured at the Uralvagonzavod plant, with some 200 assembled in India. Russian press reports estimate the deal is worth some $700 million.
In contrast, the Russian Army has just two T-90 tanks in the European part of its territory, according to data Moscow supplied in January under the treaty limiting conventional forces in Europe.
And despite President Vladimir V. Putin's pledge to boost weapons procurement, the Russian Army is only scheduled to receive 30 T-90 tanks this year. That is a small fraction of the 350 new tanks that Col. Gen. Anatoly Sitnov, the weapons chief for the Russian armed forces, says are needed each year.
This year, the Russian Air Force is purchasing just 12 SU-30 fighter and attack planes, although with exports in mind, about 50 are being produced. In 1998, the air force did not acquire a single new fighter.
While exports are vital to Russia's military complex, competition is stiff. Western nations can offer more generous financing, have longstanding customers, and offer better maintenance and spare parts service after sale. And former Soviet states like Ukraine, which also inherited Soviet defense plants, compete for orders that Russia covets.
The fact that the Russian military has fielded so few new weapons does not help either; many customers like to buy only systems that have been put to the test.
Still, the Russians have some advantages. Low labor costs make their weapons cheaper than those of Western counterparts. They also have a reputation for producing high-quality armored systems, anti-tactical missile systems and artillery.
Russia's weapons trade has consequences for its foreign policy, according to some experts here. The defense establishment is still dominated by men reared in cold war enmity; the competition for sales has reinforced the notion that America is an unfriendly rival whose success comes at Russia's expense, particularly since NATO has expanded its membership and hence its arms clientele into the former Soviet bastion of Central Europe.
"It makes the defense establishment even more anti-American," said Dmitri V. Trenin, the deputy director of the Moscow Carnegie Center. "This is not just the abstract notion of competition. It is a confrontation over money."
The vast majority of Russia's arms exports go to two nations: China and India. Their primary interest is in acquiring the means to make weapons, not just to buy the weapons systems themselves, a development that contributes to the spread of advanced military technology.
Russia's major deals with China include a licensing agreement permitting Beijing to co-produce SU-27 aircraft, and the sale of two destroyers. In addition to the pending tank contract with India, another deal under discussion would provide the Indians with the Russian aircraft carrier Admiral Gorshkov and the MIG-29 planes that would be on it.
Measured in terms of agreements, Russia accounted for 40 percent of weapons sales to Asia between 1995 and 1998, according to Richard F. Grimmett of the Congressional Research Service in Washington.
"The Russians are highly dependent on arms contracts with those two countries," Mr. Grimmett said. "China and India have tremendous leverage in terms of getting the advanced equipment they are seeking."
With a younger, more dynamic president now in the Kremlin and sales at stake, the Russians appeared to go all out to make this week's arms fair in the Urals -- the second annual event here -- a prestigious occasion. Mr. Putin himself showed up.
And there were several new pieces of weaponry. One notable new item was a tank support vehicle, which has a crew of five. It has the protection of a tank but is outfitted with a unique set of weapons, including grenade launchers, a 30-millimeter cannon and four antitank missiles. The Russians appear to have designed the weapon with an insurgency like the one in Chechnya in mind, but it was a big hit with the Chinese, who clustered around it.
Another novel system that attracted attention was Nakidka, basically a tarpaulin that is draped over equipment to foil weapons guided by radar and heat-seeking devices that create images from the heat of objects.
Foreign military officials also seemed impressed by the Iskander surface-to-surface missile, which was shown for the first time, and the S-300 system, which is designed to shoot down Scud-type missiles.
One of the hits of the arms fair were the T-80 and T-90 jumping tanks, which zoomed up a ramp and leaped through the air.
Hundreds of foreigners who identified themselves only as defense attaches, intelligence experts or trade officials but often declined to give their names, prowled among the exhibits. Many carried sophisticated cameras and snapped detailed pictures of firing mechanisms, artillery tubes and weapons chassis.
Kuwaiti military officials eagerly talked with the Russians about their tanks. An Iranian delegation wanted to see executives at Uralvagonzavod. Iran has a fleet of T-72 tanks and is interested in upgrades, said Mr. Yamov, the advertising director.
General Dynamics, for its part, has been exploring the idea of acquiring Russia's Arena system, which uses a radar to detect antitank missiles or grenades and destroys them by firing munitions, according to Aleksandr I. Kobin, the general director of Rosvooruzheniye, the Russian arms sales agency. He indicated that President Putin would have to decide whether the system could be provided to the Americans.
Officials from the American corporation, based in Falls Church, Va., declined to discuss their interest in Arena, but they were certainly taking a close look at the Russian tanks.
"No one country has the corner on good ideas," said Philip W. Lett, the former program manager for the United States Army's M-1 tank program and a General Dynamics consultant.
And despite their long alliance with Washington, the South Koreans expressed interest in exploring production with the Russians. As a South Korean defense attache put it, "Business is business."

HEADLINE: John Pastore, Longtime Rhode Island Politician, Dies at 93

BYLINE: By RICHARD GOLDSTEIN

 BODY:
John O. Pastore, the first Italian-American to be elected as a governor and sit in the United States Senate, and a dominant figure in Rhode Island politics for three decades, died yesterday. He was 93 years old.
He had been in a nursing home in North Kingstown, R.I., for treatment of Parkinson's disease. 
 "Rhode Island is the smallest state in the union and I am the smallest governor in the United States," the 5-foot-4-inch Mr. Pastore once told a group of German editors visiting the statehouse in Providence. When he went to Washington, he became the smallest senator. But in his 26 years in Washington he established himself as a formidable presence, a liberal Democrat regarded as a fierce debater with a booming voice and a firm grasp on the issues of his day.
He staked out a specialty in nuclear power matters as chairman of the powerful Joint Committee on Atomic Energy and in 1963 provided important backing for the Kennedy administration's controversial treaty with the Soviet Union barring nuclear tests in the atmosphere.
In waging a successful fight for ratification, Senator Pastore displayed his flair for the dramatic. During the debate he flung open his jacket and struck the left side of his chest. "I say to those who have doubts about this treaty that I want them to open their heart and look into their consciences," he implored fellow senators. "I want them to realize what they might be doing. If by their vote they destroy and kill the treaty, God help us! God help us!"
His son, John O. Pastore Jr., a cardiologist, was secretary of the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War when the Boston-based organization, jointly founded by American and Soviet physicians, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1985. He is also survived by his wife, Elena, and daughters, Francesca Pastore and Louise M. Harbourt.
Senator Pastore also held posts on the Commerce and Appropriations Committees as well as the Senate Democratic Policy Committee, making him one of the Senate's most influential members.
He led a bitter but losing battle to block the politically restrictive McCarran-Walter Immigration Act that passed over President Harry S. Truman's veto and played an important role in passage of the 1964 Civil Rights Act barring discrimination in public accommodations and cutting off federal financing of discriminatory programs.
Senator Pastore was floor manager of legislation suspending equal-time provisions of the Federal Communications Act to bring about the televised Kennedy-Nixon Presidential debates in 1960. As chairman of the Senate's communications subcommittee, he sometimes took a conservative stance on social issues. In the late 1960's and 1970's, he denounced what he viewed as excessive violence and sexual content in television programming, at one point expressing dismay over the double-entendre of a shaving cream commercial featuring an attractive young woman saying, "Take it all off."
The son of an immigrant tailor, left fatherless at age 9, he epitomized the self-made man. "I always felt there were two strikes against me, and to succeed I had to do a better job than anyone else," he said.
Mr. Pastore, who served as governor of Rhode Island from 1945 to 1950 and who never lost an election, was fortunate to have come of age politically at an opportune time. He entered statewide politics when Italian-Americans were voting in increasingly significant numbers in urban areas and using their growing economic strength to provide financial backing for political candidates they favored.
For a man whose rise reflected inroads by Italian-Americans on political gains made by Irish-Americans, John Orlando Pastore had an intriguing birthday. He was born in the largely Italian Federal Hill section of Providence on St. Patrick's Day -- March 17, 1907.
His father, Michele, a native of Potenza in southern Italy, supported his wife, Erminia, and their four children with his tailor shop, and the family seemed to be moving up the economic ladder. But Michele Pastore died suddenly in May 1916 while his wife was pregnant with their fifth child. Mrs. Pastore went to work as a seamstress in a department store while John cared for the three younger children and did the cooking and cleaning.
Mrs. Pastore made sure her children were well-dressed and well-mannered, and young John developed a penchant for fastidiousness. "When he cleaned house, he moved every stick of furniture," his mother would remember. "He never did anything by halves." His impeccable dress would become a hallmark in his public life -- he changed his shirts in the middle of the day if they bore the slightest signs of wear.
In 1927, while working as a $15-a-week claims adjuster for an electric utility company, Mr. Pastore enrolled in evening law school classes offered by Northeastern University of Boston at a Providence Y.M.C.A. In 1932 he set up a law office in the basement of the family home, but with the Depression in full force, he attracted few clients.
One Sunday in 1933, Mr. Pastore waited outside St. Bartholomew's Church until Tommy Testa, an important local politician, came out. "I'd like to go into politics," Mr. Pastore told him. Mr. Testa, who would recall how "I liked Johnny's manner," helped him obtain the Democratic nomination for the Rhode Island General Assembly, and he was elected to two-year terms in 1934 and 1936.
Seeking a better-paying post, Mr. Pastore then gained an appointment as an assistant state attorney general, and by the early 1940's his oratorical skill was winning over juries in criminal cases. One day a young woman named Elena Caito was passing by a courthouse while Mr. Pastore was prosecuting a case. As Mr. Pastore's son told the story long afterward: "The transom over the door was open. She could hear this booming voice coming out, and she asked one of her brothers, 'Who is that?' So they got introduced." In July 1941, they were married.
In 1944, Mr. Pastore was asked to run for lieutenant governor, a part-time position, on the statewide Democratic ticket headed by Gov. J. Howard McGrath. The Democrats won, and then Mr. Pastore got a huge break, succeeding to the governor's chair in October 1945 when Mr. McGrath was appointed solicitor general in the Truman administration. Mr. Pastore was narrowly elected to the statehouse in November 1946, but two years later he gained a second term with ease.
Although he was the first person of Italian descent to be elected governor, he was not the first to serve in a statehouse. Charles Poletti, a son of Italian immigrants who had been lieutenant governor of New York State, served as governor in December 1942 to complete the term of Gov. Herbert Lehman, who resigned to direct American war-relief efforts in Europe.
A liberal on social-welfare matters, Mr. Pastore as governor worked with business interests, pushing through a sales tax, rather than relying solely on corporate income taxes, to pay for public improvements neglected during World War II. He maintained a popular touch, eating lunch with statehouse employees in their cafeteria, and he was adept at cultivating the press.
He was known for punctuality. While presiding over the State Senate as lieutenant governor, he became irked by its failure to start sessions promptly at 1 p.m. So one day he convened the body precisely at 1 o'clock and then promptly adjourned it since nobody was ready to conduct business.
The Democratic leader ran into the Senate chamber and angrily shouted at Mr. Pastore, "Don't you dare ever do that again."
Mr. Pastore retorted: "Don't you ever dare what you did -- drinking beer in the statehouse while you are supposed to be attending the Senate session."
In November 1950, Mr. Pastore was elected to the United States Senate to fill out the unexpired term of Mr. McGrath, who had moved from the solicitor general's post to the Senate, then resigned to become President Truman's attorney general. In 1952, Mr. Pastore was elected to the first of his four full terms in the Senate.

LENGTH: 470 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Cloak, Dagger, Echelon

BYLINE: By Tom Zeller 

 BODY:
WHAT else but the shadow of Big Brother could provoke equal anger from the American Civil Liberties Union, thousands of Internet enthusiasts and the French government? And what else but the elusive magic of digital communications could make that shadow so mysterious?
 The specter is Echelon, the not-so-supersecret surveillance cooperative that grew out of a cold-war agreement between Britain and the United States to share intelligence data, and that now includes Canada, Australia and New Zealand. The European Union has been sufficiently unnerved by Echelon to commission two reports on its capabilities. And earlier this month a French prosecutor began a preliminary investigation into whether the surveillance network is engaged in economic espionage. Here at home, Representative Bob Barr, Republican of Georgia, has been pressing the National Security Agency to demonstrate that Echelon does not spy on ordinary Americans. 
 But what is Echelon exactly? Most of what is known comes from recycled reports in the news media, but enough evidence has surfaced, including documents released by the N.S.A. under the Freedom of Information Act, that the existence of Echelon is rarely questioned.
 At its core, Echelon is a network of ground stations with dishes aimed at the dozen or so satellites that now shepherd much of the world's television, fax, Internet and voice data. High-capacity computers allow millions of signals per hour to be intercepted and scanned for keywords of interest to each country's intelligence community.
 That agencies like the N.S.A. are mining the spill-off from those satellites should come as no surprise, according to John Pike, a policy analyst for the Federation of American Scientists. "You've got heaping piles of information just sitting up there, all for the price of a satellite dish."
 Questions about how that information is used, and whether or not laws are being violated, are driving the current debate, which is itself clouded by hyperbolic estimates of Echelon's capabilities. A British Web site, for example, seeks to expose Echelon as a source of "psychotronic attacks" and "mind control experimentation." Several other sites claim that Echelon is capable of collecting and processing every e-mail message, every phone call and every fax on the planet.
 "I would be very skeptical that the N.S.A. could or even would try to process every bit of data out there," said Dr. Jeffery Richelson, a senior fellow at the National Security Archives. "It makes sense to question how information they do gather is used, but the hysterical idea that the N.S.A. really cares about the e-mail conversations of everyday citizens is bottom-line nonsense. What everyone is worried about doesn't really exist."
 "Of course," he added, "50 years from now it could."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Drawing
 
Chart: "The Spy Cooperative"
The National Security Agency and its counterparts in the Echelon partnership neither confirm nor deny the existence of the network. But a picture can be sketched from N.S.A. documents, published reports and experts' analysis. The concept is simple: linked ground stations collect and share data from orbiting satellites. The exact number of collection sites is unknown, but these are thought to be the main stations.
 
Computers at each site scan incoming communications for keywords of interest to each member country. Messages containing hits are forwarded to the intelligence agency of the country whose dictionary contained the keyword.

YAKIMA, WASHINGTON: Located 125 miles southwest of Seattle on the site of the U.S. Army's Yakima Firing Center.
 
LEITRIM, CANADA: Operated by the Canadian Communications Security Establishment, this site is thought to monitor the skies over Latin America.
 
SUGAR GROVE, W. VA.: Reports of a commercial satellite monitoring operation here first surfaced nearly 20 years ago.
 
MORWENSTOW, UNITED KINGDOM: Operated by Britain's Government Communications Headquarters. This site is believed to tap into satellites between the Atlantic and Indian Oceans.
 
GERALDTON, AUSTRALIA: Roughly 200 miles north of Perth. This is considered an important site for monitoring North Korea and Pakistan.
 
WAHOPAI, NEW ZEALAND: The station figured prominently in the latest Echelon report to the European Parliament.
 
Chart: "Several Ways to Snoop"
There are numerous ways to collect communications, but not all are thought to be plugged into the Echelon network.
 
LAND LINE TAPPING: Wire tapping works well for targeted investigations of individuals. But the absence of a central routing system for phone calls and the inability of computer technology to interpret and digitize millions of different voices simultaneously make mass collection unfeasible.
 
MICROWAVE INTERCEPTION: The rise of digital networks has made some interception of communication signals easier. Phone, fax and e-mail data carried between microwave towers also spill out into space and can be intercepted.
 
FIBER OPTIC CABLES: Buried or submerged fiber optic lines are logistically difficult to tap, but intelligence agencies are able to intercept signals at electronic amplifier points, which are necessary to send optic signals over long distances.
 
COMMERCIAL SATELLITE INTERCEPTION: Commercial satellites are the easiest means for intelligence agencies to collect and analyze large amounts of data simultaneously. They are also thought to be the primary targets of Echelon. Although voice signals are still difficult for Echelon's computers to interpret, e-mail, fax and telex data are easily scooped up as they are relayed through space.
(Sources: National Security Archives; Federation of American Scientists; Interception Capabilities 2000, report to European Parliament)

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
A Cell-Phone Company At Old-Economy Prices

BYLINE: By MICHELLE LEDER 

 BODY:
WHAT should investors make of Audiovox, the mobile telephone handset provider that has been called the poor man's Qualcomm? Though Audiovox, based in Hauppauge, N.Y., has been reporting stellar sales growth and has surpassed earnings expectations for three quarters, the stock, having soared through March, is now down 32 percent this year, compared with a 10.7 percent climb in the Standard & Poor's Communications Equipment index.
The reasons include strong competition, falling profit margins and the company's dependence on a single customer for the bulk of its sales. 
 Stacked next to Qualcomm, a much-better-known maker of cellular telephones (as well as chip sets) that became a Wall Street darling, Audiovox remains inexpensive, now trading at $31.375, about 17 times its estimated 2001 earnings of $1.89 a share. Qualcomm, meanwhile, is trading at 46 times 2001 estimates of $1.37 a share, even after falling by about two-thirds this year.
But the two control similar pieces of the $48.4 billion North American market for handsets. In 1999, Audiovox had 10 percent, while Qualcomm had 11.2 percent, according to Dataquest, a market tracker.
As a result, some investors saw Audiovox as a bargain. "It was a cheap way to play Qualcomm," said Jayne Stevlingson, a portfolio manager for the Oppenheimer Discovery fund. But she is now having doubts, and has sold 50,000 of her 300,000 Audiovox shares.
Alan Alpers, a senior portfolio manager at Navellier Fund Management, has also pulled back, citing the stock's difficulty in breaking past the high $20's. "Fundamentally, everything looks good, so it's kind of a mystery," he said.
Before last year, Audiovox stock struggled to break $10, as the company was still best known for its decidedly unsexy car audio equipment. Car electronics now makes up only 20 percent of the business, with handsets accounting for the rest. By March 7 of this year, less than a month after it sold 3.1 million shares at $45 each in a secondary offering, the stock had reached a record of $72.50. Then, amid the selloff in technology stocks, Audiovox fell further and faster than most.
The company's strongest defender is John J. Shalam, 67, the entrepreneur who turned his $15,000 investment 35 years ago into a company that reported $1.16 billion in sales last year, an 89 percent increase over 1998. "We don't think the ride was justified to $72 because that's not realistic," Mr. Shalam, the chief executive, said recently, just after trying to shore up his support at a meeting for analysts and investors in Manhattan. "But we believe that it deserves to trade at $40 to $50."
The five analysts who follow the stock, including four whose firms were involved in the secondary offering, recently raised their earnings expectations for Audiovox. All but one have strong buys on the stock. "Compared with its competitors who are trading at 47 times 2001 earnings, this company is clearly undervalued," said Michael Sheldon, chief market strategist for Spencer Clarke, an investment boutique in Manhattan that did not help underwrite the stock.
The analysts' consensus is that Audiovox will earn $1.64 a share for the current fiscal year, which ends on Nov. 30, and $1.89 a share in 2001. But last month, the analysts lowered their 52-week price targets to $40 to $50 a share from as high as $70.
MR. SHELDON, among others, says he remains concerned about the company's falling margins. In 1998, Audiovox had gross margins, or profits before interest and taxes, of 14.4 percent. Last year, they fell to 11.6 percent; most analysts expect them to go below 10 percent this year as competitors cut prices.
Another concern is that up to 80 percent of Audiovox's handset sales are to one customer, Verizon Communications, the combined Bell Atlantic-GTE cellular service provider. Mr. Shalam said that having so many orders in hand from Verizon helped the company avoid having excess inventory. But Ms. Stevlingson worries that "when you have one customer that controls 80 percent of your revenue, they're basically telling you what to price it at."

HEADLINE: The World;
Ulster and Israel Look In a Mirror at Each Other

BYLINE: By WILLIAM A. ORME Jr. 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM

 BODY:
DAVID TRIMBLE, the leader of Northern Ireland's new power-sharing government, paid a brief visit here recently, shortly before Ulster re-erupted into flames last week and Middle East negotiators hunkered down for endgame peace talks in Washington.
As one veteran peacemaker to another, he held a comradely chat with Yossi Beilin, the Israeli justice minister who helped lay the groundwork for the Camp David summit, and another with Oded Eran, who ran Israel's preliminary negotiations with the Palestinians. Earlier, in Gaza, he met with Yasir Arafat and other senior Palestinian officials. 
 An Israeli reporter buttonholed him and asked him to contrast the parties in conflict here with the two sides of the Ulster dispute. Mr. Trimble refused. "There is no room for comparison," he said flatly. "The Israeli-Palestinian conflict is much more complex than ours."
The disappointed Israeli pressed on: Isn't the Irish problem far more entrenched, with enmities dating back 500 or 600 years?
Mr. Trimble wasn't buying it. The present Irish troubles began barely three decades ago, he replied, while "your conflict is 3,000 years old."
Perhaps. From Ulster or from here, peace seekers tend to see the other conflict as one inherited from the past, and their own as one based in the more manageable present.
Returning home, Mr. Trimble was quickly pulled into the peculiar dynamics of the Ulster "marching season," which celebrates the defeat of the Catholic King James II by the Protestant King William III 310 years ago.
The Palestinians and Israelis, meanwhile, were ensconced in the Catoctin hills, confronting seemingly intractable issues -- refugees, borders, the ownership of Jerusalem -- which are rooted not in ancient history but in Israel's victory over Arab forces here just half a century ago.
Fresh wounds, however, are the most painful, noted Meron Benvenisti, one of Israel's leading social commentators. "The conflict here is much more raw, and even among intellectuals there is less understanding of the other side's position and history than you would find in Northern Ireland," said Mr. Benvenisti, who wrote his Harvard doctoral thesis on Ulster politics 20 years ago.
Unlike most Israelis who have compared the conflicts, Mr. Benvenisti agrees with Mr. Trimble that the dispute between Israelis and Arabs -- whatever its timeline -- is inherently more difficult. The religious and ethnic division and distrust is more profound, the economic and political disparities are far greater, and at the explosive heart of the conflict are mutually exclusive territorial claims, he notes.
Yet for all those reasons, he and others here say, Israelis and Palestinians should look at Northern Ireland for instructive parallels, warning signs and, more recently, practical lessons in how to resolve conflicts.
Not all the lessons are encouraging. The riots that raged through Northern Ireland last week could be seen as a foreshadowing of the internal problems many expect Israel and the Palestinians will confront after a settlement. With the staunchly loyalist Royal Ulster Constabulary faced off against Orange Order marchers, the parades that had long been a flashpoint for friction with Catholics instead exposed deep rifts within the Protestant community. Similarly, Israeli troops are braced to confront militant Jewish settlers, while Palestinian police are prepared to battle radical Islamist opponents of a peace pact.
The bloody terrorist bombings by breakaway Irish Republican factions after the Good Friday agreement was reached in 1988 offer another object lesson for the future here, some observers believe. And the fierce resistance within the Irish Republican Army to unequivocal disarmament is likely to have its parallels in the Fatah movement and other armed Palestinian factions after an accord, Mr. Beilin said.
"These are the two longest-running conflicts since the second world war," said Mr. Beilin, who visited Belfast in January. "In both cases we now seem close to a solution, but in Northern Ireland this week we saw the fragility of the process. Good Friday can be followed by Bad Sunday."
In April, Mr. Beilin convened a workshop here where Israeli and Palestinian officials traded insights with Irish and British experts in the Ulster conflict. What struck him most forcefully, he said, is the need for peace agreements to reflect the power of "symbols and rituals," along with more tangible things like political institutions and economic benefits. An example: Mr. Beilin believes Israel should let a Palestinian flag fly over the Dome of the Rock, the crowning monument of Jerusalem's Old City -- an image shocking to many Israelis, but to Palestinians a powerful statement of their national identity.
Mr. Beilin particularly admires the artful blurring of sovereignty lines in the Good Friday accord. The Republic of Ireland now has a formal consultative role in the Northern Irish government, a concession that for many Protestant loyalists struck at the core of their British identity. Yet in return the Republic withdrew its historic claim on the province and formally recognized the United Kingdom's rule there for the first time.
President Clinton has also repeatedly drawn comparisons. In speeches in Northern Ireland he pointed to the Oslo accord as a sign of the possibility of cooperation between once-bitter enemies, and when visiting Israel and the Palestinian territories, he cited the Good Friday accord as an example of what he hoped negotiators could achieve in final-status talks here.
The most significant parallel is the critical mediation of President Clinton himself, said David Scannell, a veteran Irish diplomat, who worked on the Northern Ireland settlement before being sent to Israel as Dublin's ambassador four years ago. But when looking at the political backdrop to both negotiations, Mr. Scannell is discouraged about President Clinton's chances for securing a settlement here.
Israeli polls still show a solid 40-percent-plus opposition to a peace accord, he noted. In the referendum approving the Good Friday pact, support was overwhelming in the Irish Republic -- it passed 94 percent to six percent -- and still resounding in the predominately Protestant North, where it carried by 71 percent to 29 percent.
Mr. Benvenisti is similarly pessimistic, saying that in the critical "emotional aspects of the conflict," Israelis and Palestinians do not appear ready for a lasting, binding compromise. Yet he adds that the increasing normalization of life in Belfast, with its two long-warring communities, may offer hope for a resolution of the dispute over ethnically divided Jerusalem.
"It used to be said that if you know the solution to the Irish question, you don't know the question," Mr. Benvenisti said. "The same could still be said here."

HEADLINE: New Economy;
Poor country, rich country: Two very different fronts of growth in the satellite radio industry.

BYLINE: By Simon Romero 

 BODY:
IT is not every day that the trailblazer of a multibillion-dollar niche of the satellite industry is an entrepreneur betting on the commercial potential of Africa. No wonder Noah Samara is smiling at the irony.
"The fundamental difference between one person and another, rich or poor, is access to information," said Mr. Samara, who was born in Ethiopia, raised in Tanzania and educated at the University of California at Berkeley. "It is kind of funny that our basic approach of profiting from providing that access is ahead of what is happening in the developed world." 
 Late last year, Mr. Samara's company, the WorldSpace Corporation, based in Washington, initiated satellite radio-broadcasting service in a region stretching from Cairo to Cape Town, providing Africa with 25 audio channels of news, music, entertainment and educational programming.
WorldSpace's foray into Africa was a milestone for the budding satellite radio industry. In various regions, including North America, the idea is that an array of high-quality radio channels will prove more attractive to many listeners than their local radio stations -- like the way that cable television and satellite television changed broadcast television.
WorldSpace's digital audio broadcast system, which depends on a solar-powered satellite beamed into space from a launch site in French Guiana, is a harbinger of things to come. So far, the company has showed promise in urban areas with large expatriate communities wanting regional news, such as Indian merchants in Kenya or Nigerians living in other African countries.
But it will be far from Africa, on the dashboards of automobiles in the United States, where the development of the industry is expected to be played out with fervor.
In four years, satellite radio is expected to grow from virtually nothing into a $2.4 billion global industry, according to C.E. Unterberg Towbin, a brokerage firm that focuses on the satellite industry. In this country, the two companies seen fueling the growth are Sirius Satellite Radio and XM Satellite Radio, which have received the only two licenses from the Federal Communications Commission to offer satellite radio.
By this time next year, both companies hope to be able to deliver 100 audio channels throughout the United States, for a monthly charge of about $10. The service is to be available to either fixed or mobile locations. Test versions of the receiving antenna are small domes only a few inches in diameter that could be attached externally to the rear windows of automobiles. Each of the channels will be devoted to a specific theme, like jazz or classical or salsa music, with much of the programming produced at Sirius's studio in New York and XM's in Washington.
Sirius went public in 1994; its shares closed at $49.25 on Friday, more than double last fall's price. XM went public in October and announced last week that it had completed a final round of financing with the private placement of $235 million in convertible stock, raising its total funds to $1.26 billion. Its publicly traded shares, which spent last fall in the low teens, closed Friday at $40.875.
Investors in the companies, which include major car manufacturers and satellite companies, are wagering that consumers in the United States will be eager to pay for CD-quality radio in their automobiles -- on the assumption that radio is as essential to the car as television is to the home.
"Our business model foresees us becoming profitable if we capture just 1 percent of the market," said David Margolese, the president of Sirius. "It's premised on the idea that a lot of people in a prosperous, large country like this one will be willing to spend a little extra to get top-quality radio programming when they're in traffic."
So far, Sirius has distribution agreements with Ford Motor, DaimlerChrysler and BMW, while XM has an agreement with General Motors and is in talks to form a similar agreement with the Honda Motor Company. When Sirius successfully launched the first of three satellites it plans to send into space, from the Baikonur Cosmodrome site in Kazakhstan earlier this month, its shares rose 10 percent in one day.
"This is a chance to buy into something that could profoundly change the way Americans consume their music," said Peter J. Eichler, the president of Aletheia Research and Management, a $150 million money management firm in Santa Monica, Calif. "It's easy; you just have to choose between two companies because the industry is controlled by a duopoly."
Still, there are obstacles to overcome before service is rolled out by next year. Sirius needs to launch two more satellites, while XM Satellite Radio also needs to launch both of its two planned satellites, which it intends to do from a mobile launching site in the Pacific Ocean -- the first later this year. Analysts say there is about a 10 percent chance of a failure for each of the companies' launches, and such a failure could mean delays in the initiation of consumer service.
There is also concern over the quality of reception, even though both companies say that tests indicate listeners will have virtually static-free coast-to-coast reception.
"The quality should be fine, but this might depend on the construction of some line-of-sight apparatus on the ground to ensure seamless transmission, and that deployment could get expensive," said William Kidd, who covers the satellite radio industry for Unterberg.
Regardless of what happens, analysts don't expect either company to show a profit before 2004. In the time being, some people are pondering the effect satellite radio will have on the conventional radio broadcasting industry, which has not been shaken by a major technical innovation since the introduction of the FM band. (Of course, there is Internet radio broadcasting. But that requires a computer and Internet access, and it may be years before wireless versions are viable.)
Since the rules regarding ownership of multiple radio stations were loosened under the Telecommunications Act of 1996, the broadcast industry has been through extensive consolidation, with large media companies like Clear Channel Communications and Viacom acquiring small radio stations throughout the country.
Two large satellite radio companies could further concentrate power in the radio industry, critics say. "Radio will become more of a wasteland because satellite radio won't offer much space for localism," said Robert McChesney, a mass media professor at the University of Illinois in Urbana-Champaign. "Remember the mom-and-pop radio stations? They will all be gone."
With their large production studios, though, satellite radio companies say that they could produce content unparalleled by small radio stations. "We can surpass radio's golden age," said Hugh Panero, the president of XM. "We'll be able to tailor content in ways people wouldn't dream of."
Of course, these are rich-country problems. WorldSpace, which is backed by investors from Saudi Arabia and from several African countries, plans to expand into Asia, and then into South America, with two additional satellites.
With a substantially different business model from those of Sirius and XM, WorldSpace will concentrate on providing satellite radio service to people who are stationary, and perhaps not yet prosperous enough to buy a car. The company hopes to make money from advertising aimed at regions with a combined population of more than four billion people.
"Nothing," Mr. Samara said, "can cross the geographic and cultural divides like radio can."

HEADLINE: A Theater Maverick Says He's Not Fretting About a Lean Spell;
Cameron Mackintosh Isn't Turning Out Broadway Hits the Way He Used To

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
"Martin Guerre" didn't make it to Broadway last season. "Oklahoma!" is no longer coming next season. "Cats" is closing. So is "Miss Saigon." "Putting It Together" did not last earlier this year. And whether there will be a future for "The Witches of Eastwick," which opens in London tomorrow night, is anyone's guess.
Whither Cameron Mackintosh, the guiding force behind them all? The boyish British producer who brought Broadway one long-running blockbuster after another in the 1980's and early 90's -- "Cats," "Miss Saigon," "The Phantom of the Opera" and "Les Miserables" -- is not turning them out as he used to. Maybe the age of the megamusical has come and gone. Gone, too, perhaps is the age of the maverick producer. Or has Sir Cameron, 53, simply lost the touch? 
 "He's had a tough 10 years," said Gordon Davidson, artistic director of the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles. "But he's indefatigable."
Along Broadway he has a legion of admirers who don't doubt that sooner or later he will be back with another hit; he still hopes to bring his acclaimed revival of "Oklahoma!" across the Atlantic next summer. "He's really the only giant we have left in our business," said Rocco Landesman, president of Jujamcyn Theaters. "Cameron is the last singular idiosyncratic producer."
In recent interviews in London and by phone from New York, Sir Cameron did not seem particularly concerned about the state of his career. The Sunday Times of London lists him as one of Britain's 200 richest people, estimating his personal wealth at $600 million. He owns seven theaters in the West End of London. He was knighted in 1996 for his services to British theater. "When it's meant to stop, I can do other things," he said, sipping tea in his London office of overstuffed couches and oriental rugs. "I'm not in any way wedded to doing theater for the rest of my life."
Talking to Sir Cameron one gets the feeling he might be ready to hang it up, spend more time at his estate in Scotland, the vineyard in the South of France, that dairy farm in Somerset, England. "We make very nice cheddar," he said. "We raise our own sheep. All of that I find equally satisfying."
"Life is for living," he added at another point. "Life isn't just for musical theater."
Speaking by telephone a few days ago he sounded confident about his musical "Witches," derived from John Updike's novel and written by two young Americans, John Dempsey and Dana P. Rowe. "I'm enjoying it, the cast is having a good time, audiences seem to like it," Sir Cameron said. "Now we need several good reviews."
But "Witches" and "Oklahoma!," while ambitious, are clearly shows of a different order from his earlier extravaganzas in which chandeliers crash, helicopters land, barricades revolve and tires rise. Economics comes into play. "Phantom of the Opera," which cost about $8 million when it was originally produced in 1988, would cost nearly twice that now. The expense of taking big shows on the road, where much of the profit resides, have escalated as well.
"Costs being a great factor, the spectacle of those musicals is very difficult to continue, except for someone like Disney," said Gerald Schoenfeld, chairman of the Shubert Organization, which owns the theaters that house Sir Cameron's Broadway productions.
"They really represented a golden age," he added. "Now it is winding down." ("Miss Saigon" and "Cats" are to close before the end of the year.)
Sir Cameron said he was not preoccupied with his dwindling presence on Broadway. "When I grew up wanting to put on shows and musicals, I never dreamt any would run 5 years, let alone 9 or 10 or even 20," he said. "To have any sense of sadness would be stupid, and because they're good shows, they will appear in other guises forever. I would much rather go out still being thought of as good shows rather than faded replicas."
Born in Enfield, in north London, the son of a timber merchant who played the trumpet and a secretary, Sir Cameron fell in love with theater at age 8, when his aunt took him to see "Salad Days," a musical by Julian Slade and Dorothy Reynolds. His first theater job was as an apprentice stagehand at the Theater Royal Drury Lane, during the run of "Camelot" in 1965. "Miss Saigon" recently closed at that theater (not one of his), and "Witches" is now ensconced there.
After he worked as a stagehand and stage manager, Sir Cameron's first big West End production was a revival of "Anything Goes" in 1969, which flopped. His first hit came in 1976, when he invested in the revue "Side by Side by Sondheim," which came to New York.
Sir Cameron said he was disappointed that his revival of "Oklahoma!" would not come to New York this year, a decision announced 10 days ago, citing scheduling difficulties involving the show's production team. "There isn't enough time to do it properly," he said. "That's not the way I produce things, in a hurry."
In particular the show has been trying to work around the schedule of Sir Trevor, who is artistic director of the Royal National Theater in London. Other members of the production team include Susan Stroman as choreographer and Anthony Ward as set designer. Plans to bring "Oklahoma!" were canceled once before, when the Actors Equity Association refused Sir Cameron's request to bring the all-British cast to Broadway last year. For the production that was supposed to come this season, he had agreed to try to cast American actors. (In a similar showdown, Sir Cameron successfully insisted that Jonathan Pryce play the Eurasian narrator in "Miss Saigon" despite Equity's calls for an Asian actor.) Sir Cameron said that he hoped the show would make it to New York in about a year.
Sir Cameron disputed a report that the problem with "Oklahoma!" had to do with the amount that SFX Theatrical Group was asking for the Ford Center for the Performing Arts. "I'm sure a deal would have been sorted out," he said.
As to why "Martin Guerre" never made it to New York, Sir Cameron said that musical, which received poor reviews out of town, was a difficult challenge. Based on a 1982 film and the 16th-century case history about a soldier returning from war, the musical had been about four years in the making. Sir Cameron said even he turned it down at first. "It took me a long time to get into the subject matter," he said. "I couldn't see what was intriguing about it."
Gradually, Sir Cameron said, he came to understand what the authors -- Claude-Michel Schonberg and Alain Boublil, who also wrote "Les Miz" and "Miss Saigon" -- were trying to accomplish. "I'm a huge admirer of both of them," Sir Cameron said. "I made a fortune beyond my dreams on two of their shows. My misgivings about it initially were how you tell the story, which has been the practical search for the authors."
Sir Cameron is a hands-on producer who works closely with his creative team -- asking questions, making suggestions -- and then checks in regularly during rehearsals.
"Everything is produced by committee these days," Mr. Landesman said. "There are very few producers who have their own personal imprint on their shows."
Sir Cameron said it was important not to hand a project to a director too quickly, that he prided himself on being able to prod the writers to do their best work. And when he does turn a show over, he said, it's like letting a child venture forth into the world. "I'm not in charge anymore," he said of "Witches." "I had to pass the baton."
He makes no secret of preferring old-fashioned like "South Pacific" and "Oliver!" He will revive "My Fair Lady" in the West End next season, with his longtime colleague Trevor Nunn directing. It is "arguably the greatest book musical ever written," he said. "Every note is perfect."
He said that he was rarely attracted to anything that did not have a strong dramatic theme, and that the work he did was almost always based on classics.
His love of the conventional may seem difficult to reconcile with his love of Stephen Sondheim's work. But there is darker Sondheim ("Passion"), and there is lighter Sondheim ("Putting It Together"), and Sir Cameron does not profess to like it all. "He's one of my closest friends," he said of Sondheim. "Could I produce all his other shows? I don't have the personality that has a rapport with some of the characters he writes about."
After seeing "Company," for example, Sir Cameron said he loved the score but not its effect on him. "I couldn't understand why, having been so theatrically excited, I came out of the theater feeling gutted," he said. "One of my strong suits is I still care as much."
It is that caring, producers say, that suggests that Sir Cameron will be around the theater for some time to come.
"The fact that a few things he has done haven't worked out doesn't mean anything," said Roger Berlind, a longtime Broadway producer. "He's an extraordinary showman. He ain't going away."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: JDS Who? Fast Growth, Farflung Fold And Worries

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON 

 BODY:
When JDS Uniphase announced last week that it was buying a competitor, SDL, for an astounding $41 billion in stock, many on Wall Street wondered, who are these guys?
Sure, JDS was one of the hottest companies of 1999, its stock price soaring more than 900 percent. But its business -- making components for fiber optic networks -- was hardly the most glamorous angle of the telecommunications industry. 
It has been only a year since JDS Fitel, a Canadian telecommunications equipment maker, merged with the Silicon Valley company Uniphase to become JDS Uniphase. At that point, the company had a market capitalization of only $14 billion. But in the last year, JDS has been on an acquisition tear, agreeing to buy 10 companies -- including SDL -- for more than $63 billion in stock or cash.
Suddenly, JDS Uniphase is a behemoth with a stock market value of $100 billion, raising the eyebrows of not only investors but antitrust regulators as well.
Why? JDS Uniphase makes fiber optic equipment like receivers and amplifiers that generate and direct pulses of light and distribute bits of information at eye-blink speed over optical networks. Demand for such components is sizzling: customers like Nortel Networks and Lucent Technologies need those pieces to build the Internet superhighway.
As such, JDS's acquisition strategy has been to buy component suppliers that can fill the gaps in its product line, providing it a more complete catalog of fittings and fixtures to offer its telecommunications company customers.
This is a time-honored strategy in technology circles, similar to the way Texas Instruments acquires hardware specialists or Computer Associates buys up software boutiques. Yet, although the strategy makes sense in a hot market, it can also be risky.
Along with the products gained through the nine acquisitions finalized, about half of JDS's 17,000 employees are also new to the fold. Operations are spread far and wide -- from China to Canada, and scattered on the East and West Coasts of the United States.
And acquiring and making products to meet demand in the booming fiber optics network market is more than a full-time job. So, really, who has time to pay attention to the minutiae of integrating all those new members of the JDS Uniphase family?
Possibly no one. And that is what worries some money managers, analysts and industry consultants who wonder if JDS Uniphase's reach is fast exceeding its grasp.
"If you've gotten used to a certain size of deal, you have a process in place," said Mark Sirower, a merger adviser at the Boston Consulting Group. "When you go to multibillion-dollar deals, it's a much bigger management challenge."
Investors punished JDS's stock price last Monday, knocking it down 13 percent upon the announcement of its merger with SDL. Though the shares had recovered most of the lost ground by Friday, analysts are concerned that the SDL deal comes too fast on the heels of the $18 billion agreement in January to acquire E-Tek Dynamics, a merger completed on June 30 after months of scrutiny by the Department of Justice. Only now is E-Tek beginning to be combined with JDS.
Leery that the fiber optics industry may be consolidating too quickly, the Justice Department demanded concessions of JDS, the industry leader for several products, before approving the acquisition of E-Tek, one of the largest makers and buyers of optical thin-film filters, which divide beams of light so they can transmit more information. E-Tek had deals with other makers to be the exclusive buyer of their filters, and the Justice Department forced E-Tek to give up those deals before allowing the JDS merger to proceed.
The Justice Department could require various concessions in the SDL acquisition, too.
"We think the regulatory approval process will be somewhat involved and could add volatility to the two stocks over the next six months," Tom Astle, Merrill Lynch's senior optics analyst, wrote in an assessment of the SDL deal last week.
Charles J. Abbe, the president of JDS Uniphase, who himself came aboard only in February after JDS bought Optical Coding Laboratory Inc., acknowledges that the expanding company is still very much a work in progress. But rather than a liability, he sees the company's structure as a new-economy paradigm. "We are forging a geographically diverse model," he said. "We are a virtual management team."
With each acquisition, Mr. Abbe said, the first group to be integrated is the sales force, which reports to him. But he acknowledged that senior managers of most departments could meet only by videoconferencing because they were too farflung to gather in person. Rather than being concentrated at JDS's headquarters in San Jose, Calif., or Ottawa, managers who head business units are situated at whichever acquired company has the relevant area of expertise.
Take JDS Uniphase's operations in optical thin-film coating. Because Mr. Abbe's old company, called OCLI, has a particular expertise in that specialty, he said, the operations of other acquired companies in that sector report to a manager in Santa Rosa, Calif., OCLI's former base.
Similarly, executives at two other companies acquired last year -- AFC Technologies, formerly of Hull, Quebec, and Oprel Technologies, whose previous address was Nepean, Ontario -- report to executives in Freehold, N.J.
Confusing? Only to the uninitiated, Mr. Abbe said. "Whatever we do is tested against the idea of serving the customer effectively," he added. Because demand for networking products is booming, the acquired companies have a common goal of getting product out the door fast. That, he said, is the tie that binds; anything more would seem too constraining.
"The way we bring them into the fold is that the strategies are very clear and the charter is understood," he said. "Beyond that, we aren't going to bring them into the fold."
Mr. Astle, the Merrill analyst, said that despite the risks, the purchase of the San Jose-based SDL would be positive for both companies if they delivered as promised. He points to the primordial merger of JDS Fitel and Uniphase as the template for what the management team can do well. Jozef Straus, now chief executive of JDS Uniphase, was chief executive at JDS Fitel.
For one thing, executives remained focused on what customers wanted, he said, freed from the corporate jockeying that distracts even the best managers during a merger. And the company continued to foster its own in-house research and development instead of relying solely on the companies they bought.
But as with any investment, past performance is no guarantee of future results. "Just because you put a bunch of products together doesn't mean they will be better off," said Mr. Sirower of Boston Consulting. In other words, a merger can make sense on paper but not succeed unless it is executed well. "It's separate to the economies of why you are doing a deal," he said.
Mr. Straus said JDS Uniphase had an advantage in these fast-changing times: The fiber optics component field is such a close community that the senior management teams at many of the companies JDS has acquired have known one another for some time. JDS Fitel, for instance, once had a joint venture with OCLI.
Mr. Straus said he had known Donald Scifres, chief executive of SDL, for nearly a decade. "We share the same passion," he said. "That is the essence of this merger."
